The scheme is named SIDBI - Loan for Purchase of equipment for enterprise's Development (SPEED).
The Ministry/Department responsible for this scheme is SIDBI.
The component of the scheme is Credit.
The sub-component is not specified.
Applicants must be MSME units with at least 3 years of operations and stable sales and cash profits in the immediate past 2 years.

For New to Bank (NTB) customers, eligible expenditure includes machinery purchased from OEMs with whom SIDBI has an MoU. The present list of 8 OEMs is Lokesh Machines Ltd., Jyoti CNC Automation Ltd, Milacron India Pvt Ltd, ACE Designers Ltd, ACE Manufacturing Systems Ltd., Bharat Fritz Werner (BfW), HURCO India Pvt Ltd., and Batliboi Ltd.
For existing customers, any OEM is eligible, and the proposed machinery should relate to the same line of business.
Second-hand/refurbished machines are not eligible.
Assistance is up to 100% of the machinery cost, with a maximum of Rs. 1 crore for NTB customers and up to Rs. 2 crore for existing SIDBI customers.
SIDBI reserves the right to sanction a lower amount based on the assessment of repayment capacity.
The tenure for the loan is 2 to 5 years, including a moratorium of 3-6 months.
A link for details is provided: https://sidbi.in/en/products
The language of the VDP information is English.
Vendor Development Programmes (VDPs) are strategic initiatives to strengthen the participation of MSMEs in the public procurement ecosystem.
VDPs bridge MSMEs and major buyers including CPSEs, State PSUs, and Large & Mega industries by facilitating meaningful interactions and showcasing MSME capabilities.
MSMEs, State & Central PSUs, Large & Mega Industries, Defence Organizations, and Indian Railways can attend VDPs.

VDPs offer focused buyer-seller meets, raise awareness about public procurement policies, reserved products, and price preference schemes, and facilitate the onboarding of MSMEs onto digital procurement platforms like GeM and TReDS.
Key activities of VDPs include Awareness Sessions on RAMP overview, public procurement policies, GeM onboarding, TReDS registration, MSME incentives, and E&S Compliance.
Buyer Presentations detail procurement needs and onboarding requirements of buyers (CPSEs/ State PSUs/ Industries).
Buyer-Seller Meets involve direct Q&A and stall-based interaction.

To enroll in a VDP, click on 'Enroll Now', select the District and RAMP component, view the details of location, venue, date, and time from the calendar, and click 'Click Here' under the Enroll column to enter details.

The contact for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP) - AP MSME Development Corporation includes Mr. Pranav Reddy (Email ID: pranavreddy@kpmg.com), Dr. T Vijay Krishna Kanth (Email ID: pd@citdindia.org), and S. Venkata Krishna (Email ID: svkrishna@citdindia.org).
The Ministry of MSME has a scheme called A Scheme for Promoting Innovation, Rural Industry & Entrepreneurship (ASPIRE).
The ASPIRE scheme's component is Skill development and Entrepreneurship.
The ASPIRE scheme's sub-component is Finance Grant.
The applicants for the ASPIRE scheme can be Technical/research institutes, Incubation schemes of MSME/NSIC/KVIC/Coir Board/Other Ministries/Departments, and Private incubators.
Under the ASPIRE scheme, a one-time grant of 100% of the cost of Plant & Machinery (excluding land and infrastructure) or up to Rs. 100 lakh (whichever is less) is provided.

For incubation centers set up under PPP mode with NSIC, KVIC, Coir Board, or any other GOI Institution/agency, the ASPIRE scheme provides a one-time grant of 50% of the cost of Plant & Machinery (excluding land and infrastructure) or Rs. 50 lakh (whichever is less).
The ASPIRE scheme targets setting up a total of 150 such centers.
The estimated financial outgo for the ASPIRE scheme is Rs. 135 Crore.
The Ministry of Commerce and Industries has a scheme called Champion Service Sector Scheme.
The Champion Service Sector Scheme's component is Infrastructure/Skill development.
The applicant for the Champion Service Sector Scheme is the Respective Ministry/Department.
The Champion Service Sector Scheme provides assistance in the selected 12 champion sectors.

Udyam Registration is a strategic initiative by the Government of India.
The purpose of Udyam Registration is to formalize and integrate the MSME sector into the formal economy.
Udyam Registration is a digital, self-declaration based certification system.
Udyam Registration is a foundational step for MSMEs.
MSMEs can access government schemes, financial services, market opportunities, and digital platforms through Udyam Registration.
This intervention will significantly simplify the registration process.
This intervention will eliminate documentation burden.
Udyam Registration offers a permanent identity number called the Udyam Registration Number.
The Udyam Registration Number empowers MSMEs with seamless access to various benefits.

The page describes the 'Micro & Small Enterprises Cluster Development Programme (MSE-CDP)'.
MSE-CDP is a flagship scheme of the Ministry of Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises (MSME), Government of India.
MSE-CDP aims to enhance productivity, competitiveness, and sustainability of MSEs through a cluster-based approach.
The scheme supports both Common Facility Centres (CFCs) and Infrastructure Development (ID) projects.
MSE-CDP addresses challenges like lack of technology, inadequate testing facilities, skill gaps, and absence of market linkages for MSEs.
Common Facility Centres (CFCs) are central to MSE-CDP.
CFCs create shared infrastructure for enterprises within a cluster.
CFCs provide access to machinery, testing labs, quality certification, design support, training, research & development, and other common services.
The funding pattern for CFCs under MSE-CDP is detailed.
For a Common Facility Centre with a Total Project Cost of Rs 5 crore to Rs 10 crore, the funding pattern is 70% Govt of India share, 20% State Govt share, and 10% SPV Share.
For a Common Facility Centre with a Total Project Cost of Rs 10 crore to Rs 30 crore, the funding pattern is 60% Govt of India share, 20% State Govt share, and 20% SPV Share.

A different funding pattern applies to projects in Aspirational Districts, NER, Hill States, island territories, LWE affected districts, and clusters with more than 50% micro/villages or women-owned or SC/ST-owned units.

For these specific locations/clusters, with a Total Project Cost of Rs 5 crore to Rs 10 crore for a Common Facility Centre, the funding pattern is 80% Govt of India share, 15% State Govt share, and 5% SPV Share.

For these specific locations/clusters, with a Total Project Cost of Rs 10 crore to Rs 30 crore for a Common Facility Centre, the funding pattern is 70% Govt of India share, 15% State Govt share, and 15% SPV Share.
Admissible items for Setting up of Common Facility Centres (CFCs) are listed.
Common Production/Processing Centres are admissible under CFCs.
Common Recycling/Resource Recovery Plants are admissible under CFCs.
Industry 4.0 and its Learning Facilities, Additive Manufacturing Facilities, and Digital Infrastructure are admissible under CFCs.
Design/Incubation Centres are admissible under CFCs.
Testing and Quality Upgradation Facilities/Product Standards Development are admissible under CFCs.
Packaging Facilities are admissible under CFCs.
Training Centres/Skill Upgradation Facilities are admissible under CFCs.
R&D Centres are admissible under CFCs.
Effluent Treatment Plants are admissible under CFCs.
Waste management, disposal, and sustainable handling of biodegradable wastes in industrial areas, including biogas/Bio-CNG projects, are supported under CFCs.
Common Logistics Centres are admissible under CFCs.
Common Raw Material Banks are admissible under CFCs.
Plug & Play Facilities are admissible under CFCs.
Common Renewable Energy Generation (Solar, Wind, Bio) and Energy Management equipments are admissible under CFCs.
Safety and Disaster Risk Reduction equipments are admissible under CFCs.
Facilities relating to backward/forward linkages for value addition in by-products/waste of cluster units are admissible under CFCs.
Any common facilities that will improve competitiveness and productivity of cluster units are admissible under CFCs.
Export Promotion Facilities for FPO, such as for processing, storage (cold chains), Pack Houses, testing, and packaging, are admissible under CFCs.

Common Facilities for services sector, including automobile, tourism, hospitality, health & medical, farm, Dry cleaner, Testing Laboratories, repair and maintenance, or any sector prioritized by the Government of India/State Government, are admissible under CFCs.
CFCs for Greenfield clusters for holistic development of the MSME sector are admissible.
Items for CFCs may be added or deleted with the recommendation of NPAC and approval of Secretary MSME/Minister MSME.
Cluster Identification involves identifying a group of Micro and Small Enterprises (MSEs) operating in a similar sector or value chain.
The cluster should demonstrate common requirements for technology, testing, training, or infrastructure.
Formation of a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) is required.
The enterprises must form a registered legal entity (SPV).
The SPV is responsible for planning, implementation, and management of the CFC.
Preparation of a Detailed Project Report (DPR) is necessary.
The SPV, with support from Technical Consultants and the State Nodal Agency (SNA), prepares a DPR.
The DPR should include cluster profile, justification, technology needs, cost estimates, business model, implementation plan, and financial details.
Submission to the District Industries Centre (DIC) is the next step.
The SPV submits the DPR and application through the DIC.
The DIC examines and forwards the proposal to the State Government/State Nodal Agency (SNA).
Appraisal by SIDBI (Technical Agency) is conducted.
SIDBI undertakes techno-economic appraisal of the project, checking feasibility, financial viability, and compliance with guidelines.
Scrutiny by the State Level Steering Committee (SLSC) follows.
The proposal is placed before the SLSC for recommendation.
Once approved by SLSC, it is forwarded to the Development Commissioner (MSME), Ministry of MSME.
Examination by the National Project Appraisal Committee (NPAC) occurs.
Based on SIDBI's appraisal and SLSC's recommendation, the proposal is considered by the NPAC.
The NPAC may approve, defer, or seek clarifications.
Final Approval is granted by the NPAC, Ministry of MSME.
The NPAC accords final approval to the project.
Post-approval, the GoI grant is released in installments, linked to physical progress as mentioned in the DPR.
Implementation is carried out by the SPV.
The SPV undertakes civil works, machinery procurement, installation, and commissioning as per DPR.
Progress is monitored jointly by the State Government and MSME-DI.
Operationalisation of the CFC occurs after completion.
After completion of civil and machinery works, and upon submission of Utilization Certificates (UCs), the CFC becomes functional for member enterprises.
The document 'MSE-CDP Guidelines' is available.
The 'Financial Support to MSMEs in ZED Certification Scheme' is offered by the Ministry of MSME.
The component of this scheme is 'Technology'.
The sub-component is 'Finance'.
The applicant for this scheme is Manufacturing Micro, Small and Medium enterprises (MSME) having Udyam Registration.
The Quantum of Assistance includes Assessment & Rating/Re-rating/Gap analysis/Hand holding.
The subsidy provided by the Government of India for Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises will be 80%, 60% and 50% respectively.
There is an additional subsidy of 5% for MSMEs owned by SC/ST/women for assessment & rating/rerating/gap analysis/hand holding.
Assessment/Rating by empanelled Credit Rating Agencies/other Agencies is valid for 4 years.
The Ministry of MSME will subsidize 80% of Micro, 60% of Small, 50% of Medium Enterprises' Certification Fee for Assessment/Rating, with an average of 70% of the Fee.
The Assessment Fee for Desktop Assessment is Rs. 10,000/-.
The Assessment Fee for ZED rating Complete Assessment is Rs. 80,000/-.
Additional rating for Defence angle, i.e., Defence ZED, by empanelled Credit Rating Agencies/other Agencies is valid for 4 years.
The Ministry of MSME will subsidize 80% of Micro, 60% of Small, 50% of Medium Enterprises' Certification Fee for Defence ZED rating, with an average of 70% of the Fee.
The Assessment Fee for Defence ZED rating is Rs. 40,000/- per enterprise.

Gap Analysis, Handholding, and Consultancy for improving rating of MSMEs are provided by Consultants through QCI/NPC, Field formations of O/o DC-MSME viz. MSME-DI, MSME-TC including its autonomous bodies, BEE etc.
The Ministry of MSME will subsidize 80% of Micro, 60% of Small, 50% of Medium Enterprises' Consultancy charges for Gap Analysis/Handholding/Consultancy, with an average of 70% of the Fee.
The Hand holding charges are Rs. 1.9 Lakh per enterprise.
In case of MSMEs owned by SC/ST entrepreneurs, an additional support of Rs 10,000/- will be provided for handholding.
Re-Assessment/Re-Rating by Credit Rating Agencies & Other Agencies is available.
The Ministry of MSME will subsidize 80% of Micro, 60% of Small, 50% of Medium Enterprises' Certification Fee for Re-Assessment/Re-Rating, with an average of 70% of the Fee.
The Assessment Fee for Re-Assessment/Re-Rating is Rs. 40,000/- per enterprise.
A link for details of the ZED Certification Scheme is provided.
The Ministry of MSME offers the Skill Upgradation & Mahila Coir Yojana (MCY) scheme.
The MCY scheme's component is skill development.
The sub-component of MCY is Finance Grant.
Coir artisans and workers engaged in the coir industry are eligible applicants for MCY.
Under MCY, a stipend of Rs. 3,000 per month is provided per trainee.
Under MCY, an honorarium of Rs. 15,000 per month is limited for the trainer.
Under MCY, Rs. 400 per head per month is provided to the training sponsoring agency for operational costs.
The government has announced several measures for MSMEs under 'Atmanirbhar Bharat' due to hardships faced during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Rs. 3 lakh crore in collateral-free automatic loans are available for MSMEs.
Rs. 20,000 crore in subordinate debt is available for stressed MSMEs.
Rs. 50,000 crore in equity infusion for MSMEs is available through a Fund of Funds.
Global tenders will be disallowed for procurements up to Rs. 200 crore.
The definition of MSMEs has been revised.
All receivables of MSMEs will be cleared by the Government and PSUs within 45 days.
A Micro enterprise is defined as having an investment of less than Rs. 1 crore and a turnover of less than Rs. 5 crore.
A Small enterprise is defined as having an investment of less than Rs. 10 crore and a turnover of less than Rs. 50 crore.
A Medium enterprise is defined as having an investment of less than Rs. 50 crore and a turnover of less than Rs. 250 crore.
The Credit Guarantee Fund Trust for Micro and Small Enterprises (CGTMSE) was set up by the Ministry of MSME and SIDBI.
The objective of CGTMSE is to facilitate credit flow to the MSE sector without the need for collaterals or third-party guarantees.
CGTMSE aims to reassure lenders that the Guarantee Trust will cover losses up to 85% of the outstanding amount in case of default by an MSE unit that availed collateral-free credit.
CGTMSE provides cover for credit facilities up to Rs. 200 lakh extended without collateral or third-party guarantees.
A guarantee and annual service fee is charged by CGTMSE.
Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS) aims to create electronic bill factoring exchanges for MSMEs to encash receivables without delay.
TReDS will provide MSMEs with greater access to finance and encourage timely payments from corporates.
Sellers, buyers, and financiers are participants in TReDS.
Banks, NBFC-Factors, and other financial institutions permitted by the RBI can participate as financiers in TReDS.
Transactions processed under TReDS are 'without recourse' to MSME sellers, meaning they are not liable if the buyer defaults.
Authorization from the RBI is required to set up and operate a TReDS platform under the Payment and Settlement Systems (PSS) Act, 2007.
TReDS entities undertake KYC (Know Your Customer) of participants adhering to RBI's Master Direction - Know Your Customer (KYC) Direction, 2016.

A sick unit is defined as a Micro or Small Enterprise where any borrower account remains NPA for three months or more, or there is an erosion in net worth due to accumulated losses to the extent of 50% of its net worth in the previous accounting year.
GST is levied on all supplies made for a consideration and for the furtherance of business, with some exceptions.
A provisional GSTIN (PID) can be used on invoices for making supplies without waiting for the final GSTIN.
Manufacturers are not necessarily required to be registered under GST if they deal only in exempted goods or have an intra-State turnover below Rs. 20 lakh.
MSME Technology Centres of the Ministry of MSME provide state-of-the-art machinery and equipment for designing and manufacturing quality tools.
MSME Technology Centres conduct training programs to provide skilled manpower to industries, especially MSMEs, with over 90% placement for trained individuals.

The Ministry supports improving manufacturing competitiveness through capacity building, technology upgradation, design interventions, product improvement, IP rights, lean technologies, nurturing ideas, and digital empowerment.
Financial assistance of up to Rs. 36 lakh is available for lean manufacturing competitiveness for MSMEs (per mini cluster of 10 units, minimum 4 units for 10 months).
Reimbursement is provided for obtaining National and International standard certifications under the 'Zero Defect and Zero Effect' initiative.
Assistance is provided for business solution software like ERP through e-platforms under 'Digital MSME'.

Reimbursement for Intellectual Property Rights registration includes up to Rs. 1 lakh for domestic patents, Rs. 5 lakh for foreign patents, Rs. 2 lakh for GI registration, and Rs. 0.10 lakh for trademarks.
Financial support of up to Rs. 1 crore is available for setting up IP facilitation centers for 5 years.
Financial assistance is provided to MSMEs for engaging design consultants for design interventions (project range Rs. 15 lakh to Rs. 40 lakh).
Financial assistance of Rs. 1.5 lakh is provided for final year student projects done for MSMEs.

The scheme 'Building Awareness on Intellectual Property Rights (IPR)' is implemented by the O/o DC (MSME) under the National Manufacturing Competitiveness Programme (NMCP) to enhance awareness of MSMEs about protecting their ideas and business strategies.
Credit Linked Capital Subsidy Scheme (CLCSS) is for technology upgradation of Micro and Small enterprises (MSEs).
The CLCSS scheme is continued from April 1, 2017, with revised guidelines effective from August 13, 2019.
Under CLCSS, a 15% capital subsidy, limited to a maximum of Rs. 15 lakh, is provided to eligible MSEs for upgrading their technology.
To benefit from CLCSS, MSEs manufacturing a product and wanting to upgrade technology can approach nodal banks/agencies/eligible financial institutions for a term loan.

Nodal agencies for CLCSS implementation include SIDBI, NABARD, Canara Bank, Bank of Baroda, Bank of India, The Tamilnadu Industrial Investment Corporation Limited (TIICL), Andhra Bank, State Bank of India, Punjab National Bank, Corporation Bank, and Indian Bank.
More details on CLCSS can be found on www.dcmsme.gov.in under Technology Up-gradation - CLCSS.
Subsidy under CLCSS is released to the concerned Nodal bank/agency and kept in a Term Deposit Receipt (TDR) for 3 years.
The beneficiary unit must remain in commercial production for at least three years after installing eligible plant & machinery on which CLCSS subsidy was availed.
Resources like Videos, PDF files, FAQs, and LMS are available on the GeM portal for sellers to learn the selling process.
Startups can register innovative products/services on Startup Runway by uploading details in the Seller Dashboard under the #Startupindia link, provided they are DPIIT registered.
During GeM registration, an option is available to select the organization as an MSE, requiring UAM and linked mobile/Aadhaar number.
Registering as an MSE on GeM provides the benefit of mandatory government buyer purchases of a certain percentage of products from MSEs annually.
MUDRA (Micro Units Development & Refinance Agency Ltd.) is a financial institution set up by the Government of India for the development and refinancing of micro units enterprises.
MUDRA provides funding to the non-corporate small business sector through last-mile financial institutions like Banks, NBFCs, and MFIs.
MUDRA's role includes refinancing all last-mile financiers (NBFCs, MFIs, Societies, Trusts, Section 8 Companies, Small Finance Banks, Regional Rural Banks) lending to micro/small business entities.
MUDRA also partners with state/regional financial intermediaries to provide finance to last-mile financiers of small/micro business enterprises.
MUDRA loans are available in three categories: 'Shishu' (up to Rs. 50,000), 'Kishor' (Rs. 50,000 to Rs. 5 lakh), and 'Tarun' (Rs. 5 lakh to Rs. 10 lakh).
Food processing is an eligible activity for coverage under MUDRA schemes.
Artisans can avail assistance under the 'Shishu' category of MUDRA for setting up their own enterprise.
MUDRA refinance schemes cover traders and shopkeepers, including those operating on a franchise model like ice cream parlors.
MUDRA is a refinance agency, not a direct lending institution; it provides refinance support to intermediaries who then finance beneficiaries.
Loan terms and conditions for MUDRA loans are governed by the lending institution's rules and RBI guidelines.
A one-page application format for the 'Shishu' category and a three-page indicative format for 'Kishor' and 'Tarun' categories are available on the MUDRA website.
Repayment terms, eligibility, and action plans for MUDRA assistance are governed by the lending institution's norms and RBI guidelines.
Interest rates on MUDRA loans are deregulated, and banks are advised to charge reasonable rates within RBI guidelines.
Handicapped persons are eligible for PMMY (MUDRA) loans if they have a business plan for income-generating activity.
The Emergency Credit Line Guarantee Scheme (ECLGS) provides 100% credit guarantee coverage by NCGTC for funding provided under GECL.
Eligibility criteria for ECLGS include MSME borrower accounts with combined outstanding loans up to Rs. 25 crore as of Feb 29, 2020, and annual turnover up to Rs. 100 crore in FY 2019-20.
Borrower accounts must be classified as regular, SMA-0, or SMA-1 as of Feb 29, 2020, to be eligible for ECLGS; NPA or SMA-2 accounts are not eligible.
MSME borrowers must be GST registered if such registration is mandatory; this condition does not apply to MSMEs not required to obtain GST registration.
Loans provided in individual capacity are not covered under ECLGS.
Loans under PMMY extended on or before Feb 29, 2020, and reported on the MUDRA portal are covered under ECLGS.
GECL will be extended as a separate loan account, distinct from the borrower's existing loan account(s).
Interest rates on GECL are capped at RBI prescribed external benchmark linked rates + 1% (max 9.25% p.a.) for Banks and FIs, and not exceeding 14% p.a. for NBFCs.
The tenor of loans provided under GECL is four years from the date of disbursement, with no pre-payment penalty.
A moratorium period of one year on the principal amount is provided for GECL funding, during which interest is payable.
The principal amount of GECL shall be repaid in 36 installments after the moratorium period.
Indicative turnaround time for sanctioning GECL loans is the same as prescribed by the Department of Financial Services for credit support during the COVID-19 pandemic.
NCGTC will not charge any guarantee fee under the ECLGS.
No additional processing fee shall be charged by lenders for additional credit extended under GECL.
MLIs will not ask for any additional collateral for the GECL facility.
Any member of the EPF Scheme, 1952, with a UAN employed in an establishment or factory covered under the EPF & MP Act, 1952, is eligible for an advance from EPF to fight the COVID-19 pandemic.
No certificate or document is required from the EPF member or employer to avail the COVID-19 advance.
Online claims for EPF advance can be filed through the Unified Member Portal (https://unifiedportal-mem.epfindia.gov.in/memberinterface) or the UMANG mobile app.
EPF claims can be filed through a mobile phone by logging into the Unified Member Portal or using the UMANG mobile app.
The Credit Guarantee Scheme for MSEs (CGTMSE) facilitates credit flow to the MSE sector without collateral or third-party guarantees.
CGTMSE covers credit facilities up to Rs. 200 lakh extended without collateral or third-party guarantees.
The Distressed Asset Fund - Subordinated Debt for Stressed MSMEs (DAF-SDSM) provides credit facilities to promoters of stressed MSMEs for infusion as equity/quasi equity/sub-debt.
The Credit Guarantee Scheme for Subordinate Debt (CGSSD) provides guarantee coverage to Member Lending Institutions (MLIs) for credit facilities extended to eligible MSMEs under the DAF-SDSM scheme.
The objective of CGSSD is to provide credit facilities to promoters of stressed MSMEs (SMA-2 and NPA accounts eligible for restructuring) who will infuse this credit as quasi equity or sub-debt.
Promoters are required to bring in 10% of the sub-debt amount as collateral to avail the sub-debt facility.

The CGSSD scheme is applicable to sub-debt sanctioned for a maximum period of 10 years from the guarantee availment date or March 31, 2021, whichever is earlier, or until Rs. 20,000 crore of guarantee amount is approved.
Eligibility criteria for CGSSD include stressed MSME borrower/entities (SMA2 and NPA accounts) eligible for restructuring and commercially viable.
The maximum tenor for loans provided under CGSSD is from the guarantee availment date or March 31, 2021, whichever is earlier.
A moratorium period of up to 7 years on the principal payment is prescribed under DAF-SDSM; only interest is paid during this period.
The principal amount under DAF-SDSM shall be repaid within a maximum of 3 years after the completion of the moratorium period.
The CGTMSE guaranteed portion under CGSSD will be assigned zero risk weight.
Credit extended under CGSSD will rank second charge on all existing assets.
Lending institutions can go for a one-time settlement (OTS) in respect of defaulted cases covered under CGSSD, but must keep the Trust informed.
Guarantees under CGSSD are issued by Banks logging into the CGTMSE Portal and applying for coverage; CGTMSE approves the guarantee within 24 hours upon payment of the fee.
Recovery proceedings are considered concluded after the decree has been enforced and recovery completed by the MLI, or if the decree becomes time-barred.
Further queries regarding CGSSD can be addressed to querysubdebt@cgtmse.in.
The Scheme for Fund for Regeneration of Traditional Industries (SFURTI) was launched to make traditional industries more productive, competitive, and sustainably developed.
Financial assistance under Revamped SFURTI is Rs. 2.50 crore per regular cluster (up to 500 artisans) and Rs. 5.00 crore per major cluster (more than 500 artisans).
The time frame for project implementation under SFURTI is 12-18 months.

Soft Interventions under SFURTI include general awareness, counseling, motivation, trust building, skill development, capacity building, institutional development, exposure visits, market promotion, design and product development, and participation in training programs.

Hard Interventions under SFURTI include creation of Common Facility Centres (CFCs), Raw Material Banks (RMBs), up-gradation of production infrastructure, tools and technological up-gradation, warehousing facilities, training centers, and value addition/processing centers.
Working capital is not provided under SFURTI; it must be arranged by the Implementing Agency (IA).
The cost of land is not included in the project cost under SFURTI; land must be arranged by the IA/SPV.
Formation of a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) is mandatory to seek final approval for hard interventions under SFURTI.
The purpose of the SPV is to develop and sustain the cluster after the project implementation period.
Artisans must be members of the SPV, and at least 33% of artisans shall be members of the Management Committee/Board of the SPV.
Training is provided to artisans under SFURTI's Soft Intervention initiatives through awareness camps, workshops, and exposure visits.
MSME Testing Centres (TCs) promote standardization by providing common testing facilities to ensure products meet national/international standards.
MSME TCs help MSMEs improve and maintain the quality of raw materials, intermediate, and final products.
MSME TCs provide calibration facilities for measuring instruments to help MSMEs improve their processes.
MSME TCs provide testing facilities for export products through Export Facilitation Centres.
To submit a sample for testing, a letter from the customer detailing the product, tests required, product specification, and grade is needed, along with a copy of the online payment receipt.
Samples can be sent by post or courier along with the required letter and payment receipt.
Test/Calibration charges are available upon request and can be obtained from the respective MSME Testing Centre.
Full test charges must be paid in advance before submitting the samples.
The charges provided by MSME Testing Centres are not inclusive of GST; GST is levied at 18% on total test charges, including postal charges.
A link for downloading the Test/Calibration Report in softcopy will be sent to the registered email address, and the original copy will be dispatched via Speed Post.
Test reports/calibration certificates can be collected directly from the office by producing a proper authorization letter from the original customer.
To collect equipment/instruments/testing samples after testing/calibration, a prior written request is required, and items must be collected within 3 months of completion.
MSME Testing Centres have NABL accreditation as per ISO/IEC 17025:2017, AERB recognition, BIS recognition, and are well-recognized by various government and industry organizations.
If a contractor produces a letter from a Government Department/PSU, the Test Report can be issued in the name of the assignee Government Department/PSU.
The lead time for testing samples and issuing Test Reports varies depending on the test(s) requested and the laboratory's workload, but efforts are made to deliver on time.
Customers can challenge Test Results by witnessing the test method or submitting a fresh sample for re-test upon payment of charges.
Corrections in Test Reports due to technical or typing errors will be made at no cost upon written notification; corrections requested by the customer may incur charges.
MSME-TCs can assist units in exporting their products by providing testing facilities and ensuring products meet international standards.
BIS (Bureau of Indian Standards) is the nodal agency in India for product standards, providing third-party guarantee of quality, safety, and reliability.
NABL (National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories) is a self-governing body providing third-party assessments of laboratory quality and technical capabilities.

ILAC (International Laboratory Accreditation Cooperation) is an international organization for accreditation cooperation involved in the assessment and accreditation of testing and calibration laboratories.
APLAC (Asia Pacific Laboratory Accreditation Cooperation) is an organization of laboratory accreditation bodies in the Asia Pacific area fostering the development of competent laboratories.
FPO (Fruit Products Order) mark is issued by the Ministry of Food Processing Industry and develops standards for food products.
European Standards (ENs) are documents ratified by European Standardization Organizations (CEN, CENELEC, or ETSI).
Quality Control Orders are part of a system for verifying and maintaining a desired level of quality in a product or process.
The BEE Star rating scheme is an energy efficiency standard for appliances sold in India, indicating their annual electricity consumption.
The CHAMPIONS portal can help MSME units by providing guidelines on product testing in MSME-TCs/TS and maintaining equipment through calibration.
Contact information for AP MSME DC includes an address in Mangalagiri, Andhra Pradesh, and email addresses: ceo-apmsmedc@ap.gov.in, edinframsmedc@ap.gov.in, apmsmedc@gmail.com.

The Ministry of Science and Technology Energy offers a grant for R&D in aquaculture and marine biotechnology.
The scheme is named Animal/Agr i culture/Marine BioTechnology/BioResource Programme.
The component is Grant.
The applicant can be individuals or institutions.
The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy has a scheme for setting up distributed grid-connected solar PV power projects in Andaman and Nicobar and Lakshadweep Islands with capital subsidy.
The scheme name is Scheme for Setting up of Distributed GridConnected Solar PV Power Projects in Andaman and Nicobar and Lakshadweep Islands with Capital Subsidy.
The component is Finance.
The applicant can be CPSUs like NTPC, NLC, SECI, REIL, etc.

The types of projects supported include standalone Solar PV Power Projects, standalone Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS), Solar PV plants with BESS, transmission systems for Solar PV Power Plants, and floating Solar PV power plants (with or without BESS) in Andaman & Nicobar Islands and Lakshadweep Islands.
The Government of India offers a CFA of up to 40% of the project cost.
The scheme is implemented through Central Public Sector Undertakings (CPSUs) like NTPC, NLC, REIL, SECI on a Build, Own and Operate (BOO) basis.
Andaman & Nicobar and Lakshadweep Administrations will purchase electricity from the Implementing Agencies at a tariff determined by JERC/CERC, considering the CFA.
The Integrated Infrastructural Development (IID) scheme is managed by SIDBI.
The component of the IID scheme is Credit.
The applicant for the IID scheme can be public sector corporations or NGOs.
The ceiling on the project cost for the IID scheme is Rs. 500 lakh.
Costs exceeding Rs. 500 lakh for the IID scheme can be met by the State/UT Government.
The Ministry/Department for the Infrastructure Development: Sub scheme-MSE CDP is the Ministry of MSME.
The scheme name is Infrastructure Development: Sub scheme-MSE CDP.
The component of the Infrastructure Development: Sub scheme-MSE CDP is Infrastructure.
The sub-component of the Infrastructure Development: Sub scheme-MSE CDP is Finance.
The applicant for the Infrastructure Development: Sub scheme-MSE CDP is SPV in consultation with the state department of MSME.

Infrastructure Development Projects under the MSE CDP scheme cover facilities like power distribution, water, telecommunication, drainage, pollution control, roads, banks, raw material storage, marketing outlets, common services, and technological backup for MSEs.
The GoI grant for the MSE CDP scheme is restricted to 60% of the project cost.
The project cost limit for industrial estates under the MSE CDP scheme is Rs. 10.00 crore.
The project cost limit for flatted factory complexes under the MSE CDP scheme is Rs. 15.00 crore.
The GoI grant for the MSE CDP scheme is 80% for projects in NE & Hilly States, Island territories, Aspirational Districts/LWE affected Districts.
The GoI grant for the MSE CDP scheme is 80% for industrial areas/estates/flatted factory complexes with more than 50% micro/village or women-owned or SC/ST units.
The State/UT Governments will meet the cost in excess of Rs. 10.00 crore/Rs. 15.00 crore or any escalation in cost for the MSE CDP scheme.
A variation of a maximum of 10% is admissible in component-wise cost, keeping the overall project cost unchanged for the MSE CDP scheme.
The scheme is called Top up loan for immediate purposes (TULIP).
The scheme is offered by SIDBI.
The component of the scheme is Credit.
The sub-component is not specified.
Applicants must have at least a 1-year association with SIDBI with a satisfactory track record.
Applicants must be expanding in the same line of business at the same location.
Applicants must have had a cash profit in the last financial year.
Eligible expenditures for the loan include the purchase of machinery/equipment.
Eligible expenditures for the loan include need-based civil construction/renovation.
Eligible expenditures for the loan include the acquisition of DG sets/other MFAs (including testing equipment, dies & moulds etc.).
Eligible expenditures for the loan include margin money for working capital (MMWC).

The loan can be used to execute sudden/specific/bulk orders that are self-liquidating in nature and are against a minimum BBB rated counterparty or a state/central government department counterparty with a track record in making timely payments.
The assistance provided is 30% of the existing exposure or 20% of net sales, subject to a maximum of Rs. 2 Crore.
The maximum repayment period for the loan is 5 years, including a moratorium of up to 6 months.
A link for more details is provided: https://sidbi.in/en/products.
The scheme is called Custom Duty Concession.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the scheme is the Ministry of Heavy Industries and Public Enterprises.
The component of the scheme is Tax Exemptions.
The sub-component of the scheme is Finance.
Any manufacturer in the automotive sector is eligible to apply for this scheme.
The assistance provided is a concessional rate of customs duty for the selected import of machinery and equipment.
A link for more details is provided: https://www.cbic.gov.in/resources//htdocs-cbec/customs/cst1718-020218/G.E.%2043.pdf;jsessionid=EA532A40D49282CDE1DD684EA43F3490.
The scheme is named Composite Loan.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the Composite Loan scheme is SIDBI.
The component of the Composite Loan scheme is Credit.
The sub-component of the Composite Loan scheme is not specified.
The applicants for the Composite Loan scheme are Artisans, micro-units, village and cottage industries.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Composite Loan scheme is a loan not exceeding Rs. 25 lakh.
A link for more details on the Composite Loan scheme is provided: https://sidbi.in/oldsmallb/bank-schemes/composite-loan-scheme-0
The scheme is named Promotion of Indian Spice Brands Abroad.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the Promotion of Indian Spice Brands Abroad scheme is the Ministry of Commerce and Industries.
The component of the Promotion of Indian Spice Brands Abroad scheme is Credit.
The sub-component of the Promotion of Indian Spice Brands Abroad scheme is Interest.
The applicants for the Promotion of Indian Spice Brands Abroad scheme are all spices exporters having brands registered with Spices Board.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Promotion of Indian Spice Brands Abroad scheme is an interest-free loan up to 100% for slotting fee and 50% for product development.

A link for more details on the Promotion of Indian Spice Brands Abroad scheme is provided: https://www.indiafilings.com/learn/promotion-of-indian-spice-brands/#:~:text=Under%20this%20scheme%2C%20the%20Government,beyond%20the%20ethnic%20Indian%20population.
The Ministry of Textiles offers the Integrated Textile Park scheme.
The Integrated Textile Park scheme falls under the 'Infrastructure' component and 'Finance' sub-component.
Applicants for the Integrated Textile Park scheme can be Industries Associations or Groups of Entrepreneurs, or SPVs (Special Purpose Vehicles).
Under the Integrated Textile Park scheme, the Government of India's support (Grant or Equity) is limited to 40% of the project cost, with a maximum ceiling of Rs. 40 crore for parks.
The combined equity stake of the Government of India, State Government, and State Industrial Development Corporation cannot exceed 49% in the Integrated Textile Park scheme.

For the first two projects in Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Manipur, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, Tripura, Sikkim, and Jammu & Kashmir, Government of India support for the Integrated Textile Park scheme is 90% of the project cost, capped at Rs. 40 crore.
A link for details on the Integrated Textile Park scheme is provided.
The Ministry of Textiles offers the Yarn Bank Scheme.
The Yarn Bank Scheme falls under the 'Finance' component and has no specified sub-component.
Applicants for the Yarn Bank Scheme can be Registered Cooperative Societies, Trusts, Companies set up under the Companies Act, 1956, or Firms set up under the Limited Liability Partnership Act, 2008.
Under the Yarn Bank Scheme, the Government provides an interest-free corpus fund of a maximum of Rs. 200 Lakh per yarn bank to the applicant for raw material.
A link for details on the Yarn Bank Scheme is provided.
The scheme is named Science and Technology Application for Rural Development (STARD).
The Ministry/Department associated with STARD is the Ministry of Science and Technology Energy.
The component of STARD is Grant.
The sub-component of STARD is not specified.
Recognized schools, colleges, NGOs, etc., are eligible applicants for STARD.
STARD provides long-term support for core personnel, equipment, salaries, travel, overheads, etc.
A link for more details on STARD is available at https://www.scienceandsociety-dst.org/stard.htm.

Applicants for the Revamped Scheme of Fund for Regeneration Of Traditional Industries (SFURTI) can be NGOs, Institutions of the Central, State and, Semi-Government Field functionaries of State and Central Govt., Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs), and similar agencies with expertise in cluster development.
The financial assistance for any specific project under the Revamped Scheme of Fund for Regeneration Of Traditional Industries (SFURTI) is subject to a maximum of Rs. 5 crore.
For Regular Clusters (up to 500 artisans) under the Revamped Scheme of Fund for Regeneration Of Traditional Industries (SFURTI), the Per Cluster Budget Limit is Rs. 2.50 crore.
For Major Clusters (more than 500 artisans) under the Revamped Scheme of Fund for Regeneration Of Traditional Industries (SFURTI), the Per Cluster Budget Limit is Rs. 5 crore.
For North Eastern Region (NER), J&K, and hilly states, the assistance ratio under the Revamped Scheme of Fund for Regeneration Of Traditional Industries (SFURTI) is 95%:5%.
The IA/SPV may deposit their share under the Revamped Scheme of Fund for Regeneration Of Traditional Industries (SFURTI) in a phased manner, with a minimum of 25% in a single installment.

For Women/ SC/ ST under the Tourism Policy 2021-25, the employment creation incentive is INR 1,50,000 per local employment position for high-end IT jobs, INR 1,12,500 for mid-level IT jobs, and INR 75,000 for entry-level IT jobs.

The SIDBI Retail Trade Loan Scheme (RLS) is a credit component for existing well-performing MSE Retail & Wholesale Traders.

To be eligible for the SIDBI RLS scheme, applicants must have a minimum of 3 years in operations with stable sales and cash profits in the past 3 years, and a satisfactory track record with Banks/FIs/NBFC for the past 12 months.

The scheme covers MSE Retail Traders & Dealers (dealing with products of at least one large reputed supplier having turnover of around Rs.1000 crore or more) and Wholesale Traders. Export trade & large commercial real estate-based models are not covered.

Eligible expenditures for the SIDBI RLS scheme include: For Capex: Acquisition of business premises, godown, shop, office premises, repair, furnishing, renovation of existing business premises and/or purchase of furniture & fixtures, equipment's, tools, computers, UPS, DG set, etc.

For working capital/additional working capital (in case the borrower is already having working capital/overdraft facility with some other Bank/FI), the assistance is up to Rs. 50 lakh for Retailers/traders and dealers, and up to Rs. 100 lakh for Wholesale traders (stockists, super stockists, etc.).
Finance towards working capital can be a maximum of 20% of the sales turnover of the last financial year.
The tenure for the SIDBI RLS scheme is 36 to 60 months, including a moratorium of up to 3 months.
A link for more details on the SIDBI RLS scheme is provided: https://sidbi.in/en/products.
The Export Market Promotion (EMP) scheme is offered by the Ministry of MSME.
The scheme name is Export Market Promotion (EMP).
The component of the scheme is Marketing.
The sub-component is Activities/Support/Finance/Financial assistance.
Manufacturers, Entrepreneurs, and Exporters of Coir are eligible applicants.

Assistance includes delegation, consultancy, information sourcing, participation in seminars and conferences, participation in international fairs/buyer-seller meets, publicity abroad, external market development assistance, and Coir Industry Awards.

Financial assistance for participation in International Exhibitions/Trade Fairs/Buyer seller Meets in foreign countries covers 100% of the space rent, up to a maximum of Rs. 1.00 lakh or the actual rent paid, whichever is lower, per exporter/enterprise.

Financial assistance for economy class airfare covers 100% of the fare, up to a maximum of Rs. 1.50 lakh and Rs. 1 Lakh in India, or the actual fare paid, whichever is lower, for one representative of the exporter.
Financial assistance for freight charges covers actual costs, up to a maximum of Rs. 25,000 in foreign countries and Rs. 20,000 in India, per exporter/enterprise.
The link for details of the Export Market Promotion (EMP) scheme is provided.

To enroll, click on 'Enroll Now' to be redirected to the Enrollment Calendar page.
Select your District and RAMP component on the Enrollment Calendar page.
The calendar will display details of location, venue, date, and time.
Click on 'Click Here' under the Enroll column in the calendar and enter your details.
There is an 'Enroll' button linking to Enrollment.aspx?ID=ALL.

The contact name is Ms. Aishwarya Jojo.
The email ID for Ms. Aishwarya Jojo is aishwaryajojo@kpmg.com.

The document is titled 'Schemes'.
The scheme aims to enable the manufacturing sector to be competitive through QMS & QTT.
The Ministry/Department associated with the scheme is the Ministry of MSME.
The Scheme Name is 'Enabling Manufacturing Sector to be Competitive through QMS &QTT'.
The Component is 'Technology'.
The Sub Component is 'Finance'.

Expert organizations like Quality Council of India (QCI), National Recruitment Board for Personnel and Training, Consultancy Development Corporation, National Productivity Council, Standardisation, Testing & Quality Certification (STQC, a Society under the Ministry of IT), IIQM (Indian Institute of Quality Management), Industry Associations that have taken an active interest in QMS/QTT, Technical Institutions, Engineering Colleges, Tool Rooms and similar bodies, and MSEs can apply for assistance under this scheme.
The Quantum of Assistance includes funding support for the introduction of appropriate course modules in technical institutions through expert organizations.
The Quantum of Assistance includes funding support up to Rs. 79,000/- per program for conducting QMS/QTT awareness campaigns for MSEs through expert organizations.
The Quantum of Assistance includes funding support up to Rs. 2.5 lakh per unit for the implementation of QMS and QTT in selected MSMEs through expert organizations.
The Quantum of Assistance includes funding support for conducting C-watch studies for products having threats from foreign goods.
A link for details is provided, which is a JavaScript function call.

The Ministry/Department for the Special Economic Zone Scheme is Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology.
The Scheme Name is Special Economic Zone Scheme.
The Component for the Special Economic Zone Scheme is Finance.
The Sub Component for the Special Economic Zone Scheme is Tax Exemptions.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Special Economic Zone Scheme includes duty-free import/domestic procurement of goods for SEZ development, operation, and maintenance.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Special Economic Zone Scheme includes 100% Income Tax exemption on export income for SEZ units under Section 10AA of the Income Tax Act for the first 5 years.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Special Economic Zone Scheme includes 50% Income Tax exemption on export income for the next 5 years.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Special Economic Zone Scheme includes 50% of the ploughed-back export profit for the next 5 years.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Special Economic Zone Scheme includes exemption from Central Sales Tax.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Special Economic Zone Scheme includes exemption from Service Tax.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Special Economic Zone Scheme includes exemption from State sales tax.
Supplies to SEZs are zero-rated under IGST Act, 2017, as Central Sales Tax, Service Tax, and State sales tax have been subsumed into GST.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Special Economic Zone Scheme includes other levies as imposed by the respective State Governments.
The Quantum of Assistance for the Special Economic Zone Scheme includes a single window clearance for Central and State level approvals.
A link for more details on the Special Economic Zone Scheme is provided at https://www.meity.gov.in/content/export-promotionschemes#tab1.
NRDC is a large repository of technologies across various industries.

Industries covered include Agriculture and Agro-processing, Aerospace, Bio Technology, Chemicals, Pesticides, Drugs and Pharmaceuticals, Food, Metallurgy, Electronics and Instrumentation, Building Materials, Mechanical, Electrical and Electronics.
Licensing of technologies by NRDC has led to the establishment of many small and medium scale industries.
A list of NRDC technologies across various sectors is available at https://www.nrdcindia.com/TechnologyList.
A compendium of the latest significant technologies available for commercialisation is attached below.

The compendium covers areas such as agriculture, electrical, electronics, chemical, electrochemical, mechanical, engineering, oceanographic, corrosion, and allied areas including food and millet technologies.
A total of 262 technologies with TRL 6 and above are summarized in the compendium.
NRDC has filed over 2000 patent applications.
NRDC manages the IPR portfolio (Patents, Trademarks, Designs, Copyrights) for R&D Institutes, Educational Institutes, Individual Inventors, and startups.

NRDC offers services in Intellectual Property, including Prior Art Searches, IP Drafting, Filing and Prosecution, Patent Maintenance, Patent/Technology Landscaping, Formulation of IP Policy/Guidelines Strategies, Conducting IP Awareness Workshops/Seminars, Evaluating the potential of R&D results for IP, and Commercializing Patented Inventions.
NRDC offers funding support through various schemes.

The Program for Inspiring Inventors and Innovators (PIII) - Patent Assistance scheme supports grassroots innovators, entrepreneurs, academic institutions, R&D organizations, and start-ups in securing patent protection.
Under PIII, NRDC provides financial assistance for expenses up to the grant or registration of the patent.
NRDC facilitates patent filing for novel technologies and innovations.
NRDC's Techno Commercial Support aims to bridge gaps in the innovation chain and transform inventions into industry-ready technologies.
This support is offered to Indian inventors, scientists, technocrats, NRDC Awardees, Licensees, and other eligible stakeholders to enhance marketability and industry acceptance.
NRDC provides financial assistance for Development Projects and value addition for Priority Projects to support further development and value addition of selected technologies.
This support is for R&D institutions, academia, licensees, and individual innovators to facilitate commercial production and market readiness.
NRDC Seed Funding support is extended to early-stage start-ups developing new products or new applications of existing products, incubated in Central/State supported institutions.
Seed Funding support is up to 30 lakhs against equity.
The Technology Development Validation and Commercialisation (TDVC) Scheme aims to bridge the gap between laboratory innovations and commercialization.
The TDVC Scheme provides financial and technical support for further development, validation, and value addition of promising technologies.
The TDVC Scheme's objective is to facilitate manufacturing industries to move from the Proof of Concept stage to commercialization.
Value-added services provided by NRDC include IP Management, IP Valuation, NETRA, Design Clinic, and Reports.
NRDC assists Innovators, Entrepreneurs, Start-ups, R&D Organizations, Government Establishments, Ministries, and Public & Private Industries in securing IP protection in India and foreign countries.
NRDC provides technical and legal consultancy services for IP filing and related services for manufacturing technology/processes/products.
NRDC provides IPR and Technology Management Consultancy Services to R&D institutes/Industries/DPSUs.

Specific IPR and Technology Management Consultancy Services include Patent Search and Analysis, Patent Landscaping/Mapping/White Space Analysis, Filing of Patents, Trademarks, Designs, Copyrights, Geographical Indications in India and abroad (PCT/Conventional Filing), Formulating IPR Policies, Organising IPR Awareness Programs, IP management of start-ups, and Establishment of IP Facilitation Cells.
NRDC assists Innovators, Entrepreneurs, Start-ups & R&D Organizations in IP & Technology Valuation.
IP and Technology Valuation determines the financial worth of intangible assets like patents and technologies.
IP and Technology Valuation guides decisions on licensing, sales, and protection.
IP and Technology Valuation serves as a tool for IP Portfolio Management, assessment of IP value, and legacy remedy.
NRDC, in collaboration with CSIR-NIScPR, established the National Establishment for Technology Readiness Assessment (NETRA) facility.
NETRA provides a comprehensive overview of technology maturity levels across various Science & Technology domains.
NETRA bridges the gap between technology developers and end-users.
NETRA assesses Technology Readiness Levels to ensure technologies receive necessary guidance and support for commercialization.
NRDC's Design Clinic Facility helps MSMEs/Startups with product design & development, design process, and design thinking.
The Design Clinic Facility aims to generate innovative design solutions to improve the competitiveness of MSMEs/Startups.
The Design Clinic Facility diagnoses design problems and suggests remedial steps through a multidisciplinary team of design experts.
The Design Clinic Facility assists Startups/MSMEs/Industries/Academia in designing, improving, and synchronizing their products with regulatory guidelines.
The Design Clinic Facility focuses on improving the aesthetic, functional, and marketability aspects of products.
NRDC offers other value-added services to support innovation commercialization.
These services include market surveys to assess demand, competition, and adoption potential.
Feasibility studies are offered to evaluate the economic, technical, and operational viability of ventures.
Basic Engineering Design Packages (BEDPs) are provided, offering technical specifications and process flow details for industrial operations.

The Trade Infrastructure for Export Schemes (TIES) is a scheme under the Ministry of Commerce and Industries.
TIES has a component of Infrastructure and a sub-component of Finance Subsidy.
Eligible applicants for TIES include Central and State Agencies, Export Promotion Councils, Commodities Boards, SEZ Authorities, and Apex Trade Bodies recognized under the EXIM policy.
Under TIES, the Government of India (GOI) provides 50% of the project cost (excluding land) subject to a ceiling of INR 20.00 Crore.
For North Eastern States and Himalayan States including J&K, GOI support is 80% of the total equity in the project with a ceiling of Rs 20.00 Crore.
Land is not eligible for grant under TIES.
A link for TIES details is provided: https://commerce.gov.in/writereaddata/UploadedFile/MOC_636289964499400263_TIES_Ffinal_guidelines_18_04_2017.pdf.
The Integrated Processing Development Scheme (IPDS) is under the Ministry of Textiles.
The IPDS scheme has a component of Technology.
The IPDS scheme has a sub-component of Finance.
Applicants for the IPDS scheme can be Industries Associations/Group of Entrepreneurs or SPVs (Special Purpose Vehicles).
The Government of India provides grant support under the IPDS scheme, limited to 50% of the project cost.
For projects with Zero Liquid Discharge Systems under IPDS, the grant ceiling is Rs. 75 crores.
For projects with conventional treatment systems under IPDS, the grant ceiling is Rs. 10 crores.
Support for marine discharge projects under IPDS is analyzed on a case-to-case basis with a maximum ceiling of Rs. 75 crores.
The project cost for IPDS is borne by the Center, State, Beneficiary, and Bank loan in the ratio of 50:25:15:10 respectively.
The Plastic Park Scheme is under the Ministry of Chemicals & Fertilizers (Department of Pharmaceuticals).
The Plastic Park Scheme has a component of Infrastructure.
The Plastic Park Scheme has a sub-component of Finance.
Applicants for the Plastic Park Scheme can be Industries Associations/Group of Entrepreneurs or SPVs (Special Purpose Vehicles).
Under the Plastic Park Scheme, grant funding is provided for Buildings and Plants and Machineries.
The grant funding for the Plastic Park Scheme is up to 50% of the project cost, with a ceiling of Rs. 40 crores per project.
The Coir Industry Technology Upgradation Scheme (CITUS) is offered by the Ministry of MSME.
The CITUS scheme's component is Technology.
The CITUS scheme's sub-component is Finance Grant.
Entrepreneurs in the categories of SHGs, Associations, Enterprises from small/medium/cooperative/public sector are eligible applicants for the CITUS scheme.
Financial assistance for the CITUS scheme is 25% of the cost of admissible items of Plant and Machinery procured by Coir units for modernization, upgradation, and/or establishing a new unit.
The upper ceiling of financial assistance for the CITUS scheme is Rs. 2.50 crores per coir unit/project.
A link for details on the CITUS scheme is provided at https://msme.gov.in/sites/default/files/Revised_Operation_Guidelines_of_CVY.pdf.
The Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme is offered by SIDBI.
The Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme's component is Credit.
An eligible MSME unit is an applicant for the Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme.
SIDBI assistance for the Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme can be considered for existing customers solely banking with SIDBI.
SIDBI assistance for the Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme can be considered for existing customers of SIDBI who also bank with other banks.
SIDBI assistance for the Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme can be considered for existing well-performing units that do not have a working capital facility with any other bank.
SIDBI assistance for the Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme can be considered for new entities where SIDBI is considering a term loan.
Takeover of working capital accounts as part of a term loan takeover may be considered for the Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme, subject to compliance with takeover guidelines.
The Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme offers the option to choose a banking platform from 2-3 banks.
The Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme offers seamless approvals as per customer instructions for setting DP etc.
The Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme offers a single window for term loan customers to avail working capital facilities.
A link for details on the Working Capital (CASH CREDIT) scheme is provided at https://sidbi.in/en/products.
The Ministry of Food Processing Industries offers a scheme called Operation Greens.
Operation Greens has a component focused on Technical Infrastructure.
Within the Technical Infrastructure component, there is a sub-component for Finance.
A single promoter can apply for the Operation Greens scheme.
Assistance for Plant & Machinery and related technical civil works under Operation Greens is 50% of the eligible project cost, with a maximum of Rs. 50 crores per project.
If the Project Implementing Agency (PIA) is an FPO and belongs to SC/ST, the grant-in-aid is 70% of the project cost, capped at Rs. 50 crores per project.
A link for more details on Operation Greens is provided: https://mofpi.nic.in/Schemes/operation-greens.
The RAMP program includes workshops on Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs) at the district level.
IPRs are legal rights that protect creations of the mind and innovation.
Understanding IPR is crucial for MSMEs and startups to safeguard competitive advantages, attract investments, and generate new revenue streams.
The district-level IPR workshops under RAMP aim to enhance MSMEs' understanding of IPR.
Unregistered MSMEs, new entrepreneurs, and Self-Help Groups (SHGs) are encouraged to attend the IPR workshops.
Attending the IPR workshops helps MSMEs safeguard their intellectual property, leading to technology upgradation and improved market competitiveness.
Understanding IPR encourages MSMEs to engage in creative endeavors like patenting inventions, registering trademarks, and safeguarding designs.
Awareness of IPR helps MSMEs align with international standards and protect their interests globally.
The IPR workshops cover understanding the concept of IPR, its importance, and the need for IPR for MSMEs.
Topics include benefits of IPR for MSMEs, its role in innovation and competitiveness, and GoI schemes supporting IPR filing.
The workshops introduce IPR tools such as Patents, Trademarks, Copyrights, Industrial Designs, and GI Tags.
Information on National and International IP Laws, including key Indian IP laws and international frameworks like TRIPS and WIPO, will be discussed.
The procedure for registration of various IPs, including forms, timelines, and fees, will be covered.
Case studies and real-life examples related to IPR will be presented.
Fundamentals of technology transfer, including licensing and types of technology transfer agreements, will be explained.
Patenting and patent law, including patentability criteria, drafting patent applications, and best practices, will be a topic.
Enforcement of IPR rights, legal remedies, and the role of courts and tribunals will be discussed.
The workshops will cover how to identify IPR infringement and the actions to be taken.
The impact of IPR on MSMEs and business growth, including success stories and economic benefits, will be highlighted.
Environmental & Social (E&S) compliance and its significance for MSMEs, including aligning innovation with sustainable practices, will be discussed.
To enroll in the workshops, users need to click on 'Enroll Now' and select their district and RAMP component.
The enrollment calendar will display the location, venue, date, and time of the workshops.
Users can enroll by clicking 'Click Here' under the Enroll column in the calendar and entering their details.

The scheme is named SIDBI Assistance to facilitate emergency response against Corona Virus (SAFE).
The Ministry/Department involved is SIDBI.
The component of the scheme is Credit.
The sub-component is not specified.
For new customers to the bank, applicants must have at least two years of cash profits and their account must not be in the SMA1/2 category.
For existing bank customers, applicants must have cash profit in the last audited balance sheet and their account must not be in the SMA1/2 category.
The eligible expenditure is to finance all existing MSMEs manufacturing products or providing services directly related to fighting Corona Virus.
The loan amount can be up to Rs. 50 Lakh.
The interest rate is 5% p.a. fixed on a reducing balance basis.
The tenure for a Term Loan is up to 5 years, including moratorium.
The tenure for a Working Capital Term Loan (WCTL) is up to 18 months, including moratorium.
The scheme is named Participation in International Fairs and Exhibitions with Tea Board.
The Ministry/Department involved is Ministry of Commerce and Industries.
The scheme name is Participation in International Fairs and Exhibitions with Tea Board.
The component of the scheme is Subsidy.
The sub-component is Finance.
All exporters holding a valid export license are eligible applicants.
The quantum of assistance is economy class airfare for one representative from India.

The scheme name is Critical Technology Programme (CTP).
The Ministry/Department associated with the scheme is Ministry of Science and Technology Energy.
The component of the scheme is Grant.
The applicant for the scheme can be individuals, academic groups, R&D institutions, and units.
The Quantum of Assistance (in Brief) includes salaries, equipment, consumables, internal travel, and overheads.
The link for details of the scheme is https://www.dcsa.mil/mc/ctp/.
The Credit Linked Capital Subsidy (CLCS) scheme is provided by NABARD.
The Credit Linked Capital Subsidy (CLCS) scheme is a credit component.
The Credit Linked Capital Subsidy (CLCS) scheme is for SMEs.
The Credit Linked Capital Subsidy (CLCS) scheme provides capital subsidy for technology up-gradation of MSEs in specified products/sub-sectors by introducing approved technologies.
The Ministry of Corporate Affairs offers the Fast Track Exit Mode scheme.
The Fast Track Exit Mode scheme is a support component.
The Fast Track Exit Mode scheme is for defunct companies under section 560 of the Companies Act, 1956.

The Fast Track Exit Mode scheme allows defunct companies to have their names struck off the register of companies by modifying the existing route through e-form - 61, following new Guidelines for 'Fast Track Exit mode'.
The Guidelines for the Fast Track Exit Mode are enclosed.
The link for details on the Credit Linked Capital Subsidy scheme is http://www.dcmsme.gov.in/schemes/credit_link_scheme.htm.
The link for details on the Fast Track Exit Mode scheme is https://www.fasttrackexitmode.com/pdf/Procedure_under_FTE.pdf.
The scheme is named 'Science and Technology (S&T) for Coir'.
The Ministry/Department responsible for this scheme is the Ministry of MSME.
The component of the scheme is Technology.
The sub-component of the scheme is Finance Grant.
The applicants for this scheme are the Central Coir Research Institute, Kalavoor and Central Institute of Coir Technology, Bangalore.

The Quantum of Assistance (in Brief) for the scheme includes modernization of production processes, development of machinery and equipment, product development and diversification, development of environment-friendly technologies, and technology transfer, incubation, testing, and service facilities.
The Ministry allocates funds for the above activities.
The Director RDTE, heading the Research Institutes CCRI & CICT of the Board, is the nodal officer for all S&T programmes, fund utilization, settlement, and furnishing reports to HO.
Funds will be released to the Research Institutes from HO of Coir Board on a quarterly basis upon certification of utilization of 70% of previously released funds.
The period for implementation of programmes under S&T activities is 2017-18 to 2019-20.
The scheme is named 'Loans Under Partnership with OEM'.
The Ministry/Department responsible for this scheme is SIDBI.
The component of the scheme is Credit.
The sub-component of the scheme is not specified.
The applicants for this scheme are MSMEs with at least 3 years of existence and a satisfactory financial position.
The Quantum of Assistance (in Brief) for the scheme includes investment in Plant & Machinery purchased from respective OEMs.
The loan amount is generally up to Rs. 100 Lakh, with higher amounts considered subject to Bank's guidelines.
The repayment period is normally up to 60 months, including eligible moratorium.
The Ministry of MSME offers a scheme called Raw Material Assistance.
The Raw Material Assistance scheme falls under the 'Credit' component and 'Finance' sub-component.
Registered MSMEs are eligible applicants for the Raw Material Assistance scheme.
The Raw Material Assistance scheme provides financial assistance for the procurement of raw materials for up to 90 days.
This scheme helps MSEs avail benefits like bulk purchase and cash discounts.
The scheme also handles procedures, documentation, and letters of credit for imports.
The Ministry of Chemicals & Fertilizers (Department of Pharmaceuticals) has a scheme named Pharmaceutical Promotion and Development Scheme (PPDS).
The PPDS falls under the 'Finance' component.
The Department of Pharmaceuticals, or institutions, organizations, voluntary organizations, or non-government organizations supported financially by the department, can be applicants for the PPDS.
The objective of the PPDS is to promote, develop, and support export promotion in the pharmaceutical sector.
Financial support is extended for seminars, conferences, and exhibitions under PPDS.
PPDS supports delegations to and from India for export and investment promotion.
Studies and consultancies are also supported under PPDS to facilitate growth and address critical issues in the pharma sector.
Government departments, institutions, and agencies can receive 100% grant for programs organized under PPDS.
Autonomous bodies, private agencies, associations, private institutions, NGOs, or others can receive a 75% grant for activities organized on the initiative or suggestion of the department.

Autonomous bodies, private agencies, associations, private institutions, NGOs, or others can receive a 50% grant for activities organized on their own initiative that are relevant to the department's mandate.
For mega events like India Pharma and India Medical Expo, the grant amount will be determined based on estimates and past expenditure, with concurrence from IFD/Department of Expenditure.
For studies, surveys, online surveys, and magazines, grants will be 100%, 75%, or 50% based on the category specified in the guidelines.
The Ministry of MSME offers the Credit Guarantee Finance Scheme (CGTMSE).
The scheme's component is Finance.
The sub-component is Collateral free loan.
The applicant for the CGTMSE scheme is Micro & Small Enterprises.
CGTMSE provides credit guarantees to financial institutions that offer loans to MSMEs.
The Ministry of MSME offers the Marketing Hub/Exhibition Centres by Associations Sub scheme - MSE CDP.
The component of the Marketing Hub/Exhibition Centres by Associations Sub scheme - MSE CDP is Marketing.
The sub-component of the Marketing Hub/Exhibition Centres by Associations Sub scheme - MSE CDP is Finance.
Applicants for the Marketing Hub/Exhibition Centres by Associations Sub scheme - MSE CDP must be Clusters, Industrial associations/Consortia Associations desirous of availing GoI assistance.
These applicants need to form an SPV comprising at least 20 member units of the association.
The SPV must be a Section 8 company as per the Companies Act 2013.
The GoI grant for this scheme is restricted to 70% of the project cost, with a maximum of Rs. 20.00 crore.
For CFCs in NE & Hill States, Island territories, Aspirational Districts/LWE affected Districts Clusters with more than 50% micro/village or women-owned or SC/ST units, the grant is 90%.
The project cost includes the cost of land, subject to a maximum of 25% of the project cost.
The Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology offers a Scheme for promotion of manufacturing of electronic components and Semi-conductors.
This scheme falls under the 'Technology' component and 'Finance Subsidy' sub-component.
The scheme is applicable to investments in new units as well as expansion of capacity, modernization, and diversification of existing units.
The assistance provided is a financial incentive of 25% of capital expenditure for the manufacturing of goods.
The Ministry of MSME offers a Marketing Assistance Scheme.
This scheme falls under the 'Marketing' component and 'Finance' sub-component.
MSMEs, Industry Associations, and other organizations related to the MSME sector are eligible to apply for this scheme.
For participating in an international exhibition/trade fair, the maximum net budgetary support is restricted to Rs. 30 lakh per event, with a ceiling of Rs. 40 lakh for Latin American countries.
For organizing domestic exhibitions/trade fairs, the budgetary support towards net expenditure is normally restricted to a maximum of Rs. 45 lakh.

For participation in an exhibition/trade fair, financial assistance ranging from 25% to 95% of the Air-Fare and space rent will be provided to entrepreneurs based on the size and type of the enterprise.
Financial assistance for co-sponsoring an event is limited to 40% of the net expenditure, with a maximum amount of Rs. 5 lakh.
The Ministry of Science and Technology Energy offers a scheme called Technology Business Incubators (TBI).
The component of the Technology Business Incubators (TBI) scheme is Finance.
The applicant for the Technology Business Incubators (TBI) scheme can be R&D institutions or academic institutes.
The Technology Business Incubators (TBI) scheme provides financial assistance for five years.
The Ministry of Communication and Information Technology offers a scheme called Duty Exemption and Remission.
The component of the Duty Exemption and Remission scheme is Tax Exemptions.
The sub-component of the Duty Exemption and Remission scheme is Finance.
All licensed exporters are eligible to apply for the Duty Exemption and Remission scheme.
The Duty Exemption and Remission scheme issues advance licenses, permits duty-free replenishment of inputs, and drawback of import changes.
The Mega Leather, Footwear and Accessories Cluster (MLFAC) is a sub-scheme of the Indian Footwear Leather and Accessories Development Programme.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the MLFAC scheme is the Ministry of Commerce and Industries.
The Scheme Name is Mega Leather, Footwear and Accessories Cluster MLFAC Sub Scheme Indian Footwear Leather and Accessories Development Programme.
The Component of the MLFAC scheme is Infrastructure.
The Sub Component of the MLFAC scheme is Finance.
The Applicant for the MLFAC scheme is SPV (Special Purpose Vehicle).
Assistance for the MLFAC scheme is graded up to 50% of the eligible project cost, excluding the cost of land.
The maximum Government of India (GOI) assistance for the MLFAC scheme is Rs. 125 crore.
An outlay of Rs. 360 crore has been proposed for 3-4 new MLFACs over 3 years.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the PM Formalization of Micro food processing Enterprises Scheme (PMFME) is the Ministry of Food Processing Industries.
The Scheme Name is PM Formalization of Micro food processing Enterprises Scheme (PMFME).
The Component of the PMFME scheme is Financial, technical and business support.
The Sub Component of the PMFME scheme is Finance.
The Applicant for the PMFME scheme is Existing Micro food processing enterprises.
The PMFME scheme aims for the upgradation of existing micro food processing enterprises and adopts the One District One Product (ODOP) approach.
Individual micro food processing units can avail a credit-linked capital subsidy of 35% of the eligible project cost, with a maximum ceiling of Rs. 10 lakh per unit.
The beneficiary contribution for individual units under PMFME should be a minimum of 10%.
The remaining balance for individual units under PMFME should be a loan from a Bank.
Support is provided to FPOs (Farmer Producer Organizations), SHGs (Self-Help Groups), and Cooperatives for capital investment along the entire value chain with a credit-linked grant of 35%.
Seed capital of Rs. 40,000 per SHG member engaged in food processing is provided for working capital and purchase of small tools.
A credit-linked grant of 35% is provided to FPOs, SHGs, cooperatives, state-owned agencies, and private entrepreneurs for developing common infrastructure.
Common infrastructure development under PMFME includes common processing facilities, labs, warehouses, cold storage, packaging, and incubation centers.
Support for branding and marketing under PMFME is limited to 50% of the total expenditure.

The Ministry/Department for the Assistance to Training Institutions (ATI) scheme is the Ministry of MSME.

The Component of the ATI scheme is Skill development Training institution's infrastructure.
The Sub Component of the ATI scheme is Finance.
Institutions of the Ministry of MSME are eligible applicants for the ATI scheme.
Existing State level EDIs are eligible applicants for the ATI scheme.
The Quantum of Assistance for the ATI scheme will not exceed the actual amount for strengthening/expansion of the infrastructure required by the training institutions of this Ministry.
The maximum assistance to State level EDIs for the ATI scheme will be restricted to Rs.2.5 crore in each case.
Assistance for skill development programmes under the ATI scheme will be provided as per the prescribed rates.
The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy is associated with the Grid Connected Solar Rooftop Scheme.
The Grid Connected Solar Rooftop Scheme falls under the 'Finance' component.
The applicant for the Grid Connected Solar Rooftop Scheme is Residential Consumers.
Component A of the Grid Connected Solar Rooftop Scheme provides Central Financial Assistance (CFA) to the Residential sector for 4 GW.
CFA is provided at 40% for solar rooftop capacity up to 3 kWp.
CFA is provided at 20% for solar rooftop capacity beyond 3 kWp and up to 10 kWp.
CFA is provided at 20% for Group Housing Societies (GHS) or Resident Welfare Associations (RWA) capacity up to 500 kWp, limited to 10 kWp per house and a total of 500 kWp.
Domestic manufactured modules and solar cells must be used for the Grid Connected Solar Rooftop Scheme.
CFA is calculated based on the benchmark cost of MNRE for the state/UT or the lowest cost discovered in tenders for that state/UT in that year, whichever is lower.
Power Distributing companies (DISCOMs) are the implementing agencies for Component A of the scheme.
Component B of the Grid Connected Solar Rooftop Scheme provides incentives to DISCOMs for an initial 18 GW capacity.
Incentives for DISCOMs are based on achievements above the baseline (cumulative RTS capacity installed at the end of the previous financial year).
No incentives are provided for capacity addition up to 10%.
5% incentives are provided for capacity addition beyond 10% and up to 15%.
10% incentives are provided for capacity addition beyond 15%.

A partnership with FyrstGen creates an AI-driven platform for youth and women entrepreneurs in AP.
