The scheme is named 'International Trade Fairs/Meetings (Spices Board Schemes)'.
The Ministry/Department responsible for this scheme is the Ministry of Commerce and Industries.
The component of the scheme is Reimbursement.
The sub-component is Finance.
The applicant for this scheme is all registered exporters and representatives of associations.
The quantum of assistance is reimbursement of 50% airfare with limits as per terms for individual exporters.
For delegations, the quantum of assistance is 50% reimbursement with a Rs. 1.5 lakh limit per year per exporter.
A link for details is provided: http://www.indianspices.com/sites/default/files/tradeFairsparticipation.pdf
The scheme is named 'Special Liquidity support to MSME's through NBFC's'.
The Ministry/Department associated with this scheme is SIDBI.
The component of the scheme is Credit.
The sub-component is Loan via NBFC.
The applicants for this scheme are MSMEs requiring funds for bona fide business purposes.
The quantum of assistance is Financial assistance.
A link for details is provided: https://sidbi.in/files/circulars/20200422161912.pdf

The scheme is called National SC-STHUB.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the National SC-STHUB scheme is the Ministry of MSME.
The component of the National SC-STHUB scheme is Welfare.
The sub-component of the National SC-STHUB scheme is Finance.
The applicant for the National SC-STHUB scheme is the Ministry of MSME through the National Small Industries Corporation (NSIC).

For the National SC-STHUB scheme, each activity's proposals would be submitted and forwarded by various organizations, including NSIC, to the Empowered Project Approval Committee chaired by the Secretary, MSME for approval.
A link for details on the National SC-STHUB scheme is available at https://msme.gov.in/sites/default/files/guidelinesSC-ST-HUb.pdf.
The scheme is called Single Point Registration.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the Single Point Registration scheme is the Ministry of MSME.
The component of the Single Point Registration scheme is Marketing.
The applicant for the Single Point Registration scheme is MSME.
Units registered under the Single Point Registration scheme are eligible for benefits including issue of tender sets free of cost and exemption from payment of Earnest Money Deposit (EMD).
Tender participating MSEs quoting a price within the L1+15% band are allowed to supply up to 20% of the requirement by bringing down their price to the L1 price, where L1 is a non-MSE.
Every Central Ministry/Department/PSU must set an annual goal of minimum 20% of total annual purchases of products or services produced or rendered by MSEs.
Out of the mandatory 20% procurement from MSEs, 4% is earmarked for units owned by Scheduled Castes/Scheduled Tribes.
Additionally, 358 items are reserved for exclusive purchase from the MSE sector.
A link for details on the Single Point Registration scheme is available at https://www.nsic.co.in/schemes/Single-Point-Registration.aspx.
RAMP is a centrally sponsored initiative by the Government of India.
RAMP is supported by the World Bank.
RAMP is designed to transform the MSME sector.
RAMP aims to improve MSME productivity.
RAMP aims to improve MSME competitiveness.
RAMP aims to improve MSME resilience.
RAMP aims to strengthen the MSME ecosystem.
RAMP focuses on strengthening coordination and institutions at National and State levels to better support MSMEs.
RAMP focuses on building and integrating technology platforms to streamline MSME operations and access to services.
RAMP focuses on enhancing firm capabilities and improving access to domestic and international markets.
RAMP focuses on strengthening the receivables financing market to improve cash flow for MSMEs.
RAMP focuses on enhancing guarantee products towards increased greening and gender participation.
RAMP focuses on promoting global competitiveness through quality certifications.
RAMP focuses on protecting innovation with intellectual property rights support.
RAMP offers workshops for udyam registration support and formalization services.
RAMP offers comprehensive 20-day training programs covering entrepreneurial skills, business planning, and sector-specific technical competencies.
RAMP offers training and empowering local professionals to provide comprehensive business support, guidance, and facilitation services to MSMEs.
RAMP offers strategic buyer-seller meetings connecting MSMEs with international buyers, export facilitation services, and global market access initiatives.
RAMP offers supply chain integration workshops connecting MSMEs with PSUs, large corporations, and government procurement opportunities.
RAMP offers awareness workshops on trade receivables discounting, invoice financing, and liquidity enhancement programs through TReDS platforms.
RAMP offers workshops on modern and sustainable packaging solutions with comprehensive branding support.
RAMP offers workshops for Zero Defect Zero Effect (ZED) certification support, quality management systems, and international standard compliance assistance.
RAMP offers workshops for Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) awareness, patent filing support, and innovation protection strategies.
RAMP targets 2,600 Udyam Registrations by 2027.
RAMP targets 2,184 Entrepreneurship & Skill Development Programs by 2027.
RAMP targets 1,200 Business Service Providers Empanelment by 2027.
RAMP targets 10 Reverse Buyer Seller Meets by 2027.
RAMP targets 91 Vendor Development Programs by 2027.
RAMP targets 364 TReDS Awareness Workshops by 2027.
RAMP targets 104 Modern & Green Packaging Workshops by 2027.
RAMP targets 32,760 ZED Certifications by 2027.
RAMP targets 182 IPR Awareness Workshops by 2027.
The RAMP State Nodal Agency is the Andhra Pradesh MSME Development Corporation.
The Dairy Venture Capital Fund is a scheme under NABARD.
The Dairy Venture Capital Fund is a credit component.
The Dairy Venture Capital Fund is available to individuals.
The Dairy Venture Capital Fund offers 50% of the outlay as an interest-free loan.
The scheme is named Pashmina Wool Development.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the Pashmina Wool Development scheme is the Ministry of Textiles.
The component of the Pashmina Wool Development scheme is Infrastructure.
The applicant for the Pashmina Wool Development scheme is Pashmina wool growers in the project area.
The Pashmina Wool Development scheme provides/exchanges Pashmina bucks, sheltering, pasturing, fodder, and combing, de-hairing, shearing, and training.
The link for details on the Pashmina Wool Development scheme is http://woolboard.nic.in/download/I.B.pdf.
The scheme is named Scheme of Information, Education and Communication.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the Scheme of Information, Education and Communication is the Ministry of MSME.
The component of the Scheme of Information, Education and Communication is IEC.
The sub-component of the Scheme of Information, Education and Communication is Finance.
The applicant for the Scheme of Information, Education and Communication is implemented by the Media Cell of the Ministry of MSME.

General Financial Rules (GFRs) would be followed while dealing with matters involving public finances in respect of activities to be undertaken in para 5 of the guidelines for the Scheme of Information, Education and Communication.
The link for details on the Scheme of Information, Education and Communication is https://msme.gov.in/sites/default/files/guidelines.pdf.
The scheme is for the Implementation of HACCP/ISO Standards/Food Safety/Quality Management Systems.
The Ministry/Department responsible is the Ministry of Food Processing Industries.
The scheme name is Implementation of HACCP/ISO Standards/Food Safety/Quality Management Systems.
The component of the scheme is Technical Infrastructure.
The sub-component of the scheme is Finance Subsidy.
The applicants for this scheme can be Central/State Government Organizations, IITs, Universities, and the private sector in the food processing sectors.
Assistance is provided as grant-in-aid in the form of reimbursement of expenditure towards the implementation of HACCP/ISO Standards/Food safety/Quality Management Systems.
The reimbursement is at 50% of the eligible project cost.
The maximum assistance is Rs. 17 lakhs.
The Ministry is not accepting fresh applications as a temporary measure to clear pending proposals.
The link for details is https://mofpi.nic.in/Schemes/food-safety-qualityassuranceinfrastructure/implementation-haccp-iso-22000-iso9000-ghp-gmp-etc.
The scheme is SIDBI-Loan for Purchase of equipment for enterprise's Development Plus (SPEED PLUS).
The Ministry/Department responsible is SIDBI.
The scheme name is SIDBI-Loan for Purchase of equipment for enterprise's Development Plus (SPEED PLUS).
The component of the scheme is Credit.
The sub-component of the scheme is Machinery purchased from identified OEMs.
Applicants must be MSME units with at least 5 years of operations and stable sales and cash profits in the immediate past 3 years.
Applicants must have a minimum net sales of Rs. 5 crore and no operating loss in the immediate past two years.

Eligible expenditure includes machinery purchased from identified OEMs manufacturing high-end machines or authorized dealers/Indian subsidiaries of such foreign OEMs with whom SIDBI has entered into an MoU.
The proposed machinery should relate to the same line of business.
Second-hand/refurbished machines are not eligible.
Assistance is up to 100% of the machinery cost.
The maximum assistance for new SIDBI customers is Rs. 2 crore (based on 20% - 30% FD).
The maximum assistance for existing SIDBI customers is Rs. 3 crore (based on 15% - 30% FD).
The tenure for the loan is 2 to 5 years, including a moratorium of 3-6 months.
The link for details is https://sidbi.in/en/products.

The Production Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme is for the promotion of domestic manufacturing of critical Key Starting Materials (KSMs)/Drug Intermediates (DIs) and Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs) in India.
The Ministry/Department responsible for the PLI Scheme is the Ministry of Chemicals & Fertilizers (Department of Pharmaceuticals).

The Scheme Name is the Production Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme for promotion of domestic manufacturing of critical Key Starting Materials (KSMs)/Drug Intermediates (DIs) and Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs) In India.
The Component of the PLI Scheme is Finance.
The Sub Component of the PLI Scheme is Finance Incentives.
Applicants for the PLI Scheme are Manufacturers of critical KSMs/DIs and APIs registered in India, subject to threshold investment in green field projects.
The tenure of the PLI Scheme is from FY 2020-21 to FY 2029-30.
For fermentation-based products under the PLI Scheme, the incentive for FY 2023-24 to FY 2026-27 is 20%.
For fermentation-based products under the PLI Scheme, the incentive for FY 2027-28 is 15%.
For fermentation-based products under the PLI Scheme, the incentive for FY 2028-29 is 5%.
For chemical synthesis based products under the PLI Scheme, the incentive for FY 2022-23 to FY 2027-28 is 10%.

The section is titled 'Reverse Buyers Sellers Meet'.
The section is titled 'About Program'.
The Reverse Buyer Seller Meet (RBSM) is a key initiative to promote international trade.
The RBSM facilitates global market access for India's Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs).
RBSM is a dynamic platform where selected global buyers are invited to directly engage with Indian MSMEs.
RBSMs allow for meaningful business interactions.
RBSMs allow for product demonstrations.
RBSMs allow for on-the-spot negotiations.
RBSMs remove intermediaries.
RBSMs offer MSMEs an opportunity to present their offerings first hand.
RBSMs help MSMEs understand international buyer expectations.
RBSMs help MSMEs secure export orders.
Unregistered MSMEs can attend.
New Entrepreneurs can attend.
SHGs can attend.
MSMEs engaged in manufacturing or value-added services across various sectors can attend.
Export Oriented MSMEs can attend.
Industry Clusters and Associations can attend.
Technology Enabled MSMEs can attend.
Agro-based and Handicraft Units can attend.
Women Entrepreneurs & Startups can attend.
The section is titled 'Why to attend?'.
Reverse Buyer-Seller Meets (RBSMs) play a crucial role in promoting trade and business partnerships between MSMEs and international buyers.
RBSMs provide a platform for MSMEs to showcase their products and services to foreign buyers.
This exposure helps MSMEs access new markets.
This exposure helps MSMEs expand their customer base beyond national borders.
RBSMs facilitate one-on-one meetings between exporters and foreign buyers.
These interactions allow both parties to discuss business prospects.
These interactions allow both parties to negotiate deals.
These interactions allow both parties to establish long-term relationships.
Foreign buyers can assess the quality, standards, and manufacturing processes of MSMEs firsthand.
This helps build trust and confidence in the products they intend to source.
RBSMs reduce the cost and effort involved in identifying reliable suppliers.
Foreign buyers can meet multiple exporters in one location instead of traveling to different countries.

The Andhra Pradesh Tourism Policy 2020-2025 aims to develop tourism in Andhra Pradesh and position it as a preferred tourist destination.
The policy is valid from the date of issue until March 31, 2025.
The policy replaces the earlier Tourism Policy of 2015-2020.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh is committed to the socio-economic development of the state and views the tourism sector as a key growth engine.
The government intends to build world-class luxury resorts and tourism infrastructure, attract investments, develop unique products, and position Andhra Pradesh as a preferred tourism destination.
The policy was approved after considering suggestions from various stakeholders and detailed consultations.
All concerned departments are required to take appropriate action to implement the provisions of the Andhra Pradesh Tourism Policy 2020-25.

Andhra Pradesh has a long coastline (974 kilometers), rich cultural heritage, historical religious places, serene valleys and hills, forts, national parks, bird sanctuaries, and caves, indicating vast tourism potential.
The tourism industry contributed approximately 6.8% to India's GDP in 2019 and created about 3.98 crore jobs (8% of the Indian workforce).
The tourism industry adds over $30 billion annually to India's Forex reserves, representing 5.6% of total exports.
Andhra Pradesh's domestic tourist footfall increased from 93 million in 2014 to 237 million in 2019.
Tirupati is the most visited place in Andhra Pradesh by domestic tourists, attracting over 36 million tourists annually.
Andhra Pradesh has received multiple awards for comprehensive tourism development.
The policy emphasizes the engagement of local communities, industry stakeholders, and government departments for effective implementation.

Abbreviations used in the policy include ADP (Annual Development Premium), ALR (Annual Lease Rent), APTA (Andhra Pradesh Tourism Authority), APSSDC (Andhra Pradesh State Skill Development Corporation), COD (Commercial Operations Date), DOT (Department of Tourism), EoDB (Ease of Doing Business), GoAP (Government of Andhra Pradesh), GoI (Government of India), MoT (Ministry of Tourism, Government of India), NIDHI (National Integrated Database of Hospitality Industry), NSDC (National Skill Development Council), PRASAD (Pilgrimage Rejuvenation and Spirituality Augmentation Drive), PPP (Public Private Partnership), SAATHI (System for Assessment Awareness and Training for Hospitality Industry), SRO (Sub Registrar Office), UNWTO (United Nations World Tourism Organization), and WTTC (World Travel & Tourism Council).

The vision of the policy is to sustainably develop tourism in Andhra Pradesh and position it as a preferred tourist destination by developing luxury resorts and providing world-class tourism products and experiences.

Objectives of the policy include developing high-end luxury resorts, attracting private investments and entrepreneurship, positioning the state as a preferred tourism destination, creating an environment for co-creation of tourism products, fostering skill development, providing quality tourist experiences, and promoting responsible tourism practices.
The policy is applicable to tourism units registered and commenced construction during the 2015-2020 policy period and achieving COD within the new policy period.
The policy is also applicable to new tourism units applying for registration and commencing construction within the policy period.
This policy supersedes any previous GO/Circular that contradicts its provisions.

Strategic interventions include offering attractive incentives and land parcels, incentivizing private investments and PPP projects, facilitating Ease of Doing Business (EoDB), effective marketing, theme-based development, skill development, and infrastructure development.

Thrust areas include investor outreach, industry linkages, development of specific tourism themes (Buddhist, Adventure, Eco, Rural), prioritizing theme parks, and improving inter-departmental coordination.

The policy acknowledges the impact of COVID-19 and incorporates emerging trends such as safety and security, virtual tours, digital marketing, weekend getaways, preference for personal transport, and increased awareness of responsible and nature-based travel.
APTA will work with industry bodies to ensure compliance with safety guidelines and encourage SAATHI certification.
APTA will create virtual tours and short videos for tourist destinations and prioritize digital marketing.
APTA will promote road trips and weekend getaways and create tourism circuits for short trips.
APTA will improve tourism signage and facilitate self-drive rental companies.
APTA will encourage responsible tourism practices and has identified Rural, Eco, Buddhist, and Adventure Tourism as thrust areas.
Field officers are a critical source of information for tourism development planning.
APTA will collaborate with hospitality institutes, experts, and industry associations to track key indicators and plan initiatives.
APTA will utilize the registration portal to collect anonymous tourist statistics for planning and strategy.
Rural Tourism development will focus on promoting Arts and Crafts, integrating them with tourism activities, and establishing experience centers.
Agri Tourism/Farmstays will be encouraged by promoting farm owners to construct accommodation for tourists, listing them on digital channels, and providing training to helpers/guides.
Heritage Tourism will involve modernization and renovation of historical monuments, exploring the conversion of heritage buildings into accommodation, and conducting heritage walks/tours.
Action plans for Heritage Tourism include promoting heritage walks, hotels, and cultural tourism, developing museums with modern technology, and conserving monuments.
Buddhist Tourism development will focus on promoting circuits, operating tour packages, and promoting sites in key international markets.
Action plans for Buddhist Tourism include popularizing its historical significance and developing special circuits.
Eco Tourism development will focus on low-impact experiences with high community involvement, emphasizing responsible tourism.
Activities for Eco Tourism include creating trekking routes, promoting cycling, facilitating wildlife safaris with local entrepreneurship, and setting up nature camps.
Action plans for Eco Tourism include developing nature trails, basic tourism infrastructure, and a state-level body for Eco Tourism development.

Beach and Water Based Tourism will be developed by facilitating water sports, developing boating and cruise infrastructure, identifying locations for water villas, and encouraging beach shacks through a transparent bidding process.
Action plans for Beach and Water Based Tourism include developing beach strips as water sports hubs and increasing blue flag certified beaches.
Adventure and Recreation Tourism will be facilitated by encouraging adventure sports operators and attracting investment from global players in amusement and theme parks.
Action plans for Adventure and Recreation Tourism include fast-tracking proposed projects and initiating concept studies.
Religious Tourism will be promoted through documentation, creation of tour packages, and roadshows.
Action plans for Religious Tourism include nation-wide outreach for developed sites and prioritizing intra-state outreach for upcoming sites.
Cuisine Tourism will focus on developing tourist circuits showcasing unique cuisine, organizing food festivals, and collaborating with the Coffee Board of India for coffee tourism.
Action plans for Cuisine Tourism include community participation, collaboration with operators for packages and festivals, and national expansion.
Wellness Tourism will be promoted by encouraging the development of spiritual ashrams and wellness centers, leveraging Ayurveda, Siddha, and other wellness practices.
Action plans for Wellness Tourism include encouraging the development of Spiritual Centres/Ashrams and promoting quality spa and wellness centers.

MICE Tourism will be developed by creating an ecosystem with convention centers, quality hotels, and attractions beyond business purposes, supported by major convention centers and stakeholder partnerships.
Action plans for MICE Tourism include identifying new MICE hubs, collaborating with star-hotels for mega-MICE projects, and engaging with associated stakeholders.
Medical Tourism aims to develop key zones as Medical Hubs for economical treatment, strengthening the ecosystem for hassle-free living and treatment.
Action plans for Medical Tourism include developing Healthcare Hubs as Medical SEZs, connecting with the NRI doctor community, and developing a medical tourist ecosystem.
Quality tourism infrastructure, including hospitality and connectivity, is crucial for destination development.
The majority of tourism infrastructure projects are expected to be driven by private sector investment, with a smaller proportion through PPP and direct government investment.
Hospitality infrastructure is well-developed, with the government-run AP Tourism Development Corporation operating hotels and resorts.
Priority tourist destinations have been selected for hotel and resort development, with attractive incentives and land policies.
Wayside Amenities will be developed on major highways connecting tourist locations under PPP mode or private investment.
Homestays are an integral part of hospitality infrastructure, providing alternate income and authentic local experiences.
APTA will facilitate the development and operation of homestays, promoting them through marketing initiatives and offering sensitization and skill development workshops.
APTA has identified land parcels for tourism infrastructure development, which will be available online.
Last mile connectivity will be developed for tourist locations, especially in hills and forests.
Basic amenities like washrooms, changing rooms, and drinking water will be provided at identified tourist destinations.
APTA will explore comprehensive destination development through Special Tourism Zones (STZs).
The Department of Tourism will actively pursue central government schemes like Swadesh Darshan and PRASAD.
GoAP will explore funding for tourism infrastructure development through multilateral agencies like the World Bank and Asian Development Bank.
APTA has established a mechanism for registration of all tourism trade stakeholders.
APTA will collaborate with industry players to facilitate industry linkages and promote SAATHI and NIDHI certification.
GoAP will implement a quality framework to standardize tourism products and services.
Skills and service are key drivers of tourist experience, necessitating a skilled workforce.
The tourism sector in Andhra Pradesh is estimated to require over 1 million skilled manpower by 2022.
GoAP aims to cultivate a pool of trained world-class manpower for the tourism industry in coordination with APSSDC and leading institutes.
Initiatives will be undertaken to meet the demand for skilled manpower and raise awareness about tourism and customer service.
Developing dedicated Tourism Universities/Hotel Management institutes is necessary for formalizing tourism education and skill development.
Activity-based training modules will be developed for various stakeholders, including taxi drivers, hotel staff, guides, and tour operators.
State guide licenses will be issued, and training completion certificates will be encouraged.
Internship opportunities will be explored to enable experience building.
The policy aims to promote sustainable and responsible tourism.
Responsible waste management, including reduction, disposal, and recycling, will be emphasized.
APTA will collaborate with various organizations to sensitize communities on waste management.
Tourist destinations will be declared plastic-free zones.
Destination development plans will be created for major tourist destinations, considering carrying capacity, access, and infrastructure.
Involvement of host communities in destination planning and development will be prioritized.
Accessible tourism for persons with disabilities and reduced mobility will be encouraged through technology, sensitization, and infrastructure development.
Sensitization campaigns will be implemented for the safety and security of tourists, including women and children.
COVID, health, and hygiene-related sensitization workshops will be conducted for tourism industry stakeholders.
An omni-channel marketing strategy will be employed to attract tourists.
APTA will encourage partnerships between state tour operators and operators in key source markets.
APTA will partner with tourism and related departments of other states.
APTA will establish industry linkages through webinars, roadshows, and partnerships with industry bodies.
Iconic tourism destinations will be promoted through mass media and on-ground campaigns.
Brand campaigns will leverage the unique natural and socio-cultural elements of the state.
APTA will create and utilize digital assets for customized digital marketing campaigns.
Interactive digital content, including virtual tours, AR, and VR applications, will be developed.
Familiarization trips for influencers will be explored for promotion.
APTA will engage tourists actively to capture their perspectives and experiences.
Initiatives like gamification, interactive forums, and democratizing content creation will be explored.
Tourism projects are classified into Micro, Small, Medium, Large, and Mega categories based on investment and turnover.
To be eligible for incentives, projects must comply with policy clauses and minimum requirements.
Mega Tourism projects and 5-star and above projects will be accorded 'Industry' status.
GoAP will waive 100% of Land Use Conversion charges if conversion is permitted.
100% reimbursement of stamp duty and transfer duty on land purchase and lease/mortgages will be provided for new tourism units.
100% reimbursement of net SGST accrued to the state for new tourism units for five years or until 100% of fixed capital investment is realized.
Electricity charges for new tourism projects will be reimbursed at Rs. 2.00 per unit for five years from COD.
Government land allotment procedures for tourism projects are detailed.
Land allotment can be done for Hotels, Resorts, MICE Centres, Wayside amenities, Amusement Parks, Golf Courses, etc., with specified maximum land extents.
The lease tenure for most projects is up to 33 years plus a 3-year construction period.
The lease tenure for Mega Tourism Projects/5-Star and above hotels is up to 90 years plus a 4-year construction period.
Project objectives (Minimum Development Obligations) and quality goals (Minimum Service Obligations) will be defined.
Land will be allotted through a competitive and transparent bidding process for most projects.
For Large Projects, Mega Tourism Projects/5-Star and above projects, land will be allotted through the SIPB route.
Land allotment can be on lease rent basis, lease rent and revenue sharing basis (ADP), or freehold basis.
For lease rent basis, the bidding parameter is Annual Lease Rent (ALR), with an upset price of 1% of the SRO value.
For lease rent and revenue sharing basis, the fixed lease rent is 1% of SRO value, and the bidding parameter is Additional Development Premium (ADP).
The lease payment begins from the date of land handover.
Annual Lease Rent (ALR) and/or Additional Development Premium (ADP) will be enhanced by 5% every three years.
Lease payments are payable in advance on a quarterly basis.
Optional deferment periods of two years or the period of achieving Commercial Operations (whichever is earlier) may be allowed.
Bidders must demonstrate Technical and Financial Capabilities.
For Mega Projects/5 Star/7 Star projects, consortium members must have experience operating such facilities.
A bidder can participate as a sole bidder or in a consortium (max 3 members for Mega/5-star projects, max 2 for others).
Bid Security is 1% of the estimated project cost.
Performance Security is a Bank Guarantee for 2.50% of the estimated project cost.
Project Development Fee is a non-refundable DD for 1.00% of the estimated project cost, capped at Rs. 50 Lakhs.
A Bank Guarantee equal to one year's ALR and ADP is required upon site handover.
Bids are evaluated first for technical and financial eligibility, then financial proposals are opened.
Tie-breaking procedures include best and final offers, technical scores, and draw of lots.
The land lease deed is conditional upon meeting implementation milestones, Minimum Development Obligations, and maintaining Minimum Service Obligations.
Leased land must be used only for the purpose for which it was leased.
Non-compliance can lead to cancellation of the conditional land lease.
Consequences of cancellation include resumption of land and assets, no compensation to the developer, and invocation of the Performance Bank Guarantee.
Leased land cannot be alienated, transferred, sub-leased, sold, or mortgaged without government consent.
The lock-in period is two years post Commercial Date of Operations (COD).
For Mega Tourism Projects/5 Star and above projects, additional incentives may be given on a case-by-case basis.
Land may be allotted directly on leasehold or freehold basis for Mega Tourism Projects/5 Star and above projects.
Other PPP models like Joint Venture, Developer-Brand Operator, and Deferred Annuity can be adopted for Mega Tourism Projects/5 Star and above projects.
A Special Purpose Company (SPC) may be created for development of luxury hotels, resorts, STZs, and tourism infrastructure.
A Detailed Project Report (DPR) is required for Mega Tourism Projects/5 Star and above projects, which will be evaluated by an Evaluation Committee and processed through SIPB to the Cabinet.
The Government aims to facilitate a conducive environment for tourism investments through timely clearances and responsive post-investment facilitation.
Institutional arrangements are in place to secure accelerated tourism development.
The State Investment Promotion Board (SIPB) processes bids for PPP projects and proposals for Mega/Unique Tourism Projects.
APTA will act as the Nodal Agency and establish an 'Investment Facilitation Cell' as a 'Single Desk Bureau' to assist investors.
The Single Desk system in the Industries Department will be leveraged for timely approvals.
A 'New Tourism Unit' is defined as a new Tourism Infrastructure Project or Service commenced within the policy period.
Total Project Cost includes land, building, plant and machinery, infrastructure facilities, vehicles, installation charges, technical know-how, and movable/immovable equipment.
Ineligible investments include working capital, goodwill, second-hand machinery, capitalized interest, consumables, assets with a lifespan less than five years, and know-how fees to sister concerns.
Date of Commercial Operations (COD) is the date the Tourism Unit is open to tourists on a commercial basis.

Eligible Tourism Infrastructure Projects include Hotels (min 3-star), Resorts, Water villas, Heritage Hotels, Amusement Parks, Theme Parks, MICE Centres, Golf Courses, Botanical gardens, Urban/Rural Haats, Tourism & Hospitality Training Institutes, Wayside amenities, Spiritual/Wellness Centers, Museums, Arts/crafts/culture centers, Farm stays/Agri-tourism, Homestays, and Service apartments.

Eligible Tourism Services Projects include Beach side Shacks, Water sports, Water Ride/Sailing facilities, Sea/River Cruises, Adventure Services, Ropeways, Heli-Tourism, Aero sports, Farm (Agri) tourism, Rural Tourism Services, Heritage Walks, Caravan Tourism, Inbound Tour Operators/Travel Agents, Cab services/Car hire services, Food courts/Restaurants at tourist destinations, Rest rooms, Cloak rooms, Parking facilities, Souvenir Shops, and Light & Sound/Laser Shows.
The Strategic Investment Plan was submitted by Andhra Pradesh by the first due date of August 15, 2023.
The Ministry of MSME facilitated several meetings for the SIP Evaluation.
The RAMP Programme Committee (RPC), headed by the Secretary (MoMSME), approved the recommendations of the SIPEC, including the funding quantum, in its meeting on November 10th.
In its 4th meeting on August 2, 2023, the RPC recommended incentivizing something.
A list of selected project proposals from Andhra Pradesh, along with the recommended funding quantum, is annexed.
The RPC also recommended that 50% of the total approved amount for part-financing be released.
Subsequent tranches of Grant-in-Aid will be released only after 75% of the first tranche is utilized and at least 50% of the project targets are achieved.
The fund flow arrangement will follow the guidelines issued by the Department of Expenditure, Ministry of Finance on March 9, 2023, and subsequent orders.
The Ministry of MSME will release Grant-in-Aid to the Central Nodal Agency (CTR Ludhiana).
CTR Ludhiana will set drawing limits for the States as per the Sanction Order issued by the Ministry.
States will draw on a real-time basis from the CNA of the RAMP scheme when making payments to vendors, beneficiaries, etc.
The available drawing limit will decrease with utilization.
As per the Department of Expenditure OM dated March 27, 2023, CNA limits will be frozen on March 31, 2023, at 12:00 midnight.
Limits remaining with the States will be made zero on March 31, 2023, at 12:00 midnight.
The Ministry will allocate fresh limits for the next financial year.
The RAMP Programme Implementation Manual (PIM) was circulated to all participating States during the signing of the Letter of Undertaking (LoU).
States are required to prepare an Implementation Plan for selected project proposals being part-funded under RAMP.
The Implementation Plan for each selected proposal must contain specific elements.
An M&E framework for each selected proposal is to be drawn up.
The M&E framework should contain the baseline figure for each identified indicator and the data source.
Every State should have a State Programme Implementation Unit (SPIU) in place within the State Industries/MSME Department, with procurement done as per GFR 2017.
Funds of Rs. 5 Crore already provided for SIP preparation should be utilized for the SPIU.
Additional funds for SPIU will be considered only after the utilization of the Rs. 5 Cr already sanctioned.
The SPIU will be responsible for the implementation, monitoring, and evaluation of selected projects.
The SPIU shall coordinate with the NPMU in the Ministry for any assistance.
The State should draw and submit an Outreach plan for the identification and mobilization of MSMEs.
The total Grant-in-Aid to the State includes an amount equivalent to something.
States are required to obtain approval from the Ministry before launching any branding campaign.
Any unspent balance in the Zero Balance Sub Agency account as of March 31st of every year will revert to the Central Nodal Agency (CTR Ludhiana) account, along with accrued interest.
States shall provide DLI-wise M&E data to the Ministry on a monthly basis, disaggregated by SC/ST/Women/PwD.
States shall provide implementation status of part-funded projects on a monthly basis.
States shall provide semi-annual and annual reports.
States shall submit Utilization Certificates of funds utilized every six months.
States shall submit Financial reports and Contract management reports at the end of every six months (July 31st and January 31st).
If States do not submit these reports by the due date, further funds will not be released (para 8.3.5(e) of PIM).
State Governments must conduct internal audits for financial management and procurement transactions as laid out in the PIM (para 8.5 to 8.6 in PIM).
State Governments/SPIU/Implementing Agencies shall submit a compliance report to the Ministry on audit observations from the internal audit.
The financial audit of SPIU and participating public and private sector Implementing Agencies will be conducted by their statutory auditors.
The audit report should be submitted to the Ministry within 9 months of the end of each financial year, i.e., by January 31st of the subsequent year (Para 8.6(9) of PIM).

If the SPIU and participating public/private Implementing Agencies have a 'disclaimer or adverse' audit opinion or fail to submit audit reports on time, further grants will not be released to such States (para 8.6(h) of PIM).
SPIU and participating public/private Implementing Agencies shall submit a compliance report to the Ministry on the financial audit observations within 3 months from the date of the audit report.

All funds released to the States will be subject to the World Bank's 'Guidelines on Preventing and Combating Fraud and Corruption in Programmes for Results Financing' dated February 1, 2012, and revised on July 10, 2015.
If any condition is left out in this communication, the provisions laid out in the Programme Implementation Manual will be applicable.
States may take immediate action to complete preliminary steps and start project implementation at the earliest.
Implementation Plans and M&E frameworks may be communicated to the Ministry in time.
The National NPMU may be contacted for further assistance/information.
The SIPEC recommended, and RPC approved, benchmarking of costs for activities included in existing Ministry schemes.
For Awareness Programmes part-funded under RAMP, rates approved under the Awareness Programmes component of MSME Champions schemes will be followed.
The funds for Awareness Programmes are capped at Rs. 70,000 per one-day workshop.
States should ensure maximum participation in Awareness Programmes.
Wherever possible, awareness programmes on different subjects may be clubbed.
Payment of Honorarium to guest faculty for Awareness Programmes will be as per FR/SR.
States are required to report disaggregated information on the number of MSMEs benefited from Awareness Programmes, especially SC/ST/Women/PwD.
For Entrepreneurship Development Programmes (EDPs), the ESDP Guidelines of the O/o DCMSME will be followed.
The ceiling for one EDP/ESDP of 4-6 weeks duration is Rs. 1.25 lakhs per programme, irrespective of the city class.
Subjects relevant to the RAMP proposals approved in the State may be selected for EDPs.
Intake capacity for EDPs may be 25-30 participants per programme.
For less than 25 participants in an EDP, the expenditure will be restricted on a pro-rata basis (Rs 2500/- per participant).
Payment of Honorarium to guest faculty for EDPs will be as per extant FR/SR.
States are required to report disaggregated information on the number of MSMEs benefited from EDPs, especially SC/ST/Women/PwD.
For Training of MSME Department / DIC officials, the guidelines for training of officers of DCMSME will be followed.
A rate of Rs 4000 per participant is fixed for training of MSME Department/DIC officials.
This rate covers expenditure towards coordination, inauguration, valedictory sessions, honorarium to guest speakers, stationery, lunch, tea & refreshments, field visits, and training kit.
TA/DA for training of MSME Department/DIC officials will be borne by the concerned State Govt.
For Skill Development/Training of MSME, the guidelines for ESDP training in the O/o DCMSME will be followed.
A ceiling of Rs. 2500 /MSME /day is fixed for Skill Development/Training of MSME.
For Vendor / Business Development Programmes, the guidelines of the Procurement and Marketing Scheme of the Ministry will be followed.
A ceiling of up to Rs. 5 lakhs per VDP / BDP has been considered for a two-day Vendor/ Business Development programme.
This ceiling includes a two-day exhibition of MSME products/PSE products.
Only Awareness Programmes on components of MSME Champions Scheme (ZED, ILEAN, Innovative) are covered under MSME Champions Scheme.
SIPEC recommended that proposals received from States for interventions related to Guarantees for MSEs be compiled and wait-listed.
The RPC approved the recommendation to wait-list proposals for Guarantees for MSEs.
Depending on fund availability, wait-listed proposals for Guarantees for MSEs will be considered at a later stage.
This Ministry is organizing Regional TReDS workshops, hence States that proposed TReDS related Workshops/Awareness Programmes were not considered for funding.
Proposals which are leveraging existing schemes were considered.
The Committee appreciated initiatives proposed by States related to greening, online dispute resolution, and online marketing.

However, as these are covered under existing Ministry schemes like MSME GIFT, MSME-SPICE, Scheme for Online Dispute Resolution for Delayed Payments, and MSME-WOMEN, they were not considered for separate funding from the RAMP Budget.
Due to overlap, these proposals have not been considered for part funding under RAMP.
An amount of 5% of the overall approved support from the RAMP budget for a State has been allocated for IEC (Information, Education, Communication).
States are required to take approval from the Ministry of MSME before launching any branding campaign.
Rs 5 Cr has already been disbursed to States/UTs towards SIP preparation.
This includes the cost of SIP preparation and the cost of establishing and maintaining a State Programme Implementation Unit (SPIU).
The resource cost for professional services for monitoring and evaluation of SIP-supported projects is to be supported under funds already allocated for the SPIU.
The Government of India is encouraging states to promote exports to meet the target of USD 400 Bn in merchandise exports.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh aims to give a holistic 'PUSH' to exports from the State.
The PUSH framework promotes value addition in exports, upgrades infrastructure and institutions, streamlines processes, and harnesses digital technology.
The State Investment Promotion Board approved the Andhra Pradesh Export Promotion (APEX) Policy 2022-27 on May 12, 2022.
The Andhra Pradesh Export Promotion (APEX) Policy 2022-27 aims to establish Andhra Pradesh as a leading export hub.

The policy focuses on developing world-class logistics and export infrastructure, promoting high-quality product portfolios, enabling robust export-oriented institutions, and creating integrated export ecosystems.
District export action plans with quantifiable targets have been prepared to promote districts as 'Export Hubs'.
A dedicated Export Facilitation Cell has been established in each District Industries Centre.
The Export Facilitation Cell is mandated to conduct workshops for capacity building and provide guidance to exporters.
The District Industrial and Export Promotion Committee (DIEPC) has been constituted under the Chairmanship of the District Collector.
The DIEPC is mandated to promote exports and implement action plans for identifying potential export products.
APTPC has been notified as the Dedicated State Export Facilitation Cell.
The State Export Facilitation Cell provides guidance and support services to manufacturer exporters throughout the project life cycle.
The State Export Promotion Committee is constituted under the Chairmanship of the Chief Secretary to Government.
The Commissioner of Industries is the Convenor of the State Export Promotion Committee.
The Regional Authority, DGFT, is the Co-Convenor of the State Export Promotion Committee.
The State Export Promotion Committee resolves issues related to export promotion, including customs and state clearances.
The Government proposes to develop enabling infrastructure for robust export-oriented infrastructure and integrated export ecosystems.
This includes development of Transport Infrastructure (Roadways, Railways, Airways, Port Infrastructure, Greenfield Fisheries Harbors, Inland Waterways).
Development of Multi Modal Logistic Parks is proposed.
Development of Warehousing Capacity is proposed.
Developing Cold Storage Chain is proposed.
Inland Container Depots are proposed.
Free Trade Warehousing Zones (FTWZ) are proposed.
Digital Interventions for access to information are proposed.
An exclusive Web-Portal will be put in place to provide access to export promotion information.
Creation of Labs for Quality Standards and Marketing support is proposed.
Training & Capacity Building of exporters is proposed.
Fiscal Incentives are proposed.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh proposes to extend incentives/facilities to increase private participation in export infrastructure development.
Subsidy for Reefer Vehicles: 25% investment subsidy on the cost of reefer vehicles, limited to INR 10 Lakhs per vehicle (max two vehicles per unit).
Subsidy on Certification Charges: Additional 10% subsidy over the Gol subsidy for MSMEs availing quality certification under ZED scheme.
Reimbursement of 50% certification cost (max INR 2 Lakh per unit per annum) for compulsory markings like CE, CCC, GMP, Phytosanitary certificates, GFSI recognized schemes.
An additional 5% subsidy will be extended to women, SC, ST, and other backward community-run MSME units for certification charges.
Participation in International Trade Fairs: 30% subsidy in Ground rent.
Awards & Recognition for Exporters: Major export awards will be instituted.
Establishing Corpus Fund for Marketing: A corpus fund of INR 10 Cr will be created for promotion of exporters and marketing.
The Director of Industries, C&EP, Mangalagiri is requested to take necessary action.
This order is issued with the concurrence of the Finance Department.
Andhra Pradesh has a 974 km long coastline with 14 notified non-major ports and one major port.
Andhra Pradesh contributes 5.8% of total Indian exports.
The State exported goods worth INR 1.24 lakh Cr (USD 16.9 Billion) in FY 2020-21.
Exports during 2021-22 (up to Nov 21) stood at USD 22.88 Billion, a 36% growth over the previous year.
Andhra Pradesh ranked ninth in the Export Preparedness Index 2021 by Niti Aayog.
AP ranked second, next to Gujarat, in the exports performance pillar.
The State has the fourth largest warehousing capacity (13.38 Lakh MT) and fifth largest cold storage capacity (15.67 Lakh MT).
Andhra Pradesh has 3 Inland Container Depots (ICDs) and 17 Container Freight Stations (CFSs).
The State has 5 Air Cargo Terminals and 283 Rail Road Goods Sheds.
Andhra Pradesh has been ranked as the best state in India for 'Ease of Doing Business' for three consecutive years.

The State focuses on Champion Sectors (Marine & Sea Food, Pharma & Formulations, Organic Chemicals, Iron & Steel, Ship, Boat & Floating Structures, Rice & Cereals, Spices & Coffee, Automobile & Components, Imitation Jewellery) and aspirational sectors (Ready-made Garments, Processed Stone, Processed Food, Electronic Components) for export diversification.
Challenges in export promotion include improvements in infrastructure, inadequate testing laboratories, fragmented institutional framework, transport connectivity, and access to finance.
The vision of the policy is to establish Andhra Pradesh as a leading export hub.
The objective is to achieve the top position in the country in export performance during the policy period.
The objective is to achieve exports of Rs. 3,50,000 Crores in 5 years.
The objective is to encourage value addition and export diversification while discouraging the export of basic commodities.
The strategy involves a 'PUSH' framework: Promotes value addition, Upgrades Infrastructure & Institutions, Streamlines processes, and Harnesses digital technology.
An exclusive Web-Portal will provide access to information related to export promotion at a single point.
The portal will include trade statistics, data bank of exports, updates on trade fairs, virtual showrooms, market intelligence, and more.
A mobile application called PLACE (Platform for Logistics and Cargo Effluence) will be developed to improve logistics efficiency.
The PLACE app will promote RAIL SUGAM and Freight Operation Information System (FOIS) applications.
The State's warehousing capacity will be augmented to 56 Lakh MT during the policy period.
Andhra Pradesh needs substantial expansion of cold storage infrastructure.
The State will promote more cold storage facilities through private participation and under the Central assistance on Mission for Integrated Development of Horticulture (MIDH) scheme.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh will set up 5 animal feed supply depots in coastal districts.
The State will develop a multimodal cold-chain network for perishable products.
The State will develop 9 Fishing harbors along with Sea Food Processing parks.
Government of India approved 2 Multi Model Logistics Parks (MMLP) to Andhra Pradesh under the Bharatmala Pariyojana Scheme.
Andhra Pradesh exchanged an MoU with NHLML for the development of MMLPs at Visakhapatnam and Ananthapur.
One more MMLP is proposed at YSR Kadapa District.
ICDs will be developed in PPP mode to facilitate freight aggregation.
Developing 4 more greenfield ports is planned to triple seaport traffic handling capacity.
The government will pursue increasing direct shipping lines to key countries like the US and Europe.
The average turn-around time of all non-major ports in Andhra Pradesh will be maintained at 1.4 days.
Development of Inland waterways is planned, utilizing 888 Km of national waterway network.
FTWZ are being promoted in the State in addition to the one operational in Sricity, Chittoor.
Marine clusters will act as knowledge hubs for marine sector activities.
Integrated Air Cargo Complex will be expanded and developed at Visakhapatnam airport.
GoAP will create a hub and spoke model connecting flights to International Airports in Visakhapatnam, YSR Kadapa, and Tirupati.
A detailed study on Road connectivity to remote locations will be conducted.
Additional stoppages for provisioning of truck lay-bys will be created.
Andhra Pradesh is pursuing the establishment of Centres of Excellence in thrust sectors with the Government of India.
The enabling infrastructure will be developed through private participation.
The Commissioner of Industries is the Implementing Agency of the Export Promotion Policy.
The AP Trade Promotion Corporation supports the Commissioner of Industries.
District export action plans have been prepared to promote districts as 'Export Hubs'.
A dedicated Export Facilitation Cell has been established in each District Industries Centre.
District Industrial and Export Promotion Committees (DIEPCs) have been constituted under the Chairmanship of the District Collector.
Sub-groups for each identified potential export product will be created, involving stakeholders.
Bottlenecks for exports and skill requirements will be identified.
Progress will be reviewed regularly in DIEPCs, co-chaired by a DGFT representative.
Issues requiring intervention of GoAP or Gol will be brought to the notice of the State Level Export Promotion Committee.
APTPC has been notified as the Dedicated State Export Facilitation Cell.
The State Export Promotion Committee is constituted under the Chairmanship of the Chief Secretary to Government.
In ICDs, office space will be provided for Participating Government Agencies (PGAs) for sample testing.
The State machinery will assist MPEDA in implementing the catch certificate.
Aquatic Quarantine Lab facilities will be established near Visakhapatnam and Kakinada Ports.
NABL accredited Quality Testing Labs/infrastructure will be strengthened.
Government will introduce 50 food safety on wheels (FSWs) to improve food testing infrastructure in remote areas.
Government will pursue with CDSCO to bring Drug Testing Labs in Andhra Pradesh.
Efforts will be made to train exporters on pre-export inspection and procedures.
Government of Andhra Pradesh will strive for the establishment of a WTO Cell.
GoAP will work through AP Trade Promotion Corporation (APTPC) for marketing support.
Brand Building for 'SVAYAM Andhra' will be undertaken.
'Produce to Export' Campaign will be run throughout the state.
GI tagging will be pursued for products unique to Andhra Pradesh.
Marketing agencies will be empanelled to assist with digital marketing campaigns.
Partnerships and MoUs will be formed with global trade organizations.
The department will work with DGFT in arranging funding for trade center development.
State EFC will train exporters on trade processes, quality standards, and policy incentives.
Institutions specific to International trade, such as IIFT and IIP, are being established.
Training-cum-Guidance Centres in Export Promotion will be established in each district.
Andhra Pradesh State Council of Higher Education/Universities/Intermediate Education will consider introducing Foreign Trade courses.
GoAP will provide incentives to promote exports in addition to the Industrial Development Policy 2020.
MSMEs with a valid Import Export Code (IEC) will be eligible for a 25% investment subsidy on reefer vehicles.
GoAP will give an additional 10% subsidy over the Gol subsidy for MSMEs availing quality certification under ZED scheme.
Reimbursement of 50% certification cost (max INR 2 Lakh per unit per annum) for compulsory markings.
An additional 5% subsidy will be extended to women, SC, ST, and other backward community-run MSME units for certification charges.
30% subsidy in Ground rent for participation in International Trade Fairs.
The state will create a corpus fund of INR 10 Cr for the promotion of exporters and marketing.
Major export awards will be instituted by the State Government in partnership with organizations like FIEO, FICCI, APEDA, MPEDA.
The detailed operating guidelines for the Policy shall be issued separately.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh (GoAP) has directed the Department of Industries to formulate a new Andhra Pradesh MSME & Entrepreneur Development Policy.
The aim of the new policy is to spur the growth of MSMEs in the State.
The policy aims to transform Andhra Pradesh into a competitive, inclusive, and preferred global manufacturing destination.
The policy aims to promote the AatmaNirbhar (Self-reliant) India vision by 2047.
The policy aims to foster a dynamic MSME ecosystem.
The policy aims to increase the competitiveness of the MSME sector in Andhra Pradesh.
The MSME sector is considered a growth engine contributing towards reducing regional imbalances, poverty alleviation, and assuring more equitable distribution of national income and wealth.
MSMEs account for 50 percent of global GDP, representing 90 percent of businesses and approximately 70 percent of employment globally.
Nationally, the MSME sector contributes significantly to the overall growth of the industrial economy.
The MSME sector contributes 30 percent to India's GDP.
The MSME sector contributes around 48 percent of total exports.
The MSME sector is a source of employment for around 110 million people, ranking second after the agriculture sector.
There are approximately 63.4 million MSME units in India.
MSMEs contribute about 33.4 percent of India's manufacturing output.
The Department of Industries conducted extensive consultation meetings with industrial associations, mega industries, and departments at district and state levels to solicit feedback for the policy.
The Department of Industries submitted a new Andhra Pradesh MSME & Entrepreneur Development Policy, 4.0 (2024-29).
The Finance Department has provided remarks regarding the policy.
The Finance Department suggested that the pay-out period of incentives may be rationalized.
The Finance Department suggested that Technology Upgradation incentive and Capital Subsidy should be mutually exclusive.
The Finance Department suggested that Total subsidy/incentive must be limited to 75% of FCI.
The Finance Department suggested that the Department may take an appropriate call regarding additional capital subsidy for women/SC-ST/specially abled entrepreneurs.
The Government has introduced the Andhra Pradesh MSME & Entrepreneur Development Policy, 4.0 (2024-29).
The policy aims to achieve the goal of 'One Entrepreneur, One Family' by 2030.
The detailed policy is appended at Annexure.
Incentives mentioned in the policy will be extended to eligible Industries as per operational guidelines to be notified separately.
The Director of Industries, Mangalagiri and the CEO, AP MSME Development Corporation, Vijayawada shall take necessary action for implementing operating guidelines for this Policy.
This order is issued with the remarks of the Finance (FMU-I&I, Energy and I&C) Department.
The policy is valid for 5 years from the date of notification or until a new policy is announced.
The policy may be amended and modified during implementation, with amendments applied prospectively.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh may extend the policy period as required.
The policy is applicable to the entire State.
The policy is applicable to new and existing enterprises investing and establishing new units.
The policy is applicable to existing enterprises investing in expansion of units.
The vision of the policy is to spur the growth of MSMEs in the state and transform Andhra Pradesh into a state with 'One Family One Entrepreneur' by 2030.

The guiding principles of the policy include a strong focus on formalizing MSMEs, aligning initiatives with national priorities, emphasizing product competitiveness, leveraging business support institutions, encouraging private sector participation, using technology and ESG for sustainable growth, facilitating convergence between stakeholders, and enhancing inclusion and diversity.

The policy targets include attracting INR 50,000 Crores in manufacturing investment from MSMEs, formalizing 22 lakh MSMEs, generating over 5 Lakh direct and indirect employment, doubling MSME exports to USD 12 Bn by 2029, facilitating integration of 500+ MSME Champions in Global Value Chains, setting up 5 sector-specific Centres of Excellence/Technology centres/extension centres, and setting aside a corpus of INR 500 Crores.
The policy envisages setting up of 'Ratan Tata Innovation Hubs' with a Central Unit at Amaravati and five linked hubs in zonal locations.
These hubs will foster innovation, entrepreneurship, and mentor startups.
The hubs will facilitate technology and skill upgradation in emerging sectors.
Each hub will be mentored by reputed business groups.
The hubs will promote research and value chain integration across 10 thrust sectors with export potential.
Support structures under the policy will be linked to these Innovation Hubs.
The Innovation Hubs will facilitate top-performing MSMEs to showcase 'Export Guides'.
MSMEs will be encouraged to create digital profiles.
The Ratan Tata Innovation Hubs will forge ties with national and international trade bodies, industrial associations, and testing & certification laboratories.
The hubs will support participation in international trade fairs.
The Innovation Hubs will provide analysis of major export markets and potential export-specific products.
The hubs will host a repository of Business Development Service (BDS) providers.

The policy has eight pillars: MSME Facilitation, Creation of Incubation and Acceleration Infrastructure and Supporting Mentorship, Enhance unit level competitiveness, Access to Finance, Sustainability & Circularity, Import Substitution / Export Promotion, Adopting cluster-based approach for infrastructure development, and Building Inclusive and Equitable MSME Ecosystem.
Pillar 1: MSME Facilitation aims to foster a favorable business environment by providing handholding and facilitation support.
A dedicated Chief Minister (CM) Udyami helpline shall be launched for MSMEs.
Entrepreneur Capability Centres (ECCs) will be set up in a hub and spoke model.
An Industry 4.0 Technology Centre will be established in Amravati in PPP mode.
Five sector-specific extension centres will be established, linked to the Industry 4.0 technology centre.
The Government will strengthen the MSE Facilitation Councils (MSEFCs) for speedy redressal of disputes.
An Online Dispute Redressal (ODR) mechanism is being designed.
The policy aims to ease regulatory compliances for new Micro Enterprises and startups through self-certification.
Capacity building will be implemented through the RAMP program, with over 7,000 workshops planned.
Business development service providers will be empanelled to provide MSMEs with access to resources and expertise.
Pillar 2: Creation of Incubation and Acceleration Infrastructure and Supporting Mentorship focuses on supporting startups.
A Virtual Incubation Platform will be created, integrating all MSME incubators in the state.
Mentorship Connect will onboard mentors to provide handholding support to startups.
Industry associations will be strengthened to be more responsive to MSME needs.
Incubation and Acceleration Programs will be initiated at major business incubators.
Thematic acceleration programs will be initiated at IIT Tirupathi and IIM Visakhapatnam.
MSMEs led by women and entrepreneurs from disadvantaged sections will receive preferential access to incubation programs.
Resources from corporates will be channelized towards incubators.
Rural Business Incubators (R-TBIs) will be developed in each district to nurture rural ideas.
Pillar 3: Enhance unit level competitiveness offers a comprehensive package for new/existing MSMEs.
Innovation Networks will support joint projects between industry associations/units and technical/R&D/academic institutions.
The AP Future Skills Connect Platform will be launched to develop a skilled workforce.
The state shall facilitate implementation of GoI's schemes for Employment and Skilling.
GoAP shall provide 100% assistance with respect to Employer contribution to EPF to medium units.
GoAP shall provide support for skill upgradation incentives to MSMEs.
Handholding support for E-commerce will be provided, including onboarding MSMEs on the ONDC platform.
Pillar 4: Access to Finance aims to ensure adequacy and availability of finance to MSMEs.
Government will direct all SPSUs and companies with a turnover of INR 250 Crores and above to get onboarded onto the TReDS platform.
The State Government will develop a framework with TReDS platform providers for increasing MSME onboarding.
The Andhra Pradesh Credit Guarantee Scheme will partner with CGTMSE by extending additional guarantee cover.
A corpus of INR 100 crore will be set aside with CGTMSE for the additional guarantee.
Focused measures will be taken to prevent incipient sickness and revive distressed/sick MSMEs.
Regular review meetings will be held by General Managers of DICs.
Interest rebate of 6% will be provided to identified/eligible sick units.
Deferment of CT arrears (purchase tax, sales tax, and interest) for 3 years will be provided.
Relief in Energy Charges will be provided for sick industrial units.
Digital lending platforms will be promoted for enhanced financial coverage to MSMEs.
Pillar 5: Sustainability & Circularity encourages MSMEs towards sustainable development.
An energy mapping exercise will be initiated to identify clusters with above-average energy consumption.
Support will be provided for energy/water audits and waste management.
A one-time reimbursement of 75% of water audit cost (capped at INR 1 lakh) will be provided to MSMEs.
A one-time reimbursement of 75% of energy audit cost (capped at INR 2 lakhs) will be provided to MSMEs.
25% of the cost incurred on approved equipment for implementing energy/water audit recommendations will be reimbursed.
Solutions provided by Start-ups for waste management, conservation, resource efficiency, and climate change will be preferred.
A cluster-based MSME rooftop solar program will be initiated.
Circular economy measures will be supported in MSME parks.
Pillar 6: Import Substitution / Export Promotion focuses on integrating MSMEs into the global value chain and adopting a targeted import substitution strategy.
The policy encourages MSMEs to leverage e-commerce exports opportunities.
Export-specific collaborations will be initiated with major export marketplaces.
Linkages with the ODOP scheme will be promoted for cross-border B2C e-commerce sales.
GoAP shall undertake a comprehensive assessment to identify products with potential for manufacturing in AP for import substitution.
The information on imported products will be made available for dissemination through GTIH.
Government will identify 500 MSME units from thrust sectors and develop them as 'Export Champions'.
Global conferences will be organized with leading brands, suppliers, and distributors.
Training programs and courses will be launched to equip MSMEs with skills on contemporary design, sustainable packaging, and global branding.
Government will incentivize MSMEs for upgrading production processes with a focus on resource efficiency and environmental sustainability.
100% reimbursement of charges incurred by MSMEs for acquiring certifications and consultancy will be supported.
Reverse buyer seller meets (RBSMs) will be organized to provide MSMEs a platform for targeting international buyers.
An automated tool will be created for matchmaking of MSMEs with prospective buyers.
Pillar 7: Adopting cluster-based approach for infrastructure development aims to propel and support infrastructure development through a cluster-based approach in a PPP mode.
Nano parks and MSME parks with plug and play infrastructure and shared facilities will be established in PPP mode.
These parks will be developed on a Public-PrivatePeople partnership model.
Government shall support the establishment of sector-specific Common Facility Centers (CFCs) and testing and certification labs in PPP mode.
Two dedicated anchor buyer led ancillary parks will be established.
MSME cluster mapping will be done on the PM Gati Shakti Portal.
A geo-tagged State MSME cluster map will be created.
A data-driven cluster competitiveness index will be developed.
Pillar 8: Building Inclusive and Equitable MSME Ecosystem aims to promote balanced industrial growth and development.
GoAP has stipulated an MSME Public Procurement policy, mandating 25% in public procurement from micro and small enterprises (MSEs) registered within the State.
Government shall issue orders allowing state entities to float separate tenders for exclusive procurement from MSMEs.
GoAP shall encourage the acceptance of insurance surety bonds in lieu of bank guarantees.
State entities will submit monthly reports to AP MSME Development Corporation confirming mandated procurement from MSMEs.
A minimum of 4% procurement from MSEs owned by disadvantaged groups (BC/SC/ST) and 3% from women-owned MSEs will be mandated within the total procurement from MSMEs.
A framework for state-led vendor development program will be established.
10% additional capital subsidy will be offered for women/BC/SC/ST/specially-abled/MSMEs having domicile in the state, undergoing expansion/diversification/new investment.
20% of the land/factories shall be reserved for women/BC/SC-ST/specially-abled/MSEs in MSME Industrial parks/flatted factory complexes.
Working women hostels and crÃ¨ches shall be established in collaboration with project promoters.
Medium enterprises will be offered a Business Development Credits (BDCs) to the extent of 2% of their growth in turnover for a 5-year period.
BDCs can be used for prescribed business development activities.
25% assistance for listing & raising money in SME stock exchange with a cap of INR 5L shall be provided to medium enterprises.
Medium enterprises with a track record of high performance will be given preference while identification of 500 Champion units.
To avail policy incentives, the entity should meet the definition of Micro Small and Medium Enterprises Development Act, 2006 and be registered with the Udyam portal.
Micro Enterprises: Investment in Plant and Machinery or Equipment does not exceed INR 1 crore and turnover does not exceed INR 5 crore.
Small Enterprises: Investment in Plant and Machinery or Equipment does not exceed INR 10 crore and turnover does not exceed INR 50 crore.
Medium Enterprises: Investment in Plant and Machinery or Equipment does not exceed INR 50 crore and turnover does not exceed INR 250 crore.

An entity will be considered a Startup if it is incorporated up to ten years from incorporation/registration, has a turnover not exceeding one hundred crore rupees in any financial year, and is working towards innovation, development, or improvement of products or processes or services, or has a scalable business model with high potential for employment generation or wealth creation.
Incentives are applicable only for enterprises involved in Manufacturing activity during the policy period.
The overall incentive MSME can claim shall not exceed 75% of FCI.
100% stamp duty and transfer duty paid by the industry on purchase of land meant for industrial use will be reimbursed.
100% stamp duty for lease of land/shed/buildings, mortgages and hypothecations will be reimbursed.
Stamp duty will be reimbursed only one time on the land.
100% fee charged for land conversion will be reimbursed.
Capital Subsidy for Micro Enterprises: 25% of FCI (Cap - INR 25 Lakh) on CoD/1st invoice in 2 equal annual installments.
Additional capital subsidy of 10% for women/BC/SC/ST/specially-abled entrepreneurs (max cap INR 7 Crore).
Capital Subsidy for Small Enterprises: 25% of FCI (Cap â INR 1.5 Crores) on CoD/1st invoice in 3 equal annual installments.
Capital Subsidy for Medium Enterprises: 25% of FCI (Cap â INR 7 Crores) on CoD/1st invoice in 4 equal annual installments.
Technology Upgradation Cost for Micro Enterprises: 20% of FCI, Capped at INR 20 Lakhs, in 2 equal annual installments.
Technology Upgradation Cost for Small Enterprises: 20% of FCI, Capped at INR 1 Crore, in 3 equal annual installments.
Technology Upgradation Cost for Medium Enterprises: 20% of FCI, capped at INR 5 Crore, in 5 equal annual installments.
Power Cost Reimbursement for Micro Enterprises: INR 1 per unit for 6 years from DCP, capped at INR 1 Lakh per annum.
Power Cost Reimbursement for Small Enterprises: INR 1 per unit for 6 years from DCP, capped at INR 5 Lakh per annum.
Power Cost Reimbursement for Medium Enterprises: INR 1 per unit for 6 years from DCP, capped at INR 15 Lakh per annum.
Net SGST Reimbursement for Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises: 100% for 6 years, with an annual cap of 5% of annual turnover.
Skill Upgradation Cost for Micro Enterprises: INR 5,000 per person for a maximum of 10 persons.
Skill Upgradation Cost for Small Enterprises: INR 10,000 per person for a maximum of 20 persons.
Skill Upgradation Cost for Medium Enterprises: 100% of Employer contribution to EPF, capped at INR 1 Lakh per annum, for 3 years.

Energy & Water Audit Cost for Micro Enterprises: 75% of Water audit cost (capped at INR 1 Lakh), 75% of energy audit cost (capped at INR 2 Lakhs), during policy period. 25% of cost of equipment (capped at INR 20 Lakhs).

Energy & Water Audit Cost for Small Enterprises: 75% of Water audit cost (capped at INR 1 Lakh), 75% of energy audit cost (capped at INR 2 Lakhs), during policy period. 25% of cost of equipment (capped at INR 40 Lakhs).

Energy & Water Audit Cost for Medium Enterprises: 75% of Water audit cost (capped at INR 1 Lakh), 75% of energy audit cost (capped at INR 2 Lakhs), during policy period. 25% of cost of equipment (capped at INR 50 Lakhs).
Local Procurement Subsidy for exporting units in select sectors: 1% of annual export turnover for 3 years, with overall cap of INR 15 Lakhs for Micro Enterprises.
Local Procurement Subsidy for exporting units in select sectors: 1% of annual export turnover for 3 years, with overall cap of INR 1.5 Crore for Small Enterprises.
Local Procurement Subsidy for exporting units in select sectors: 1% of annual export turnover for 3 years, with annual cap of INR 7 Crore for Medium Enterprises.
Quality Certification Cost Top Up: 100% cost for Micro Enterprises. Balance of GoI subsidy to cover 100% cost for Small and Medium Enterprises.
The Commissionerate of Industries serves as the overarching agency for implementing and monitoring the policy.
The Commissioner of Industries shall coordinate implementing GOI schemes such as PM Vishwakarma and RAMP program.
The Commissioner of Industries oversees regulatory approvals and manages financial incentives through the Andhra Pradesh Single Desk and Industries incentive Portals.
At the district level, District Industrial Officers (DIOs) shall facilitate and monitor policy implementation.
AP MSME Development Corporation (APMSMEDC) is the agency in charge of implementing schemes under the policy, Cluster Development Programme, RAMP program, and infrastructure development.
A State Level Empowered Committee under the Chairmanship of Secretary to Government, Industries and Commerce, GoAP will be constituted to monitor policy implementation.
The Committee will recommend mid-course corrections for smooth implementation of the Policy.
A Policy Implementation Cell headed by Commissioner/Director of Industries, Commerce and Export Promotion will assist the Committee.
A State Level Review and Monitoring Committee would be set up under the Chairmanship of Secretary to Government, Industries and Commerce, GoAP.
This Committee shall be the authority to interpret the policy measures, incentives & concessions.
Operating guidelines for this policy will be issued separately.
India's Logistics and supply chain costs currently amount to US$400 billion, up to 14% of the GDP, compared to the global average of 8%.
The Government of India formulated PM-Gatishakti, National Master Plan for providing Multi Modal connectivity.
States play a critical role in lowering overall logistics costs by establishing an enabling policy framework.
The State Investment Promotion Board approved the AP Logistics Policy 2022-27.
The Government has issued the 'Andhra Pradesh Logistics Policy 2022-27'.
The policy aims to address infrastructure gaps in logistics & supply chain in the State.
The policy aims to bring in transparency and accountability to improve logistics and bring private participation.
The policy aims to promote green, sustainable development.
The Government will prepare a State Logistic Plan duly mapping existing and upcoming logistical facilities.
Annual plans will be prepared based on the priority of projects.
An institutional set-up is proposed to be established to bring Stakeholder Departments under one umbrella for integration of logistic infrastructure and services.
An Empowered Group of Secretaries will be constituted under the Chairmanship of Chief Secretary.
A State Network Planning Group (NPG) will be set up with all the Head of the Stakeholder Departments as members.
A Technical Support Unit (TSU) with experts/officers from relevant departments will be established.
A State Logistic Cell (SLC) will be established in the Industries and Commerce Department.
City Logistic Cells (CLCs) will be established under State Logistics Cell and under the jurisdiction of MA&UD.
GoAP proposes to develop enabling infrastructure as per the State Master Plan.

Infrastructure projects include Transport Infrastructure (Roadways, Inland Waterways), Railways, Greenfield Fisheries Harbours, Development of Multi Modal Logistic Parks, Warehousing Capacity, Cold Storage Chain, Inland Container Depots, Free Trade Warehousing Zones (FTWZ), and Gas Distribution Network.
GoAP will streamline and simplify various laws and regulations and bring all approvals/clearances related to the logistic sector under EoDB.
Testing Facilities and Certifications will be created to reduce the time for sample testing.
A Command and Control Center (ICCC) will be set up integrating all IT applications.
AP Skill Development Corporation will identify required skill sets for the logistics sector and train the workforce.
Start-up Companies will be encouraged to drive overall innovation and efficiency in the logistic Sector.
5% of the area will be earmarked for development of logistic facilities in upcoming Industrial Parks/Hubs.
All clearances/Approvals will be provided through Single Desk.
The state accords the status of 'Industry' to the Logistics and Warehousing Sector.
100% Stamp duty reimbursement on land registration will be provided.
Re-imbursement of 75% of the amount spent on patent registration (limited to Rs 5 lakh for domestic and Rs 10 lakh for international patent) will be provided.
All other incentives as per IDP 2020-23 will be applicable.
Mega Projects with investment more than Rs.500 Crore or providing employment to more than 1000 people will be considered for tailor-made incentives.
NETRA provides an overview of technology maturity and readiness for integration.
NRDC collaborated with CSIR-NIScPR to establish the NETRA facility.
NETRA helps identify technological gaps, associated risks, and enabling factors for decision-making.
NETRA utilizes a Technology Readiness Level (TRL) scale from 1 to 9.
The TRL scale ranges from 'Basic Principles Observed' to 'Actual System Proven in Operational Environment'.
The document discusses Research, Development, and Deployment.
NETRA covers various technology sectors.
National Research Development Corporation (NRDC) is located at 20-22, Zamrudpur Community Centre, Kailash Colony Extension, New Delhi 110048.
NRDC's email is netra@nrdc.in.
NRDC's EPABX number is +91 11 29240401-07.
NRDC's website is www.nrdcindia.com.
