The document is a Detailed Project Report (DPR) for the establishment of a Common Facility Centre (CFC) for the Printing Cluster in Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh.
The project is submitted to the Office of the Development Commissioner (MSME), Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises, Government of India.
The project is supported by AP MSME Development Corporation and the Department of Industries and Commerce, Government of Andhra Pradesh.
The project is prepared by Intaglio Technical and Business Services.
The SPV (Special Purpose Vehicle) submitting the project is Veeranjaneya Printers and Tonners Association, located in Tirupati.
The Printing Cluster in Tirupati has 92 units employing over 500 people directly and nearly 3000 indirectly, with a turnover of Rs. 6440 Lakhs.

The primary objective of the CFC is to provide necessary technological interventions and crucial machinery to the cluster units to upgrade their production capabilities and overcome financial constraints.
The total project cost is estimated at Rupees 2519.26 Lakhs.

The funding for the project is proposed as: GoI Grant of Rupees 1763.48 Lakhs (70%), Government of Andhra Pradesh Grant of Rupees 377.89 Lakhs (15%), and SPV contribution of Rupees 377.89 Lakhs (15%).

The project components include Land Cost (0.5 Acres for 30 years Lease) for Rs. 45.00 Lakhs, Buildings (10800 Sq. Feet) for Rs. 183.83 Lakhs, Plant and Machineries for Rs. 2062.94 Lakhs, and Miscellaneous Fixed Assets for Rs. 45.00 Lakhs.

The proposed interventions include Pre-Press Equipment (Design Studio, Computer to Plate making unit), Advance Printing Technology (Multi-color offset Printing Machine, Large Size Screen Printing Machine, Fabric Printing Machine, Eco-Friendly Cloth Banner Printing Machine, Digital Press), Post Press Equipment (Cutting Machine, Case Maker, Perfect Binding Machine, etc.), Skill Development and Training Setup, and Environmental Section (Solar Power, Rainwater Harvesting).
The project is considered financially viable with an IRR of 26%, NPV of (2468.84), Breakeven Point of 40%, and ROCE of 36%.
Sensitivity analysis for a 5% reduction in revenue shows IRR of 24%, NPV of 2328.13, Breakeven Point of 41%, and ROCE of 33%.
Sensitivity analysis for a 10% reduction in revenue shows IRR of 22%, NPV of 2187.41, Breakeven Point of 43%, and ROCE of 31%.
The achievable ratios by the project (IRR 26%, NPV positive, Breakeven point 40%, ROCE 36%) meet or exceed the MSE-CDP Guidelines.
The implementation schedule is estimated for 18 months, with commercial usage starting from the 17th month.

After intervention, the number of units is projected to increase from 92 to 150, turnover from Rs. 64.40 Crore to Rs. 100 Crores within 3 years, direct employment from 500 to 800, and indirect employment from 3000 to 5000.
The cluster aims to improve profit margins by 25% to 30% and establish 15 exporting units.
The Tirupati district is described as a spiritual capital with numerous historic temples, including the Tirumala Venkateswara Temple.
The district is also home to the Satish Dhawan Space Centre and is an educational hub with institutions like IIT Tirupati and Sri Venkateswara University.
Tirupati has a tropical wet and dry climate.
The city's economy is heavily influenced by tourism, primarily due to the Tirumala Venkateswara Temple.
Tirupati is known for its Tirupati Laddu, which has a Geographical Indication tag.
The printing industry in India is growing, with a significant number of printing institutes and graduates entering the field annually.
The Indian printing industry's value was over 225 billion Indian rupees in 2021 and was expected to exceed 250 billion rupees by 2024.
The cluster members currently use traditional offset printing machinery and screen printing technology, with limitations in modern equipment and finishing facilities.

Major problems identified in the cluster include outdated CTP processing technology, lack of high-resolution multi-color printers, absence of variable data printing technology, and insufficient finishing and post-press machining facilities.
The proposed CFC interventions aim to address these critical gaps by providing advanced machinery and facilities.
Sivakasi is highlighted as India's printing hub, contributing significantly to the country's offset printing solutions.
The project aims to increase individual cluster profit margins by 30%, produce export-oriented products, and diversify products.
The total project cost is Rs. 2519.26 Lakhs, with a breakdown of costs for land, buildings, and machinery.
The means of finance include contributions from the SPV, the Government of Andhra Pradesh, and the Government of India.
Detailed machinery lists with technical specifications and costs are provided.
The power requirement for the CFC is estimated, and the water requirement will be met by a borewell.
The organizational setup and manpower requirement for the CFC are outlined, including designations, salaries, and annual costs.
The implementation schedule is detailed, outlining tasks and timelines over 18 months.
The revenue generation mechanism for the project's sustainability is based on service charges for individual machines, with projected annual revenues from various sections.

Financial feasibility analysis at 100% capacity, including project cost, means of finance, depreciation, working capital, revenue generation, breakeven analysis, projected profit and loss, cash flow statement, and balance sheet, is presented.
Sensitivity analysis for 5% and 10% reductions in capacity or sales is also provided, showing the impact on financial ratios.

The conclusion emphasizes the need for technological upgrades and skill development in the Indian printing industry to remain competitive, and the role of the CFC in supporting the Tirupati cluster units.
The 8th State Level Steering Committee Meeting of MSE-CDP was held on 27-03-2024.
The meeting reviewed the progress of ongoing CFCs and ID Projects in Andhra Pradesh.
The Printing Cluster, Tirupati proposal was recommended by the 7th SLSC and accorded Final Approval during the 3rd National Project Approval Committee (NPAC) Meeting held on 05.03.2024.
The means of finance for the Printing Cluster, Tirupati CFC were confirmed as 70% GoI Grant, 15% State Government contribution, and 15% SPV contribution, totaling Rs. 2519.26 Lakhs.
An undertaking from the Implementing Agency/SPV is required, stating that CFC facilities will be equally open to non-SPV members.
The meeting also reviewed the status of completed and ongoing ID Projects in Andhra Pradesh.
Several new CFC and ID proposals were identified or are under DPR preparation.
The Chairman instructed the SPV to reassess land requirements and submit revised DPRs for deferred proposals due to various shortfalls.
The Chairman also advised SIDBI to expedite the appraisal of new proposals and suggested considering Scheduled Commercial Banks for appraisal on a case-to-case basis.
The meeting highlighted the importance of timely submission of documents, utilization certificates, and adherence to MSE-CDP guidelines.

DFO, Visakhapatnam, was in attendance.

The Andhra Pradesh IT Policy 2021-24 aims to transform the ITE&C department into a revenue center, generate large-scale local employment in the IT/IT Enabled Services sector, and focus on innovation and emerging technologies.
The policy is valid retrospectively from April 1, 2021, to March 31, 2024.
The policy aims to create three state-of-the-art concept cities and an 'Integrated Technology Park' in Visakhapatnam.
The policy outlines fiscal incentives for attracting IT industry, including employment creation incentives, 'Work from Home' incentives, and boosts to the gig economy.
The policy introduces business process reforms, including deemed Industrial Area Local Authority (IALA) approval and a comprehensive investment portal.
IT companies/IT parks/Integrated Technology Park will be exempt from the AP Pollution Control Act, except for power generation sets.
IT companies will be exempt from inspections under several Acts, including the Factories Act 1948 and the AP Shops and Establishments Act 1988.
General permission for 3-shift operations with women working at night is available for IT parks/IT companies, with safety precautions.
IT industry is declared as essential services under AP Essential Services Maintenance Act.
IT units are permitted to file self-certifications.
The ITE&C department will strive to offer infrastructure such as land and plug and play office space to the industry.
Allotment of Government land or land held by authorized agencies to IT companies/IT Parks will be based on the recommendation of CCITEI.
IT units with 250 employees and a minimum annual turnover of INR 15 Cr. are eligible for land allotment.
IT companies with a current headcount of minimum 10,000 people globally or a turnover of INR 500 Cr. are eligible for land to develop their own IT campus.
Foreign IT companies need to be Fortune 1,000 or have a market capitalization of at least USD 50 Million to develop their own IT campus.
IT park developers need prior experience of developing at least 10,00,000 sq ft. built-up space and a minimum annual revenue of INR 25 Cr.
Mixed-purpose land usage will be allowed up to 30 percent of the developed land allotted for commercial activities.
A one-time incentive of INR 50,000 per employment created, capped at 60 percent of the land value, will be granted to IT park developers.
The Government may approve a customized incentive package for mega projects (generating employment of minimum 5,000 entry-level IT professionals or investment of at least INR 500 Cr.).
The ITE&C Department will act as a service provider to all GoAP Departments for IT procurement.
Andhra Pradesh Technology Services (APTS) will be mandated for IT and hardware procurement in the State.
Procurement exceeding INR 10 lakhs must be implemented through APTS.
APTS will establish rate contracts for commonly procured IT hardware and software services.
The department will develop a portal to enable market access to local IT firms.
For IT requirements up to INR 1 Cr., 100 percent procurement value will be from IT companies/startups operating in Andhra Pradesh.
For IT requirements above INR 1 Cr., preference will be given to Andhra Pradesh IT companies by adding 5 percent additional marks in technical evaluation.
Incentives are intended to encourage new investments and activities in the IT space.
Incentives will be disbursed within 6 months from the date of issue of the order.
Andhra Pradesh Electronics and Information Technology Agency (APEITA) will be the nodal agency for implementing the Policy.
CCITEI will be responsible for incentive approvals, administration, land allotment, and resolving policy interpretation ambiguities.
Detailed operating guidelines for the Policy will be issued separately.

AP MSME Development Corporation is a Government of Andhra Pradesh undertaking committed to strengthening the MSME ecosystem.
AP MSME DC facilitates access to markets, capacity building, technology adoption, infrastructure, and policy support.
AP MSME DC is the nodal agency for the implementation of the RAMP scheme in Andhra Pradesh.
The Raising and Accelerating MSME Performance (RAMP) scheme is a World Bank-assisted Central Sector Scheme launched by the Ministry of MSME, Government of India.
The RAMP scheme is designed to strengthen the MSME ecosystem by addressing key challenges through strategic initiatives.
The scheme emphasizes resilience, competitiveness, and sustainability of MSMEs post-COVID-19.
The RAMP scheme is envisioned as a central sector scheme.
It is aimed at improving the performance and capacity of the MSME sector, ensuring its sustained growth in the post-COVID economy.
RAMP supports the implementation of the National MSME Reform Agenda and builds upon the success and lessons learned from previous government initiatives.
The scheme focuses on digital empowerment, green practices, access to credit, skilling, quality certification, and market linkage.
Key features of the RAMP scheme include support to State Governments through Strategic Investment Plans (SIPs) for targeted interventions.
It encourages innovation and technology adoption by MSMEs.
It improves access to markets through e-commerce and global linkages.
It facilitates quality certification and compliance under schemes such as ZED.
In Andhra Pradesh, the RAMP scheme is implemented by AP MSME DC.
AP MSME DC actively engages with stakeholders to ensure outreach and capacity building at the grassroots level.
Interventions under the RAMP include awareness creation, infrastructure development, cluster strengthening, and promotion of quality and green certification among MSMEs.
The Zero Defect, Zero Effect (ZED) Certification Scheme is a flagship initiative by the Ministry of MSME.
The ZED scheme aims to promote awareness among MSMEs regarding quality, environmental sustainability, and regulatory compliance.
The scheme encourages MSMEs to manufacture products with Zero Defect and adopt processes with Zero Effect on the environment.
ZED certification is awarded at Bronze, Silver, and Gold levels based on an MSME's adherence to quality standards, resource efficiency, and eco-friendly practices.
This initiative helps MSMEs enhance their competitiveness, embrace sustainable manufacturing, and gain global recognition.
This Expression of Interest (EoI) is issued by AP MSME DC to invite agencies to participate in conducting ZED workshops.
The workshops aim to promote awareness of the ZED scheme, organize workshops, and facilitate the issuance of ZED certifications for eligible manufacturing MSMEs.
This EoI is applicable to all eligible legal entities including private companies, not-for-profit organizations, government institutions, and training agencies.
The eligible entities must have experience in ZED certification or capacity building for MSMEs and possess valid QCI certification.
AP MSME DC intends to empanel multiple agencies to conduct a total of 1638 workshops and facilitate 32,760 ZED certifications across all 26 districts of Andhra Pradesh.
The assignment is Onboarding of agency for ZED Workshops & Certification under the RAMP Scheme.
The issuing authority is AP MSME Development Corporation.
The scope includes 1638 Workshops & 32,760 ZED Certifications.
The EoI Release Date is June 7, 2025.
The Pre-Bid Meeting Date is June 13, 2025.
The Submission of Queries deadline is June 13, 2025, by 5:00 PM to ed-inframsmedc@ap.gov.in.
The Last Date for Submission of applications is June 20, 2025.
The Opening of applications is on June 23, 2025.
Information of EoI is available on www.apmsmedc.gov.in and www.apmsmeone.ap.gov.in.
The Mode of Submission is Offline.
The address for submission of the hard copy of the EoI is 2nd Floor, PVS Land Mark, Mangalagiri, Guntur District â 522503.
The Finance for each workshop is Rs. 70,000 (includes all taxes).
The Empanelment Validity is Till March 31, 2027.
The selected agency will be responsible for conducting awareness workshops and facilitating ZED certification for MSMEs in Andhra Pradesh under the RAMP scheme.
The scope of work includes mobilizing participants, managing logistics, providing bilingual training, and ensuring compliance with reporting requirements.
Selected agencies must conduct 1-day awareness workshops in all allotted Districts across the state.
Each workshop should mobilize 50+ MSME participants.
A minimum of 20 ZED certifications per workshop is required (target: 32,760 certifications in total).
Bilingual training materials (Telugu & English) must be provided.
The agency must handle logistics including venue, equipment, handouts, and registration.
Workshop-wise reports, photos, and documentation must be submitted.
The agency must comply with AP MSME DC's monitoring & reporting framework.
Technical criteria for onboarding multiple agencies include being a registered legal entity in India with at least 3 years of existence as of the EOI Publishing date.

The applicant should be recognized or empaneled by the Quality Council of India (QCI) as an empanelment assessment agency or empaneled to conduct ZED awareness programs and possess a valid empanelment certificate as of the EOI Publishing date.

Applicants must have successfully executed at least one work order related to creating awareness on ZED during the last two financial years (FY 2023â24 and FY 2024â25) or currently executing at least one work order related to creating awareness on ZED.
The applicant should have facilitated at least 300 ZED Certifications in the last three (3) financial years.
The Applicant should have a minimum revenue of Rs. 20 Lakhs per annum from professional fees during any of the last 3 (three) financial years.
The applicant should have at least 3 trainers certified by the QCI pertaining to quality.
Applicants meeting all required technical criteria will be selected, and district-wise workshops will be allocated to all qualified applicants in a randomized manner.
The agency should submit documentation of experience, technical capabilities, previous engagements, and relevant certifications.
Short-listing of Applicants: Those who meet all the required technical criteria will be considered technically qualified.
District-wise targets for the available workshops and certifications will be allocated to all shortlisted applicants in a randomized manner.
The evaluation of technical proposals will be carried out by a designated Evaluation Committee consisting of key officials.
The committee will assess proposals based on predefined criteria to ensure fairness, transparency, and alignment with the EoI objectives.
The committee members will review submissions, verify eligibility, and make informed recommendations for the selection of qualified applicants.

The Evaluation Committee includes the CEO of AP MSME Development Corporation (Chairperson), Executive Director of APIIC (Member), Joint Director (MSME), O/o Commissioner of Industries (Member), Asst Director, MSME - DFO, Visakhapatnam, GoI (Member), Chief Engineer, APIIC (Member), Deputy General Manager, MSME - Technology Centre, Govt. of India, Visakhapatnam (Member), and Executive Director, AP MSME Development Corporation (Member Convenor).
Tentative District-wise Awareness Workshops on 'ZED Certification' are planned up to March 2027.
The total state-wide target for conducting awareness workshops on ZED during FY 2025-26 and FY 2026-27 is 1,638.
The annual district-wise targets are tentative and may vary.
The consultant shall be eligible for payments from APMSME-DC on a monthly basis, based on the number of workshops conducted during the previous month.
Payment milestones are subject to feedback reports from the respective General Manager â District Industries Centre, Department of Industries, Government of Andhra Pradesh.
The payment is â¹70,000 (including GST) per workshop and 20 certifications from that particular workshop.
60% of the payment will be released upon completion of the workshop.
The remaining 40% will be released only after the completion of 20 ZED certifications for each workshop.
In total, there are 1628 workshops and 32,560 ZED certifications planned.
Milestone 1: On completion of each workshop to create awareness on ZED certification - 60% of Payment.

Milestone 2: On achievement/facilitation of twenty (20) ZED certifications per workshop (ZED registration to be made on or after the date of completion of workshop), within 6 months from the date of completion of workshop - 40% of Payment.

Documents required to be submitted by participating companies as a response to this EoI to showcase their proof of experience include: Certificate of Incorporation/Registration, PAN & GST self-attested copies, work orders for ZED Certification Experience, beneficiary list with certification proof for minimum 300 ZED certifications executed, Audited financials + CA Certificate (2022-23, 2023-24 & 2024-25) for Turnover â¥ â¹20 lakh in any FY, a valid QCI certificate issued no earlier than the date of release of the EoI, and a Legal Affidavit for not being blacklisted.
Certified Trainers require QCI emplaned certificate + Resumes of the Trainers.
A Technical write-up is required for Methodology & Work Plan.
Annexure I: Covering Letter is addressed to the Chief Executive Officer, Andhra Pradesh MSME Development Corporation.
The subject of the covering letter is Submission of EoI for Selection of Agency for Conducting ZED Workshops and ZED Certifications across Andhra Pradesh.
The applicant confirms that the information furnished in the documents is true to the best of their knowledge and that any false information shall lead to disqualification.

Annexure II: Profile of the EoI Participant requires details such as Name of the Agency, Constitution, Registered Office Address, Presence in Andhra Pradesh, Presence in India (State-wise), Total No. of ZED Workshops Executed, Total No. of ZED Certifications Facilitated, No. of Certified Trainers, Core Business Activities, Valid QCI emplaned certificate as on date of publishing EoI, and Financial Turnover for FY 2022-23, 2023-24, and 2024-25.

Work orders and work completion certificates must be submitted for all mentioned projects.

The curriculum on Training to Business Development Service Providers (BDSPs) under the Raising and Accelerating MSME Performance (RAMP) Scheme in Andhra Pradesh is prepared and submitted by the Association of Lady Entrepreneurs of India (ALEAP).
The implementing agency for this curriculum is AP MSME Development Corporation.

The curriculum covers various government schemes, Udyam, GeM, and ZED registrations, navigating the Single Desk Portal, government subsidies and incentives, trade fairs, vendor development, export promotion, credit facilitation, public procurement, business planning, DPR preparation, financial and taxation considerations, and environmental & social compliance.
Chapter 1.1 provides an overview of various government schemes related to credit access, marketing linkages, capacity building, technology, and manufacturing competitiveness.

Chapter 1.2 highlights the importance of these schemes for MSMEs, emphasizing economic growth, employment generation, technological advancement, market access, infrastructure development, skill development, and financial inclusion.
Chapter 2 covers the Udyam, GeM, and ZED Registration Process, including step-by-step guides and benefits of each registration.
Chapter 3 details navigating the Single Desk Portal for approvals, including assistance for BDSPs and practical insights on streamlining approval processes.
Chapter 4 provides in-depth knowledge of subsidies available under MoMSME and Government of Andhra Pradesh schemes, and how to guide MSMEs in availing these financial benefits.

Chapter 5 discusses trade fairs, vendor development, and export promotion, including strategies for facilitating MSME participation and connecting them with potential vendors and export opportunities.
Chapter 6 focuses on credit facilitation and financial institutions, including building relationships and understanding loan application processes and documentation requirements.

Chapter 7 covers the public procurement process and tender applications, offering guidance on participating in government procurement opportunities and tips for successful tender applications and compliance.

Chapter 8 deals with business planning and preparation of Detailed Project Reports (DPRs), including practical steps for creating comprehensive DPRs and highlighting financial and taxation considerations.
Chapter 9 addresses Environmental & Social (E&S) Compliances and their significance for MSMEs.
The RAMP scheme aims to benefit more than 5.5 Lakh MSMEs during the program period (FY 2022-23 to 2026-27).
The program implementation will be 85% through the State agencies.
The Self Reliant India (SRI) Fund is an Alternative Investment Fund (AIF) established by the Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises through NSIC Venture Capital Fund Limited (NVCFL).
The SRI Fund aims to provide capital support to Daughter Funds for onward provision to MSMEs as growth capital, through equity, quasi-equity, and debt.
The MSME Champions scheme is a merger of 6 components of the erstwhile Technology Upgradation Scheme (TUS) for a period of 5 years (2021-22 to 2025-26).
The MSME Champions scheme has 4 components: MSME-Sustainable (ZED), MSME-Innovative (Incubation, IPR, Design), MSME-Competitive (Lean), and Digital MSME.
The MSME Sustainable (ZED) Certification aims to promote Zero Defect Zero Effect (ZED) practices amongst MSMEs.
The MSME-Innovative scheme promotes innovation in incubation, design intervention, and IPR protection.
The MSME Competitive (Lean) Scheme aims to enhance productivity, efficiency, and competitiveness of MSMEs through the application of Lean Techniques.
The Procurement and Marketing Support (PMS) Scheme aims to promote new market access initiatives for MSMEs.
The International Cooperation (IC) Scheme aims to build capacity of MSMEs for entering export markets.
The National SC-ST Hub Scheme aims to provide professional support to Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe Entrepreneurs.
The A Scheme for Promotion of Innovation, Rural Industries and Entrepreneurship (ASPIRE) aims to set up a network of Livelihood Business Incubators (LBIs).
The Khadi Gramodyog Vikas Yojana is an umbrella scheme for the development of the Khadi industry.
The Credit Guarantee Scheme for Micro & Small Enterprises (CGTMSE) aims to encourage first-generation entrepreneurs by facilitating credit guarantee support for collateral-free loans.
The Prime Minister's Employment Generation Programme (PMEGP) aims to provide financial assistance to set up self-employment ventures and generate sustainable employment opportunities.
The PM Vishwakarma scheme enables artisans and craftspeople to build enterprises.
The Tool Rooms and Technical Institutions component of the scheme aims to improve access of MSMEs to tooling facilities and provide industry-ready manpower.
The Andhra Pradesh MSME & Entrepreneur Development Policy 4.0 (2024-29) offers competitive incentives to MSMEs and Entrepreneurs.
Amendments to the policy provide enhanced incentives for SC/ST entrepreneurs, including support for capital expenditure, land cost, and power tariff subsidy.
The policy offers different levels of incentives for Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises based on their category (General, Special, SC/ST).
The policy also provides incentives for Technology Upgradation & Acquisition Cost reimbursement, Net SGST Reimbursement, and Piped Water Supply.
Special packages are available for Early Bird Projects, Large Industries, Medium Enterprises, and SC/ST Entrepreneurs.
The policy aims to position Andhra Pradesh as a premier global hub for high-value electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing.
The Andhra Pradesh Textile, Apparel, and Garments Policy (4.0) 2024-29 aims to position Andhra Pradesh as a global hub for textile manufacturing.
The Andhra Pradesh IT & Global Capability Centers (GCC) Policy (4.0) 2024-29 aims to position the state as a leading IT and GCC hub.
The Andhra Pradesh Electronics Manufacturing Policy 2024-29 focuses on attracting investments and creating jobs in the electronics manufacturing sector.
The Andhra Pradesh Food Processing Policy (4.0) 2024-29 aims to transform the state into a leading food processing hub.
The Andhra Pradesh Private Industrial Parks Policy (4.0) 2024-29 aims to promote private sector-led industrial park development.
The Andhra Pradesh Data Centre Policy (4.0) 2024-29 aims to position the state as a preferred hub for data centers and digital infrastructure.
The Andhra Pradesh Semiconductor and Display Fab Policy (4.0) 2024-29 aims to position the state as a hub for semiconductor fabrication and display manufacturing.
The Andhra Pradesh Integrated Clean Energy Policy 2024 is designed to establish the state as a leader in renewable energy and clean energy technologies.
The Andhra Pradesh Tourism Policy 2024-29 aims to position the state as a top tourism destination in India.
The Andhra Pradesh Sustainable Electric Mobility Policy (4.0) 2024-29 aims to establish Andhra Pradesh as a premier global hub for high-value electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing in India.
The Andhra Pradesh Export Promotion (APEX) Policy 2022-2027 aims to establish Andhra Pradesh as a leading export hub.
The Andhra Pradesh Retail Parks Policy (2021-26) aims to boost organized retail trade, attract investments, and create employment opportunities.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh has set a target to generate 20 lakh (2 million) employment opportunities by 2029.
The curriculum covers the benefits of Udyam Registration, GeM Registration, and ZED Certification in enhancing business opportunities.
Udyam Registration provides financial benefits, market expansion, government support, technology and infrastructure support, skill development, and ease of doing business.

GeM provides direct access to government procurement, faster and secure payments, no registration fees, lower transaction costs, simplified and transparent procurement processes, and additional government incentives.

ZED Certification provides financial benefits and subsidies, market expansion and global recognition, quality and process improvement, sustainability and environmental benefits, and financial and credit support.
The curriculum also covers navigating the Single Desk Portal for approvals, including assistance for BDSPs and practical insights on streamlining approval processes.
It details government subsidies and incentives available under MoMSME and Government of Andhra Pradesh schemes, and how to guide MSMEs in availing these financial benefits.
The curriculum includes guidance on participating in government procurement opportunities and tips for successful tender applications and compliance.
It covers business planning and preparation of Detailed Project Reports (DPRs), including practical steps and financial and taxation considerations.
The curriculum addresses Environmental & Social (E&S) Compliances and their significance for MSMEs.

The objectives of the RAMP - One Day BDS workshop include building the capacity of Business Development Service (BDS) providers, creating awareness about RAMP and MSME schemes, enhancing knowledge in business planning and DPR preparation, promoting local MSME engagement, and developing a pool of trained BDS providers.

Key activities and outcomes of the workshop include orientation sessions, technical training, entrepreneurial exposure, communication skills development, screening and evaluation of participants, and networking and linkages with MSMEs and government institutions.

The Andhra Pradesh government has issued G.O.Rt.No.09 on 11/01/2024 regarding the Administrative sanction for Rs.10.7 Crore as state contribution for the Raising and Accelerating MSMEs Performance (RAMP) Programme.
The RAMP Programme is a World Bank Supported Scheme co-sponsored by the Ministry of MSME, Government of India.

The RAMP Programme aims to support COVID resilience and recovery, improve market access, access to credit, strengthen institutions and governance, improve Centre-State linkages, address delayed payments, and promote greening of MSMEs.
The Ministry of MSME, Government of India, has issued RAMP Guidelines and an Implementation Manual.

The AP State Raising and Accelerating MSMEs Performance (RAMP) Programme Committee (AP-SRPC) has been constituted with the Spl. CS to Government as Chairman and the CEO, AP MSME Development Corporation as Member-Convenor.
The Government of India has approved Rs.107.07 Crores for the implementation of the RAMP Programme in Andhra Pradesh.
The State Government's share is 10% of the project cost, amounting to Rs.10.7 crores.
The Government of India will release Rs.42.83 Crores as the first installment to Andhra Pradesh.
75% of the first installment must be utilized to achieve at least 50% of the project targets by March 31, 2024, otherwise the unspent balance will be taken back by the Government of India.
The CEO, AP MSME Development Corporation, requested administrative sanction and release of the 10% state contribution (Rs. 10.7 crores).
The Industries, Commerce and Export Promotion Department has an allocation of Rs. 11,44,60,76,000/- for the financial year 2023-24.
Rs.25.00 crores have been allocated under HoA:2851-00-800-11-09-310/312 (Development of Clusters in Tiny Sector) for the financial year 2023-24.
The Government has accorded administrative sanction for Rs.10.7 crores (Rupees Ten crores and Seventy lakhs only) as the 10% State share for the RAMP Programme implementation.
The sanctioned amount will be debited to the Head of Account 285100-800-11-09-310/312 (Development of Clusters in Tiny Sector) - Other Grant-in-Aid for FY 2023-2024.
The Commissioner of Industries will draw and disburse the Rs.10.7 Crores to the CEO, AP MSME Development Corporation.
The sanctioned amount must be utilized as per the scheme guidelines.
The CEO, MSME Development Corporation / Commissioner of Industries shall take necessary action.
This order is issued with the concurrence of the Finance (FMU-I&I, Energy and I&C) Department.
The Andhra Pradesh Electronics Manufacturing Policy (4.0) 2024-29 has been approved.
This policy aligns with the Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Policy (4.0) 2024-29.
The IT,E&C Department consulted with Electronics Industrial associations, mega industries, and state departments to develop the policy.
The Finance Department has stipulated that the cap on incentives will be limited to a maximum of 75% of FCI under all categories.

The policy aims to make Andhra Pradesh a premier destination for the electronics manufacturing industry by providing world-class infrastructure, fostering innovation, bringing the entire electronics value chain to the state, and creating large-scale employment opportunities.
The policy envisions a conducive environment for electronics manufacturing.
The policy aims to build a sustainable electronics manufacturing ecosystem that contributes to the state's economic development.
This policy is valid for 5 years from the date of notification or until a new policy is announced.
Amendments and modifications to the policy will be applied prospectively.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh may extend the policy period.
Incentives mentioned in the policy will be extended to eligible industries as per operational guidelines to be notified separately.
The IT,E&C Department will issue operational guidelines for the policy.
The policy is issued with the remarks of the Finance (FMU-I&I, Energy and I&C) Department.
Andhra Pradesh has a long coastline and several major ports, facilitating trade.
The state has attracted significant investments, including in the automobile sector, and initiated the development of industrial corridors.
Andhra Pradesh has consistently ranked high in Ease of Doing Business rankings.
The state's Gross State Domestic Product (GSDP) is estimated at INR 14.39 Lakh Crores for 2023-24.
The state has implemented comprehensive infrastructure plans, including ports, airports, industrial corridors, and utilities.
The state has a diversified economy with contributions from agriculture, industry, and services.
Andhra Pradesh has a strong foundation in manufacturing and is positioned as a key export base.
The state aims to integrate deeper into global value chains and become a dominant manufacturing destination.
There are over 1,066 Large and Mega Enterprises operating in Andhra Pradesh.
Since the state's formation, INR 1.4 Lakh Crores in investments have been realized, creating 2.54 lakh employments.

The highest investment values in the state are in Chemicals and Petrochemicals (36%), Infrastructure (15%), Basic Metals & Alloys (8%), Food, Agro & Marine Products (6%), Renewable Energy (6%), Auto & Auto components (6%), and Electrical & Electronics (5%).
Andhra Pradesh's export portfolio includes raw materials, with significant exports to RCEP (28%) and USMCA (25%) trade blocks.
Top export products include pharmaceuticals, marine products, shipbuilding & floating structures, organic chemicals, iron, steel, wood pulp, and fiber.
Andhra Pradesh has 9 Lakh formalized micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs), accounting for 3.23% of India's formalized MSMEs.
MSMEs generate nearly 10 jobs for every INR 1 Crore investment and contribute significantly to the GDP (23.5%) and exports (28.3%).
There are 28 exclusive MSME parks in Andhra Pradesh with a 64% occupancy rate.
The state is implementing 9 Common Facility Centers (CFCs) and 32 Infrastructure Development projects for MSME clusters.
Andhra Pradesh is developing 3 industrial corridors: Visakhapatnam-Chennai, Chennai-Bengaluru, and Hyderabad-Bengaluru.
The state has 1 major and 5 non-major ports, 7 airports, an extensive road network, and comprehensive rail routes.
Andhra Pradesh is a power surplus state with an installed power generation capacity of 20 GW, over 39% from renewable sources in FY23.
The state is developing significant renewable energy capacity.
Andhra Pradesh has numerous higher education institutions, including central universities, IIM, IIT, IIPE, and NID.
Approximately 75% of students in Andhra Pradesh choose Science streams after 10th grade.
The state has a literacy rate of around 67% and a labor force participation rate of 55%.
Andhra Pradesh has been graded in the 'achievers' category for coastal states in Logistics ease (LEADS report 2023).
Andhra Pradesh ranks 8th in the NITI Aayog's Export Preparedness Index 2022.
8 districts from Andhra Pradesh are among the 'Top 100 Export Districts' in India.
The state is in the top 10 in the NITI Aayog's Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) Performance Report 2023-24.
Andhra Pradesh was recognized as one of the top 7 leading states in energy efficiency by the Bureau of Energy Efficiency in 2023.
The electronics industry produces electronic devices assembled from transistors and integrated circuits.
The global Electronics System Design and Manufacturing (ESDM) sector is growing due to technological advancements and consumer demand.
Technologies like 5G, IoT, AI, and autonomous systems are transforming the ESDM sector.
Asia-Pacific is the dominant region in the ESDM sector, led by China, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan.
The global semiconductor shortage has highlighted the importance of the ESDM sector.
India is becoming a major player in the ESDM sector, driven by 'Make in India', PLI scheme, and the Indian Semiconductor Mission.
India's skilled workforce, startup ecosystem, and demand for electronics are driving advancements in the sector.
India is well-positioned to become a global hub for ESDM.
The electronics sector has shown exceptional performance in India's exports, rising from 9th in FY18 to 4th in FY24.
Exports of electronic goods were USD 29.11 billion in FY24.
Andhra Pradesh is emerging as a leading destination for ESDM in India due to its strategic coastal location, infrastructure, and industrial base.
The state has dedicated manufacturing clusters in Visakhapatnam, Tirupati, Nellore, Sricity, Kadapa, and Anantapur.
Andhra Pradesh offers a skilled workforce, competitive land and power rates, and proactive governance.
The state has state-of-the-art industrial parks, SEZs, and Electronics Manufacturing Clusters (EMCs).
The state's logistics capabilities, including ports and airports, enhance its export preparedness.
The Visakhapatnam-Chennai Industrial Corridor strengthens the state's position as a manufacturing hub.
The policy is valid for 5 years from the date of notification or until a new policy is announced.
The policy may be amended and modified prospectively.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh may extend the policy period.
The policy is applicable to new and existing enterprises investing in new units or expansion.
The vision is to establish Andhra Pradesh as the premier destination for the electronics industry.
The motto is to reduce the cost of production and improve the speed of business for enterprises.
The policy aims to create a globally attractive manufacturing hub and a competitive ecosystem for sustainable manufacturing.

Guiding principles include attracting FDI, employment creation, building global brands, capitalizing on demographic dividend, green energy transition, leveraging inland waterways, port-based value addition, dovetailing with Gol schemes, and end-to-end domestic value creation.
The policy aims to encourage product perfect value creation and support enterprises in achieving global quality standards.
The government will provide support for globally recognized quality certifications.
The policy focuses on attracting FDI by creating a conducive business-friendly environment.
The state will highlight its strategic advantages, including location, skilled workforce, and resources, to attract FDI.
The government will engage with global giants through targeted outreach programs and high-level delegations.
The policy aims to support employment creation, targeting 5 lakh jobs over the next five years.
Andhra Pradesh has a qualified manpower pool due to numerous engineering colleges, ITIs, polytechnics, and skill colleges.
The government is committed to Human Resource development and promoting private sector participation in skilling institutes.
The government promotes the use of renewable energy sources to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and mitigate climate change impacts.
The state aims to achieve 40 GW energy from renewable sources by 2030.
Industry 4.0, leveraging IoT and AI, is crucial for transforming production methods and enhancing competitiveness.
The state will create a conducive environment for research, workforce training, and bridging skill gaps related to AI and IoT.
The government aims to harness the potential of inland waterways for goods transportation.
Andhra Pradesh is poised to become a 'Logistics Hub for the East' due to its strategic location and port infrastructure.
The state will enhance value addition near ports for high-value goods.
The state will complement Government of India initiatives to enhance industrial growth and attract investment.
The state will focus on strategies for end-to-end value creation for domestic raw material industries.
The state will encourage GI tagging of local produce.
Targets include increasing production to USD 50 Billion by the end of the policy period, attracting investments worth USD 10 Billion, and creating 5 Lakh new jobs.
The approach includes reducing the cost of production, enabling speed of doing business, strengthening MSMEs and entrepreneurs, focusing on targeted subsectors, and providing financial incentives.

The government intends to reduce the cost of production through land consolidation, efficient infrastructure, efficient logistics, rationalization of tariffs and duties, and improved labor productivity.
Andhra Pradesh has three National Industrial Corridors: VCIC, CBIC, and HBIC.
The industrial corridors will enhance the competitiveness of the manufacturing sector and facilitate employment creation.
The state has four existing electronic manufacturing clusters that will be integrated into the industrial corridor network.
External infrastructure like road, water, and power will be provided to electronic manufacturing clusters.
The government will attract investments for sector-specific giga-size fulfillment centers to manage raw material inventory.
The state will focus on developing National Waterway 4 (NW-4) for inland water transport.
The state will prioritize road infrastructure projects connecting Dedicated Freight Corridors (DFCs) to seaports.
The government will take measures to rationalize power tariffs, water tariffs, and other charges affecting cost competitiveness.
Efforts will be made to achieve equilibrium tariff structures for price stability for manufacturers.
The government will roll out a Skill Census to collect data on workforce skill sets and identify gaps.
The government intends to bring public-private partnership model-based ITIs for industry adoption to train students on specific skills.
Land parcels will be earmarked for the development of dormitories with supporting amenities for industrial workers.

The policy aims to enable the speed of doing business through a Single Window Mechanism 2.0, a Dedicated Investment Facilitation Cell, assistance to foreign investors, re-engineering of regulatory processes, and an integrated data management system.
The Single Desk Portal (SDP) helps industries obtain regulatory clearances.
The SDP supports end-to-end transaction processing with online payment and application status tracking.
An investment facilitation cell has been created to coordinate with multiple agencies for approvals.
A Liaison Officer will assist each investor in following up with departments and tracking approval progress.
The Electronic Policy aims to strengthen the trend of attracting foreign investments.
The government is committed to providing world-class infrastructure, R&D centers, and quality human capital to attract FDI.
Country-specific desks will provide bespoke investor facilitation and handholding services.
Services requiring approvals will be classified into three categories based on self-certification, inspection, and defined SLAs.
An integrated data management system will provide information on demand, market, infrastructure, value chain, etc.
The system will track industrial output from each district and integrate with systems like Gati Shakti.
A dedicated forum of industry associations, experts, and government will receive feedback from industry.
MSMEs are considered the backbone of economic growth and major employment generators.
As of February 2024, there are around 7.41 lakh registered MSME units in Andhra Pradesh.
The MSME sector employs around 61.98 lakh people as of July 2024.
The state will introduce a dedicated MSME and Entrepreneur Development Policy.
More than 175 MSME parks will be developed, with at least one park per constituency.
A dedicated corpus of INR 500 Cr will be created for CGTMSE, technology transfer, revival of sick units, R&D, etc.
A holistic 8-dimensional approach will be adopted to elevate MSME competitiveness and nurture entrepreneurs.

Targeted subsectors for investment promotion include Semiconductor Fab, Display Fab, ATMP, OSAT, PCBs, Compound Semiconductors, Passive and Active Components, Batteries, Automotive Electronics, Mobile and Accessories, Consumer Electronics, IT Hardware, Telecom Devices, LED, IoT devices, and e-Waste Processing.

The state classifies investment categories into four bands: Sub Large Projects (>50 â 200 Cr), Large Projects (>200 â 1,000 Cr), Mega Projects (>1,000 â 5,000 Cr), and Ultra Mega Projects (>5,000 Cr).
The overall incentive a company can claim shall not exceed 75% of the eligible fixed capital investment (EFCI).
An ESCROW account-based disbursement mechanism is being worked towards for timely disbursement of incentives.
Sub-Large Projects (FCI >50 Cr up to 200 Cr) are eligible for a 20% Capital subsidy of EFCI, disbursed in 5 equal annual installments.
Projects with an Employment/Investment ratio >10 for Sub-Large Projects will receive an additional 5% Capital subsidy.
Projects attaining value addition for Sub-Large Projects will receive an additional 5% Capital Subsidy.
Sub-Large Projects are eligible for fixed power cost reimbursement at INR 1 per unit for 5 years.
Sub-Large Projects are eligible for 100% net SGST reimbursement for 5 years from the date of commercial production.
Sub-Large Projects are eligible for 100% reimbursement of stamp duty and transfer duty on land purchase and lease/mortgages.
Sub-Large Projects are eligible for Recruitment Assistance of INR 4,000 per male employee and INR 6,000 per female employee per month for 6 months for first-time recruits.
Large Projects (EFCI >200 Cr up to 1,000 Cr) are eligible for a 25% Capital subsidy of EFCI, disbursed in 7 equal annual installments.
Projects with an Employment/Investment ratio >3 for Large Projects will receive an additional 5% Capital subsidy.
Projects attaining value addition for Large Projects will receive an additional 5% Capital Subsidy.
Large Projects are eligible for fixed power cost reimbursement at INR 1 per unit for 5 years.
Large Projects are eligible for 100% net SGST reimbursement for 5 years.
Large Projects are eligible for 100% reimbursement of stamp duty and transfer duty on land purchase and lease/mortgages.
Large Projects are eligible for Recruitment Assistance of INR 4,000 per male employee and INR 6,000 per female employee per month for 6 months for first-time recruits.
Mega Projects (EFCI >1,000 Cr up to 5,000 Cr) are eligible for a 30% Capital subsidy of EFCI, disbursed in 10 equal annual installments.
Projects with a Direct employment to investment (E/I) ratio >2 for Mega Projects will receive an additional 5% Capital subsidy.
Projects attaining value addition for Mega Projects will receive an additional 5% Capital Subsidy.
Mega Projects are eligible for fixed power cost reimbursement at INR 1 per unit for 5 years.
Mega Projects are eligible for 100% net SGST reimbursement for 5 years.
Mega Projects are eligible for 100% reimbursement of stamp duty and transfer duty on land purchase and lease/mortgages.
Mega Projects are eligible for Recruitment Assistance of INR 4,000 per male employee and INR 6,000 per female employee per month for 6 months for first-time recruits.
Mega Projects shall be offered tailor-made benefits.
Ultra Mega Projects (investment >5,000 Cr) will be offered tailor-made benefits on a case-to-case basis.
Operational guidelines for the policy will be issued separately.

The policy aims to attract investments in Semiconductor Fab, Display Fab, ATMP, OSAT, PCBs, Compound Semiconductors, Passive and Active Components, Batteries, Automotive Electronics, Mobile and Accessories, Consumer Electronics, IT Hardware, Telecom Devices, LED, IoT devices, and e-Waste Processing.
The document is a format for a Detailed Proposal for a Common Facility Centre (CFC).
Section 1 is 'Proposal under consideration'.
Section 2 is 'Brief particulars of the proposal'.
Under Section 2, the applicant's name, contact details, and registered/administrative address are required.
If the administrative address differs from the CFC facilities address, it must be provided.
The location of the Common Facility Centre (CFC) and the address where facilities are proposed must be provided.
Details of the main facilities being proposed must be provided.
Section 2.1 is 'Introduction: brief about'.
Section 2.1.1 discusses the general scenario of industrial growth/cluster development in the state.
Section 2.1.2 specifies the sector for which the CFC is proposed.
Section 2.1.3 covers the cluster and its products, future prospects, competition scenario, and backward and forward linkages.
Basic data of the cluster, including the number of units, type of units (Micro/Small/Medium), employment (direct/indirect), turnover, and exports, is required.
Section 2.1.4 explains how the proposed CFC is relevant to the growth of the concerned cluster/sector.
Section 3 is 'Information about SPV' (Special Purpose Vehicle).
Information required for the SPV includes its name and address.
Registration details of the SPV, including registration as a Section 8 company under the Companies Act 2013, are needed.
Names of State Government and MSME officials in the SPV must be provided.
The date of formation of the company (SPV) is required.
The date of commencement of business for the SPV is required.
The number of MSE Member Units is required.
Bye-laws or Memorandum of Association (MoA) and Articles of Association (AoA) must be submitted.
The main objectives of the SPV are required.
The SPV should have a character of inclusiveness, providing for the enrollment of new members to enable prospective entrepreneurs in the cluster to utilize the facility.
Information on whether inclusiveness is included or not is required.
The authorized share capital of the SPV is required.
The shareholding pattern of the SPV is required (Annexure-3 to be filled in).
A commitment letter for the SPV's upfront contribution is required.
Details of a project-specific account in a scheduled bank are required.
Information regarding the utilization of facilities by SPV members and others in a cluster, and evidence of utilizing at least 60% of installed capacity, is required.
The main role of the SPV is required.
Trust building of the SPV is important for the success of the CFC.
Section 4 is 'Details of Project Promoters / Sponsors'.
Brief bio-data of the promoters is required.
Details of the promoters are to be provided.
Information on compliance with KYC guidelines is required.
Details of connected lending, specifically whether directors/promoters of the SPV have directorships in any bank, are required.
Adverse auditor remarks, if any, from the audit report should be provided; if the SPV is new, this can be indicated as not applicable.
Particulars of previous assistance from financial institutions/banks should be provided; if the SPV is new, this can be indicated as not applicable.

Information about the office bearers of the SPV is required, including their age, educational qualification, relationship with the chief promoter, experience (capacity/industry/years), Income Tax/Wealth Tax status (returns for 3 years to be furnished), and other concerns/interests/financial stake.
Information on pending court cases initiated by other banks/FIs, if any, should be provided; if the SPV is new, this can be indicated as not applicable.
Details of the management set-up are required.
Details regarding who will be the main persons involved in running the CFC and its operations should be indicated.
Section 5 is 'Eligibility as per guidelines of MSE-CDP' (Micro and Small Enterprises Cluster Development Programme).
The GoI grant will be restricted to 60%/70%/80% of the project cost, with a maximum of Rs. 30.00 crore, as per scheme guidelines.

The cost of the project includes the cost of land (maximum 25% of project cost), building, pre-operative expenses, preliminary expenses, machinery & equipment, miscellaneous fixed assets, and support infrastructure like water supply, electricity, and margin money for working capital.
The entire cost of land and building for the CFC shall be met by the SPV/State Government concerned.
If existing land and building are provided by stakeholders, their cost will be determined by a valuation report from an approved agency; this cost can be considered towards the project contribution.
CFCs can be set up in leased premises, provided the lease is legally tenable and for a long duration (e.g., 15 years).
Any escalation in project cost above the sanctioned amount will be borne by the SPV/State Government; the Central Government will not bear any financial liability arising from CFC operations.
The Detailed Project Report (DPR) should be appraised by a bank (if bank financing is involved), an independent Technical Consultancy Organization, or SIDBI.
Proposals must be approved and forwarded by the concerned state government.
Evidence must be furnished regarding the SPV members' ability to utilize at least 60% of the installed capacity.
Section 6 is 'Implementing Arrangements'.
The name of the Implementation Agency is required.
The role of the Implementing Agency (e.g., project implementation and monitoring, sending progress reports, issuing Utilization Certificates) is required.
The implementation period is required.
The commitment of the State Government for upfront contribution is required.
The commitment of loans (working capital and/or term loan) is required.
Section 7 is 'Management and shareholding details'.
Section 8 is 'Technical Aspects'.
The scope of the project, including components/sections of the CFC, is required.
Locational details and availability of infrastructural facilities are required.
Technology details are required.
Provision for Industry 4.0, AI, and innovations, if any, should be indicated.
Details of raw materials/components are required.
Details of utilities, including power and water, are required.
Effluent disposal arrangements are required.
Manpower details are required, including a table for the description of the employee and the number of employees.
Section 9 is 'Implementation Schedule'.

A table is provided for activities, their start dates, and completion dates, including Preparation of Project Report, Sanction of Grant from Government of India, NOC from Pollution Control Board, Site Development, Building up-keep, Placement of order to equipment supplier, Supply of equipments by suppliers, Installation of equipments at site, Sanction of power connection, Trial Run, and Commercial Production.
A PERT Chart for all activities, in accordance with the activity-wise timeline prescribed in MSE-CDP guidelines, must be a mandatory part of the DPR.
Section 10 is 'Project components'.
The estimated project cost (in lakhs of Rupees) is required.
Details of Land, Site Development, and Building & Civil Work are required.
Details of Plant & Machinery are required.
Comments on Plant and Machineries from the Office of the DC, MSME are required.
Details of Miscellaneous fixed assets are required.
Details of Preliminary expenses are required.
Details of Pre-operative expenses are required.
Details of Contingency Provisions are required.
Details of Margin money for Working Capital are required.
Proposed Means of Financing are required.
SPV contribution is required.
Grant-in-aid from the Government of India under MSE-CDP is required.
Grant-in-aid from the State Government is required.
Bank Loan/others are required.
Arrangements for utilization of facilities by cluster units are required.
Section 11 is 'Fund requirement / availability analysis'.
Details must be provided to ensure the project pace is not affected by fund unavailability.
Section 12 is 'Usage Charges'.
Section 13 is 'Comments on Commercial viability'.

A table is provided for particulars and amounts related to Land and Building, Plant & Machinery (including MFA, Installation, Taxes/duties, Contingencies, etc.), Preliminary & Pre-operative expenses, and Margin money for Working Capital, with a total.
Another table is provided for Description, Number, and Amount.
A table is provided for Particulars, Percentage, and Amount, with a total.
Section 14 is 'Financial Economic viability'.
Assumptions underlying profitability estimates, projected cash flow statements, and projected balance sheets are placed at Annexure.

A summary of key parameters for the first 5 years is given in a table, including Net Block, Current Assets, Current Liabilities, Long term borrowings, Capital, Reserves and Surplus, Unsecured loan, Net Worth (incl. GoI Subsidy as Quasi-equity), Income, Gross profit, Depreciation, Profit after tax, and Gross Cash Accruals.
The projected revenue of the SPV is based on specific assumptions.
Section 15 is 'Projected performance of the cluster after proposed intervention'.

A table is provided to compare 'Before Intervention' and 'After Intervention' for particulars like Units (including details of SC/ST/Women/Minorities), Employment, Production, Exports, Import Substitution, Number of patents expected, Investment, Turnover, Profit, Quality, Certification, and Any others (No. of ZED certified units).
Section 16 is 'Status of Government approvals'.
The status of Pollution control approval is required.
Section 17 is 'Favorable and Risk Factors of the project: SWOT Analysis'.
Section 18 is 'Risk Mitigation Framework'.
Key risks during the implementation and operations phase of the project and their mitigation measures are to be outlined.
Section 19 is 'Economics of the project'.
Debt Service Coverage Ratio (DSCR) projections for 10 years are required.
Balance sheet & P/L account projections for 10 years are required.
Break-even point analysis is required.
Section 20 is 'Commercial Viability'.

Financial appraisal tools to be employed include Return on Capital Employed (ROCE), Debt Service Coverage Ratio (DSCR), Break-Even (BE) Analysis, Sensitivity Analysis, and Net Present Value (NPV) / Internal Rate of Return (IRR).
For ROCE, a return in excess of 25% is desirable.
For DSCR, the acceptance rule is a cumulative DSCR of 3:1 during the repayment period.
The break-even point should be below 60% of the installed capacity.
Sensitivity analysis will be performed for major financial parameters with a 5-10% drop in user charges or a 10-20% fall in capacity utilization.

For NPV, it needs to be positive, and the IRR should be above 10%. The discount rate is 10%, and the project life is a maximum of 10 years, supported by a technical expert/institution's recommendation.
Section 21 is 'Conclusion'.
The document is a Corrigendum from the Government of Andhra Pradesh, AP MSME Development Corporation.

The subject is the extension of the bid submission date for the selection of machinery vendors for supply, installation, and commissioning of machinery for Schedule B, D, E, G & J for a CFC in the Printing Cluster, Tirupati.
The bid submission timeline has been extended by two (02) weeks up to January 22, 2026.
The Bid Schedule shows the original and revised/extended dates and times for various activities.
The Bid Calling Date remains December 31, 2025.
The Pre-Bid Meeting date and time remain January 02, 2026, at 3:00 PM.
The Issue of Pre-Bid Clarifications date and time remain January 05, 2026, at 3:00 PM.
The Bid Closing Date & Time is revised to January 22, 2026, at 3:00 PM.
The Technical Bid Opening Date & Time is revised to January 23, 2026, at 3:00 PM.
The Financial Bid Opening Date & Time will be intimated later.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh has issued G.O.Ms.No.125 on 14-07-2025.

The Ministry of MSME, Government of India, sanctioned the Strategic Investment Plan (SIP) of Andhra Pradesh under the RAMP (Raising and Accelerating MSME Performance) scheme via DOL/AFI/RAMP/2023/Cycle-I on 11.12.2023.
G.O.Ms. No.85, Industries & Commerce (Prog-I) Department, dated 08.12.2022, was read.
The CEO, AP MSME Development Corporation, provided e-file no.INC64-COOR/10/2025-JD-INFRA (Computer No.2850740).
The RAMP scheme is a World Bank-supported central sector scheme aimed at strengthening the MSME sector's resilience, enhancing competitiveness, and facilitating economic recovery post-COVID-19.
The RAMP scheme provides comprehensive support to MSMEs by addressing key challenges, fostering innovation, and ensuring a robust business environment.
The Andhra Pradesh MSME Development Corporation (AP MSME DC) is designated as the Nodal agency for RAMP implementation in the state.
Various interventions have been outlined in the SIP approved by the Government of India to promote MSME growth and development.
AP MSME Development Corporation is implementing structured training programs under nine key components across the state.

The AP State Raising and Accelerating MSMEs Performance (RAMP) Programme Committee (AP-SRPC) was constituted with the Special Chief Secretary to the Government, Industries & Commerce Department as chairman, and the CEO, APMSMEDC as Member-Convener.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh has onboarded a State Programme Implementation Unit (SPIU) to oversee the planning, execution, monitoring, and evaluation of RAMP-funded initiatives.
The objectives of the RAMP Scheme include promoting formalization of MSMEs, facilitating access to credit, and providing need-based skill training to MSME entrepreneurs.
The scheme also aims to create awareness on Intellectual Property Rights (IPR), Zero Effect Zero Defect (ZED), and Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS).
RAMP enhances MSMEs' access to markets, finance, and relevant business information.

The RAMP programme aims for inclusive outreach and equitable access by extending training, handholding support, and entrepreneurial development services to all eligible stakeholders, with a special focus on women, Scheduled Castes (SC), Scheduled Tribes (ST), and minority communities.
The key components and details of RAMP and allocated targets are to be achieved by March 2027.
Udyam Registration Workshops aim to provide awareness and support for MSME Udyam registration.
2,600 Udyam Registration Workshops are planned.
The cost per workshop for Udyam Registration is Rs. 70,000.
Udyam Registration Workshops are to be implemented by Nodal Officers assigned by the District Collector.
Vendor Development Programs (VDPs) facilitate market linkages with PSUs and large industries.
91 Vendor Development Programs are planned.
The cost per VDP is Rs. 5,00,000.
VDPs are to be implemented through Empanelled Vendors.
Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS) workshops promote invoice financing for MSMEs.
182 workshops for PSUs and 182 workshops for MSMEs are planned for TReDS.
The cost per TReDS workshop is Rs. 70,000.
TReDS workshops are to be implemented through Empaneled vendors in collaboration with RXIL, Invoice MART, and M1Xchange as per G.O.Ms. No. 7,1 dated 05.05.2025.
Entrepreneurship & Skill Development (ESDP) programs aim for entrepreneurship and self-employment through training.
2,184 ESDP programs are planned.
The cost per ESDP program is Rs. 1,25,000.
ESDP programs are to be implemented by M/s Thredz IT Pvt., Ltd in 14 districts under Packages 2 & 4, and by MSME TC, Puducherry and NI-MSME in 12 districts under Packages 1 & 3.
Modern & Green Packaging and Branding workshops aim for capacity building in eco-friendly product packaging.
104 workshops for Modern & Green Packaging and Branding are planned.
The cost per workshop for Modern & Green Packaging and Branding is Rs. 70,000.
Modern & Green Packaging and Branding workshops are to be implemented by the National Institute of Design (NID - AP) in collaboration with SERP.
Reverse Buyer-Seller Meets (RBSMs) bring buyers and sellers together for export business opportunities.
10 RBSMs are planned.
The cost per RBSM is Rs. 81.9 lakh.
RBSMs are to be implemented by the Federation of Indian Export Organization (FIEO).
Business Development Service (BDS) Providers workshops focus on empanelment and training of BDS providers.
1,200 BDS providers are to be empanelled.
The cost per BDS empanelment is Rs. 5,000.
BDS Provider workshops are to be implemented by the Association of Lady Entrepreneurs of India (ALEAP).
Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) workshops promote innovation and IP awareness among MSMEs.
182 IPR workshops are planned.
The cost per IPR workshop is Rs. 1,00,000.
IPR workshops are to be implemented by the National Institute of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (NI-MSME).
ZED Certification workshops aim for awareness and certification for Zero Effect and Zero Defect standards.
1,638 workshops and 32,760 certifications for ZED are planned.
The cost per ZED workshop is Rs. 70,000.
ZED Certification workshops are to be implemented by Council of India (QCI) empaneled agencies.
The Andhra Pradesh MSME Development Corporation (AP MSME DC) functions as the State Nodal Agency for RAMP implementation.
AP MSME DC is responsible for overall planning, fund allocation, coordination, and monitoring of the RAMP scheme.
AP MSME DC coordinates with district administrations and empaneled vendors/government institutions for effective delivery of RAMP components.
District Collectors play a critical role in ensuring RAMP program benefits reach eligible beneficiaries.
District Administrations coordinate with implementing partners or nodal officers to identify and mobilize beneficiaries.
District Administrations can establish direct coordination with empaneled vendors or institutions.
Contact details of all empaneled vendors and agencies are provided in the RAMP Explainer Document (Annexure-I).
District Collectors can plan convergence with concerned departments for direct implementation of program components.
District Collectors ensure implementation of all RAMP components across all assembly constituencies for equitable geographic coverage.
District Administrations may provide logistics support where required.
Details of funds released district-wise for Udyam Registration Workshops are enclosed as Annexure-III.
RAMP implementation can be carried out through empaneled agencies, government institutions, or designated nodal officers.
District Collectors are ordered to execute and monitor RAMP components in Andhra Pradesh for successful implementation and target achievement.
The CEO, AP MSME Development Corporation, Mangalagiri, and District Collectors shall take necessary action.
The RAMP programme is a centrally sponsored initiative of the Government of India, supported by the World Bank.
The RAMP programme aims to improve the productivity, competitiveness, and resilience of the MSME sector.
Andhra Pradesh is selected to pilot and scale the RAMP initiative.
The approved SIP aligns with Disbursement Linked Indicators (DLIs) and Key Result Areas (KRAs) from the national Program Implementation Manual (PIM).
The explainer document supports operational execution at the ground level for district officials, implementing agencies, and stakeholders.
The explainer consolidates interventions, budgets, timelines, expected outcomes, and implementation responsibilities.
ESDPs aim to equip youth, women, and SC/ST with self-employment capabilities.
RBSMs facilitate market access and export linkages for MSMEs.
Udyam Registration Awareness Workshops drive formalization of unregistered units.
VDPs enhance MSME participation in public procurement and supply chains.
ZED Workshops promote sustainability, quality standards, and lean manufacturing practices.
MGP Workshops elevate product design, branding, and shelf-life.
BDS Provider Empanelment creates a grassroots support ecosystem through trained professionals.
TReDS Awareness workshops increase MSME access to liquidity and invoice financing.
IPR Workshops foster innovation and protect intellectual assets.
The Ministry of MSME benchmarks each activity for consistency across states while allowing state-specific customizations.
The State Programme Implementation Unit (SPIU) oversees planning, execution, monitoring, and evaluation of RAMP-funded initiatives.
All data and performance indicators are integrated with the AP MSME ONE Platform for real-time reporting and beneficiary tracking.
The program allocates up to 5% of the SIP outlay for mobilization, awareness, branding, and stakeholder engagement (IEC).
Robust Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) frameworks, internal audit systems, and financial compliance protocols ensure transparency and accountability.
The revised MSME definition increases investment and turnover limits by 2.5 times and 2 times respectively across categories.
This reclassification enables businesses to grow without losing MSME benefits.
The reform promotes scale, formalization, and institutional credit access.
The revised definition harmonizes policy with RAMP goals.
The revised definition expands the target universe for state-led interventions in Andhra Pradesh.
The RAMP Explainer serves as a working manual for District Administration, implementation partners, and field teams.
Andhra Pradesh aims to create scalable models for national MSME development strategies.
The state reaffirms its vision of enabling 'One Family, One Entrepreneur'.
Udyam Registration is a Government of India initiative to formalize and integrate the MSME sector.
Udyam Registration is a digital, self-declaration-based certification system.
Udyam Registration is a foundational step for MSMEs to access government schemes, financial services, market opportunities, and digital platforms.
Udyam Registration simplifies the process, eliminates documentation burden, and provides a permanent identity number.
Udyam awareness workshops aim to create awareness about Udyam registration benefits.
Workshops encourage unregistered enterprises to formalize and become eligible for government support.
MSMEs are informed about benefits like priority sector lending, subsidies, and reimbursements.
Udyam registration enables seamless integration with platforms like GeM, TReDS, and SAMADHAAN.
Formal registration provides financial advantages like lower interest rates and collateral-free loans.
Workshops guide MSMEs on participating in the MSME Survey Phase II on the AP MSME ONE Portal.
Udyam Awareness Workshops are one-day events, lasting 4-6 hours.
Targeted participants for Udyam Awareness Workshops are unregistered MSMEs and new entrepreneurs.
2,600 Udyam Awareness Workshops are to be conducted by FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per Udyam Awareness Workshop is Rs. 70,000.
Each Udyam Awareness Workshop aims to benefit 50 MSMEs, with a minimum of 20 registrations.
District Collectors review progress and ensure district targets for Udyam awareness workshops are achieved.
Nodal officers lead the planning and implementation of Udyam awareness workshops.
Nodal officers coordinate with Industrial Associations to identify and mobilize unregistered MSMEs.
Nodal officers ensure resource allocation and pre-workshop preparations are in place.
Nodal officers ensure at least 20 MSMEs complete Udyam registration during the workshop.
Nodal officers ensure submission of Utilization Certificates and Completion Reports within 7 days of workshop completion.
Participants are made aware of the MSME Phase II survey on the AP MSME One portal.
RAMP State Programme Implementation Unit (RAMP-SPIU) provides guidance, templates, and support for workshops.
RAMP-SPIU reviews overall progress and provides necessary support.
Industrial Associations support in identifying and mobilizing MSMEs for Udyam registration.
Industrial Associations circulate workshop details and encourage participation.
Nodal officers organize workshops per the tentative calendar and district-wise targets shared by AP MSME DC.
Nodal officers mobilize a minimum of 50 existing, unregistered MSMEs per workshop.
Participants must have a PAN and be existing MSME unit owners.
Industrial Associations (IAs) support outreach and mobilization of MSMEs.
Suitable venues are selected and confirmed for workshops.
Training materials, participant kits, projectors, laptops, and banners are ensured for workshops.
Three resource persons are present at each workshop: a trainer, a technical assistant, and an IPO/Engineering Assistant from GSWS.
The trainer covers Udyam Registration, ONDC, and state MSME policies.
The technical assistant provides hands-on support for Udyam registration.
The IPO/Engineering Assistant assists with the MSME Survey Phase II on the AP MSME ONE Portal.
Each Udyam awareness workshop has a budget of â¹ 70,000.
Districts receive an 80% advance for each workshop, with the remaining 20% released upon submission of the Completion Report.
Nodal Officers, in coordination with district administration, ensure workshops are implemented within budget.

Permissible budget heads for Udyam awareness workshops include Venue Rental, Stage/Branding/Audio/Presentation Setup, Catering, Stall Setup, Printing & Stationery, Trainer & Technical Assistant, Manpower & Event Support Staff, Photography & Videography, Transport & Logistics, Mementos/Welcome Kits, and Miscellaneous Expenses.
Udyam awareness workshops cover Introduction to Udyam Registration, Andhra Pradesh Industrial Policies, and ONDC.
Introduction to Udyam Registration includes significance, benefits, enterprise classification, and online process overview.
Andhra Pradesh Industrial Policies cover MSME & Entrepreneur Development Policy 4.0, Industrial Policy 4.0, and Food Processing Policy 4.0.
ONDC sessions cover benefits for MSMEs and the registration process.
Environmental & Social (E&S) compliance is covered, with collection of E&S compliance forms from each participant.
Post-programme activities include submitting attendance and feedback forms, distributing certificates, and linking with MSME for credit access.
Post-programme activities include handholding support for UDYAM registration.
Press releases are published about the workshops.
Workshop completion reports include total attendees (with social category and gender), photos, E&S compliance forms, and a list of registered MSMEs.

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for Udyam Awareness Workshops include Workshops Conducted, MSMEs Mobilized, Provision of Amenities, Udyam Registrations Completed, Reporting Timelines, Participant Feedback, and E&S Compliance Forms Collected.
Workshops Conducted are measured by the number of workshops conducted as per calendar and target.
MSMEs Mobilized are measured by the total number of MSMEs attending, captured by gender and social category.
Provision of Amenities is measured by availability and adequacy of hall, food, materials.
Udyam Registrations Completed are measured by the number of MSMEs successfully registering during or after the workshop.
Reporting Timelines are measured by timely submission of Utilization Certificate and Completion Report.
Participant Feedback is measured on the quality and relevance of workshop sessions.
E&S Compliance Forms Collected are measured by the number of correctly filled forms submitted.
Contact details for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP) are provided.
Entrepreneurship and Skill Development Programmes (ESDPs) are key initiatives under RAMP for Andhra Pradesh.
ESDPs aim to promote and strengthen an entrepreneurial culture by providing training in entrepreneurial and technical skills.
ESDPs bridge the gap for individuals lacking formal training and resources to become entrepreneurs.
ESDPs enhance managerial capabilities of existing entrepreneurs.
ESDP workshops are conducted for 4 weeks (20 days) in all assembly constituencies.
Training is tailored to meet specific assembly constituency demands.
Andhra Pradesh districts are divided into four packages for ESDP implementation.
M/S Thredz IT Private Ltd conducts ESDP in Packages 2 and 4.
MSME Technology Centre and Ni-MSME conduct ESDP in Packages 1 and 3.
ESDP workshops have a budget of Rs. 1,25,000/- per workshop.
Each ESDP workshop aims to benefit a minimum of 25 participants.
District Collectors monitor ESDP workshop progress and ensure district targets are met.
Nodal officers facilitate venue identification and logistical arrangements for ESDP workshops.
Nodal officers facilitate collaboration between banks, industries, and implementation partners for ESDP workshops.
Nodal officers support the implementation partner in mobilizing beneficiaries for ESDP workshops.
Nodal officers supervise ESDP implementation at the assembly constituency level and verify outcomes and KPIs.
Nodal officers conduct at least two physical visits to each ESDP workshop.
Line Departments (SERP, MEPMA, Handlooms & Textiles, Handicrafts, DRDA, etc.) share sector-wise training requirements.
Line Departments assist in mobilizing participants and disseminating workshop details.
Line Departments support venue arrangements and recommend trainers/resource persons.
Line Departments assist in arranging lunch for ESDP workshop participants.
RAMP State Program Implementation Unit (RAMP-SPIU) develops and shares the annual workshop calendar and targets.
RAMP-SPIU provides training modules, workshop templates, IEC material, and technical support.
RAMP-SPIU monitors progress, provides handholding support, and ensures reporting alignment with RAMP objectives.
RAMP-SPIU coordinates with line departments and IA for workshop execution.
Implementing Agencies (IAs) organize and conduct ESDP workshops as per the calendar and targets.
M/s. Threadz IT Pvt Ltd is the IA for Packages 2 & 4, covering specific districts.
