Ni-MSME and MSME-TC are the IAs for Packages 1 & 3, covering specific districts.
Total workshop targets are allocated per package.
IAs engage certified trainers/expert speakers for each workshop.
IAs collaborate with line departments in mobilizing beneficiaries for ESDP workshops.
IAs coordinate on-ground execution, including venue setup, training materials, AV aids, participant registration, feedback collection, and post-workshop reporting.
IAs ensure quality assurance and submit documentation of outcomes, photos, videos, attendance records, and invoices within 7 days of workshop completion.
IAs support in documenting success stories from ESDP workshops.
Industrial Associations assist IAs/GM-DICs in identifying beneficiaries.
Industrial Associations disseminate workshop details and nominate industry professionals as guest speakers.
Industrial Associations extend support in logistics or venue where possible.
Beneficiary categories prioritized for ESDP include SHGs, final year ITI/polytechnic students, and individuals with similar skill sets.
Convergence with line departments like DRDA, SERP, MEPMA, Handlooms & Handicrafts, DIC is crucial for participant mobilization.
Department-wise data consolidation enables practical beneficiary mapping.
Line departments may assist in arranging venue support and training materials/equipment.

Post-programme activities for ESDP include submission of attendance and feedback forms, distribution of certificates, linkage with MSME for credit access, and handholding support for UDYAM registration.
ESDP workshop curriculum includes Entrepreneurship Development (10 Days) and Financial Literacy training (10 Days).
Entrepreneurship Development topics include Introduction to Entrepreneurship, Business Idea Generation, Business Planning, Project Report Preparation, Marketing Strategies, and Digital Marketing.

Financial Literacy topics include State and Central Government schemes, credit loans, interest rates, digital payments, income-expense records, cash flow management, profitability, and financial analysis.

Skill Training topics cover Beautician, Hotel Management, Dairy Farming, Fish Farming, Bamboo products, Cell phone repair, Fashion Technology, Food Products, Millet-based products, Tailoring, Muggam works, Bakery items, Jute bag making, Honey processing, Agarbatti making, Asst. Surveyor, Asst. Electrician, Web Developer, Solar PV installer, Asst. Plumber, Jewellery Design, and as per requirement.
The budget of Rs. 1,25,000 is allocated per ESDP workshop.
Budget is released directly to the IA upon receipt of necessary documentation.

KPIs for ESDP include Workshop conducted, MSMEs/Participants Mobilized, Utilization & Reporting Timelines, Diversity of Participation, E&S Compliance Forms Collected, and Post-Workshop Adoption/Initiatives.
Workshop conducted is measured by the number of ESDP workshops conducted per district/assembly consistency.
MSMEs/Participants Mobilized is measured by the total number of entrepreneurs attending, categorized by social category and gender.
Diversity of Participation includes participant breakup by Gender, Social Category, Sector, Type/Size of Enterprise, with a minimum of 40% participation from SC/ST and women.
Post-Workshop Adoption/Initiatives are measured by the number of candidates who set up businesses, obtained Udyam Registration, or scaled up/diversified their business.
Table 1 lists the package-wise district allocation for ESDP.
Contact details for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP) and Implementing Agencies (IAs) for ESDP are provided.
Business Development Services (BDS) ecosystem is a key part of the RAMP SIP for Andhra Pradesh.
BDS aims to support MSME growth by addressing non-financial needs.
BDS Providers guide MSMEs in starting up, managing operations, and expanding.
BDS support areas include government scheme facilitation, access to finance, business planning, marketing, and approvals via the AP Industries Single Desk Portal.
M/s. ALEAP is the Implementing Agency (IA) for BDS workshops.
BDS workshops are one-day events.
Targeted beneficiaries for BDS workshops are existing BDS providers and new BDS providers identified from ESDP training.
1200 BDS empanelments are targeted by FY 2026-27 (520 existing, 680 new, with focus on women).
A minimum of 5 BDS providers are to be empaneled in each assembly constituency.
The budget allocated per BDS empanelment is Rs. 5,000/-.
District Collectors monitor BDS empanelment progress and ensure district targets are met.
Nodal officers facilitate collaboration between banks, industries, and the implementation partner for BDS workshops.
Nodal officers support in arranging lunch for BDS workshop participants.
Nodal officers supervise BDS program implementation and verify empanelment status.
Line Departments (SERP, MEPMA, ITE&C, etc.) share lists of existing Mee Seva, CSC providers, and women entrepreneurs providing BDS services.
RAMP State Program Implementation Unit (RAMP-SPIU) develops and shares the annual workshop calendar and targets for BDS.
RAMP-SPIU provides training modules, workshop templates, IEC material, and technical support for BDS implementation.
RAMP-SPIU monitors progress and ensures reporting alignment with RAMP objectives.
RAMP-SPIU coordinates with district administrations, line departments, and IA for BDS workshop execution.
Implementing Agency M/S ALEAP conducts BDS training in convergence with ESDP workshops.
ALEAP executes workshop delivery as per curriculum, schedule, and guidelines.
ALEAP engages certified trainers/expert speakers for BDS workshops.
ALEAP issues certificates from recognized organizations for trained BDS providers.
ALEAP coordinates on-ground execution, including venue setup, participant registration, feedback collection, and post-workshop reporting.
ALEAP ensures quality assurance and submits documentation of outcomes, photos, videos, attendance records, and invoices within 7 days of workshop completion.
ALEAP supports in documenting success stories from BDS workshops.
Prioritized beneficiaries for BDS include existing providers (MeeSeva, CSCs, ESDP Cells, placement cells) and new providers from ESDP batches (focus on women-led).
Existing BDS providers receive training alongside new BDS providers as part of ESDP.
BDS workshops are held at ESDP workshop locations, with ALEAP coordinating with the ESDP implementation partner.
Implementation partners prepare training materials, participant kits, and AV setups for BDS workshops.
Implementation partners prepare banners and IEC collaterals with AP MSME DC and RAMP logos.
Post-programme activities for BDS include submission of attendance and feedback forms, tracking empanelled BDS, creating a BDS directory, and quarterly impact review.

BDS training workshop topics include Introduction to Business Development Services, Overview of Schemes, Credit Facilitation, Availing Subsidies and Incentives, Step-by-step process connections, Tendering and Vendor Development, and Public Procurement and Tender Participation Guidance.
The budget of Rs. 5,000 is allocated per BDS Empanelment.

KPIs for BDS Empanelment include BDS Empanelment, MSMEs/Participants Mobilized, Utilization & Reporting Timelines, Diversity of Participation, E&S Compliance Forms Collected, and Post-Training Engagement.
BDS Empanelment is measured by the number of BDS providers empaneled per district/assembly constituency.
MSMEs/Participants Mobilized for BDS is measured by the total number of entrepreneurs attending, with gender and social category breakdown.
Diversity of Participation in BDS is measured by BDS certified empanelment by Gender, Social Category, and Sector.
Post-Training Engagement in BDS is measured by the number of MSMEs supported by trained BDS providers.
Contact details for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP) and Implementing Agency (ALEAP) for BDS are provided.
Vendor Development Programmes (VDPs) strengthen MSME participation in the public procurement ecosystem.
VDPs bridge MSMEs and major buyers (CPSEs, State PSUs, Large & Mega industries).
VDPs facilitate interactions and showcase MSME capabilities.

VDP objectives include organizing buyer-seller meets, promoting inclusive procurement (4% SC/ST, 3% women), raising awareness on public procurement policies, facilitating onboarding onto GeM and TReDS, and identifying import substitution opportunities.
VDPs contribute to the national goal of building an Atmanirbhar Bharat.
VDPs are conducted by Empanelled Implementation Partners.
VDPs are two-day programs.
Targeted participants for VDPs include MSMEs, State & Central PSUs, Large & Mega Industries, and Defence Organizations.
91 VDPs are planned across the state by FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per VDP is Rs. 5 lakhs.
Each VDP aims to benefit 100 MSMEs.
District Collectors monitor VDP implementation progress.
District Collectors send formal invitations to procurement wings of shortlisted organizations.
District Collectors provide assistance to nearby district collectors for mobilization of organizations.
District Collectors ensure the district meets its annual VDP target.
Implementation Partners shortlist and follow up with CPSEs, State PSUs, and Large & Mega Industries.
Implementation Partners coordinate with industrial associations to mobilize relevant MSMEs based on buyer needs.
Implementation Partners empanel and coordinate with vendors for logistics (venue, stage, catering, branding).
Implementation Partners handle all event logistics and ensure timely execution of the two-day program.
Implementation Partners report calendar deviations to AP MSME DC.
Implementation Partners submit program completion reports within 7 days of completion.
RAMP State Program Implementation Unit (RAMP-SPIU) finalizes the tentative annual calendar for VDPs.
RAMP-SPIU compiles and shares lists of products and sectoral requirements from buyers.
RAMP-SPIU provides operational guidance and support, and helps reach potential participants.
Industrial Associations assist in mobilizing MSMEs, especially from focus sectors.
Industrial Associations help reach potential participants and circulate VDP details.
CPSEs, State PSUs, Large & Mega Industries (Buyers) participate in VDPs upon invitation.
Buyers share lists of products/components for local procurement in advance.
Buyers present procurement needs and engage with MSMEs at stalls.
MSMEs (Sellers) register and attend VDPs with product samples and brochures.
MSMEs participate in buyer-seller interactions and onboarding activities (GeM, TReDS).
Sector selection and buyer shortlisting for VDPs are based on procurement requirements and local MSME capabilities.
At least four buyers are shortlisted per VDP.
Shortlisting is done after verifying MSME capacity to fulfill buyer needs.
Implementation Partners ensure at least one month is set aside for VDP preparation.
Implementation Partners finalize venue and event dates based on buyer availability.
Implementation Partners target a minimum of 100 MSMEs per VDP (50 per sector per day).
Each VDP follows a two-day structure.
VDPs may be organized in collaboration with CPSEs or other relevant agencies.
Daily VDP agenda focuses on one sector/line of activity with at least two buyers per day.
MSME participation is a minimum of 50 per day.
VDP awareness sessions cover RAMP overview, public procurement policies, GeM onboarding, TReDS registration, MSME incentives, and E&S Compliance.
Buyer presentations detail procurement needs and onboarding requirements.
Buyer-Seller Meets involve direct Q&A and stall-based interaction.
The budget of Rs. 5,00,000 is allocated per VDP.
Budget is released directly to the Implementation Partner upon receipt of necessary documentation.
Implementation Partners publish a press release about the program.
Implementation Partners submit program completion reports including total MSME attendees (with category/gender), total buyers participated, total MoUs/Leads documented, and E&S compliance forms.

KPIs for VDPs include Programmes Conducted, MSMEs Mobilized, Buyers Mobilized, Provision of Amenities, Procurement Leads Generated, Reporting Timelines, Participant Feedback, and E&S Compliance Forms Collected.
Programmes Conducted are measured by the number of VDPs conducted as per calendar and target.
MSMEs Mobilized are measured by total MSMEs attending, captured by gender and social category.
Buyers Mobilized are measured by the total number of buyers mobilized relevant to local MSME activity.
Provision of Amenities is measured by availability and adequacy of AC hall, food, refreshments, and materials.
Procurement Leads Generated are measured by MoUs/Leads documented by buyers post-event.
Reporting Timelines are measured by timely submission of Completion Reports (within 7 days).
Participant Feedback is measured on program quality and relevance.
E&S Compliance Forms Collected are measured by the number of correctly filled forms submitted.
Contact details for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP) and Implementation Partner for VDPs are provided.
Reverse Buyer Seller Meet (RBSM) promotes international trade and market access for Indian MSMEs.
RBSMs are platforms where global buyers engage directly with Indian MSMEs.
RBSMs allow for business interactions, product demonstrations, and negotiations.
RBSMs offer MSMEs an opportunity to present offerings firsthand, understand buyer expectations, and secure export orders.
RBSMs are typically sector-focused, providing MSMEs access to niche global markets.
RBSMs provide insights into international quality standards, packaging, and pricing benchmarks.
RBSMs foster a collaborative environment for innovation, partnerships, and B2B linkages.
RBSMs are conducted by the Federation of Indian Export Organization (FIEO).
RBSM durations are 2-3 days.

Targeted beneficiaries for RBSMs include MSMEs in manufacturing/value-added services, export-oriented MSMEs, industry clusters, technology-enabled MSMEs, agro-based and handicraft units, and women entrepreneurs & startups.
10 RBSMs are planned by FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per RBSM workshop is Rs. 81,90,000/-.
District Collectors monitor RBSM workshop progress in the district.
District Collectors ensure the district meets its overall RBSM target till FY 2026-27.
Nodal Officers assigned by District Collectors facilitate coordination with industry associations and export-oriented MSME clusters.
Nodal Officers ensure overall supervision of RBSM program implementation and timely progress updates.
Nodal Officers participate in RBSM workshops.
RAMP State Program Implementation Unit (RAMP-SPIU) prepares and finalizes the RBSM calendar.
RAMP-SPIU oversees implementation at all levels, ensures adherence to standards, and monitors KPIs.
RAMP-SPIU reviews implementation status and recommends fund release based on reports.
Implementing Agencies plan and organize RBSMs, including venue setup, branding, and logistics.
Implementing Agencies identify, invite, and confirm participation of foreign buyers, MSMEs, startups, and industry associations.
Implementing Agencies support logistical arrangements and hospitality for international buyers.
Implementing Agencies assist exhibitors in product display and interactions.
Implementing Agencies collect and validate MSME product profiles, prepare exhibitor directories, and facilitate matchmaking.
Implementing Agencies gather post-event data on business leads, buyer-seller interactions, and participant feedback.

Implementing Agencies ensure quality assurance and submit workshop-wise documentation, including outcomes, photos, videos, attendance records, and utilization certificates within 7 days of completion.
Industry Associations support mobilization and participation of MSME exporters.
Industry Associations provide market trends and demand information to guide event planning and matchmaking.
Industry Associations support in identifying relevant foreign buyers and facilitate introductions.
Mobilization for RBSMs ensures relevant stakeholders, especially MSMEs, actively participate.
The district administration is informed one month before mobilizing participants for RBSMs.
The venue and logistical support for RBSMs are arranged by the Federation of Import Export Organisations.

Post-programme activities for RBSM include submission of attendance and feedback forms, follow-up support to MSMEs, lead conversion monitoring, success story documentation, and RBSM tracker monitoring.
The RBSM tracker monitors MSME export orders, challenges, and feedback.

The RBSM curriculum includes Export Promotion Policies & Incentives, Trade Statistics and Market Access, Banking Regulations & Export Documentation, Certification & Testing Requirements, Success Stories & Buyer Interaction, and Networking & Feedback Collection.
The budget for a 2-day RBSM event is INR 81,90,000.
KPIs for RBSMs include Workshops Conducted, Participants (MSMEs and Foreign Buyers) Mobilized, Export Orders & MoUs, Reporting Timelines, and Feedback & Compliance.
Workshops Conducted are measured by the number of RBSM workshops conducted as per district/year-wise targets.
Participants: MSMEs and Mobilized/Invited Foreign Buyers are measured by the number of MSMEs and foreign buyers participating.
Export Orders & MoUs are measured by export orders and MoUs signed post-event.
Reporting Timelines are measured by submission of UC and completion reports within 7 days.
Feedback & Compliance are measured by collection of participant feedback and E&S forms.
Contact details for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP) and Implementing Agency (FIEO) for RBSMs are provided.
Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs) are legal rights protecting creations of the mind and innovation.
IPRs incentivize innovation and creativity by allowing creators to own and control their creations.
Understanding IPR is crucial for MSMEs to safeguard competitive advantages, attract investments, and open revenue streams.
District-level awareness workshops on IPR are designed to enhance MSMEs' understanding of IPR.
These workshops enable MSMEs to protect ideas, support technology upgradation, and improve competitiveness through IPR utilization.
21 IPR workshops were conducted across 15 districts in FY 2024â25.
IPR workshops facilitate MSMEs' awareness of IP protection's importance in enhancing competitiveness, innovation, and business sustainability.
IPR workshops are one-day events.
Targeted beneficiaries for IPR workshops are MSMEs and Startups/Entrepreneurs.
182 IPR workshops are planned by FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per IPR workshop is Rs. 1,00,000/-.
Each IPR workshop aims to benefit 50 SMEs.
District Collectors provide administrative support and monitor IPR workshop implementation.
Nodal Officers appointed by District Collectors support IA in mobilizing MSMEs and entrepreneurs.
Nodal Officers facilitate on-ground support for workshops and supervise program implementation.
Nodal Officers verify outcomes and KPIs achieved by implementation agencies.
Nodal Officers encourage active participation from industrial clusters and relevant institutions.
RAMP State Programme Implementation Unit (SPIU) develops and shares the annual workshop calendar and district-wise targets for IPR.
SPIU provides technical guidance for implementation.
SPIU monitors progress, provides handholding support, and ensures reporting alignment with RAMP objectives.
SPIU reviews invoices submitted by IA in line with the state-issued calendar and targets.
Implementing Agency (IA) â NIMSME, Hyderabad leads IPR Awareness Workshop implementation.
IA executes workshop delivery as per curriculum, schedule, and guidelines.
IA develops training modules, banners, and IEC materials in line with RAMP guidelines.
IA arranges qualified trainers, expert speakers, and workshop materials.
IA coordinates on-ground execution, including venue setup, participant registration, feedback collection, and post-workshop reporting.
IA ensures quality assurance and submits workshop-wise documentation, attendance records, and utilization certificates to Nodal Officer/APMSMEDC within 7 days of completion.
Industrial Associations assist IA/Nodal Officer in identifying MSMEs and startups for IPR awareness.
Industrial Associations disseminate workshop details and encourage participation.
Industrial Associations support logistics, venue, or refreshments where possible.
Beneficiary mobilization for IPR workshops involves identifying and mobilizing MSMEs, startups, and aspiring entrepreneurs through DICs and Industry Associations.
Enterprises working on innovative products or with potential IP assets are prioritized for IPR workshops.
Suitable training venues accommodating 50 participants with basic amenities are arranged.
Workshop kits including stationery, printed modules, banners, and registration forms are arranged.
AV setup for presentations and live demonstrations is arranged.
Participation is tracked through attendance sheets, and participants' E&S compliance forms are collected.
Participant feedback is collected to evaluate training quality, delivery, and relevance.
IA uploads workshop details to the APMSME One Portal on the same day for real-time monitoring.
IA submits Completion Report, Feedback Summary, and Utilisation Certificate (UC) to AP MSME DC within 7 days of the workshop.

IPR workshop curriculum covers Understanding the Concept of IPR, Need for IPR for MSMEs, GoI Schemes and Mechanisms to Support IPR Filing, Introduction to IPR Tools, National and International IP Laws, Procedure for Registration, Fundamentals of Technology Transfer, Patenting and Patent Law, Enforcement of IPR Rights, Infringement of IPR, Impact of IPR on MSMEs and Business Growth, and Environmental & Social (E&S) Compliance.
The total budget allocated per IPR workshop is Rs. 1,00,000/-.
Budget is released directly to the Implementing Agency (IA).

KPIs for IPR Workshops include Workshops Conducted, MSMEs Mobilized, Post-Workshop IPR Filings Initiated, Utilization & Reporting Timelines, Participant Feedback, E&S Compliance Forms Collected, and Diversity of Participation.
Workshops Conducted are measured by the number of IPR workshops conducted as per district calendar and assigned targets.
MSMEs Mobilized are measured by the total number of MSMEs and startups attending the IPR workshop.
Post-Workshop IPR Filings Initiated are measured by the number of MSMEs initiating applications for Patents, Trademarks, Copyrights, or other IPRs post-workshop.
Utilization & Reporting Timelines are measured by timely submission of UC, Attendance List, and Completion Report.
Participant Feedback is measured on content quality, relevance, speaker effectiveness, and usefulness of sessions.
E&S Compliance Forms Collected are measured by the number of correctly filled forms submitted.
Diversity of Participation is measured by participant breakup by Gender, Social Category, and Type/Size of Enterprise.
Contact details for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP) and Implementing Agency (NIMSME) for IPR are provided.
Capacity Building of Clusters/MSMEs on Modern and Green Packaging & Branding Techniques is a strategic initiative.
This intervention emphasizes adopting green packaging solutions to promote the greening of MSMEs.
Modern packaging influences consumer choice, ensures compliance with international standards, and enhances brand recognition.
This intervention introduces MSMEs to eco-friendly packaging techniques.
Workshops on Modern & Green Packaging & Branding are conducted by the National Institute of Design (NID), AP.

Zero Defect Zero Effect (ZED) workshops and Certification are key interventions under the RAMP SIP for Andhra Pradesh.
This initiative promotes ZED Certification among MSMEs to enhance global competitiveness and sustainability.
ZED aims to enhance manufacturing quality and environmental sustainability among MSMEs.
Phase I of ZED focuses on awareness, handholding, and encouraging sustainable practices.
Phase II supports eligible MSMEs in achieving graded certification levels (Bronze, Silver, Gold).
ZED certifications improve competitiveness, facilitate market access, and align MSMEs with global supply chain requirements.
ZED workshops are one-day events.
Targeted beneficiaries for ZED workshops are existing and new MSMEs in the manufacturing sector.
1,638 ZED workshops and 32,760 ZED certifications are planned by FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per ZED workshop is Rs. 70,000.
Each ZED workshop aims to benefit a minimum of 50 MSMEs.
Each workshop should result in at least 20 ZED certifications within six months of completion.
District Collectors monitor ZED workshop and certification progress in the district.
District Collectors ensure the district meets its overall ZED target till FY 2026-27.
Nodal officers support IA in mobilizing beneficiaries for ZED workshops.
Nodal officers facilitate collaboration between industries and the implementation partner for ZED workshops.
Nodal officers supervise ZED program implementation and verify outcomes and KPIs.
Nodal officers assist MSMEs in navigating the ZED registration and certification process.
Nodal officers conduct physical visits to workshops to assess program quality on a random basis.

RAMP-SPIU provides training modules, workshop templates, IEC material, and technical support.

IAs ensure a minimum of 20 ZED registrations per workshop within six months.

IAs ensure quality assurance and submit documentation of outcomes, photos, videos, attendance records, and invoices within 7 days of workshop completion.

Industrial Associations assist in mobilizing MSMEs in the manufacturing sector for ZED workshop participation.
Industrial Associations promote ZED benefits among members and provide case studies or speakers if required.
Prioritized MSMEs for ZED workshops include Udyam registered MSMEs in manufacturing, those aiming for quality/sustainability certifications, export-oriented MSMEs, and MSMEs in industrial clusters.
Implementation partners prepare training materials, participant kits, and AV setups for ZED workshops.
ZED workshops aim to prepare MSMEs for ZED certification and build competitiveness.

The budget of Rs. 70,000 is allocated per ZED workshop.
Budget is released directly to the implementing agency (IA).
KPIs for ZED Workshops include Workshops Conducted, MSMEs/Participants Mobilized, Utilization & Reporting Timelines, E&S Compliance Forms Collected, and Post-Workshop Adoption/Initiatives.
Workshops Conducted are measured by the number of ZED workshops conducted per district/assembly constituency.
MSMEs/Participants Mobilized are measured by the total number of MSMEs attending, categorized by gender, social category, and MSME classification.
Utilization & Reporting Timelines are measured by timely submission of UC, Attendance List, and Completion Report.
E&S Compliance Forms Collected are measured by the number of correctly filled forms submitted.
Post-Workshop Adoption/Initiatives are measured by the number of MSMEs obtaining ZED certification from the workshop.
Contact details for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP) and Implementing Agency for ZED are provided.
Trade Receivables Electronic Discounting System (TReDS) workshops strengthen MSMEs' access to finance.
TReDS is an RBI-regulated digital platform enabling MSMEs to convert trade receivables into immediate liquidity.
Delayed payments are a critical challenge for MSMEs, impacting cash flow and growth.
Government of India mandates CPSEs and companies with turnover above â¹250 crore to onboard TReDS.

Government of Andhra Pradesh issued G.O. Ms. No. 71 dated 05.05.2025, directing State PSUs, Municipal Corporations, and Autonomous Bodies/Societies to register on TReDS platforms (RXIL, M1xchange, Invoicemart).
RAMP intervention aims to accelerate MSME growth, enhance liquidity, and ensure transparent and timely payments.
TReDS workshops are conducted by Empanelled Vendors.
Two types of workshops are conducted: Awareness Creation Programme for MSMEs and Sensitization for Large Industries â CPSEs â Govt. Depts.
364 workshops are planned in total by FY 2026-27 (182 for MSMEs, 182 for large industries/CPSEs/Govt. Depts.).
The budget allocated per TReDS workshop is Rs. 70,000/-.
Each TReDS workshop aims to benefit 30 MSMEs.
District Collectors extend administrative support for TReDS workshop implementation.
Knowledge Partners (RXIL, M1xchange, Invoicemart) act as technical resource partners and deliver training sessions.
Knowledge Partners support training content and curriculum development.
Nodal Officers provide expert guidance, platform demonstrations, and assist with onboarding queries.
Nodal Officers are responsible for onboarding MSMEs/Large Industries onto the TReDS platform.
Nodal Officers facilitate coordination among stakeholders at the district level.
Nodal Officers support mobilization of relevant departments and participation.
Nodal Officers assist in identifying suitable venues and ensuring necessary arrangements.
CPSEs/SPSEs/Large Industries/Municipal Corporations encourage their vendors to attend workshops.
CPSEs/SPSEs/Large Industries ensure registration and onboarding on the TReDS platform.
CPSEs/SPSEs/Large Industries share feedback and practical insights during sessions.
Municipal Corporations/State Departments support mobilization of government autonomous bodies and procurement-linked departments.
Municipal Corporations/State Departments encourage internal procurement officials for sensitization.
Municipal Corporations/State Departments assist in logistical coordination if workshops are hosted within their premises.
RAMP State Programme Implementation Unit (SPIU) develops the annual workshop calendar and assigns district-wise targets.
SPIU coordinates with knowledge partners and trainers for scheduling and content delivery.
SPIU monitors progress, compiles documentation, and submits reports to the Government of India.
Implementing Agencies coordinate with CPSEs/SPSEs and large industries for industry-level participation.
IAs oversee logistics and ensure attendance compliance on the AP MSME One Portal.
IAs lead TReDS Awareness Workshop implementation in the district.
IAs ensure preparation of banners and IEC materials in line with RAMP guidelines.
IAs coordinate on-ground execution, including venue setup, participant registration, feedback collection, and post-workshop reporting.
IAs ensure quality assurance and submit documentation of outcomes, attendance records, and utilization certificates within 7 days of workshop completion.
IAs connect with government autonomous bodies and procurement-linked departments to obtain vendor lists.
Mobilization of MSMEs for TReDS workshops is facilitated by the IA in coordination with municipal corporations, state government departments, bodies, and PSUs/Large Industries.
PSUs, Large Industries, and Municipal Corporations encourage vendor participation in workshops.
IAs, in coordination with PSUs, Large Industries, Municipal Corporations, and State Govt. Depts/Bodies, assist in arranging suitable venues and logistical support.
RXIL, Invoicemart, and M1xchange serve as resource partners/trainers for TReDS workshops.
Onboarding of Large Industries, PSUs, State Govt. Departments, and MSMEs onto the TReDS platform is facilitated by RXIL, M1xchange, and Invoicemart.
Onboarding details are reported to the Nodal Officer assigned by the District Collector.
IA ensures workshop details are uploaded to the APMSME One Portal on the same day for real-time monitoring.
Participants' attendance sheets and E&S compliance forms are collected.
IA submits Completion Report, Feedback Summary, and Utilisation Certificate (UC) to concerned authorities within 7 days of the workshop.
Post-programme activities for TReDS include publishing press releases, submitting completion reports (including seller/buyer attendance, TReDS onboardings, photos).

TReDS workshop curriculum includes Introduction (Overview of TReDS, platforms, benefits, eligibility, registration, case studies), Using the User Interface (dashboard features, invoice management), Making and Organizing Bills, Comprehending the Discounting Procedure, Documentation and Compliance, Security and Risk Management, Business Process Integration, and ESG Compliance Checklist.
Budget heads for TReDS workshops include Stationery, Printing & Branding, AV Setup, Catering, Event Setup, Trainer Honorarium and Travel Allowances, Venue Rental, and Miscellaneous expenses.

KPIs for TReDS workshops include Workshops Conducted, MSMEs/Participants Mobilized, Post-Workshop Registration/Onboarding, Utilization & Reporting Timelines, Participant Feedback, and E&S Compliance Forms Collected.
Workshops Conducted are measured by the number of TReDS workshops conducted as per district calendar and targets.
MSMEs/Participants Mobilized are measured by the total number of MSMEs, vendors, and procurement officers who attended.
Post-Workshop Registration/Onboarding is measured by the number of MSMEs, CPSEs/SPSEs, or Municipal Bodies that registered or initiated onboarding on TReDS.
Contact details for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP), Technical Partners (Invoicemart, RXIL), and Implementing Agency for TReDS are provided.
The RAMP Explainer is the operational backbone of Andhra Pradesh's SIP.
The explainer transforms strategy into concrete action by detailing objectives, processes, roles, timelines, budgets, and reporting formats.
The explainer ensures implementation is driven by structure and accountability.
The explainer ensures uniformity and comparability across all 26 districts and 175 constituencies.
The explainer integrates IEC, E&S compliance, feedback loops, and performance indicators into every activity.
The RAMP programme's purpose is to unlock the MSME sector's potential by institutionalizing support, expanding access, and creating market and credit linkages.
MSMEs are recognized as engines of inclusive growth, job creation, and rural transformation.
The explainer empowers the state machinery to move fast and deliver consistently with defined budgets and streamlined approvals.
Andhra Pradesh aims to build a model for MSME development planning, execution, and scaling.
The document sets a standard for timely, inclusive, and outcome-oriented performance.

The West Godavari District is a leading coconut-producing region in Andhra Pradesh.
The proposed Common Facility Centre (CFC) aims to address challenges in the coconut industry.
CFC objectives include Technological Empowerment, Capacity Building, Value Addition, Sustainability Initiatives, and Industry Collaboration.
The CFC will feature facilities for de-husking, grating, extracting milk and oil, and processing dry products.
Parallel processing units will handle value-added production and by-product utilization.
The CFC will implement stringent quality control measures.
The project is expected to increase efficiency and output, reduce dependency on external facilities, and minimize production costs.
The project will contribute to the local economy by increasing employment and enhancing skills through training.
The CFC will adhere to environmentally sustainable practices and continuously innovate.
The CFC represents a transformative opportunity for the coconut industry in West Godavari.
The total investment for the project is Rs. 2997.45 Lakhs.
Land and building expenditure is Rs. 636.08 lakhs.
Plant and machinery expenditure is Rs. 2256.92 lakhs.
Preliminary and pre-operative expenses account for Rs. 59.45 lakhs.
Working capital margin is Rs. 45 lakhs.
Government of India Grant is 70% of the project cost (Rs. 2098.21 Lakhs).
Government of Andhra Pradesh Contribution is 15% of the project cost (Rs. 449.62 lakhs).
SPV Contribution is 15% of the project cost (Rs. 449.62 lakhs).
The project demonstrates strong financial viability with positive financial ratios.
Average Return on Capital Employed (ROCE) is 33%.
The project has a positive Net Present Value (NPV) of Rs. 4496.12 lakhs at a 10% discount rate.
The Internal Rate of Return (IRR) exceeds the benchmark rate of 17.12%.
Sensitivity analysis indicates the project can withstand decreases in user charges and capacity utilization.
Before intervention, the cluster had 69 units, 729 direct and 867 indirect employees, Rs. 125 Cr production, and Nil exports.

Profit margin is projected to increase from 10-12% to 15-20%.
Product quality is expected to improve with advanced machinery.
ISO, TUV, BIS Certification compliance is expected from the majority of units.
5 units may go for ZED certification within two years.

India is the largest coconut-producing country in the world, accounting for 31.45% of global production.
Coconut crop contributes around Rs. 30,795.6 crore to India's GDP.
The coconut palm provides food security and livelihood to over 12 million people in India.
India's coconut productivity is 9,346 nuts per hectare.
Highest coconut producing states in India (2022) include Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Andhra Pradesh, and West Bengal.
Copra processing, coconut oil extraction, and coir manufacturing are traditional coconut-based activities in India.
Kerala, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, and Andhra Pradesh account for 89.13% of India's coconut area and 90.77% of production.
India's coconut production trend shows growth.
The Government of India provided financial assistance for area expansion and productivity improvement under coconut initiatives.
India plays a prominent role in global coconut and related products supply.

Strong export growth creates employment in various coconut-based product industries.

The Coconut Board of India implements programs to develop the coconut industry.

Coconut Palm Insurance Mission and Kera Suraksha Insurance Scheme protect farmers from calamities.
The Technology Mission on Coconut (TMoC) aims to synergize efforts and address gaps in coconut farming.
TMoC key components include developing and adopting technologies for pest/disease management, processing, product diversification, and market research.
The Coconut Development Board (CDB) is a statutory body under the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare.
CDB functions include industry development, technical knowledge dissemination, financial assistance, marketing improvement, and scheme implementation.

Andhra Pradesh has been increasing coconut production through modern farming practices and improved varieties.
The state focuses on value addition to coconut products to increase farmer and entrepreneur income.

The facility aims to provide training on sustainable and efficient processing practices.
The facility aims to promote the development of value-added coconut products.
The facility aims to encourage environmentally friendly processing methods and sustainable practices.
The facility aims to collaborate with local government agencies and stakeholders to promote the coconut industry.

The Chairman directed the committee to forward the challenges faced in the implementation of the MSE-CDP-CFC scheme and proposed resolutions to GOI.
Challenges in the implementation of the Micro & Small Enterprises Cluster Development (MSE-CDP) Scheme and proposed solutions were discussed.
Issue 1: Land should be in the name of the SPV by the time of application under the scheme (clause-7C).

Proposed Solution 1: The scheme approval may be in two phases: a. In-Principle approval (lands identified, SPV gives undertaking to make lands available within 3 months), b. Final Approval (after lands are registered in SPV's name and other formalities completed). This mechanism is followed in other Gol departments' interventions for MSMEs.
Issue 2: Allowing the leasing of lands of any property owned by members or their family members.

Proposed Solution 2: A check mechanism that the member of the SPV has to transfer the lands by a registered deed in the name of the SPV, which cannot be reverted till the end of the project period or 25 years, may be placed. This will ensure members shoulder more responsibility and attract bank finance.
Issue 3: Appraisal by commercial banks not up to the quality expected by SIDBI and long time for appraisal by SIDBI.

Proposed Solution 3: a. SIDBI may train commercial banks for proper preparation of DPRs. b. SIDBI can increase manpower for appraising proposals from Andhra Pradesh. c. Follow proper timelines for field inspections by SIDBI to avoid unnecessary delays.
Issue 4: SIDBI faces manpower issues and delays in DPR review.
Issue 5: Field inspections by SIDBI are time-consuming.
Issue 6: Joint inspection by MSME-DFO officials is mandatory for each Gol grant release, causing delays (Clauses 17 (vii) and 17(viii)).

Proposed Solution 6: Gol Grant is utilized fully for the purchase of Plant and Machinery (P&M). P&M are tendered by the State Implementing Agency, hence payment for P&M may be given @90% in the first installment (directly to the vendor by the SPV) and 10% after commissioning of P&M. The inspection can be done after commissioning or during installation to expedite grounding of the scheme.
Issue 7: Inability for the SPV to float tenders in the e-Tendering Platforms.
Proposed Solution 7: e-Tendering Platforms may be enabled to allow SPVs created under the MSE-CDP programme for CFC sub-component to float tenders.
The Andhra Pradesh Renewable Energy Export Policy, 2020 was notified.
The orders were issued with the concurrence of Finance in their U.O.No.FIN01-FMU)ASD(IIE)/4/2020-FMU-IIEIC(Computer.No.1132369), dated:09-04-2020.
The policy is issued in the name of the Governor of Andhra Pradesh.
Srikant Nagulapalli is the Secretary to Government.
The policy is addressed to the Vice-Chairman & Managing Director, New & Renewable Energy Development Corporation of Andhra Pradesh, Tadepalli, Guntur District.
It is also addressed to the Chairman & Managing Director, Transmission Corporation of Andhra Pradesh, Vijayawada.
It is addressed to the Managing Director, Andhra Pradesh Power Generation Corporation Limited, Vijayawada.
It is addressed to the Chairman & Managing Director, Andhra Pradesh Solar Power Corporation Limited, Tadepalli, Guntur District.
It is addressed to the Chairman & Managing Director, Andhra Pradesh Green Energy Corporation Limited, Guntur District.
It is addressed to the Chairman & Managing Director, APSPDCL/APCPDCL/APEPDCL, Tirupati/Vijayawada/Visakhapatnam.
It is addressed to the Principal Secretary to Govt, Revenue Dept. and the Chief Commissioner of Land Administration, A.P., Vijayawada.
It is addressed to the Secretary (Spl CS/ Prl Secy) to Govt, Panchayat Raj & Rural Development Dept., Water Resource Dept., and Environment Forest Science and Technology Dept.

Copies are marked to the P.S to Chief Secretary to Govt., P.S to Principal Secretary to Chief Minister, P.S to Additional Secretary to Chief Minister, P.S., to Minister( Energy), and P.S., to Secretary to Govt( Energy).
The policy is titled 'A.P. RENEWABLE ENERGY EXPORT POLICY 2020'.
The policy is applicable to solar/wind/wind-solar hybrid projects.
Andhra Pradesh has significant potential for Solar, Wind, and Wind-Solar Hybrid generation.
The state has ideal conditions for setting up Renewable Energy projects for export of energy to other states.
Huge extents of land exist in the state for energy export projects.
Government of India schemes like Ultra Mega Renewable Energy Power Parks (UMREPPs) provide incentives for such projects.
Andhra Pradesh has already achieved the Renewable Power Purchase Obligation (RPO) notified by the State Commission and Ministry of Power, Government of India.

The State Government decided to notify the 'Andhra Pradesh Renewable Energy Export Policy 2020' to encourage, develop, and promote renewable energy projects by investors for energy export outside Andhra Pradesh without obligation of procurement by State DISCOMs.
'Land aggregating Agency' means an agency that aggregates government and/or private lands for allotment to renewable energy project developers.
'Park developer' means an agency that develops common infrastructure like approach roads, water supply pipelines, pooling substations, etc.
The policy objectives include facilitating 120 GW renewable energy projects.
Objectives include facilitating lease of 5 lakh acres of potential land to renewable energy export project developers.
Objectives include attracting private investments and improving the local economy.
Objectives include promoting setting up of renewable energy equipment manufacturing facilities in the State.
Objectives include generating additional revenue for the State Government.
The policy shall come into operation from the date of issuance and remain in force for five years.
Project developer eligibility includes all registered companies, private or public sector.
Power generated from projects under this policy shall be exported outside the State.
In case of supply within the state under Open Access, all charges levied by A.P. State Electricity Regulatory Commission shall be paid, and all connected regulations shall be complied with.
Energy banking (hourly/intra-day/daily/weekly/monthly/yearly) is allowed, and drawal shall be permitted.
All energy settlements shall be done on a time block-wise basis.

Any injection of energy between synchronization and declaration of Commercial Operations Date (CoD) shall be treated as inadvertent power, and no cost shall be paid by any Distribution Company in the state.
Allocation of renewable energy resource potential shall be done on a 'first come first serve' basis by the Nodal Agency through online applications.
Priority will be given to Project Developers intending to set up energy export projects along with manufacturing facilities in the state.
Government, through a land aggregating agency (NREDCAP or any other agency), will procure and aggregate government and private lands for lease to project developers.
Land lease facilitation will be done by the Nodal Agency to permitted developers against payment of prescribed charges.
Lease Period is 30 years for Variable Renewable Energy Projects.
For Government lands, the land aggregating agency shall remit the entire amount of lease rentals to the Government Treasury.
For Private lands, the land aggregating agency shall remit Rs 6,000 / acre/ year with 5% escalation every 2 years to the Government treasury.
The land aggregating agency shall charge lease rentals of Rs 31,000 / acre/ year from the date of taking possession till completion of the lease period.
Lease charges for common purposes land and unusable land will be loaded on a pro-rata basis, developer-wise.
Escalation for land lease charges is 5% every 2 years.
Green Energy Development Charges are Rs 1 lakh /MW of installed capacity/ year for the entire life of the project, starting from the commissioning date of the 1st phase.
Installed capacity will be assessed on AC or DC, whichever is higher.
These Green Energy Development Charges are payable to the State Government.
The land aggregating agency shall pay Rs 25,000 / acre/ year for aggregated private lands from the date of taking possession till completion of the lease period.
Escalation for private land lease charges is 5% every 2 years.
Local Area Development Fund (LADF): Rs 0.5 lakh per acre payable to the park developer.
Park infrastructure development charges will be collected upfront from the power developer as per Detailed Project Report (DPR) estimates, after deducting Central Financial Assistance (CFA) if any.
A one-time processing fee of Rs 2000 per acre shall be collected by the Nodal Agency.
Electricity Duty shall be paid as applicable.
Any Government agency or the project developer may act as a park developer.
Infrastructure at identified potential locations like land development, roads, water supply, etc., will be developed by the park developer.
Applicable Government schemes will be tapped by the park developer for park development.
Internal evacuation infrastructure will be developed by the park developer inside the parks.
In case of areas other than parks, internal evacuation infrastructure will be developed by the project developer.
O&M charges will be collected on a per MW basis from the project developers by the park developer.

Option 1 for connection to State Transmission Utility (STU) network: The project developer may connect to STU at their cost, transferring the line asset to APTRANSCO prior to commissioning, or APTRANSCO may build the line at the developer's cost.
Developers using the Intra-State Transmission network shall pay for Transmission charges and losses as prescribed by APERC.

Option 2 for connection to STU network: The project developer(s) may bear the entire cost of existing or new external evacuation infrastructure, including connecting line, grid substations, and upstream network up to CTU.
The construction of new network infrastructure shall be done under APTRANSCO's supervision and assets handed over to APTRANSCO before commissioning.
Developers opting for Option 2 shall pay only O&M charges as decided by APTRANSCO and be exempted from transmission charges for the entire project life.
Connection to Central Transmission Utility (CTU) network: Project developers shall follow procedures laid down by central agencies.

For all government and private lands transferred to the Land Aggregating Agency, land use conversion from 'Agriculture' to 'Non-Agriculture' shall be accorded by the Government prior to land transfer.
All lands leased from the Land Aggregating Agency can be used for Non-Agriculture purpose subject to remitting land use conversion fee by the Nodal Agency.
Projects will be exempted from obtaining any NOC/Consent for establishment under pollution control laws from AP Pollution Control Board.
The Government intends to promote Renewable Energy Manufacturing facilities.

Incentives for New Manufacturing facilities include: Priority allotment of land on long-term lease basis; Exemption from Electricity Duty for 10 years; Extending incentives as per prevailing Industrial Promotion Policies of the Government of A.P.
New and Renewable Energy Development Corporation of A.P. Ltd, (NREDCAP) shall act as the Nodal Agency.

The Nodal Agency's responsibilities include: Allocation of wind/solar resources and giving permissions; Coordination with MNRE/NTPC/SECI/AP TRANSCO, AP DISCOMs and other agencies; Facilitate land lease from the Land Aggregating Agency; Act as park developer if required.
If any conflict arises with existing policies, this policy shall take precedence.
Energy Department is authorized to issue clarifications and interpret provisions for removing difficulties under this policy.
The RAMP programme in Andhra Pradesh is anchored by a focused set of reform and investment interventions.
These interventions span institutional strengthening, market linkages, access to credit, skilling, innovation, and ease of doing business.
The approved SIP reflects a convergence of state-specific priorities with national goals.
The SIP has been meticulously crafted to align with Disbursement Linked Indicators (DLIs) and Key Result Areas (KRAs) outlined in the national Program Implementation Manual (PIM).
This explainer document has been developed to support operational execution at the ground level.
It is a comprehensive reference for district officials, implementing agencies, and stakeholders.
It consolidates the approved interventions, budgets, timelines, expected outcomes, and implementation responsibilities across various domains of MSME development.
Entrepreneurship and Skill Development Programs (ESDPs) are aimed to equip local youth, women, and SC/ST with self-employment capabilities.
Reverse Buyer Seller Meets (RBSMs) are aimed to facilitate market access and export linkages for MSMEs.
Udyam Registration Awareness Workshops are aimed to drive the formalization of unregistered units across urban and rural clusters.
Vendor Development Programs (VDPs) are aimed to enhance MSME participation in public procurement and supply chains.
Zero Defect Zero Effect (ZED) Workshops are aimed to promote sustainability, quality standards, and lean manufacturing practices.
Modern and Green Packaging (MGP) Workshops are aimed to elevate product design, branding, and shelf life.
Business Development Services (BDS) Provider Empanelment is aimed to create a grassroots support ecosystem through trained professionals.
Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS) Awareness is aimed to increase MSME access to liquidity and invoice financing.
Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) Workshops are aimed to foster innovation and protect intellectual assets.
The Ministry of MSME has benchmarked each activity to ensure consistency across states, while retaining flexibility for state-specific customizations.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh has established a State Programme Implementation Unit (SPIU) to oversee the planning, execution, monitoring, and evaluation of RAMP-funded initiatives.

All data and performance indicators are integrated with the AP MSME ONE Platform, enabling real-time reporting, disaggregated beneficiary tracking (including SC/ST/Women/PwD categories), and decision-making support.
The program strongly emphasizes Information, Education and Communication (IEC), with up to 5% of the total SIP outlay allocated for mobilization, awareness, branding, and stakeholder engagement.
Robust M&E frameworks, internal audit systems, and financial compliance protocols ensure transparency and accountability in implementation.

The Government of India has revised the definition of Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) by increasing the investment and turnover limits by 2.5 times for investment and 2 times for turnover across categories.
This reclassification marks a pivotal shift in India's MSME policy framework, aimed at enabling businesses to grow without the fear of losing benefits associated with MSME status.
This reform promotes scale, formalization, and institutional credit access by allowing more enterprises, especially growth-stage firms, to remain within the MSME fold.
It also harmonizes the policy environment with the goals of RAMP, which seeks to strengthen enterprise productivity, export potential, and digital transformation.

For Andhra Pradesh, this change expands the target universe for state-led interventions, enabling more enterprises to benefit from RAMP-funded programs such as credit facilitation, market access initiatives, and cluster development schemes, while maintaining eligibility under the expanded MSME umbrella.
The RAMP Explainer is a working manual designed to equip District Administration, implementation partners, and field teams with clarity, structure, and direction.
It reflects Andhra Pradesh's commitment to building a dynamic MSME ecosystem that is inclusive, export-oriented, digitally enabled, and environmentally responsible.
As the program unfolds, Andhra Pradesh aims not only to meet the targets set in its SIP but to create scalable models that can inform national MSME development strategies.
The state reaffirms its vision of enabling 'One Family, One Entrepreneur,' revitalizing the rural economy, and positioning MSMEs as the backbone of a resilient and self-reliant India.
Udyam Registration is a strategic initiative by the Government of India to formalize and integrate the MSME sector into the formal economy.

As a digital, self-declaration-based certification system, Udyam Registration is a foundational step for MSMEs to access government schemes, financial services, market opportunities, and digital platforms.

The initiative significantly simplifies the registration process, eliminates documentation burden, and offers a permanent identity numberâthe Udyam Registration Numberâempowering MSMEs with seamless access to various benefits.

The objectives of Udyam awareness workshops are to systematically create awareness about the benefits of registering under Udyam and encourage unregistered enterprises to formalize and become eligible for government support.
Workshops aim to inform MSMEs about the wide range of benefits unlocked, including access to priority sector lending, subsidies, reimbursements, and market development schemes.
Workshops aim to guide MSMEs on how Udyam registration enables seamless integration with platforms like GeM, TReDS, and SAMADHAAN, expanding market access and improving payment cycles.
Workshops aim to spread awareness about financial advantages, such as lower interest rates and eligibility for collateral-free loans, through formal registration.
Workshops aim to provide guidance on participating in the MSME Survey Phase II by introducing the online self-survey available on the AP MSME ONE Portal.
Primary responsibility for conducting Udyam awareness workshops lies with the Nodal officer appointed by the District Collector.
Each Udyam awareness workshop is planned for one (01) day, lasting 4-6 hours.
Targeted participants for Udyam awareness workshops include Unregistered MSMEs, New Entrepreneurs, and SHGs.
2,600 Udyam awareness workshops are to be conducted across the state until FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per Udyam awareness workshop is Rs. 70,000.
Each Udyam awareness workshop aims to benefit 50 MSMEs, with a minimum of 20 MSMEs to be registered on Udyam.
The District Collector is responsible for reviewing progress regularly and ensuring that the annual Udyam awareness workshop target for the district is achieved.
The Nodal officer appointed by the District Collector is responsible for leading the planning and implementation of Udyam awareness workshops in the district as per annual targets.
The Nodal officer is responsible for coordinating with Industrial Associations to identify and mobilize unregistered MSMEs.
The Nodal officer is responsible for ensuring at least 20 MSMEs complete Udyam registration during each workshop.
The Nodal officer is responsible for ensuring the submission of Utilization Certificates along with Completion Reports within 7 days of workshop completion.
The Nodal officer is responsible for ensuring that participants attending the workshop are also made aware of the MSME Phase II survey on the AP MSME One portal.
The RAMP State Program Implementation Unit (RAMP-SPIU) is responsible for sharing the tentative annual workshop calendar and district-wise targets.
The RAMP-SPIU is responsible for providing guidance, templates, and support for the planning, monitoring, and reporting of workshops.
The RAMP-SPIU is responsible for reviewing overall progress across districts and providing necessary support.
Industrial Associations are responsible for supporting the identification and mobilization of MSMEs yet to register under Udyam.
Industrial Associations are responsible for circulating workshop details among their member enterprises and encouraging participation.
Nodal officers appointed by the District Collector shall organize workshops per the tentative calendar and district-wise targets shared by AP MSME DC.
Nodal officers appointed by the District Collector are to mobilize a minimum of 50 existing, unregistered MSMEs per workshop.
Nodal officers must ensure that participants have a PAN and are existing MSME unit owners.
Industrial Associations (IAs) will support the outreach and mobilization of MSMEs.
Workshop planning includes selecting and confirming a suitable venue.

Workshop planning includes ensuring the availability of training materials (course curriculum, pamphlets), participant kits (pen and notepad), a projector, a laptop, and printed banners (with venue, batch code, date).

Workshop planning includes ensuring the presence of three resource persons: one trainer for Udyam Registration, ONDC, and state MSME policies; one technical assistant for hands-on Udyam registration support; and one IPO/Engineering Assistant from GSWS for the voluntary MSME Survey on the AP MSME ONE Portal.
Each Udyam awareness workshop is allocated a budget of Rs. 70,000.
The district will receive an 80% advance for each workshop, with the remaining 20% released upon submission of the Completion Report.
Nodal Officers, in coordination with the district administration, will ensure workshops are implemented within budget.

Permissible budget heads for Udyam awareness workshops include Venue Rental, Stage/Branding/Audio/Presentation Setup, Catering, Stalls Setup, Printing & Stationery, Trainer & Technical Assistant, Manpower & Event Support Staff, Photography & Videography, Transport & Logistics, Mementos/Welcome Kits, and Miscellaneous Expenses.

Each Udyam awareness workshop follows a 1-day structure with sessions on Introduction to Udyam Registration, Andhra Pradesh Industrial Policies, ONDC, Environmental & Social Compliance, Voluntary MSME Survey, and Udyam Registration Support.
The 'Introduction to Udyam Registration' session covers the significance of registration, benefits and incentives, enterprise classification, and the online registration process overview.
The 'Andhra Pradesh Industrial Policies' session covers MSME & Entrepreneur Development Policy 4.0, Industrial Policy 4.0, and Food Processing Policy 4.0.
The 'ONDC' session covers benefits for MSMEs and the registration process.
The 'Environmental & Social Compliance' session covers awareness and the collection of E&S compliance forms from each participant.
The 'Voluntary MSME Survey' session provides orientation and step-by-step guidance for completing the survey on the AP MSME ONE Portal.
The 'Udyam Registration Support' session provides on-site registration assistance with a target of at least 20 MSMEs completing registration during the workshop.
Post-programme activities include publishing a press release about the workshop.

Post-programme activities include submitting the workshop completion report, including the total number of MSMEs attended (with social category and gender), photos of arrangements, photos of MSMEs attending and being facilitated for Udyam Registration, scanned E&S compliance forms, and a consolidated list of MSMEs registered on Udyam (including unit name and Udyam registration number).

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for Udyam Awareness Workshops include Workshops Conducted, MSMEs Mobilized, Provision of Amenities, Udyam Registrations Completed, Reporting Timelines, Participant Feedback, and E&S Compliance Forms Collected.
The 'Workshops Conducted' KPI is measured by the number of workshops conducted as per the district calendar and annual target.
The 'MSMEs Mobilized' KPI is measured by the total number of MSMEs who attended, with gender and social category captured.
The 'Provision of Amenities' KPI is measured by the availability and adequacy of amenities including a well-maintained hall, food, refreshments, and required materials.
The 'Udyam Registrations Completed' KPI is measured by the number of unregistered MSMEs that successfully completed Udyam registration during or immediately after the workshop.
The 'Reporting Timelines' KPI is measured by the timely submission of the Utilization Certificate and Completion Report (within 7 days).
The 'Participant Feedback' KPI is measured by feedback on the quality and relevance of workshop sessions.
The 'E&S Compliance Forms Collected' KPI is measured by the number of correctly filled Environment & Social compliance forms submitted.

Entrepreneurship and Skill Development Programmes (ESDPs) are key initiatives under RAMP for Andhra Pradesh.
The aim of ESDPs is to promote and strengthen entrepreneurial culture by providing training in entrepreneurial and technical skills.

ESDPs are based on the understanding that many individuals, particularly youth, women, and SC/ST communities, have the potential to become successful entrepreneurs but lack access to formal training and resources.
By offering targeted education and hands-on training, ESDP aims to bridge this gap and foster a generation of self-reliant business owners.
ESDPs will also benefit existing entrepreneurs by enhancing their managerial capabilities and helping them adapt to evolving market demands.
ESDP workshops will be conducted for 4 weeks (20 days) in all assembly constituencies of the districts, covering both entrepreneurship and sector-specific skills.
The training is tailored to meet each assembly constituency's specific demands.
The districts of Andhra Pradesh have been divided into four packages to cover all districts comprehensively.
M/S Thredz IT Private Ltd and Central Institute of Tool Design have been appointed to conduct ESDP in Package 2 and Package 4 districts.
MSME Technology Centre and NI-MSME have been appointed to conduct ESDP in Package 1 and Package 3 districts.
The duration of an ESDP workshop is 4 weeks (20 days).
Targeted beneficiaries for ESDP workshops include Youth, Women, Artisans, SC/ST existing and new entrepreneursâall aged 18 years and above.
2,184 ESDP workshops are to be conducted until FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per ESDP workshop is Rs. 1,25,000/-.
Each ESDP workshop aims to benefit a minimum of 25 participants (Aspiring Entrepreneur/Existing Entrepreneur).
The District Collector is responsible for monitoring the overall progress of ESDP workshops in the district and ensuring the district meets the overall target by FY 26-27.

The Nodal officer appointed by the District Collector is responsible for identifying beneficiaries, preferably a group of individuals engaged in the same line of work or possessing similar skill sets.
The Nodal officer is responsible for facilitating support for venue identification and logistical arrangements for the workshops.

The Nodal officer is responsible for facilitating collaboration between banks, industries, and the implementation partner to ensure the active participation of bankers and subject matter experts in workshop sessions.
The Nodal officer is responsible for supporting the IA in mobilizing beneficiaries for ESDP workshops.
The Nodal officer is responsible for ensuring overall supervision of program implementation at the assembly constituency level and verifying outcomes and KPIs reported by the IA.
The Nodal officer is responsible for conducting a minimum of two physical visits to each workshop to assess program quality.

Beneficiary mobilization for ESDP workshops includes final-year students from ITIs and polytechnics who are above 18 years of age.

Surveyor, Asst. Electrician, Web Developer, Solar PV Installer, Asst. Plumber, and Jewellery Design.

Business Development Services (BDS) ecosystem is a key part of the Strategic Investment Plan (SIP) approved under the RAMP scheme for Andhra Pradesh.
It aims to support the growth of micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs) by addressing their non-financial needs.
BDS Providers play a key role in guiding MSMEs through different stages of their business journey: starting up, managing operations, and expanding.

BDS providers offer support in areas like government scheme facilitation (GoI/GoAP), access to finance, business planning, marketing, and obtaining approvals through the AP Industries Single Desk Portal.
M/s. ALEAP (Association of Lady Entrepreneurs of India) is the empanelled Implementing Agency (IA) for BDS workshops.
This initiative focuses on identifying active BDS providers in the state and building their capacities.
It also encourages and trains new individuals, especially women, to take up the role of BDS providers.
The goal is to create a strong network of trained professionals who can provide timely, relevant, and localized business development support to MSMEs across Andhra Pradesh.
The duration of a BDS workshop is one (01) day.
Targeted beneficiaries for BDS workshops include existing BDS providers (Mee Seva operators, Common Services Centres, ESDP Cells, etc.) and new BDS providers identified from ESDP training programs.
1200 BDS empanelments (520 existing and 680 new, with a special focus on women) are to be done by FY 2026-27.
A minimum of 5 BDS providers are to be empaneled in each assembly constituency through the BDS workshop.
The budget allocated per BDS Empanelment is Rs. 5,000/-.
The District Collector is responsible for monitoring the overall progress of BDS empanelment in the district and ensuring the district meets the overall target till FY 26-27.

The Nodal officer appointed by the District Collector is responsible for facilitating collaboration between banks, industries, and the implementation partner to ensure active participation of bankers and subject matter experts.
The Nodal officer is responsible for supporting lunch arrangements for participants at BDS workshops wherever feasible.

The Nodal officer is responsible for ensuring overall supervision of program implementation at the assembly constituency/district level and verifying the empanelment status of BDS providers as reported by the IA.
Line Departments (SERP, MEPMA, ITE & C, etc.) are responsible for sharing lists of existing Mee Seva, CSC providers, and professionals providing MSME services.
Line Departments are responsible for sharing lists of women entrepreneurs trained and providing BDS services in the districts.

RAMP-SPIU is responsible for providing tentative training modules, workshop templates, IEC material, and technical support for implementation.
RAMP-SPIU is responsible for monitoring progress across districts, providing handholding support, and ensuring reporting and documentation align with RAMP objectives.
RAMP-SPIU is responsible for coordinating with district administrations, line departments, and IA for workshop execution.
RAMP-SPIU is responsible for conducting BDS training in convergence with ESDP workshops in every assembly constituency.
Implementing Agency (IA) - M/S ALEAP is responsible for executing workshop delivery as per the standard curriculum, schedule, and guidelines issued by AP MSME DC.

Implementing Agency (IA) - M/S ALEAP is responsible for issuing certificates from recognized organizations for successfully trained BDS to empanel as BDS providers.

Implementing Agency (IA) - M/S ALEAP is responsible for coordinating on-ground execution, including venue setup, training materials, audio-video aids, participant registration, feedback collection, and post-workshop reporting on the AP MSME One portal.

Implementing Agency (IA) - M/S ALEAP is responsible for ensuring quality assurance and submitting workshop-wise documentation of outcomes, photos, and videos, certified attendance records to GM-DICs/AP MSME DC within 7 days of completion, along with invoices to AP MSME DC.
Implementing Agency (IA) - M/S ALEAP is responsible for supporting the documentation of success stories from the workshops.

Categories of enterprises and groups prioritized for BDS mobilization include existing BDS providers (MeeSeva Centres, Common Services Centres, ESDP Cells, Placement cells in educational institutions, and professionals providing MSME services).
New BDS providers will be selected from ESDP batch beneficiaries, with a special focus on women-led BDS providers.
Existing BDS providers will undergo training alongside new BDS providers as part of the ESDP program.
The state aims to empanel 1,200 BDS providers by 2026â27 through workshops conducted across all 26 districts and 175 assembly constituencies.

The tentative workshop curriculum for BDS includes topics like Introduction to Business Development Services, Overview of Schemes, Credit Facilitation and Interaction with Financial Institutions, Availing Subsidies and Incentives, Step-by-step process connections, and Tendering and Vendor Development.
The 'Introduction to Business Development Services' topic covers the role in connecting businesses with resources, funding, and regulatory approvals.
The 'Overview of Schemes' topic covers various MSME schemes focusing on credit access, capacity building, technology adoption, and market linkages.
The 'Credit Facilitation and Interaction with Financial Institutions' topic covers assisting MSMEs in accessing financial support by connecting them with banks and financial institutions.
The 'Availing Subsidies and Incentives' topic covers guiding MSMEs in availing subsidies and incentives offered by MoMSME and GoAP, and navigating the Single Desk Portal.

The 'Step-by-step process connections' topic covers BDS providers needing to be registered under Udyam, GeM, and ZED, and offering services like business planning, compliance assistance, tender participation, and vendor development.
The 'Tendering and Vendor Development' topic covers supporting MSMEs in vendor development, export promotion, and trade fair participation.
A budget of Rs. 5,000 will be allocated for each BDS Empanelment.

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for BDS include BDS Empanelment, MSMEs/Participants Mobilized, Utilization & Reporting Timelines, Diversity of Participation, E&S Compliance Forms Collected, and Post-Training Engagement.

The 'Diversity of Participation' KPI is measured by BDS certified empaneled by Gender and Social Category, Sector.
The 'E&S Compliance Forms Collected' KPI is measured by the number of correctly filled Environment & Social compliance forms submitted.
The 'Post-Training Engagement' KPI is measured by the number of MSMEs supported by trained BDS providers.

Vendor Development Programmes (VDPs) are strategic initiatives to strengthen the participation of MSMEs in the public procurement ecosystem.
These programmes bridge MSMEs and major buyersâincluding CPSEs, State PSUs, Large & Mega industriesâby facilitating meaningful interactions and showcasing MSME capabilities.
The objectives of VDPs are to systematically organize focused buyer-seller meets to foster direct engagement between MSMEs and CPSEs, State PSUs, Large & Mega industries.
VDP objectives include promoting inclusive procurement by supporting the 25% sourcing mandate from MSEs, 4% from SC/ST-owned, and 3% from women-owned enterprises.
VDP objectives include raising awareness among MSMEs about public procurement policies, reserved products, and price preference schemes.
VDP objectives include facilitating the onboarding of MSMEs onto digital procurement platforms such as GeM and TReDS.
VDP objectives include identifying and encouraging MSMEs to substitute imports by manufacturing components/products domestically.
VDP objectives contribute to the national goal of building a self-reliant, Atmanirbhar Bharat through strengthened MSME participation.
The duration of a VDP programme is two (02) days.
Targeted participants for VDPs include MSMEs, State & Central PSUs, Large & Mega Industries, Defence Organizations, and Indian Railways.
91 VDP programmes are to be conducted across the state until FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per VDP programme is Rs. 5 lakhs.
Each VDP aims to benefit 100 MSMEs.
The District Collector is responsible for monitoring the overall progress of VDP implementation.
The District Collector is responsible for sending formal letters for mobilization of the procurement wing of shortlisted Government/Large Organizations.
The District Collector is responsible for providing necessary assistance to nearby district collectors for the mobilization of CPSEs, State PSUs, Large & Mega industries.
The District Collector is responsible for ensuring that the district meets its annual VDP target.

Implementation Partners are responsible for handling all event logistics: venue setup, catering, stage with presentation support, sound, buyer stalls, and branding.
Implementation Partners are responsible for ensuring professional branding and staging.
Implementation Partners are responsible for ensuring timely and smooth execution of the two-day programme according to quality standards.

Implementation Partners are responsible for ensuring submission of programme completion reports to AP MSME DC within 7 days of completion.
