Reverse Buyer Seller Meet (RBSM) is a key initiative to promote international trade and facilitate global market access for India's Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs).
It is a platform where selected global buyers are invited to directly engage with Indian MSMEs.
RBSMs allow for meaningful business interactions, product demonstrations, and on-the-spot negotiations.
By removing intermediaries, RBSMs offer MSMEs an opportunity to present their offerings firsthand, understand international buyer expectations, and secure export orders.
RBSMs are typically sector-focused, providing MSMEs the advantage of targeting niche global markets while gaining insights into international quality standards, packaging, and pricing benchmarks.

The initiative supports MSMEs in navigating the complexities of global trade by fostering a collaborative environment where innovation, partnerships, and business-to-business (B2B) linkages are actively encouraged.
Federation of Indian Export Organization (FIEO) is the empanelled Implementing Agency (IA) for RBSMs.
The duration of an RBSM workshop is 2-3 days.

Targeted beneficiaries for RBSMs include MSMEs engaged in manufacturing or value-added services, Export Oriented MSMEs, Industry Clusters and Associations, Technology Enabled MSMEs, Agro-based and Handicraft Units, and Women Entrepreneurs & Startups.
10 RBSMs are to be conducted by FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per RBSM workshop is Rs. 81,90,000/-.
The District Collector is responsible for monitoring the overall progress of RBSM workshops in the district and ensuring the district meets the overall target till FY 26-27.
The District Collector is responsible for facilitating coordination with industry associations, export-oriented MSME clusters, and local trade bodies.
The Nodal Officer assigned by the District Collector is responsible for ensuring overall supervision of program implementation at the locations.
The Nodal Officer is responsible for ensuring timely progress updates and submission of detailed reports and feedback of the program.
The Nodal Officer is responsible for participating in the RBSM workshop.
RAMP State Program Implementation unit (RAMP-SPIU) is responsible for preparing and finalizing the RBSM calendar.
RAMP-SPIU is responsible for overseeing implementation at all levels, ensuring adherence to standards, and monitoring KPIs.
RAMP-SPIU is responsible for reviewing implementation status and recommending fund release based on reports.
RAMP-SPIU is responsible for planning and organizing RBSMs at the districts, including venue setup, branding, banners, and logistics.
Implementing Agency (IA) is responsible for collecting and validating MSME product profiles, preparing exhibitor directories, and facilitating matchmaking between buyers and sellers.
Implementing Agency (IA) is responsible for gathering post-event data on business leads, buyer-seller interactions, and participant feedback, and reporting on the AP MSME One portal.

Implementing Agency (IA) is responsible for ensuring quality assurance and submitting workshop-wise documentation, including outcomes, photos, videos, and certified attendance records to GM-DICs/AP MSME DC within 7 days of completion, along with invoices.
Implementing Agency (IA) is responsible for supporting the documentation of success stories from the workshops.
Implementing Agency (IA) is responsible for supporting the mobilization and participation of MSME exporters.
Industry Associations are responsible for providing market trends, demand, and potential buyer interests to guide event planning and matchmaking.
Industry Associations are responsible for supporting the identification of relevant foreign buyers and facilitating introductions for meetings.
The district administration will be informed one month before mobilizing participants from respective and nearby districts for RBSMs.
The mobilization process under RBSM ensures relevant stakeholders, especially MSMEs, actively participate and benefit.
The Federation of Import Export Organisations will conduct the RBSM workshop and arrange venue and logistical support for exporters.
Post-programme activities for RBSM include submission of Attendance and Feedback forms.
Post-programme activities for RBSM include follow-up support to MSMEs.
Post-programme activities for RBSM include lead conversion monitoring.
Post-programme activities for RBSM include success story documentation.
Post-programme activities for RBSM include using an RBSM tracker to monitor MSME export orders, challenges, and feedback.

The tentative workshop curriculum for RBSM includes topics like Export Promotion Policies & Incentives, Trade Statistics and Market Access, Banking Regulations & Export Documentation, Certification & Testing Requirements, Success Stories & Buyer Interaction, and Networking & Feedback Collection.
The budget for the 2-day RBSM event is INR 81,90,000.

The 'Workshops Conducted' KPI is measured by the number of RBSM workshops conducted as per district targets/year-wise targets.

The 'Export Orders & MoUs' KPI is measured by export orders and MoUs signed post-event.

Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs) are legal rights that protect creations of the mind and innovation.
From inventions and literary works to brands and designs, IPRs ensure creators can own and control the use of their creations, thus incentivizing innovation and creativity.
For MSMEs and startups, understanding IPR is crucial as it can safeguard competitive advantages, attract investments, and open new revenue streams through licensing or commercialization.
District-level awareness workshops on Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) have been designed to enhance MSMEs' understanding of IPR.

These workshops enable MSMEs to take proactive measures to protect their ideas and business strategies, support technology upgradation, and improve their overall competitiveness through effective utilization of IPR tools.
Currently, 21 IPR workshops have been conducted across 15 districts during FY 2024â25.
M/s NIMSME, Hyderabad is the empanelled Implementing Agency (IA) for IPR workshops.
The duration of an IPR workshop is one (01) day.
Targeted beneficiaries for IPR workshops include MSMEs, Startups/Entrepreneurs.
182 IPR workshops are to be conducted until FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per IPR workshop is Rs. 1,00,000/-.
Each IPR workshop aims to benefit 50 SMEs.
The District Collector is responsible for providing administrative support and monitoring the end-to-end implementation of the workshop.
The Nodal Officer Appointed by the District Collector is responsible for supporting the IA in mobilizing MSMEs and entrepreneurs, and facilitating on-ground support for the workshops.
The Nodal Officer is responsible for overall supervision of program implementation and verifying outcomes/achievement of KPIs by implementation agencies.

Implementing Agency (IA) is responsible for developing training modules, banners, and IEC materials in line with RAMP guidelines.

Implementing Agency (IA) is responsible for coordinating on-ground execution, including venue setup, participant registration, feedback collection, and post-workshop reporting.

Implementing Agency (IA) is responsible for ensuring quality assurance and submitting workshop-wise documentation of outcomes, attendance records, and utilization certificates to the Nodal Officer/APMSMEDC within 7 days of completion.
Industrial Associations are responsible for assisting the IA/Nodal Officer in identifying MSMEs and startups that would benefit from IPR awareness and capacity building.
Industrial Associations are responsible for disseminating workshop details through their networks and encouraging participation.
Industrial Associations are responsible for supporting logistics, venue, or refreshments to increase outreach and effectiveness, where possible.
Workshop planning for IPR includes identifying and mobilizing MSMEs, startups, and aspiring entrepreneurs through DICs and Industry Associations.
Prioritize enterprises working on innovative products or with potential IP assets for IPR workshops.
Workshop planning for IPR includes arranging a suitable training venue to accommodate 50 participants with basic amenities.
Workshop planning for IPR includes arranging workshop kits (stationery, printed modules, banners, registration forms).

The IA shall submit the Completion Report, Feedback Summary, and Utilisation Certificate (UC) to AP MSME DC within 7 days of the workshop.

The tentative workshop curriculum for IPR includes topics like Understanding the Concept of IPR, Need for IPR for MSMEs, GoI Schemes and Mechanisms to Support IPR Filing, Introduction to IPR Tools, National and International IP Laws, Procedure for Registration, Fundamentals of Technology Transfer, Patenting and Patent Law, Enforcement of IPR Rights, Infringement of IPR, Impact of IPR on MSMEs and Business Growth, and Environmental & Social (E&S) Compliance and its Significance for MSMEs.
The curriculum covers fundamental concepts, legal frameworks, practical procedures, and strategic applications of Intellectual Property Rights (IPR).
It introduces key government schemes and tools that support MSMEs in protecting, managing, and commercializing their intellectual assets.

Capacity Building of Clusters/MSMEs on Modern and Green Packaging & Branding Techniques is a strategic initiative to strengthen capabilities in modern packaging and branding.
This intervention emphasizes adopting green packaging solutions, aligning with the objective of promoting the greening of MSMEs and enhancing market access under the RAMP Scheme.
In today's competitive market, modern packaging is a powerful marketing tool influencing consumer choice, ensuring compliance with international standards, and enhancing brand recognition.
With the global shift towards eco-friendly and sustainable practices, this intervention introduces MSMEs to innovative, environmentally responsible packaging techniques.

The duration of a Packaging workshop is one (01) day.
Targeted beneficiaries for Packaging workshops include MSMEs, Clusters, Startups/Entrepreneurs, SHGs/Artisans engaged in product-making and requiring packaging support.
104 Packaging workshops are to be conducted until FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per Packaging workshop is Rs. 70,000/-.

The 'Environmental & Social (E&S) Compliance' topic covers an overview of norms and a checklist for MSMEs.
Each Packaging workshop has been allocated a budget of Rs. 70,000/-, released directly to the Implementing Agency (IA).

Zero Defect Zero Effect (ZED) workshops and Certification are key interventions under the Strategic Investment Plan (SIP) for Andhra Pradesh.
This initiative promotes ZED Certification among MSMEs to enhance their global competitiveness and sustainability.
It encourages MSMEs to become MSME Champions.
The ZED (Zero Defect Zero Effect) aims to enhance manufacturing quality and environmental sustainability among MSMEs.

Implementation of ZED is proposed in two phases: Phase I focuses on awareness, handholding, and encouraging sustainable practices; Phase II supports eligible MSMEs in achieving graded certification levels (Bronze, Silver, Gold).
ZED certifications help improve competitiveness, facilitate market access, and align MSMEs with global supply chain requirements.
Implementing Agencies for ZED workshops include A Z Quality Development company, RSJ Inspection Service Ltd, Skill Express, and Financial Inclusion Facilitators.
The duration of a ZED workshop is one (01) day.
Targeted beneficiaries for ZED workshops include Existing and New MSMEs in the manufacturing sector.
1,638 ZED workshops are to be conducted by FY 2026-27.
32,760 ZED certifications are to be achieved by FY 2026-27.
The budget allocated per ZED workshop is Rs. 70,000.
Each ZED workshop aims to benefit a minimum of 50 MSMEs.

The District Collector is responsible for ensuring the district meets the overall target till FY 26-27.

Implementing Agencies are responsible for providing handholding support for MSMEs in registering for ZED certification and uploading relevant documents.
Implementing Agencies are responsible for maintaining attendance, collecting feedback, and submitting post-workshop reports.
Implementing Agencies are responsible for ensuring participation of at least 50 MSMEs in each workshop.
Implementing Agencies are responsible for ensuring a minimum of 20 ZED registrations per workshop within six months of conducting the workshop.
Implementing Agencies are responsible for arranging lunch for participants attending ZED workshops.

The tentative workshop curriculum for ZED includes topics like Overview of ZED certification and its benefits, Government incentives linked to ZED certification, Levels of ZED certification (Bronze, Silver, and Gold), Step-by-step registration process, Environmental and Social (E&S) compliance checklist, and Interactive session on real-time registration and support.

Under RAMP, Andhra Pradesh aims to strengthen MSMEs' access to finance by promoting the Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS).
TReDS is an RBI-regulated digital platform enabling MSMEs to convert their trade receivables into immediate liquidity by auctioning them to multiple financiers.
Delayed payments are a critical challenge for MSMEs, impacting their cash flow and growth potential.
The Government of India has mandated all CPSEs and companies with an annual turnover above â¹250 crore to onboard TReDS.

The Govt of Andhra Pradesh has issued G.O. Ms. No. 71 dated 05.05.2025, directing all State Public Sector Undertakings, Municipal Corporations, and State-level Autonomous Bodies/Societies to register on TReDS platforms.
By raising awareness and enabling grassroots-level adoption of TReDS through RAMP, this intervention aims to accelerate MSME growth, enhance liquidity, and ensure transparent and timely payments.
Knowledge Partners for TReDS workshops include RXIL, Invoicemart, and M1Xchange.
The duration of a TReDS workshop is one (01) day.
364 TReDS workshops are to be conducted till FY 2026-27 (182 for MSMEs, 182 for large industries).
The budget allocated per TReDS workshop is Rs. 70,000/-.
Each TReDS workshop aims to benefit 30 MSMEs.

The tentative workshop curriculum for TReDS includes topics like Introduction to TReDS, Using the User Interface, Making and Organizing Bills, Comprehending the Discounting Procedure, Documentation and Compliance, Security and Risk Management, Business Process Integration, and ESG Compliance Checklist.
The 'Introduction to TReDS' topic covers overview, platforms and benefits, eligibility criteria & registration process, and case studies.

The district administration will receive an 80% advance for each workshop, with the remaining 20% released upon submission of the Completion Report.
Nodal Officer, in coordination with the district administration, will ensure workshops are implemented within budget.

Permissible budget heads for TReDS workshops include Stationery, Printing & Branding, AV Setup, Catering (Tea + Lunch), Event Setup, Trainer Honorarium and Travel Allowances, Venue Rental, and Miscellaneous expenses.

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) for TReDS include Workshops Conducted, MSMEs/Participants Mobilized, Post-Workshop Registration/Onboarding, Utilization & Reporting Timelines, Participant Feedback, and E&S Compliance Forms Collected.
The 'Workshops Conducted' KPI is measured by the number of TReDS workshops conducted as per the approved district calendar and monthly/annual targets.
The 'MSMEs/Participants Mobilized' KPI is measured by the total number of MSMEs, vendors, and procurement officers who attended the TReDS workshop.
The 'Post-Workshop Registration/Onboarding' KPI is measured by the number of MSMEs, CPSEs/SPSEs, or Municipal Bodies that registered or initiated onboarding on the TReDS platform.
The 'Utilization & Reporting Timelines' KPI is measured by the timely submission of Utilization Certificate, Attendance List, and Completion Report (within 7 days).
The 'Participant Feedback' KPI is measured by feedback on content quality, relevance, speaker effectiveness, and usefulness of the session.
The 'E&S Compliance Forms Collected' KPI is measured by the number of correctly filled Environment & Social compliance forms submitted.
Contact details for the State Programme Implementing Unit (RAMP) and Implementing Agencies (Technical Partners) for TReDS are provided.
The RAMP Explainer is the operational backbone of Andhra Pradesh's Strategic Investment Plan under the RAMP programme.
It transforms abstract strategy into concrete action.
By clearly detailing objectives, processes, roles, timelines, budgets, and reporting formats for each intervention, the explainer ensures implementation is driven by structure.
Every section is designed to equip stakeholders with clarity and direction.
This document defines expectations precisely: what must be done, by whom, how, and by when.
It removes guesswork from execution and replaces it with accountability, timelines, and measurable outcomes.
The RAMP Explainer ensures uniformity and comparability across the state, bringing all 26 districts and 175 constituencies under a single implementation framework.
It integrates IEC, E&S compliance, feedback loops, and performance indicators into every activity.
The RAMP programme aims to unlock the full potential of the MSME sector by institutionalizing support, expanding access, and creating lasting market and credit linkages.
It recognizes MSMEs as engines of inclusive growth, job creation, and rural transformation.
With defined budgets, streamlined approval mechanisms, and real-time integration with the AP MSME One platform, this explainer empowers the state machinery to move fast and deliver consistently.
It sets a clear standard: performance is not optional, and delivery must be timely, inclusive, and outcome-oriented.
Andhra Pradesh is building a model for how MSME development should be planned, executed, and scaled.

The Government of Andhra Pradesh has approved the Andhra Pradesh Policy for establishment of Private Industrial Parks with 'Plug and Play' Industrial Infrastructure (4.0) 2024-29.
Incentives mentioned in the policy will be extended to eligible Industries as per operational guidelines to be notified separately.

The Director of Industries, A.P., requested the issuance of Operational Guidelines for the Andhra Pradesh Policy for establishment of Private Industrial Parks with 'Plug and Play' Industrial infrastructure (4.0) 2024-29.
The Government has issued Operational Guidelines for the Andhra Pradesh Policy for establishment of Private Industrial Parks with 'Plug and Play' Industrial infrastructure (4.0) 2024-29.
The Vice Chairman & Managing Director, A.P. Industrial Infrastructure Corporation Limited, A.P and the Director of Industries, A.P., shall take necessary action accordingly.
The policy is for the establishment of Private Industrial Parks with 'Plug and Play' Industrial infrastructure (4.0) for the period 2024-29.
The policy aims to promote industrialization in Andhra Pradesh by improving the 'Ease of Doing Business' and 'Speed of Doing Business'.
The Industries Sector currently contributes less than a fourth of the Gross State Value Addition (GSVA).
The state targets to push the Industries Sector's share in GSVA to up to 30% by 2047.
The state aims to create 20 lakh jobs in the manufacturing sector by 2029.
Development of world-class manufacturing clusters is a key pillar of this initiative.
The responsibility of creating infrastructure cannot be met entirely through government fiscal resources.
Private sector players with desired expertise are to be welcomed in a participatory framework.
Andhra Pradesh has been a pioneer in developing Industrial Parks through private sector participation, citing examples like Jawaharlal Nehru Pharma city, SRI City, and Brandix.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh intends to catalyze the development of 25 clusters as major industrial destinations by 2030.

This will leverage the 3 industrial corridors being established: Visakhapatnam Chennai Industrial Corridor (VCIC), Chennai Bengaluru Industrial Corridor (CBIC), and Hyderabad Bengaluru Industrial Corridor (HBIC).
The policy provides a framework for establishing industrial parks for MSME, large, and mega industries through private sector financing and operations.
The policy aims to support best-in-class operations and maintenance services, including facility management and one-stop industry service centers.
The policy intends to promote sector-specific parks (e.g., Food Processing, Life Sciences, Semiconductor, Defense and Aerospace) and country-specific parks (e.g., Japanese Cluster, Korean Cluster).
The operational guidelines detail the implementation steps, frameworks, and mechanisms for private players to seek government support and incentives.
The scheme is applicable throughout the State of Andhra Pradesh.
The scheme covers projects commencing Commercial Production on or after October 26, 2024, and on or before October 25, 2029 (inclusive).
APICDA refers to Andhra Pradesh Industrial Corridor Development Authority, notified under 'The Andhra Pradesh Industrial Corridor Development Act, 2017'.
APIIC refers to Andhra Pradesh Industrial Infrastructure Corporation Limited, established in 1973.
APMSMEDC refers to Andhra Pradesh Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises Development Corporation Limited.
Commencement of Operations refers to the commencement of commercial production/service of a unit.

Common Internal Infrastructure includes facilities within an Industrial Park shared by Industrial Units, such as internal roads, drainage, streetlights, water distribution, electricity/energy/gas distribution, communication networks, effluent treatment plants, and common facilities centers.

Completion of Industrial Park means at least 50% of the land for Industrial Activity is sold/leased, with units occupying 50% of that area commencing operations, and at least 50% of the total Fixed Capital Investment (excluding land) is incurred.
Developer means any individual, company, LLP, society, trust, partnership firm, PSU, or other entity that proposes to develop or develop and operate Industrial Parks.
DPR means a detailed project report, with contents prescribed by APIIC, APMSMEDC, or the Executing Agency.

Estimated Project Cost includes fixed capital investment in building and infrastructure (excluding land), cost of external infrastructure (road, water, gas, rail, power connectivity up to the park boundary), and cost of land as approved in the DPR.
Facilities of Industrial Parks under the Policy are those present within the parks to be eligible for policy benefits, including those mentioned in Paras 4.5, 6.1.1, and 6.1.3.
Flatted Factory Complex (FFC) is a multi-story industrial building divided into smaller units for various businesses, located on more than 0.5 acre.
Financial Year refers to a year beginning April 1 and ending March 31 of the succeeding year.
GoAP refers to the Government of Andhra Pradesh.
Government Land refers to all lands belonging to Government Departments and state autonomous organizations.
IALA refers to the Industrial Area Local Authority.
Industrial Activity includes manufacturing, software development, IT-enabled services, and other services.
Industrial Park is a developed industrial area for manufacturing/service units, potentially including plots, residential/commercial establishments, warehousing, and common internal infrastructure.
Industrial Unit is a unit located in an Industrial Park, assessable for tax, and carrying out Industrial Activity.
Large Parks cover a minimum area of 100 Acres and up to 1,000 Acres of contiguous land.
Legal Status refers to the legal entity of the Developer at the time of DPR submission.
Mega Parks cover a minimum gross area of more than 1,000 Acres of contiguous land.
MSME Parks are spread over 10 to 100 Acres of contiguous land, with most allotments to MSME units, and may include anchor units.
Nano Parks are spread over less than 10 Acres of contiguous land, and Flatted Factory Complexes up to 10 Acres are also considered Nano Parks.
Private Industrial Parks Policy with Plug & Play Industrial Infrastructure (4.0) 2024-2029 is the policy issued vide G.O. Ms. No. 67, dated October 26, 2024.
Single Desk Portal refers to the portal set up under the Andhra Pradesh Single Desk Policy 2015.
State Investment Promotion Board (SIPB) is a committee formulated by the Government of Andhra Pradesh.
State Investment Promotion Committee (SIPC) is a committee formulated by the Government of Andhra Pradesh.
The Government shall notify existing and upcoming Industrial Parks under the AP Industrial Corridor Development Act, 2017.
For Private Industrial Parks approved under the 2024-29 policy, notification may occur after the Developer receives a unique Private Industrial Park Development Approval Order Number.
Layouts of approved Industrial Parks shall be approved expeditiously by APICDA or the concerned Urban Development Authority without fees.
Private Mega Industrial Parks and select Private Large Industrial Parks are eligible for IALA status.

The Operational Guidelines cover locations that can be developed into Industrial Parks, including notified industrial zones, areas with potential for industrial zones, and locations outside urban limits.
The guidelines specify minimum area requirements for Nano (less than 10 Acres), MSME (10-100 Acres), Large (100-1,000 Acres), and Mega (more than 1,000 Acres) Parks.
Only Industrial Parks formed under Model-I, Model-II, or Model-III with a Private Industrial Park Development Approval Order are eligible for incentives and capital subsidy.
The guidelines are also applicable for Sector Specific Industrial Parks with private sector participation.

Components of Industrial Parks eligible for incentives include Land, Processing Area (common infrastructure, industrial plots, factory buildings, common facilities buildings), and Non-processing/Social Infrastructure (max 33% of total area, with social infrastructure not exceeding 10%).
Project Cost for the policy includes components under Group B (Processing Area).
Parks with processing units in sectors like Textile and Leather must have a CETP.
The policy promotes Plug n Play Industrial Parks and Flatted Factory Sheds, especially in Nano and MSME Parks.

Essential components of Plug n Play facilities include readily available roads, sewerage connection, electrical lines, water connection, natural gas pipeline (where applicable), utility service-fire hydrants line, commercial center, skill development center, and bank/ATM facility.
Model â I: Industrial Park Development with complete private land involves the Private Developer acquiring or pooling land and developing the park.
APMSMEDC is the nodal agency for Nano Parks, MSME Parks, and Flatted Factory Complexes under Model-I.
APIIC is the nodal agency for Large and Mega Parks under Model-I.
Proposals under Model-I need to be submitted online with a Detailed Project Report.
A maximum of 3 Nano Parks/Flatted Factory Complexes can be notified per Mandal under Model-I.

Proposals for Nano Parks under Model-I are ranked based on evaluation metrics including land details, road connectivity, water source availability, electrical substation availability, prior experience, and promoter's government ownership.
A maximum of 3 MSME Parks can be notified per Mandal under Model-I.
Proposals for MSME Parks under Model-I are ranked based on similar evaluation metrics as Nano Parks, with adjusted land extent criteria.
A maximum of 4 Large Parks can be notified per District under Model-I.

Proposals for Large Parks under Model-I are ranked based on land details, road connectivity, water source availability, electrical substation availability, port connectivity, airport connectivity, existing industrial ecosystem, experience in park development, experience in operations and maintenance, and promoter's government ownership.
A maximum of 2 Mega Parks can be notified per District under Model-I.
Proposals for Mega Parks under Model-I are ranked based on similar evaluation metrics as Large Parks, with adjusted land extent and connectivity criteria.

Proposals for Model-I parks may be rejected if they are within 10 km of an Eco Sensitive Zone, within Coastal Regulation Zone, have NH/SH/MDR/river passing through, or have land affected by mining activity.

Project Proposal Submission and Approval Mechanism for Private Nano/Flatted Factory Complex/MSME Industrial Parks under Model-I involves online submission, scrutiny by District Level Scrutiny-Cum-Verification Committee (SVC), evaluation by District Industries and Export Promotion Committee (DIEPC), appraisal by Industrial Park Evaluation Committee (IPEC), and concurrence from Finance Department.
Approved proposals are notified under the Andhra Pradesh Industrial Corridor Development Act, 2017.
Timelines for approval of Private Nano and MSME Industrial Park proposals under Model-I are provided.

Post-Approval Order issuance process for Nano/MSME Parks under Model-I includes submitting building permit applications, starting construction, applying for completion certificate, and annual progress reviews.
Private Industrial Park Development Approval Orders are liable to cancellation if no substantial development occurs within two years.

Project Proposal Submission and Approval Mechanism for Private Large/Mega Industrial Parks under Model-I involves similar steps as Nano/MSME parks, with APIIC as the nodal agency for IPEC and proposals moving to SIPC, SIPB, and State Cabinet for approvals.

Model - II: Industrial Park Development with Partial Government / APIIC Land involves the Private Developer acquiring land and seeking government support to consolidate government lands for contiguity.
Conditions for Model-II include handing over proportionate developed land/built-up area to the government, and allotments to industrial units being as per prevailing regulations.
A Joint Development Agreement will be signed between the Developer and the Government Counterparty.
The Government can allot up to 40% of the gross land requirement if the title is with the Government or its agencies.
If government land transfer involves Resettlement and Rehabilitation (R&R) issues, the Private Developer must pay the amount required by the District Collector in advance.
Model-II proposals for Nano Parks and Flatted Factory Complexes are evaluated by APMSMEDC based on a marking scheme (Table 5).
Model-II proposals for MSME Parks are evaluated by APMSMEDC based on a marking scheme (Table 6).
Model-II proposals for Large Parks are evaluated by APIIC based on a marking scheme (Table 7).
Model-II proposals for Mega Parks are evaluated by APIIC based on a marking scheme (Table 8).
Model - III: Industrial Park Development with complete Government / APIIC Land involves the private sector developing parks on 100% government land in PPP mode.
Private Developers are selected through a competitive bidding process for all park types under Model-III.
A Transaction Advisor will be appointed by APIIC/APMSMEDC to manage the bidding process.
The selected Private Developer will enter into an Agreement with the Government Counterparty for project development activities.
IPEC of APIIC and APMSMEDC will shortlist potential land banks for PPP development and receive representations from other departments with land banks.
The Developer Selection Process under Model-III can follow a Single Stage or Two Stage Bidding Process.

A two-stage bidding process (Expression of Interest (EoI) cum Request for Qualification (RFQ) and Request for Proposal (RFP)) will be followed for Nano, Flatted Factory Sheds, and MSME Parks under Model-III.
A two-stage bidding process will be followed by APIIC for Large and Mega Parks under Model-III.

Procedure for land pooling involves aggregating contiguous lands, executing a Registered Irrevocable Development Agreement-cum-General Power of Attorney, and allotting reconstituted plots to original landowners.
The land pooling scheme may include provisions for laying out land, streets/roads, public spaces, lighting, and internal water supply.
The layout of the Industrial Park shall comply with prevailing AP DTCP norms.
Developers using the Land Pooling method need to upload specific documents related to land aggregation.
In case of disputes between Landowners and Developers under the Land Pooling Model, if timelines are exceeded, the Approval Order and land registration shall be cancelled.
The Government/APIIC/APMSMEDC has no role in resolving Land Pooling disputes beyond providing the Approval Order.

Stakeholder roles and responsibilities are defined for District Level Scrutiny-Cum-Verification Committee (SVC), District Industries and Export Promotion Committee (DIEPC), Industrial Park Evaluation Committee (IPEC), SIPC & SIPB, and the Developer.
The SVC scrutinizes proposals under Model-I and Model-II to ensure documentation is complete for DIEPC review.
The DIEPC analyzes proposals, confirms feasibility with line departments, coordinates land verification, and provides comments for IPEC.
The DIEPC validates information for the Evaluation Matrix used by IPEC.
The composition of the SVC and DIEPC is specified.
The IPEC grades proposals under Model-I and Model-II and supervises bid process management under Model-III.
IPEC issues Private Industrial Park Development Approval Orders for Nano, Flatted Factory Complexes, and MSME Parks.
For Large and Mega Parks, Approval Orders are issued after SIPC and SIPB approval.

IPEC is responsible for overall scheme implementation, recommending proposals to SIPC/SIPB, monitoring progress, granting approvals, notifying parks, recommending land use conversion exemptions, providing composite approvals, addressing policy issues, facilitating external infrastructure, and developing an online monitoring mechanism.
The members of the IPEC for APMSMEDC and APIIC are listed.
SIPC & SIPB review and approve proposals for Large and Mega Parks before the Development Approval Order is issued.

Developer responsibilities include procuring land (Model-I & II), preparing DPR, achieving Financial Closure, obtaining statutory approvals, developing internal infrastructure, recruiting professionals, fixing prices and allotting sites, maintaining utilities, adhering to legal compliances, furnishing progress reports, marketing the park, and indemnifying government agencies.

Implementing Agencies include Industries & Commerce Department, Andhra Pradesh Industrial Corridor Development Authority, Directorate of Town and Country Planning, Revenue Department, Municipal Administration and Urban Development Dept., Roads & Building Dept., Water Resources Dept./Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Dept., Energy Dept./AP DISCOMs, and Andhra Pradesh Pollution Control Board.

These agencies are responsible for policy steering, land allotment facilitation, developer selection, statutory clearances, park notification, dovetailing central government schemes, fulfilling external infrastructure commitments, and disbursing incentives.

General Guidelines for claiming incentives as upfront exemption include up to 100% exemption of Conversion Charges, Change of Land Use charges, Layout Approval charges, and Stamp Duty and Registration Charges for land pooling.
The DIEPC validates the extent of land for conversion and the exemption amount.
IPEC approves the exemption amount on a case-to-case basis.
Revenue Department and MA&UD Department issue Government Orders notifying the waived charges within 15 days of the Approval Order issuance.
Failure of the departments to issue the G.O. within 15 days results in 'deemed approval' for exemption.
Validity Period of Upfront Incentives is linked to the completion timelines for various park types (Nano/FFC: 2 years, MSME/Large: 3 years, Mega: as per government decision).
Failure to meet timelines can lead to revocation of G.O.s for conversion, stamp duty, registration, change of land use, and layout approval exemptions.
Procedure for claiming Capital Subsidy involves applications filed online, examination by IPEC, verification by DIEPC, and disbursement based on milestones.
Maximum Capital Subsidy limits are Rs. 5 lakh/acre for Nano/MSME Parks/FFCs and Rs. 3 lakh/acre for Large/Mega Parks.
Milestones for Capital Subsidy disbursement are defined for Nano/MSME Parks and Large/Mega Parks, including project approval, 25% progress, 75% progress, 100% completion, and operational park status.
Developed Area means Gross Area developed by the Developer, and Area Allotted means net saleable area allotted by the Developer.
Applications for Capital Subsidy are examined for land extent proposed/allotted/reserved/sold/leased/gifted for captive usage, with proportionate reduction from subsidy calculation if applicable.
The total subsidy amount eligible is mentioned in the Private Industrial Park Development Approval Order.
Developers must ensure construction specifications are equivalent or higher than APIIC mandates.
The amount due to the Developer for Capital Subsidy is released based on verified area development or allotments.
A Chartered Accountant Certificate certifying the extent of gross area developed or net saleable area allotted is required for subsidy claims.
The DIEPC or nominated members conduct field inspections to verify claims.
Rejection of claims must be clearly stated with reasons and reflected on the website.
Grievance redressal authority for Capital Subsidy claims is the office of the Commissioner of Industries, Govt. of Andhra Pradesh.
Interpretation of scheme provisions rests with the Department of Industries & Commerce / APIIC / APMSMEDC or the Government of Andhra Pradesh.
The format and content of Annexures I to V and IX are indicative and subject to change.

Annexure â I details the Components of a Detailed Project Report, including location suitability, proposed activity, land availability, clearances, anchor units, project cost, funding, physical facilities, implementing agency, gestation period, benefits quantification, sustainability issues, financial viability, and master plan.

Pulses are a significant source of nutrition and protein, especially for vegetarians in India.
India is the world's largest producer and consumer of pulses, but faces a production-demand gap, leading to imports.
Lack of proper post-harvest processing facilities contributes to significant annual losses in pulses.
The project aims to establish a Common Facility Centre (CFC) with advanced machinery to minimize processing losses and improve product quality.
The CFC will include pre-processing, post-processing, storage, testing, training, and research facilities.
The estimated cost of the CFC is Rs. 1483.06 Lakhs, with contributions from the Government of India (80%), Government of Andhra Pradesh (10%), and the Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) (10%).
The SPV, Sri Mahalakshmi Pulses Mills Cluster Association, is located in Rayavaram Mandal, East Godavari District.
The cluster has 119 Micro Units employing approximately 595 people directly and 1500 indirectly, with an estimated turnover of Rs. 77.00 Crores for 2018-19.
The project is considered technically feasible and financially viable.

Milestones already covered include SPV formation, bank account opening, land lease agreement, DPR preparation and approval, in-principle approval from MSME New Delhi, electrical load sanction, NOC from Pollution Control Board, working capital letter, micro certificate from DIC, and commitment letter from SPV.
The project's financial ratios (IRR, NPV, Breakeven Point, ROCE) are projected to meet or exceed MSE-CDP guidelines.

Expected outcomes of the project include an increase in the number of units, employment, product quality, market reach (urban, national, international), turnover, and a reduction in processing losses.
The implementation of the project is expected to take about 18 months.
East Godavari District is located in Coastal Andhra, with Kakinada as its headquarters.
The district has a significant agricultural base, with paddy being the main crop.
East Godavari District has a well-developed industrial sector, including manufacturing and construction.
The district has a core road network of 1,274.067 km and a rail network of 171.34 km.
The nearest airport to Kakinada is at Rajahmundry (65 km).
Pulses are important crops globally, providing protein, fiber, vitamins, minerals, and contributing to soil health.
Global pulse production has grown significantly, with India being the largest producer.
India imports a substantial quantity of pulses to meet domestic demand.
Pulses are a price-sensitive commodity in India, with substitutability between different pulse crops.
The Indian government has implemented measures like export bans and duty reductions to manage pulse prices and availability.
Global pulse production has shown an increasing trend, with Asia being the largest producing continent.
Dry beans, chickpeas, and dry peas are the most produced pulses globally.
India's pulse production is primarily concentrated in states like Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, and Karnataka.
Pulses are mostly cultivated under rain-fed conditions in India, often on marginal lands.
The productivity of pulses in India is lower compared to countries like the USA and Canada.
The UN declared 2016 as the International Year of Pulses, acknowledging their importance for food security, nutrition, and environmental sustainability.
Pulses are considered 'Smart Food' due to their nutritional benefits and environmental advantages.
Andhra Pradesh is a significant pulse-growing state in India.
East Godavari District is a major agricultural district, known as the 'rice bowl of Andhra Pradesh'.
Pulses are grown in East Godavari District, including black gram, green gram, and red gram.
Pulses provide essential nutrients and have health benefits, including improving heart health, lowering the risk of diabetes, and being a good source of protein and folate.
The world pulse trade involves approximately 16% of global production, with Canada being a leading exporter and India a leading importer.
Dry peas, dry beans, lentils, and chickpeas are major traded pulse products globally.
Quality standards and testing for pulses are governed by BIS, FSSAI, and Codex standards.
Key quality factors for pulses include moisture content, extraneous matter, toxic/noxious seeds, contaminants, pesticide residues, mycotoxins, hygiene, packaging, and labeling.
The Sri Mahalakshmi Pulses Mills Cluster faces challenges due to the adoption of age-old technologies, leading to variations in output quality and significant wastage.
The cluster lacks grading, sorting, polishing, and testing facilities, as well as dedicated storage and marketing mechanisms.

Hard interventions recommended for the cluster include establishing a CFC with automatic dryers, cleaning and grading machines, color sorters, polishing machines, a common packaging center, a testing facility, a common marketing and export center, cold storage, a value-added product development center, and a research and training center.

The SWOT analysis of the cluster highlights strengths in unit collaboration and input availability, weaknesses in technological backwardness and lack of skill upgradation, opportunities in market expansion and institutional support, and threats from competition and improper policies.
The project financials indicate that the CFC is a viable and support-worthy project.
The projected revenue and capacity utilization figures are provided for the years 2020-2030.
The breakeven analysis indicates that the project is financially sound.
The projected profit and loss, cash flow statement, and balance sheet are presented for the project's operational period.
The Internal Rate of Return (IRR) and Net Present Value (NPV) calculations demonstrate the project's financial attractiveness.
The Return on Capital Employed (ROCE) and other financial ratios are projected to be favorable.
The project's success is crucial for addressing the demand-supply gap in pulses, improving farmer incomes, and contributing to the socio-economic development of the region.

A Detailed Project Report (DPR) has been prepared for the 'Setting up of Common Facility Centre' for the Srikakulam Food Processing Cluster in Andhra Pradesh.
The Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) for this project is Sunrise Nature Foods Foundation, located in Srikakulam District, Andhra Pradesh.
The Implementing Agency is the Andhra Pradesh MSME Development Corporation.
The Technical Agency is the Foundation for MSME Clusters.
The DPR was submitted in December 2022.
The DPR was submitted to the Development Commissioner â MSME, Ministry of MSME, Government of India, New Delhi.

The DPR includes sections on Executive Summary, Project at a Glance, Progress so far, Schedule of Implementation, Introduction, The Proposal, Management & Share Holding Pattern, Common Medical Diagnostic Centre, Analysis of Project Economics, Stake Holder Consultation & Meetings, and Institutional, Project Monitoring & Financial Mechanisms.
Srikakulam District is located in the northeastern part of Andhra Pradesh.
The district is a significant producer of fruits in Andhra Pradesh.
There are approximately 408 micro-scale units in the Srikakulam district involved in seasonal food processing.
These units face challenges due to the lack of infrastructure for processing and storing produce, affecting operational periods and price realization.
A Common Facility Centre (CFC) is proposed to address these issues.
24 micro firms have formed a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) named Sunrise Nature Foods Foundation under the Companies Act, 2013 (Section 8) to establish the CFC.
The proposed CFC will be a Food Processing Facility operating on a self-sustainable mode.
Currently, 408 units are involved in the primary processing (ripening, sorting, grading, storage) of Sweet Corn, Mango, Pineapple, Jack Fruit, and Custard apple, operating seasonally.
The food processing units lack basic infrastructure and proper equipment, necessitating a Common Food Processing Centre.
The proposed facility will include processing lines for ripening, retorting, freezing (quick & blast), canning, and pulping.

Identified issues include the primary processing nature of firms, high investment for advanced technology, significant produce loss due to improper handling and lack of storage, and seasonal availability limiting investment.
The SPV, 'M/s. Sunrise Nature Foods Foundation', is registered under the Companies Act, 2013 (18 of 2013) as a company limited by share.
The SPV allows for enrolling new members and has obtained written commitments from 'users' of the proposed facilities.
No single unit holds more than 10% equity in the SPV, adhering to MSECDP guidelines.
The CFC management will have a three-tier structure: Board of Directors, Technical Staff, and Secretarial Staff.
The Board of Directors is the governing body, assisted by technical and secretarial staff.
The Chairman and Managing Director will oversee operations, with directors assigned specific responsibilities.
The facility will have its own technical staff as per requirements and guidelines.
A qualified person will be appointed as CEO to manage day-to-day operations, reporting to the Board of Directors.

There is no Term Loan for this project.
The beneficiaries will bear the cost of part of the machinery, building & civil works, contingencies, consultancy fees, and preliminary & pre-operative expenses as their equity.
The State Government will contribute to part of the machinery and building costs.
The GoI grant will cover a portion of the machinery cost.
The proposed project is designed to be self-sustainable, generating revenue from service (testing) charges.
Operations are expected to start from April 1st of the financial year 2024-25.

The production process for Sweet Corn Retort involves cleaning, husking, silking, inspection, cutting, washing, filling and brining, seaming, retort, cooling, and packaging.

The production process for Frozen Sweet Corn involves reception, peeling, kernel extraction, washing, inspection and sorting, blanching, cooling, removal of excess water, freezing (IQF), weighing and packing, and storage.

The production process for Frozen Mango Dices involves ripening, selection, washing, peeling and cutting, blanching & cooling, treatment (sugar solution dipping), packing and sealing, quick freeze, inspection and packing, and storage.

The production process for Pineapple Canning involves ripening, cleaning, inspection & grading, peeling & removing pith, filling and syrup process, exhausting, sealing, sterilize, cooling & drying, and storage.
The production process for Custard Apple Pulp involves raw material reception, sorting, removal of skin, pulping, blast freezing, and storage.

The document is the Revised Strategic Investment Plan (SIP) of Andhra Pradesh under the RAMP Program.
It was submitted by the AP MSME Development Corporation, Government of Andhra Pradesh.

The document contains an Executive Summary, Chapter 1: RAMP - An Overview, Chapter 2: SIP- Approach & Methodology, Chapter 3: Diagnostic Study â Key Challenges and Gaps in the MSME Ecosystem in the State of Andhra Pradesh, Chapter 4: Proposed Projects under Strategic Investment Plan (SIP), and Chapter 5: Impact of RAMP Programme on the Development of MSME Sector in Andhra Pradesh.
It also includes Annexures and a Disclaimer.
The RAMP (Raising and Accelerating MSME Performance) Scheme is a central government initiative supported by the World Bank.
The scheme aims to revitalize the Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSME) industry in India following the COVID-19 pandemic.
It is expected to benefit approximately 1.5 million MSMEs and contribute to employment generation, increased productivity, and skill development.
The total outlay for the RAMP scheme is INR 6,062.45 crore, with INR 3,750 crore as a loan from the World Bank and INR 2,312.45 crore contributed by the Indian government.

The primary objective of RAMP is to enhance the performance of 555,000 MSMEs by improving market access, facilitating credit availability, strengthening institutions, fostering collaboration between central and state governments, addressing delayed payments, promoting sustainable business practices, and expanding the reach of existing MSME schemes.
The Strategic Investment Plan (SIP) is an important component of RAMP and includes an outreach plan for identification and mobilization of MSMEs under RAMP.
The SIP for Andhra Pradesh was prepared through a systematic process involving desktop research/secondary research and primary research.
Primary research included field surveys, personal interviews, and focused group discussions.
The diagnostic study identified key challenges and gaps in the MSME ecosystem in Andhra Pradesh.
18 project proposals have been prepared with an overall budget of INR 432.74 Cr.
The Central Government contribution is INR 59.67 Cr., the State Government contribution is INR 41.99 Cr., and INR 331.08 Cr. is proposed to be funded through the RAMP fund.

The projects are categorized into 6 categories: Formalisation & Promotion of MSMEs, Entrepreneurship & Skill Development, Market Access & Support, Strengthening Receivables market and reduction of delayed payment, Improving MSME Competitiveness, Enhancing Credit support, and Strengthening Monitoring & Evaluation and Implementation Support framework for RAMP implementation.
RAMP supports the overall Covid Resilience and Recovery Programme of MoMSME.

RAMP aims at improving market access, access to credit, strengthening institutions and governance at the Centre and State, improving Centre-State linkages and partnerships, addressing issues of delayed payments, and greening of MSMEs.
RAMP is a World Bank supported Central Sector Scheme of GoI.

The scheme supports interventions in MSME institutional strengthening, convergence of State-level schemes through SIPs, firm competitiveness schemes, strengthening the receivables financing market, enhancing the effectiveness of the Credit Guarantee Trust for Micro and Small Enterprises, and addressing delayed payments through online dispute resolution.
RAMP will directly or indirectly benefit all 63 million enterprises that qualify as MSMEs.
A total of 5,55,000 MSMEs are specifically targeted for enhanced performance, with a target to include service sectors and 70,500 women MSMEs.
RAMP aims to be a job-enabler, market promoter, finance facilitator, and will support vulnerable sections and greening initiatives.
RAMP is designed in accordance with the World Bank Programme for Results (P for R) instrument.
World Bank funds under RAMP are provided to the Ministry on achievement of Disbursement Linked Indicators (DLIs).

The Programme has identified two results areas: Result Area#1: Strengthening Institutions and Governance of the MSME Programme, and Result Area#2: Support to market access, firm capabilities, and access to finance.

The six DLIs are: Implementing the National MSME Reform Agenda, Accelerating MSME Sector Centre-State collaboration, Enhancing effectiveness of MSME CHAMPIONS Scheme, Strengthening Receivable Financing Market for MSMEs, Enhancing Effectiveness of CGTMSE and Greening and Gender delivery, and Reducing the incidence of delayed payments.

A diagnostic study was undertaken as part of making the strategic investment plan (SIP) in Andhra Pradesh.
The methodology adopted was a mix of desktop research and primary research.
Desktop research involved collecting data from various government departments and published documents.
Primary research involved devising a survey plan with shortlisted respondents and data collection modes.
Questionnaires were administered to individual MSMEs, industry and trade associations, MSME-related government departments/organizations, and banks/FIs/SLBC.
A total of 2146 responses were received.
Personal interviews were conducted with representatives from key MSME institutions.
Focused Group Discussions (FGDs) were conducted to gain insights into regional and cluster-level issues.
A validation workshop was conducted to discuss pertinent issues and for broader consultations on the SIP.

Summary of Observations and Inferences from the research includes low Udyam registration, lower MSME growth rate compared to India, declining share of MSMEs, need to focus on larger employment size establishments, higher growth in urban areas, importance of specific sectors for intervention, need for women and SC/ST entrepreneurship promotion, low access to formal finance, stagnant contribution of key economic sectors to GSDP, and issues with delayed payments.

Summary of Field Survey indicates that Sri Satya Sai district elicited the highest response, while Guntur and Kakinada districts had the least.
MSMEs with less than INR 25 lakh turnover were more responsive to the survey.
The response from MSMEs was approximately in proportion to the distribution of Micro, Small, and Medium enterprises in AP.

Qualitative analysis of survey responses highlights the need for more government support, awareness of schemes, relevance of RAMP components like ZED and Lean, demand for schemes like CGTMSE and TReDS, expectations from the RAMP scheme, and interest from women and SC/ST entrepreneurs.
Technology needs include modernizing digital technology for processing incentives and educating entrepreneurs on global developments.
Marketing challenges include developing local markets and tying up with online marketing agencies.

Access to finance issues include banker sensitization, high CGTMSE service charges, reluctance of financial institutions, underutilization of collateral-free loans, demand for hypothecation of clear title deeds, need for banker support for new entrepreneurs, SLBC directions to bankers, flexible loan criteria, and special focus on SC/ST/OBC/Women entrepreneurs.
Infrastructure constraints include difficulty in land allocation for MSEs.

Other major issues include availability of skilled workmen, difficulty in obtaining licenses due to illiteracy, procurement of raw materials, lack of technical know-how updates, competition from larger units in marketing, and the need for referral programs.
