The Andhra Pradesh Policy for establishment of Private Industrial Parks with 'Plug and Play' Industrial Infrastructure (4.0) 2024-29 is approved by the Government of Andhra Pradesh.
The policy aims to promote industrial growth, employment, and investment by encouraging private participation in developing industrial parks.

Key objectives include promoting world-class industrial parks, generating employment, attracting investment, enabling operation and maintenance, facilitating land pooling from farmers, and promoting sector-specific parks.

The policy defines various terms such as APICDA, APIIC, APMSMEDC, Commencement of Operations, Common Internal Infrastructure, Completion of Industrial Park, Developer, DPR, Estimated Project Cost, Flatted Factory Complex (FFC), Financial Year, GoAP, IALA, Industrial Activity, Industrial Park, Facilities of the Industrial Parks, Industrial Unit, Large Parks, Mega Parks, Legal Status, MSME, MSME Parks, Single Desk Portal, and Nano or Tiny Parks.

The scope of the policy covers different sizes of industrial parks: Nano or Tiny Parks (less than 10 Acres), MSME Parks (10-100 Acres), Large Parks (100-1,000 Acres), and Mega Parks (more than 1,000 Acres).
The policy promotes Plug n Play Industrial Parks and Flatted Factory Sheds, especially in Nano and MSME Parks.

The policy also applies to the development of Sector Specific Industrial Parks like Biotechnology Park, Pharmaceutical Park, Toy Park, Electric Vehicles Park, Semiconductor Park, Defence and Aerospace Park, Food Processing Parks, Leather Parks, Textiles Parks, and others.
Desirable and 'Good to Have' facilities within Industrial Parks are listed.
The policy outlines models for Industrial Park Development: complete private land, partial government/APIIC land, and complete government/APIIC land.

Incentives and subsidies for Private Nano or Tiny and MSME Parks include exemptions on Conversion Charges, Change of Land Use, Layout Approval, Stamp Duty, and Registration Charges, as well as a Capital Subsidy of up to Rs. 5 lakhs per acre.

Incentives and subsidies for Private Large Industrial Parks and Mega Industrial Parks include similar exemptions and a Capital Subsidy of up to Rs. 3 lakhs per acre, with a phase-wise release schedule.
The policy encourages the development of industrial housing and hostels for employees.
Stakeholder Departments like MA&UD, Roads & Buildings, Water Resources, DISCOMs, APPCB, etc., have defined roles in facilitating private industrial park development.
APIIC/APMSMEDC will act as the nodal agency for policy implementation.
An Industrial Parks Evaluation Committee will be constituted to finalize the External Infra Support Plan and recommend proposals for approval.
Approved Parks will be notified under the Andhra Pradesh Industrial Corridor Development Act, 2017.
Operating guidelines for the policy will be issued separately.
The Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Policy (4.0) 2024-29 is operationalized through G.O.Ms.No.68, Industries & Commerce (P&I) Department, dated 26.10.2024.
The Andhra Pradesh MSME & Entrepreneur Development Policy, 4.0 (2024-29) is operationalized through G.O.Ms.No.69, Industries & Commerce (Prog.I) Department, dated 26.10.2024.
The Andhra Pradesh Food Processing Policy (4.0) 2024-29 is operationalized through G.O.Ms.No.71, Industries & Commerce (Prog.III) Department, dated 26.10.2024.
The Andhra Pradesh Sustainable Electric Mobility Policy (SMEP) (4.0) 2024-29 was amended by G.O.Ms.No.21, Industries & Commerce (P&I) Department, dated 17.02.2025.
Amendments/additions to the Andhra Pradesh MSME and Entrepreneur Development Policy 4.0 (2024-29) were issued via G.O.Ms.No.22, Industries & Commerce (Prog.I) Department, dated 17.02.2025.
Amendments/additions to the New Andhra Pradesh Food Processing Policy (4.0) 2024-29 were issued via G.O.Ms.No.23, Industries & Commerce (Prog.III) Department, dated 17.02.2025.
The Director of Industries, A.P., Mangalagiri, prepared operational guidelines after stakeholder and inter-departmental consultations.

The Government approved the Operational Guidelines for the Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Policy (4.0) 2024-29, Andhra Pradesh MSME & Entrepreneur Development Policy, 4.0 (2024-29), and Andhra Pradesh Food Processing Policy (4.0) 2024-29.
The Finance Department concurred with the proposal via U.O.No. FIN01-FMUOPC(IC)/1/2025 dt: 18.02.2025.
The Director of Industries is requested to upgrade the existing incentives portal, integrating AI-enabled deep technology measures for smooth processing of incentive claims.
The Commissionerate of Industries is the nodal agency for implementing IDP 4.0 and MEDP 4.0.
The AP Food Processing Society is the nodal agency for implementing FPP 4.0.
Micro Industry/Enterprise is defined by the Government of India's investment and turnover criteria, as provided in Annexure-4.
Small Industry/Enterprise is defined by the Government of India's investment and turnover criteria, as provided in Annexure-4.
Medium Industry/Enterprise is defined by the Government of India's investment and turnover criteria, as provided in Annexure-4.
Sub-Large Industry/Enterprise has a fixed capital investment between INR 50 Cr and INR 500 Cr for IDP 4.0.
Large Industry/Enterprise has a fixed capital investment between INR 500 Cr and INR 1,000 Cr for IDP 4.0.
Large Industry/Enterprise has a fixed capital investment between INR 50 Cr and INR 100 Cr for FPP 4.0.
Mega Industry/Enterprise has a fixed capital investment between INR 1,000 Cr and INR 5,000 Cr for IDP 4.0.
Mega Industry/Enterprise has a fixed capital investment greater than INR 100 Cr for FPP 4.0.
Ultra Mega Industry/Enterprise has a fixed capital investment greater than INR 5,000 Cr for IDP 4.0.

The Government will extend tailor-made benefits to Mega and above industries/enterprises based on specific investment requirements and impact on the state's industrial growth and employment generation.
Farmer Producer Organisation/Company definition is adopted from the Department of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare, Government of India.
Self Help Groups definition is adopted from the National Rural Livelihoods Mission (NRLM) and National Urban Livelihoods Mission (NULM).
Cooperative Society definition is adopted from the Ministry of Cooperation, Government of India.
Primary processing activity involves basic steps to prepare raw materials for consumption or further processing.
Secondary processing activity involves converting raw or minimally processed ingredients into value-added food products.
Tertiary processing activity involves producing highly processed foods ready for consumption.
IDP 4.0, MEDP 4.0, and FPP 4.0 cover projects commencing commercial production between 26.10.2024 and 25.10.2029.
The policy operating period is from 26.10.2024 to 25.10.2029, inclusive.
An Industrial Enterprise is any industrial undertaking, excluding those run departmentally by Government or having government equity, and those listed in Annexure-I.
Enterprises receiving Consent for Operation (CFO) or commencing commercial production within the policy operating period are eligible for incentives.

A New Industrial Enterprise is one with the intent and willingness to invest in the state with new machinery and has received CFO or commenced commercial production within the policy operating period.
Expansion/Modernization Projects involve existing enterprises enhancing Fixed Capital Investment by at least 25% and capacity by 25% for the same product lines.
Expansion projects require an additional 15% enhancement in employment from the base (last three years average) and employment must be in Andhra Pradesh.

Diversification Projects involve existing enterprises investing in a new product, with at least a 25% enhancement in new fixed capital investment and turnover, and at least a 15% enhancement in employment.
Fixed Capital Investment includes investment in land, building, plant, machinery, and equipment.
For Sub-Large and above investments, eligible FCI is investment in Plant, Machinery, and Equipment only.
For MSMEs, eligible FCI includes investment in Plant, Machinery, and Equipment, as well as costs for Land and Building.
Original Fixed Capital Investment refers to assets acquired before expansion/diversification, excluding depreciation or revaluation.
Production Capacity of the Original Enterprise/Industry is the highest annual production/turnover achieved in the preceding three financial years prior to expansion/diversification.
Tax refers to State Goods and Services Tax (SGST) paid to the Government of Andhra Pradesh Commercial Tax Department on goods produced.
Consent for Establishment (CFE) is the date of grant of consent to start civil works.
Consent for Operation (CFO) is the date from which the enterprise is permitted to operate.
Date of Commencement of Commercial Production (DCP) is the date of the first sale invoice or commencement of production as per IEM Part B.
Standard Investment Period is the continuous time from CFE to DCP.
Approved Project Cost is the cost approved by the term loan lending institution or lead institution.
Revised Project Cost for self-financed enterprises is an increase or decrease of not more than 10% by self-certification, or certified by a Chartered Accountant if more than 10%.
Verified Employment refers to direct jobs (on-roll, contractual, apprentice) calculated as the average number of employees over a 6-month period prior to claim submission.
An Aided Enterprise/Industry avails term loans from Scheduled Commercial Banks/Financial Institutions recognized by the RBI, APSFC, or SIDBI.
A Self-Financed Enterprise/Industry is set up with own funds without bank involvement, or with term loans obtained after production commencement.
BC Enterprise has 100% ownership by Backward Class community entrepreneurs.
Minority Enterprise has 100% ownership by minorities as defined by the Andhra Pradesh State Minorities Commission Act, 1998.
SC/ST Enterprise has 100% ownership by SC/ST entrepreneurs.
Women Enterprise has 100% ownership by women entrepreneurs.
Specially Abled Enterprise has 100% ownership by entrepreneurs with at least 40% disability.
Transgender Enterprise has 100% ownership by transgender entrepreneurs.
General Industries/Enterprises are those not covered under sectoral or special category policies.
Seasonal Industry operates principally during certain seasons or limited periods in a year.
Month refers to Calendar Months.
Financial Year is from April 1st to March 31st.
First Half Year is from April 1st to September 30th.
Second Half Year is from October 1st to March 31st of the next year.
MSMEs under Orange and Red categories are not eligible for end-to-end deemed approval.
End-to-end Deemed approval for MSMEs is operationalized through the Single Desk Portal.
Cost of land for FCI computation is normally five times the plinth area of the factory building, not exceeding the approved project cost.
Lease/Sale deeds must be registered in the name of the Enterprise/Industry/proprietor.
Stamp duty and Transfer duty are not considered for FCI computation.
Discounted land costs from APIIC will not be considered for eligible FCI.
Factory building value is limited to the approved project cost; leased building values are not considered.

Eligible civil works for FCI include main factory shed, warehouses, office/lab rooms, cooling water ponds, boiler/generator rooms, effluent treatment ponds, overhead tanks, bore-wells, fencing, gates, architect fees, compound walls, canteens, restrooms, stands, and toilets.
The total value of items like overhead tanks, bore-wells, fencing, etc., shall not exceed 10% of the total value of civil works (items a to g).
Plant and machinery value includes equipment, tools, jigs, dies, moulds, pollution equipment, and lab equipment.
Leased plant and equipment are not eligible for incentives.
Enterprises set up with total secondhand machinery are ineligible for incentives.
Imported secondhand plant, machinery, and equipment are considered new indigenous machinery if imported directly.
Indigenous secondhand machinery purchased by an enterprise should not exceed 25% of the total value of new plant and machinery.
The value of indigenous secondhand machinery will not be computed towards eligible FCI for incentives.
Secondhand machinery market value is certified by a CA, with a minimum further life of six years for MSEs and twelve years for Medium and above industries, certified by a Licensed Engineer.

Expenditure on Technical Consultancy/Feasibility study, including turn-key charges, is considered towards FCI if part of the approved project cost, capitalized, and certified by a CA, limited to 10% of the total plant machinery and equipment cost.

Plant, machinery, and equipment procured from APSFC/AP State Industrial Development Corporation/Nationalized Banks pertaining to disposed-off enterprises are eligible if they haven't enjoyed prior incentives.
Only depreciated value of such plant, machinery, and equipment, certified by a CA and with a minimum further life, is considered for eligible FCI.
New enterprises in premises of disposed-off enterprises are eligible for incentives only on new assets created with fresh investment.
Self-fabricated machinery value must be certified by a Chartered Engineer or term lending institution's engineer.
Diesel Generator and transformer costs are not allowed for FCI computation.

Items not computable towards Fixed Capital Investment include working capital, raw material, stores, consumables, spare tools, motor vehicles (except for FPP and special category enterprises), pre-operative expenses, advances, expenditure not supported by bills, investments outside approved project cost, fixed assets created after DCP (for aided enterprises), fixed assets created and payments made after DCP (for self-financed enterprises).
Enterprises with activities listed in Annexure-1 are ineligible for incentives.
Manufacturing sector projects in Annexure-1 and Service Sector projects in Annexures 2 and 3A are eligible for SC/ST/specially abled/transgender entrepreneurs.
For General/BC/minority entrepreneurs, activities in Annexure-1 are ineligible, but Service Sector activities in Annexure 2 are eligible.
New Industrial Enterprises established with leased plant and machinery are ineligible for incentives.
New Industrial Enterprises established with secondhand machinery are ineligible, except when the cost does not exceed 25% of the total plant and machinery cost.
Composite industrial enterprises manufacturing eligible and ineligible items are ineligible unless the ineligible proportion is less than 10% of total turnover.
Enterprises with activities listed in Annexure 2 or Annexure 3A are eligible for investment subsidy and power subsidy (for special category MSMEs) only.
Belated claims filed between six months and one year from the specified date are eligible for 50% of incentives; claims filed beyond one year are ineligible unless exempted.
For MSMEs, upward reclassification in investment, turnover, or both allows continued availing of non-tax benefits of the previous category for 3 years.
MSEs with leased premises require a registered lease deed for a minimum of six years from DCP; others require eight years.
Transfer of ownership is not permitted for enterprises set up by Women/BC/SC/ST/specially abled entrepreneurs, but transfer between such entrepreneurs is allowed with prior approval.
If an enterprise availing expansion/diversification had previously availed Investment Subsidy, the availed amount is deducted from the eligible subsidy, limited by the maximum cap.
Land and building purchased from existing incentivized enterprises are not considered for FCI.
Industrial enterprises setting up new units with separate identifiable investment within the same land are eligible if production linkage is absent and separate accounts are maintained.
Utilities like water, electricity, steam, and pollution control systems cannot be shared between existing and new enterprises for 'Separate Identifiable Investment'.
Machinery bills and sale bills must be maintained in the name of each unit and reflected separately in financial statements.
The decision of the State Level Committee (SLC) is final in cases of doubt/ambiguity regarding 'Separate Identifiable Investment'.
New enterprises set up at different locations under the same name are treated as new enterprises for incentives, even without separate GST registration, provided separate accounts are maintained.
Expansion/Diversification enterprises must obtain all statutory approvals.
All entrepreneurs must have a Permanent Account Number (PAN) and file Income Tax Returns.
Aadhaar number is required for Udyam Registration.
Sole Proprietorship, Partnership Firm, Company, LLP, Cooperative Society, Society, or Trust must provide GSTIN and PAN along with Aadhaar number.
Units must possess Professional Tax Registration unless exempted.
Transport sector units require mandatory GPS installation on vehicles.
Change of constitution, management, or name/style within six years (MSEs) or eight years (Medium+) from DCP requires approval from DIEPC/SLC.
Assets considered for incentives cannot be transferred/sold within the first six years (MSEs) or eight years (Medium+) from DCP.
Exemption for asset transfer/sale may be granted by SLC under specific conditions, including remittance of incentives availed.
Leasing out an enterprise/industry within six years (MSEs) or eight years (Medium+) from DCP requires prior approval from DIEPC/SLC.
Shifting location of incentivized enterprises requires approval from DIEPC/SLC.
Micro and Small enterprises can get location shift approval from the respective DIPEC for any part of the state.
Medium and above enterprises can get location shift approval from SLC for any part of the state.
Shifting production/operation outside the state during the continuous production period is prohibited; violations lead to incentive recovery.
Merger/amalgamation of incentivized enterprises requires SLC approval.
Applications for merger/amalgamation must be submitted through the Commissioner of Industries or CEO, APFPS, via GM, DIC, with necessary supporting documents.
Starting new eligible items without additional machinery allows application for incentives within the policy period from DCP.
Prior approval from DIEPC (MSEs) or SLC (Medium+) is required before producing new items to apply for incentives.
Continuous Production means working for a minimum of six years (MSEs) or eight years (Medium+) without a break.
Failure to maintain continuous production leads to cancellation of sanctioned incentives and recovery.
Break in Production is defined as not operating for more than 90 consecutive days.
Break-in-production up to three years due to reasons beyond control may be condoned by DIEPC (MSEs) or SLC (Medium+).
Any break-in-production extends the continuous production period requirement.
Entrepreneurs must file for industrial approvals on the 'Apply for approvals' section of www.apindustries.gov.in.
Entrepreneurs must file separate online claims for each eligible incentive through the 'Apply for Industrial Incentives' section on www.apindustries.gov.in.
All claims must be within one policy period.
Enterprises must have professional tax registration and pay professional tax as per G.O.Rt.No.664.
Expansion/diversification claims must be submitted separately, otherwise treated as original enterprise claims.
All enterprises must fill the Common Application Form (Annexure â 5) and other applicable forms/certificates.
For MSMEs, investment declared in the Common Application Form determines incentive quantum.
The incentives portal will integrate with APIs of line departments for AI-driven self-computation, digital validation, and fraud detection.
Units must obtain all statutory approvals/permissions/licenses; deemed approvals require necessary approvals to apply for incentives beyond the exempted period.
BC/SC/ST/Women/Specially Abled Entrepreneurs must specify their category when applying for approvals and incentives.
The overall incentive a company can claim shall not exceed 100% of FCI for Sub-Large and above investments, and 75% of FCI for MSMEs.
State Level and District Level Scrutiny/Verification Committees (SVC) are constituted for scrutinizing and recommending incentive claims.
Committees at State Level (SLC) and District Level (DIEPC) are constituted for sanctioning/rejecting claims.
Payment of Profession Tax is mandatory for industrial approvals, licenses, renewals, and incentives.
The designated DIC official inspects the enterprise and verifies records as per Annexure 16.
Micro Enterprises are inspected by IPO, Small Enterprises by Assistant Director/Deputy Director, and Medium & above by General Manager.
Inspecting officers verify plant and machinery with bills, payment proofs, and GST data.
If secondhand machinery exists, it must be certified accordingly.
For aided enterprises, financial institutions and inspecting officers certify new and secondhand machinery.
Differences of opinion on plant and machinery genuineness are resolved by District Collector/Commissioner of Industries inspection.
Ad-hoc joint inspection committees can be constituted for self-financed enterprises requiring special investigation.
Inspecting officers are responsible for inspection and must upload reports within 48 hours.
Inspection reports are available to entrepreneurs through their login.
Entrepreneurs can appeal inspection reports within 3 months of publication.
DIEPC and SLC committees decide on sanction or rejection of claims based on SVC recommendations.
Appellate authority for Micro and Small Enterprises is the District Collector; for Medium and above, it's the Commissioner of Industries or CEO, APFPS.
GM DIC's office processes claim applications and places them before SVC/DIEPC within 100 working days for Micro and Small cases.
GM/DIO forwards claim applications to Commissioner of Industries office for Medium and above enterprises, processed within 100 working days.
For FPP 4.0 applications, GM DIC forwards claims to CEO, APFPS, processed within 100 working days.
File processing hierarchy for Micro and Small enterprises at District level has a maximum of 100 days.
File processing hierarchy for Medium and above enterprises at State level has a maximum of 100 days.
Inspecting officers inspect enterprises once every 6 months (MSEs) or annually (Medium+).
Performance reports are obtained during inspection and uploaded to the portal.
Further claims are processed based on earlier inspection/performance reports without physical inspection.
Sanctioned claims are kept ready for disbursement in chronological order.
Self-declaration in the Common Application Form is sufficient for disbursement.
Entrepreneurs must submit account details and NOC from Term Loan Financial Institution if the loan is closed or outstanding is less than the incentive amount.
Investment subsidy is credited to the term loan account; other incentives can be credited to term loan or CA/CC account.
Disbursements are made in batches through consolidated release proceedings.
Industrial enterprises availing bridge loans against anticipated subsidy will have the subsidy released first to the financial institution.
Subsidy disbursement is withheld for sick/closed enterprises or those with management changes until further examination and clearance.
If a unit has been in continuous production for the prescribed period and subsidy is pending, it should be released without insisting on working status.
Incentives/concessions obtained by misrepresentation, false information, or fake documents are liable for recovery and penalty.
Industrial enterprises going out of production within the continuous production period are liable for recovery, with exceptions for condoned breaks.
Failure to furnish prescribed statements or information when called upon is grounds for recovery.
Change of management without prior approval, or shifting/leasing of assets without prior approval, can lead to recovery.
Selling the whole or part of an industrial enterprise without prior SLC approval can lead to recovery.
Transferring management without prior SLC approval can lead to recovery.
Recoveries are treated as arrears of Land Revenue under the A.P. Revenue Recovery Act, 1864.
GM, DICs are designated as recovery officers.
District Level Scrutiny-cum-Verification Committee (SVC) scrutinizes claims from Micro and Small enterprises.

District Level Scrutiny-cum-Verification Committee (SVC) comprises GM/DIO (Chairman), Manager APSFC, Zonal Manager APIIC, District Registration & Stamps, Representative of AP Food Processing Society, Representative of AP MSME Corporation, Representative of AP Technology Services, Representative from DISCOM, Assistant Commissioner (ST), Lead District Manager, Representative from Transport Department, and Deputy Director/Assistant Director (Member-Convener).
District Industries and Export Promotion Committee on Incentives (DIEPC) considers SVC recommendations and sanctions/rejects claims for micro and small enterprises.

DIEPC comprises District Collector (Chairman), Regional Authority of DGFT (Co-Chairman), Representatives from MSME, Sector specific Export Promotion Council, Quality and Standards implementation body, Sector specific Ministries (GoI & State), Commercial Taxes/GST, Road Transport Authority, Branch Manager APSFC, Deputy Chief/Inspector of Factories, Environmental Engineer APPCB, Representative from Marketing Dept., Superintendent Engineer/Divisional Engineer APTRANSCO/DISCOMs, Zonal Manager APIIC, Sectoral agencies, Representative from Social Welfare Dept., District Panchayat Officer, Commissioner Municipality/Urban Development, Lead District Officer/Manager, Five representatives of Industrial Associations, Representatives from line departments/GOI/Experts (Special Invitee), Representative of AP Food Processing Society, Representative of AP Technology Service, and GM District Industries Centre (Member Convener).
State Level Scrutiny-cum-Verification Committee (SSVC) scrutinizes claims from Medium and above enterprises.

SSVC comprises Additional Director (Chairman), Nominee of Inspector General Registration & Stamps, Nominee of Chief Commissioner of State Tax, Nominee from State Level Bankers Committee, Nominee of MD APSFC, Nominee of MD APIIC, Nominee from CMD APTRANSCO, Nominee of CMD APEPDCL, Nominee of CMD APCPDCL, Nominee of CMD APSPDCL, Representative of AP Food processing Society, Representative of MSME corporation, Representative of AP Technology Services, and Joint Director - Incentives (Member-Convener).
State Level Committee on Incentives (SLC) scrutinizes and sanctions claims of medium and above enterprises.

SLC comprises Commissioner of Industries (Chairman), Additional Secretary/Joint Secretary/Deputy Secretary (Finance & Planning), Additional Secretary/Joint Secretary/Deputy Secretary (Industries & Commerce), Commissioner of Labour or Nominee, CEO MSMEDC, CEO APFPS, ED APTS, President Federation of A.P. Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Chairman CII, President FAPSIA, President FSME, President DICCI, President Andhra Chamber of Commerce, President ALEAP, Chairman AP Spinning Mills Association, MD APSFC or Nominee, MD APIIC or Nominee, Commissioner of Commercial Taxes or Nominee, Commissioner of Tribal Welfare or Nominee, Commissioner of Social Welfare or Nominee, Commissioner of BC Welfare or Nominee, Director Commercial APTRANSCO or Nominee, Commissioner & Inspector General Registration & Stamps or Nominee, Member Secretary APPCB or Nominee, President Dalit Industrial Association, President SC-ST Chamber of Commerce & Industry, General Secretary Tribal Indian Chamber of commerce and Industry, Commissioner Transport or Nominee, Chief Commissioner Land Administration or Nominee, Convener SLBC, Nominees of Canara Bank, State Bank of India, Union Bank of India, and Additional Director of Industries (Convener).
Scrutiny-cum-Verification Committees prepare appraisal notes for claims.
SVCs meet at least once a month.
SLC and DIEPC meet at least once every two months for sanctioning incentives.
SLC decisions are final in scrutinizing, deciding eligible investment, and sanctioning incentives.
SLC can review earlier decisions.
SLC's decision/interpretation is sought for any doubt/ambiguity in guidelines.
SLC reviews and intervenes on pending claims beyond two months from DIC receipt.
Commissioner of Industries randomly inspects at least 20% of sanctioned claims by DICs.
SLC has the power to condone break-in-production up to three years for medium and above enterprises.
DIEPC has the power to condone break-in-production up to three years for micro and small enterprises.
Member Conveners convene meetings, draw minutes, and communicate them.
Member Conveners arrange maintenance of records of sanctions/disbursements.
Member Conveners place claims beyond two months at DICs before SLC for review.
Member Conveners communicate lists of sanctioned units to the Transport Department to lock ownership transfer.
GM, DICs receive and process claim applications as per seriatim and place them before SVC/DIEPC within SLA limits.
GM, DICs initiate action to recover incentives where warranted.
GM, DICs monitor enterprises with break-in-production or ownership changes and submit reports.
GM, DICs provide access for downloading online applications to inspecting officers.
GM, DICs review cases with delays beyond 7 days and place them in DIEPCs.
GM, DICs track claim pendency on the district-level dashboard.
Commissioner of Industries, CEO APFPS, CEO MSME corporation, and GMs of DICs maintain data on incentive applications, sanctions, and fund releases.
Files pertaining to sanctioned DIEPC and SLC cases must be kept for 10 years.
Industrial Enterprises receiving incentives must furnish certified audited accounts, including Balance Sheet, before June 30th of the succeeding year.
Such statements must be furnished for a minimum of six or eight years.
Industrial Enterprises must also furnish details of production, sales, employment, etc., as an Annual Return before June 30th.
MSME Enterprises may furnish only the Annual Performance Report (Annexure 15) before June 30th.
Failure to submit audited accounts or Annual Performance Report on time will stop future recurring incentives.
Interpretation matters not decided by SLC are referred to the Government in Industries & Commerce Department.
Willful misrepresentation of facts or actions leading to irregular sanction/disbursement of incentives will invite civil and criminal action, recovery, and debarment from future incentives.
Companies intending to establish Mega and above Projects must submit detailed representations with project reports to the Commissioner of Industries or CEO, APFPS.
SIPC shall scrutinize and recommend tailor-made incentives for Mega and above projects.
SIPC evaluates and recommends land extent for projects requiring more than 50 acres.
SIPC evaluates and recommends revision/modification/relaxation on contractual terms for Mega and above projects that breached SLAs.
SIPC agenda notes include firm details, proposal summary, investment break-up, financing details, land locations, approvals status, incentive wishlist, and impact to the state.
SIPC remarks are placed before the State Investment Promotion Board (SIPB) for consideration and approval.

SIPB comprises Chief Minister (Chairman), Deputy Chief Minister, Ministers for Panchayat Raj, Finance, HRD, Revenue, Municipal Administration, Agriculture, Labour, Industries, Roads & Buildings, Energy, Tourism, Special Chief Secretaries/Principal Secretaries/Secretaries to Government, Chief Secretary, and Commissioner/Director of Industries (Member/Convenor).
SIPB meets at regular intervals to examine proposals and take decisions on industrial and infrastructure investments.
SIPB evaluates SIPC recommendations and makes final decisions.
After SIPC & SIPB approvals and cabinet ratification, respective Secretaries issue Government Orders.

IDP 4.0 introduces an early bird offer on investment subsidy for the first 200 general enterprises receiving CFE within 18 months (Category I) and enterprises investing in component manufacturing within 24 months (Category II).
The early bird incentive is applicable to Sub-large and above enterprises (except those availing tailor-made incentives).
Early bird incentive overrides investment subsidy under IDP 4.0 or other sectoral policies.
Enterprises availing early bird offer can apply for other eligible incentives (excluding investment subsidy) under sectoral policies.
Early bird offer is applicable to eligible New/Expansion/Diversification projects with eligible FCI more than INR 50 Crore.
The offer window starts from a date notified by the Commissioner of Industries office.
Projects receiving CFE must submit an online intent form (Annexure 18) to claim early bird incentive.
Commissioner of Industries may extend the early bird window period.
Applications for early bird offer are scrutinized by a committee formed by the Commissioner of Industries and placed before SIPC & SIPB every two months.
Precedence order for the first 200 eligible projects is date/time of intent form submission, date/time of CFE certificate, date of committed DCP/CFO, and E/I ratio.
Preference is given to projects committing DCP within the policy period, generating high employment, and in sectors of state importance.
Of the first 200 Category I projects, 120 are reserved for new and 80 for expansion enterprises.
Enterprises under Category I & II must achieve DCP within the standard investment period for incentive eligibility.
Eligible enterprises must submit claims in the prescribed application form (Annexure â 6A) within six months from DCP.

Investment subsidy quantum for Early Bird Offer Category I (General enterprises) is 30% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 150 Cr (Sub-Large), INR 300 Cr (Large), INR 1,500 Cr (Mega), and limited to eFCI (Ultra Mega), disbursed over 5, 7, or 10 years.

Investment subsidy quantum for Early Bird Offer Category II (General enterprises) is 40% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 200 Cr (Sub-Large), INR 400 Cr (Large), INR 2,000 Cr (Mega), and limited to eFCI (Ultra Mega), disbursed over 5, 7, or 10 years.
For women/BC/SC/ST/specially-abled enterprises in sub-large category domiciled in AP, an additional 5% investment subsidy is applicable.
SLC verifies claim documents and approves early bird incentives if requirements are met.
Approved incentive amounts are disbursed in equal annual installments over the disbursement period.
Enterprises receiving DCP beyond the standard investment period will have incentives reduced by 0.5% per month of delay.
All eligible industrial enterprises submit claims for investment subsidy within six months from DCP.
Fixed Capital Investment includes investment in DeCarbonization projects.
Total Investment Subsidy (State + Central) is limited to 75% of the investment component.
Investment subsidy is applicable to identified service activities (Annexure 2 & 3A), subject to conditions.
Subsidy is released based on project cost approved by Financial Institution (aided) or Chartered Accountant (self-financed).
Approved incentive amount is disbursed in equal annual installments over the disbursement period.
Enterprises achieving DCP within the standard investment period are eligible for investment subsidy.
For Enterprises receiving DCP beyond the standard investment period, incentives are reduced by 0.5% per month of delay.
MEDP 4.0 Investment Subsidy is applicable to eligible New Enterprises only.
MEDP 4.0 Investment Subsidy quantum is 25% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 25 Lakh (Micro), INR 1.5 Crores (Small), INR 7 Crores (Medium), disbursed over 2, 3, or 4 years.
IDP 4.0 Investment Subsidy quantum is 12% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 60 Cr (Sub-Large), INR 120 Cr (Large), INR 150 Cr (Mega), INR 750 Cr (Ultra Mega), disbursed over 5, 7, or 10 years.
IDP 4.0 Investment Subsidy for Mega & Ultra Mega Projects is 15% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 150 Cr (Mega) and INR 750 Cr (Ultra Mega), disbursed over 10 years.
Requirement for installation of plant and machinery for IDP 4.0 incentives varies by project size (Sub-Large, Large, Mega & Ultra Mega).

FPP 4.0 Investment Subsidy for Primary processing units (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies, Micro, Small, Medium) is 25% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 50 Lakh (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), INR 25 Lakh (Micro), INR 1.5 Crores (Small), INR 7 Crores (Medium), disbursed over 2, 3, or 4 years.
FPP 4.0 Investment Subsidy for Primary processing units (Large) is 15% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 15 Crores, disbursed over 5 years.

FPP 4.0 Investment Subsidy for Secondary/Tertiary processing units (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies, Micro, Small, Medium) is 35% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 5 Crores (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), INR 35 Lakh (Micro), INR 3.5 Crores (Small), INR 8 Crores (Medium), disbursed over 2, 3, or 4 years.
FPP 4.0 Investment Subsidy for Secondary/Tertiary processing units (Large) is 15% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 15 Crores, disbursed over 5 years.

FPP 4.0 Investment Subsidy for Waste processing units (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies, Micro, Small, Medium) is 50% (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), 25% (Micro, Small, Medium) of eligible FCI, capped at INR 2 Crores (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), INR 25 Lakh (Micro), INR 2.5 Crores (Small), INR 5 Crores (Medium), disbursed over 2, 3, or 5 years.

FPP 4.0 Investment Subsidy for Modern Abattoirs/Meat processing/Animal Feed units (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies, Micro, Small, Medium, Large) is 50% (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), 35% (Micro, Small, Medium), 35% (Large) of eligible FCI, capped at INR 15 Crores (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), INR 35 Lakh (Micro), INR 3.5 Crores (Small), INR 15 Crores (Medium), INR 25 Crores (Large), disbursed over 2 or 5 years.
FPP 4.0 Investment Subsidy for Food Testing Laboratories (MSME) is 35% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 5 Crores, disbursed over 2 years.
FPP 4.0 Investment Subsidy is applicable to all eligible New/Expansion/Diversification projects.
Technology Upgradation Cost incentive under IDP 4.0 is Nil for Sub-Large and above.
Technology Upgradation Cost incentive under MEDP 4.0 is 20% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 20 Lakhs (Micro), INR 1 Crore (Small), INR 5 Crores (Medium), disbursed over 2, 3, or 5 years.

Technology Upgradation Cost incentive under FPP 4.0 is 35% (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), 20% (Micro, Small, Medium), 10% (Large) of eligible FCI, capped at INR 3 Crores (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), INR 20 Lakhs (Micro), INR 1 Crore (Small), INR 5 Crores (Medium), INR 10 Crores (Large), disbursed over 2, 3, or 5 years.
Technology Upgradation Subsidy is applicable to MSMEs and large units (FPP 4.0 definition) under expansion/diversification/modernization only.
Top-up subsidy on PLI/Government of India Schemes under IDP 4.0 is a capital subsidy applicable to projects approved under PLI or other GoI schemes.
The top-up subsidy is 10% of the incentive sanctioned under PLI/GoI scheme, capped at 5% of eligible FCI, disbursed over 5, 7, or 10 years.
FPP 4.0 Top-up on Government of India Schemes is applicable to projects approved under PMKSY or other state recognized GoI schemes.

FPP 4.0 Top-up incentive for Agro processing cluster, Irradiation facility, Food Safety and quality assurance (Equipment/Civil work), and Operation greens is 15% or 10% of eligible project cost, capped at INR 1 Crore, INR 10 Lakhs, or INR 5 Lakhs, disbursed over 5 years.
FPP 4.0 Top-up on AHIDF and AIF provides 2% interest subvention on term loan, capped at INR 5 Crores or INR 1 Crore, disbursed annually for 5 years.
Employment Subsidy under IDP 4.0 is applicable to new/expansion/diversification enterprises based on the Employment to Investment (E/I) ratio.
Employment subsidy is claimed only once during the policy period.

The quantum of Employment subsidy for E/I ratio between 1-3 is 8% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 40 Cr (Sub-Large), INR 80 Cr (Large), INR 400 Cr (Mega), as per eligible FCI (Ultra Mega), disbursed over 5, 7, or 9/10 years.

The quantum of Employment subsidy for E/I ratio between 3-4 is 9% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 45 Cr (Sub-Large), INR 90 Cr (Large), INR 450 Cr (Mega), as per eligible FCI (Ultra Mega), disbursed over 5, 7, or 9/10 years.

The quantum of Employment subsidy for E/I ratio greater than 5 is 10% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 50 Cr (Sub-Large), INR 100 Cr (Large), INR 500 Cr (Mega), as per eligible FCI (Ultra Mega), disbursed over 5, 7, or 9/10 years.
DIEPC or SLC approves the eligible incentive percentage based on average annual employment created.
Approved incentive amount is disbursed in equal annual installments.
Inspecting officer verifies employment annually for subsidy disbursement.
If verified employment falls below 5% of the declared figure, no incentive is disbursed for that year.
Employment means direct employment, including full-time and contractual, on payrolls.
E/I ratio calculation uses whole numbers for employment and INR crores for investment.
DeCarbonization Subsidy encourages investment in climate-friendly machinery to reduce carbon footprint.
DeCarbonization subsidy project cost shall not exceed 6% of eligible FCI.
Investment shown for DeCarbonization subsidy is deducted from eligible FCI for other capital-based subsidies.
De-Carbonization subsidy can be claimed only once during the policy period.

IDP 4.0 DeCarbonization Subsidy for Non-Red category industries is 10% (Sub-Large), 20% (Large), 20% (Mega), 30% (Ultra Mega) of project cost, capped at 6% of eligible FCI, disbursed over 5, 7, or 10 years.

IDP 4.0 DeCarbonization Subsidy for Red category industries is 15% (Sub-Large), 25% (Large), 25% (Mega), 35% (Ultra Mega) of project cost, capped at 6% of eligible FCI, disbursed over 5, 7, or 10 years.
Eligible projects for De-Carbonization subsidy include pollution/emission reducing, water conserving, waste minimizing, and energy conserving initiatives.

Reimbursement of Stamp Duty, Transfer Duty & Land Conversion Charges under IDP 4.0 is 100% of incurred cost, capped at Fees Paid, disbursed one time for Sub-Large, Large, Mega, and Ultra Mega enterprises.
Reimbursement of Stamp Duty, Transfer Duty & Land Conversion Charges under MEDP 4.0 is 100% of incurred cost, capped at Fees Paid, disbursed one time for Micro, Small, and Medium enterprises.

Reimbursement of Stamp Duty, Transfer Duty & Land Conversion Charges under FPP 4.0 is 100% of incurred cost, capped at Fees Paid, disbursed one time for Micro, Small, Medium, Large, and Mega enterprises.
Stamp Duty and Transfer Duty are applicable on purchase of land for industrial use.
Stamp duty is reimbursed only once on land/building/shed.
Stamp duty on mortgages and hypothecations for term loans is eligible on assessed FCI only.
Reimbursement of land conversion charges is applicable to all eligible New enterprises and Expansion/Diversification enterprises.
FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies can avail benefits eligible for Micro, Small, Medium, Large, and Mega categories based on investment size.
Power Cost Subsidy under IDP 4.0 is INR 1 per unit for Sub-Large, capped at INR 15 Lakh per annum, disbursed bi-annually for 2 years.

Power Cost Subsidy under MEDP 4.0 is INR 1 per unit for Micro, Small, and Medium enterprises, capped at INR 1 Lakh (Micro), INR 5 Lakh (Small), INR 15 Lakh (Medium) per annum, disbursed bi-annually for 5 years.

Power Cost Subsidy under FPP 4.0 is INR 1 per unit for Micro, Small, Medium, and Large enterprises, capped at INR 1 Lakh (Micro), INR 5 Lakh (Small), INR 15 Lakh (Medium), INR 15 Lakh (Large) per annum, disbursed bi-annually for 5 or 2 years.
FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies can avail power cost benefits eligible for Micro, Small, Medium, or Large categories.
Reimbursement is on energy consumption charges only, not on Contract Maximum Demand or other charges.
Residential & colony power consumption and open access power are not eligible for reimbursement.
Power cost reimbursement is applicable to enterprises utilizing power from DISCOMs and RECs, with the connection in the enterprise's name.
For expansion/diversification projects, reimbursement is over base power consumed, calculated annually.
Base half-year consumption is half of the highest annual power consumption of previous years.

If power connection is in the original enterprise's name for secondhand land/building purchases, no power cost reimbursement is allowed unless the connection is transferred to the present enterprise's name.

Net SGST Reimbursement under IDP 4.0 is 100% of net SGST paid for Sub-Large and Large enterprises, capped annually at 5% of turnover and overall at 100% of eligible FCI, disbursed annually for 5 years.

Net SGST Reimbursement under MEDP 4.0 and FPP 4.0 is 100% of net SGST paid for Micro, Small, and Medium enterprises, capped annually at 5% of turnover and overall at 100% of eligible FCI, disbursed annually for 5 years.
FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies can avail net SGST reimbursement eligible for Micro, Small, Medium, or Large categories.
Net SGST accrued for 5 years from DCP or until 100% eligible FCI realization, whichever is earlier, is reimbursed.
Expansion/Diversification projects receive SGST reimbursement on production above the base annual production capacity.
Base annual production is the average of the previous three financial years or 75% of installed capacity, whichever is higher.
Net SGST means SGST amount paid through the cash ledger.
Eligible units must obtain separate GST registration for eligible manufacturing activities only.
Incentives are allowed only for eligible goods manufactured in the eligible unit, not on resale.
If inter-state sales are shown as intra-state sales to get higher incentives, incentives are liable for cancellation with interest.
Form â A (Annexure 8) for sales tax department certification must be obtained and uploaded.

Skill Upgradation Costs incentive under MEDP 4.0 and FPP 4.0 is INR 5,000 per person (max 10 persons) for Micro, INR 10,000 per person (max 20 persons) for Small, and 100% of employer contribution to EPF for Medium, capped at INR 50,000 (Micro), INR 2,00,000 (Small), INR 1 Lakh per annum (Medium), disbursed one time or annually for 3 years.
IDP 4.0 does not offer Skill Upgradation Costs incentive.
Enterprises must inform GM, DIC in advance of training commencement.
Training should be practical-oriented and aimed at skill upgradation.
Energy & Water Audit Cost incentive under MEDP 4.0 and FPP 4.0 is 75% of audit cost, capped at INR 1 Lakh for Micro, Small, and Medium enterprises for audits.

Energy & Water Audit Cost incentive under MEDP 4.0 and FPP 4.0 is 25% of equipment cost, capped at INR 20 Lakhs (Micro), INR 40 Lakhs (Small), INR 50 Lakhs (Medium), disbursed one time for equipment commissioning.
IDP 4.0 does not offer Energy & Water Audit Cost incentive.
To claim this incentive, an audit report from a government-empaneled or ISO/BIS certified agency or NABL accredited lab is required.
Local Procurement Subsidy requires enterprises to generate minimum 80% of annual turnover from exports and source minimum 60% of input requirements from within the state.
Local Procurement Subsidy is extended to export-oriented enterprises (excluding specific HSN codes) registered in the state.

The incentive under policies is 1% of annual export turnover, capped at INR 7 Crores (Sub-Large) or INR 15 Lakhs (Micro), INR 1.5 Crores (Small), INR 7 Crores (Medium), disbursed annually for 3 years.
Input tax credit statements are used to determine local procurement.
Local procurement subsidy can be claimed annually for any three years during the policy operative period.
Annual Export Turnover means turnover generated from exports during the financial year.
Quality Certification Cost Top Up under MEDP 4.0 and FPP 4.0 covers the balance cost of certification after accounting for Government of India subsidy, capped at 100% of cost, disbursed one time.
IDP 4.0 does not offer Quality Certification Cost Top Up incentive.
Eligible Subsidy MEDP 4.0 includes ZED, LEAN.
Eligible subsidy under FPP 4.0 includes HACCP, GMP, GLP, ISO 9,000, ISO 22,000, TQM.
Units claiming incentives under FPP 4.0 are not eligible for MEDP 4.0 incentives for Quality Certification Cost Top Up.
Additional eligible schemes will be notified in line with new schemes introduced by Government of India.
Medium enterprises are offered Business Development Credits (BDCs) up to 2% of turnover growth for 5 years, with a matching 50% enterprise contribution.
BDCs can be used for prescribed business development activities from empaneled service providers.
Medium enterprises receive 25% assistance for listing & raising money in SME stock exchange, capped at INR 5 Lakhs.
Medium enterprises with high performance records are preferred for identification as Champion units.

Special Package of Incentives for Women/BC/SC/ST/Minority/Specially-Abled/Transgender Enterprises applies to MSME units where the sole proprietor belongs to these categories and has domicile in Andhra Pradesh.
The package also applies to women-led enterprises domiciled in the state.
Special category enterprises can apply for general category MSME incentives but not a combination of policies.
Investment Subsidy for special category MSMEs under MEDP 4.0 is 45% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 45 Lakh (Micro), INR 4.5 Crores (Small), INR 7 Crores (Medium), disbursed over 2, 3, or 4 years.
Investment Subsidy for special category Sub-Large (IDP 4.0) and Large (FPP 4.0) enterprises is 17% (Sub-Large) of eligible FCI, capped at INR 85 Crores, disbursed over 5 years.
Investment Subsidy for special category FPP 4.0 Primary Processing units is 35% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 7 Crores, disbursed over 2, 3, or 4 years.

Investment Subsidy for special category FPP 4.0 Secondary/Tertiary Processing units is 45% (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies, Micro, Small, Medium) or 25% (Large) of eligible FCI, capped at INR 8 Crores (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), INR 45 Lakh (Micro), INR 4.5 Crores (Small), INR 8 Crores (Medium), INR 15 Crores (Large), disbursed over 2, 3, or 5 years.

Technology Upgradation Subsidy for special category MSMEs under MEDP 4.0 is 40% of eligible FCI, capped at INR 40 Lakhs (Micro), INR 4 Crores (Small), INR 5 Crores (Medium), disbursed over 2, 3, or 5 years.

Technology Upgradation Subsidy for special category FPP 4.0 is 45% (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), 30% (Micro, Small, Medium), 20% (Large) of eligible FCI, capped at INR 5 Crores (FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies), INR 30 Lakhs (Micro), INR 3 Crores (Small), INR 5 Crores (Medium), INR 10 Crores (Large), disbursed over 2, 3, or 5 years.
Technology upgradation subsidy is not applicable for above medium category enterprises.
75% rebate in land cost, limited to INR 25 lakhs, is provided for SC/ST led Micro and Small Enterprises in Industrial Estates/Parks.
Power Cost Reimbursement for special category Micro and Small Enterprises under MEDP 4.0 is INR 1.5 per unit for 5 years from DCP.
Power cost subsidy also applies to service activities listed in Annexure -2 and 3A.
Net SGST Reimbursement of 100% is provided to special category Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises for 5 years from DCP or until 100% FCI realization, subject to annual caps.
Net SGST reimbursement subsidy is applicable for eligible Manufacturing activities only.
Reimbursement of Stamp duty and Transfer duty is 100% paid by the industry on purchase of land for industrial use.
Reimbursement of Stamp duty for Lease of Land/Shed/Buildings and mortgages/hypothecations is 100%.
Annexure-1 lists ineligible industries.
Annexure-2 lists enterprises related to the service industry.
Annexure-3A lists enterprises applicable only for Scheduled Castes & Scheduled Tribe Entrepreneurs.
Annexure-3B lists additional activities eligible for De-Carbonization Subsidy.
Annexure-3C lists activities qualifying as Category II (Value Added Products) for Early Bird Offer.
Annexure-3D lists activities qualifying as Primary/Secondary/Tertiary under FPP 4.0.
Annexure-4 provides the Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Notification on classification criteria.
Annexure-5 is the Common Application Form for Sanction of Incentives.
Annexure-6A is the Self-Computation Sheet for Eligible Investment Subsidy Details.
Annexure-6B is the Self-Computation Sheet for Eligible Stamp Duty Reimbursement Incentive.
Annexure-6C is the Self-Computation Sheet for Eligible Power Cost Reimbursement Incentive.
Annexure-6D is the Self-Computation Sheet for Eligible Units for Skill Upgradation Cost.
Annexure-6E is the Self-Computation Sheet for Eligible Units for Energy Audit Cost.
Annexure-6F is the Self-Computation Sheet for Eligible Units for Water Audit Cost.
Annexure-6G is the Self-Computation Sheet for Local Procurement Subsidy.
Annexure-6H is the Self-Computation Sheet for Quality Certification Cost Top Up.
Annexure-6I is the Self-Computation Sheet for Top-Up Incentive on Government of India Schemes.
Annexure-6J is the Self-Computation Sheet for Eligible Interest Subsidy Reimbursement Incentive.
Annexure-7 is the Application Form to Industries Department for Claiming SGST Incentive.
Annexure-8 (Form A) is the Application-Cum Certification of Sales Tax Department Showing Tax Paid by the Enterprise.
Annexure-9 is the Statement of Accounts & List of Plant & Machinery by Financial Institution(s).
Annexure-10 is the Application-Cum Certification of GST Authorities for Tax Returns Filed Against Invoices.
Annexure-11 is the Civil Engineer Certificate for Cost of Buildings and Other Civil Works.
Annexure-12 is the Machinery Certificate Certified by Chartered Accountant & Chartered Engineer for Self-Financed Enterprises.
Annexure-13 is the Second-Hand Machinery Certificate Certified by Chartered Accountant & Chartered Engineer for All Enterprises.
Annexure-14 is the Self-Fabricated Machinery Certificate Certified by Chartered Engineer for All Enterprises.
Annexure-15 is the Annual Performance Report.
Annexure-16 is the Document Checklist.
Annexure-17 is the Verification Cum Recommendation of GM, DIC.
Annexure-18 is the Intent Submission Form for Early Bird Offer.
The Kakinada printing cluster has 150 units employing over 900 people directly and nearly 3000 indirectly, with a turnover of Rs. 8250 Lakhs.
The Kakinada printing cluster aims to flourish by embracing newer technologies through a Common Facility Center.

The total project cost for the Kakinada printing cluster CFC is estimated at Rs. 1476.00 Lakhs, with GoI Grant of Rs. 1180.80 Lakhs, Govt. of Andhra Pradesh Grant of Rs. 147.60 Lakhs, and SPV contribution of Rs. 147.60 Lakhs.
The Kakinada printing cluster's project is considered need-based and support-worthy.
The Kakinada printing cluster's project financial ratios (IRR 27%, NPV 32%, Breakeven Point 43%, ROCE 31%) are favorable.

The Kakinada printing cluster's projected performance after interventions includes an increase in units to 250, enhanced market growth and export access, increased employment, 25 exporting units, Rs. 110 Crores turnover within 3 years, improved profit margins by 30%, and a training center.

The Kakinada printing cluster faces challenges due to outdated CTP processing technology, lack of high-resolution multi-color printers, variable data printing technology, modern finishing and post-press facilities, and product diversification.

Proposed hard interventions for the Kakinada printing cluster include a Common Facility Center with CTP, Multi-color Offset Printers (Single and Double Dummy), Variable Data Printing, Post Press Finishing Machines, Design Software, and Training Facility.
Sivakasi is India's printing hub, accounting for 60% of offset printing solutions and housing a large number of printing machines.
The Kakinada printing cluster aims to benchmark against Sivakasi by increasing profit margins by 30%, producing export-oriented products, and indulging in value-added products and diversification.
The Kakinada printing cluster's CFC will provide process correction stages and fill technological gaps.
The Kakinada printing cluster's CFC will improve competitiveness and enable cluster members to compete with larger national and multinational brands.
East Godavari District is located in Coastal Andhra, with Kakinada as its headquarters.
East Godavari District is the most populous district in Andhra Pradesh as per the 2011 Census.
The Gross District Domestic Product (GDDP) of East Godavari is Rs. 52,294 crore, contributing 10% to the Gross State Domestic Product (GSDP).
The industrial sector in East Godavari includes Mining & Quarrying, Manufacturing, and Construction.
East Godavari District has around 24 Industrial Estates.
The district's GDP has grown at a CAGR of 4.11 percent over the decade 2004-05.
The Kakinada printing cluster is 80 years old and consists of 150 units scattered across the city.
The Kakinada printing cluster units are predominantly Micro Units (100%).

The cluster members are involved in printing and graphical designing, producing items like business cards, textbooks, pamphlets, journals, wedding cards, labels, letterheads, menus, calendars, receipt books, ID cards, and packaging material.
The Kakinada printing cluster members use traditional offset printing machinery and technologies like Screen Printing, Single/Two colour Printing, and Drum/Plate type Press based Impression Printing.
The Kakinada printing cluster lacks advanced machineries hindering growth, despite high market demand due to its location in an educational hub.
The major raw materials for the Kakinada printing cluster are paper and ink, available from Rajahmundry paper manufacturing industries and dealers in Hyderabad, Vijayawada, Rajahmundry, and Kakinada.
The Kakinada printing cluster requires approximately 2000 tons of paper annually.
The cluster members use papers ranging from 60 GSM to 300 GSM in various sizes.
The Kakinada printing cluster has a progressive turnover, reaching Rs. 8250 Lakhs in 2018-19.
The Kakinada printing cluster provides direct employment to 900 people and indirect employment to 3000 people.
The printing process in the cluster involves DTP, CTF/CTP, Offset printing, and post-press activities like cutting, numbering, binding, and lamination.
The cluster units have a well-established local customer base and receive continuous demand from various institutions.

The Kakinada printing cluster's major problems include outdated offset printing plates technology, low resolution prints, lack of variable data printing, absence of coating machines, lack of modern finishing and post-press machines, manual book binding with low-quality glue, inability to meet market quality requirements, limited product diversification, and the need for common ETP, training, design development, and marketing facilities.

The critical gaps identified include outdated offset printing plates technology, low resolution prints due to poor plate quality, low standard inks, and propensity for anodized aluminum plates to become sensitive.
The cluster lacks variable printing machines for bar codes, number codes, and QR codes.
The cluster lacks finishing equipment, leading to high rejection rates and poor customer acceptance.
The Kakinada printing cluster requires a Common Facility Center with CTP machine for digital plate production.
The CFC will have an advanced Multi-color printer for high-resolution color printouts.
The CFC will have a variable printer for printing bar codes and numbers.
The CFC will have finishing machineries like cutters, UV/aqueous coating, and die punching machines.
The CFC will provide training for the workforce and upgrade skills.
The total project cost for the CFC is Rs. 1476.00 Lakhs.
The means of finance for the CFC project include SPV (10%), Govt. of Andhra Pradesh (10%), and Govt. of India (80%).
The proposed building cost for the CFC includes land development, administrative building, machine setups, training section, canteen, and sanitary section.

The proposed list of machinery for the CFC includes CTP Machine Setup, Multi Colour Offset Printing Single Dummy Setup, Multi Colour Printing Machine Double Dummy Setup, Automatic Paper Cutting Machine, Folding Machine, Gumming Machine, Lamination Machine, 4 Hi Web Double Reel Stand with Quarter Page Folder, Digital Offset Machine, Sheetfed Offset Machine Double Crown, Diesel Generator, and Computers, Scanner, Printer.
The CFC will have a power requirement of 144.5 Kw.
The CFC will have its own bore well for water supply.
The CFC will require printable ink as raw material annually.
The CFC's organizational setup includes manpower for Machining Section, Training Centre, and Administrative Section.
The implementation schedule for the CFC is estimated to be 18 months.
The revenue generation mechanism for the CFC is based on service charges for individual machines.
The projected financial calculations for the CFC's sustainability show favorable ratios.
The Kakinada printing cluster's printing industry is at a crossroads, needing modernization to compete with national and multinational companies.
The CFC will provide necessary interventions, solve problems, and support cluster units to meet market demands.
The CFC will generate additional employment and increase profit margins for cluster members.
The 6th meeting of the National Project Approval Committee (NPAC) for the Micro & Small Enterprises - Cluster Development Programme (MSE-CDP) was held on August 21, 2025.
The meeting was chaired by the Secretary (MSME).
The meeting took place in Delhi in a hybrid mode.
The minutes of the 5th NPAC meeting held on March 10, 2025, were confirmed.
The action taken report on previous meeting decisions was noted.
The NPAC ratified the extension of time granted for 40 projects under various States/UTs before the 6th NPAC meeting.
Extension of time was ratified for the Common Facility Center (CFC) in the Auto and General Engineering Cluster, Chikodi, Belgaum, Karnataka, until March 31, 2025.
Extension of time was ratified for the Common Facility Center (CFC) in the Borgaon Textile Manufacturing Cluster, Nippani, Belgaum, Karnataka, until March 31, 2025.
Extension of time was ratified for the Common Facility Center (CFC) in the Powerloom Cluster, Chikodi District, Belgaum, Karnataka, until June 30, 2025.
The NPAC ratified the decision to accept a scanned and photocopied Tripartite Agreement for setting up a Common Facility Center (CFC) in the Okhrey Carpet Cluster, West Sikkim, as a special case.
The NPAC accorded final approval for setting up a Common Facility Center (CFC) in the Readymade Garment Cluster, Bhiwandi, Thane District, Maharashtra.

The means of finance for the Readymade Garment Cluster CFC in Bhiwandi are: 70% GoI Grant under MSE-CDP (Rs. 1771.40 lakh), 15% State Government's contribution (Rs. 379.59 lakh), and 15% SPV's contribution (Rs. 379.59 lakh), totaling Rs. 2530.58 lakh.

The means of finance for the Maize Processing Cluster CFC in Sangli are: 62.4% GoI Grant under MSE-CDP (Rs. 1895.33 lakh), 13.38% State Government's contribution (Rs. 406.23 lakh), 16.46% SPV's contribution (Rs. 500 lakh), and 7.76% Bank loan (Rs. 235.65 lakh), totaling Rs. 3037.21 lakh.
The NPAC accorded final approval for setting up a Common Facility Center (CFC) in the Textile Fashion Printing Cluster, Kagal, Kolhapur District, Maharashtra.

The NPAC accorded final approval for setting up a Common Facility Center (CFC) in the Steel Processing Cluster, Madha, Solapur District, Maharashtra.

The NPAC accorded final approval for setting up a Common Facility Center (CFC) in the Apparel and Home Furnishing Cluster, Barmer, Rajasthan.

The means of finance for the Apparel and Home Furnishing Cluster CFC in Barmer are: 70% GoI Grant under MSE-CDP (Rs. 627.01 lakh), 11.31% State Government's contribution (Rs. 101.33 lakh), and 18.69% SPV's contribution (Rs. 167.39 lakh), totaling Rs. 895.73 lakh.

The NPAC accorded final approval for setting up a Common Facility Center (CFC) in the Gold Ornaments Cluster, Mangalagiri, Guntur District, Andhra Pradesh.

The 5th SLPSC meeting of MSE-CDP was held on 22.08.2022 at 11:00 AM at the Directorate of Industries, Mangalagiri, Guntur District.
Shri Karikal Valaven, IAS, Special Chief Secretary to Govt of A.P., Deptt of Commerce & Industries, chaired the meeting.
The meeting's purpose was to review the status of cluster projects in the state and ascertain reasons for delays in the execution of other CFCs.
Shri D. Chandra Sekhar, Addl. Development Commissioner, MSME-DFO, Hyderabad & Visakhapatnam, welcomed the attendees.
The Chairman instructed GM-DICs, Implementing Agencies, MSME-DFO, MSME Corporation, and concerned departments to expedite CFC/ID project implementation and initiate new proposals.
The Action Taken Report of the 4th SLSC Meeting held on 10.07.2021 was reviewed and confirmed.
The status of 5 ongoing ID Projects under MSE-CDP in Andhra Pradesh was reviewed.

These projects include: Upgradation of Industrial Park (Jewellery Park) at Machilipatnam, Krishna District; Upgradation of Growth Centre at Hindupur, Anantapuram District; Upgradation of Industrial Estate, Autonagar, Phase-IV, Guntur District; New Industrial Estate at Kopparthy, YSR Kadapa District; and New Industrial Estate at Gandrajupalli, Chittoor District.
An APIIC Official informed that three projects (Machilipatnam, Hindupur, Guntur) are in progress, and two projects (Kopparthy, Gandrajupalli) have been completed successfully.
The Chairman instructed APIIC to submit completion certificates and relevant documents for all completed ID projects.
The status of ID Projects accorded in-principle/TEAC approval was reviewed.

These projects include: Development of FFC at Atchuthapuram in non-SEZ Area, Visakhapatnam District; Upgradation of Industrial Park at Nellimarla, Vizianagaram District; and Upgradation of Industrial Park at IP Tanuku, West Godavari District.
APIIC was directed to send the DPR to SIDBI for appraisal by 26th Aug, 2022, and SIDBI was to complete the appraisal by 15th September, 2022.
APIIC submitted the proposal to SIDBI on 23-08-2022, and it was acknowledged by SIDBI on 25-08-2022.
The review of dropped components in ID projects was discussed.

Dropped components were listed for: Upgradation of Industrial Park at Singarayakonda (Prakasam District), Development of Industrial Park at Peddapuram (East Godavari District), Development of Industrial Park at Grandrajupalli (Chittoor District), and Development of New Industrial Estate at Kopparthy (YSR Kadapa District).
The committee approved the dropping of these components.
The request for Extension of Time (EOT) for the New Industrial Estate at Kopparthy, YSR Kadapa District, up to 31.07.2022 was reviewed.
The committee recommended the EOT proposal to NLSC.
The progress on 6 approved CFCs was reviewed.
The CFC in Printing Cluster, Kakinada, received final approval in the 54th NLSC and sanction order on 29.07.2021.
The GoI Grant is 70% (1033.20 Lakhs), State Govt. Contribution is 20% (295.20 Lakhs), and SPV Contribution is 10% (147.60 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 1476.00 Lakhs.
The SPV deposited 10% share in a specified account, and the State Govt. matching grant was released on 31-03-2022.
E-Tenders were called for machinery supply on 11-06-2022 and are being processed by AP MSME DC.
The Chairman instructed the IA to expedite the completion of all works for the early implementation of the CFC in Printing Cluster, Kakinada.
The CFC in Furniture Manufacturing Cluster, Rajahmundry (East Godavari District), received final approval in the 54th NLSC and sanction order on 29.07.2021.
The GoI Grant is 70% (1044.88 Lakhs), State Govt. Contribution is 20% (299.68 Lakhs), and SPV Contribution is 10% (149.85 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 1498.41 Lakhs.
A Purchase Committee was formed, and its first meeting was held to finalize specifications and tenders.
The State Govt. matching grant was released on 31-03-2022.
The SPV is yet to raise its share capital up to 10%.
The Chairman instructed the SPV to deposit its share within 15 days and directed APMSE DC to follow up.
The CFC in Jaggayyapeta Gold Ornaments Cluster (Krishna District) received final approval in the 54th NLSC and sanction order on 29.07.2021.
The GoI Grant is 76.81% (614.52 Lakhs), State Govt. Contribution is 10.00% (80.00 Lakhs), and SPV Contribution is 13.19% (105.48 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 800.00 Lakhs.
A Purchase Committee meeting was conducted.
The State Govt. matching grant was released on 31-03-2022.
The SPV deposited its matching contribution of 10%.
The Chairman instructed the IA to initiate the tender process and expedite the completion of all works for the early implementation of the CFC in Jaggayyapeta Gold Ornaments Cluster.
The CFC in Pulses & Pulses Products Cluster, Machavaram (East Godavari District), received final approval in the 54th NLSC and sanction order on 29.07.2021.
The GoI Grant is 70% (1038.14 Lakhs), State Govt. Contribution is 20% (296.61 Lakhs), and SPV Contribution is 10% (148.31 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 1483.06 Lakhs.
The SPV deposited 10% share in the specified account.
The State Govt. matching grant was released on 31-03-2022.
E-Tenders were called for machinery supply on 14-06-2022.
The Chairman instructed the IA to expedite the completion of all works for the early implementation of the CFC in Pulses & Pulses Products Cluster.
The CFC in Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster, SPSR Nellore District, received final approval in the 54th NLSC and sanction order on 29.07.2021.
The GoI Grant is 70% (576.08 Lakhs), State Govt. Contribution is 20% (164.60 Lakhs), and SPV Contribution is 10% (82.30 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 822.98 Lakhs.
A Purchase Committee meeting was conducted on 29-03-2022.
The State Govt. matching grant was released on 31-03-2022.
The SPV is yet to raise its share capital up to 10%.
The Chairman instructed the SPV to deposit its share within 15 days and directed APMSE DC to follow up.
The CFC in Gold Jewellery Cluster, SPSR Nellore, received final approval in the 48th NLSC and sanction order on 11.07.2019.
The GoI Grant is 80% (827.50 Lakhs), State Gov. Contribution is 10% (103.86 Lakhs), and SPV Contribution is 10% (103.50 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 1034.86 Lakhs.
The SPV members attended online and informed about a land issue.
The Addl. Dev. Commissioner, MSME-DFO, advised the SPV members to resolve the land issue at the earliest and suggested taking land on lease basis immediately to avoid project cancellation.
A deadline of 3 months is given to resolve the land issue.
A fire accident incident was reported to DC (MSME).
The HQ. Insurance claim is yet to be settled.
Pending CFCs were discussed, starting with the Printing Cluster, Tirupati.
The proposal for the Printing Cluster, Tirupati, was recommended by the 1st SLSC in 2018 and accorded in-principle approval by the 46th NLSC on 09.02.18.
The SPV is yet to identify land for the CFC.
The proposal is pending due to the lack of land, and the SPV is requesting State Government contribution.
The SPV members informed about the land issue and requested State Government assistance and a 10% contribution.
They requested at least Â½ acre of land from the State Government.
Smt. G. Srijina, IAS, Director of Industries, assured to look into the matter.
The Chairman directed concerned officials to take necessary action for grounding the CFC as per old MSE-CDP guidelines.
The progress on a long-pending approved CFC (Auto Engineering cluster) was discussed.
In-principle approval was accorded by NLSC, and the land issue with SEZ for denotification has been resolved.
The SPV is unable to purchase land at the specified location.
Proposals submitted by APIIC for Development of Industrial Parks under the new MSE-CDP Scheme in Andhra Pradesh were discussed.
The Chairman directed APIIC to submit the proposals.
New ID proposals were discussed, with projects identified and DPRs yet to be submitted.
New Cluster proposals were discussed, along with a roadmap for identifying new clusters.
Shri Gopala Krishna, ED, APMSME-DC, informed that 53 new clusters have been identified, and 7 Technical Consultancy Agencies have been engaged for DPR preparation.
26 DPRs are under preparation and will be placed before the next SLSC meeting.
New MSE-CDP guidelines were discussed, including the need for the State Government to formulate a State Cluster Policy.
The Director of Industries assured to look into the matter.
ADC, MSME-DFO, proposed a corpus fund of Rs. 100 crore from the state government to implement at least 40 CFC/ID projects annually.
The Chairman assured to look into the matter and take it up with the Government.
The opening of CAN and SNA was discussed.
The State Government issued orders to open CNA by the Directorate of Industries and SNAs from Implementing Agencies (APIIC and APMSME DC) and map them with the PFMS Portal.
CNA has been opened by the Director of Industries in the name of JD MSME in SBI with account number 41222857854.
The Chairman appreciated all stakeholders for their efforts in grounding CFCs and ID projects and directed to ground more projects.
Shri G.V.R. Naidu, IEDS, Assistant Director, I/C, MSME-DFO, Visakhapatnam, proposed a vote of thanks.
