The Industries and Commerce (Prog-1) Department of the Government of Andhra Pradesh issued Memo.No. 1606134/Prog-I/A2/2023 on 19/05/2023.
The memo concerns the minutes of the 6th State Level Steering Committee Meeting of MSE-CDP, Andhra Pradesh, held on 14/03/2023 at AP Secretariat, Velagapudi.

The memo refers to an e-file received from the Commissioner of Industries (e-file No. INCO2-20032/9/2021-OM II-DOI) and an email from the Asst. Director Incharge, MSME-DFO, Visakhapatnam, dated 10.04.2023.
A copy of the minutes of the 5th State Level Steering Committee Meeting of MSE-CDP, Andhra Pradesh, held on 14/03/2023 at AP Secretariat, Velagapudi, is also referenced.
The minutes of the 6th State Level Steering Committee Meeting are communicated for further necessary action.
The meeting was held under the chairmanship of the Special Chief Secretary to Government.
I. Mohan Rao is the Additional Secretary to Government.
The minutes were forwarded by order of the Section Officer, B. Radhiar.
The 6th SLSC Meeting of MSE-CDP was held on 14/03/2023 at 03:00 PM at AP Secretariat, Velagapudi, in Hybrid Mode.
The Chairman of the meeting was Sh. Karikal Valaven, IAS, Special Chief Secretary to Govt., Industries & Commerce Deptt., AP.
Sh. D. Chandra Sekhar, IEDS, Additional Development Commissioner, MSME-DFO, Hyderabad & Visakhapatnam, served as the Member Secretary/Convener.
The Convener welcomed the Chairman, Director of Industries, members of the SLSC, SPV members, GMDICs, Implementing Agencies, representatives from SIDBI, and other participants.
MSME-DFO received 20 ID Proposals, out of which 15 were scrutinized, and 5 are yet to be scrutinized.
MSME DFO, Visakhapatnam, received 25 CFC proposals, out of which 12 were scrutinized as per MSE-CDP New Guidelines.
The Convener initiated discussions as per the Agenda Points.
Agenda Point 6.1.0 discussed the progress on the approved CFC in the Auto Engineering cluster, Kakinada.
The Auto Engineering cluster proposal was recommended by SLSC and accorded in-principle approval by NLSC.
A land issue for the Auto Engineering cluster needs to be resolved.
In the 5th SLSC meeting, the Chairman directed the allotment of land on a nominal lease basis for the Auto Engineering cluster.
The Director of Industries assured to resolve the land issue for the Auto Engineering cluster before March 31st, 2023.
Agenda Point 6.1.1 discussed the progress on the approved CFC in the Gold cluster, Nellore.
The Gold cluster proposal was recommended by SLSC and accorded in-principle approval by NLSC.
A land issue for the Gold cluster needs to be resolved.
The GM, DIC, Nellore, informed about a legal problem with the land issue pending with the AP High Court.
The SPV for the Gold cluster requested time for the land issue.
The Director of Industries assured that the land issue for the Gold cluster should be resolved within a maximum of 3 months.
If the land issue for the Gold cluster is not resolved, they should go for alternate land.
The GM, DIC, Nellore, was instructed to search for alternate land for the Gold cluster within 3 months.
If the land issue for the Gold cluster is not resolved within three months, the CFC proposal will be recommended to NLSC for cancellation.
Agenda Point 6.1.2 discussed the Printing Cluster, Tirupati.
The Printing Cluster, Tirupati proposal was recommended by SLSC in 2018 and accorded in-principle approval by the office of DC (MSME) vide 46th NLSC dated 09-02-2018.
The SPV for the Printing Cluster, Tirupati, wishes to submit a new proposal under new guidelines.
The committee may cancel the old proposal for the Printing Cluster, Tirupati.
Agenda Point 6.1.3 reviewed the status of ongoing ID Projects under MSE-CDP in Andhra Pradesh.

The reviewed ID Projects include: 1. Upgradation of Industrial Park (Jewellery Park) at Machilipatnam, Krishna District. 2. Upgradation of Growth Centre at Hindupur, Anantapuramu District. 3. Upgradation of Industrial Estate, Autonagar, Phase-IV, Guntur District. 4. New Industrial Estate at Kopparthy, YSR Kadapa District. 5. New Industrial Estate at Gandrajupalli, Chittoor District.
The CDO, MSME-DFO, Visakhapatnam, informed that Utilization Certificates (UCs) for completed/ongoing projects are pending for final closure.
New ID proposals will be approved by NLSC after the submission of closure reports.
The Director of Industries instructed APIIC to compile and submit UCs for the 5 ID Projects before March 31st, 2023.
Agenda Point 6.1.4 reviewed the status of ID Projects which were accorded in-principle/TEAC Approval.

The reviewed ID Projects include: 1. Development of FFC at Atchutapuram in Non-SEZ Area, Visakhapatnam District. 2. Upgradation of Industrial Park at Nellimarla, Vizianagaram District. 3. Upgradation of Industrial Park at IP Tanuku, West Godavari District.
All three proposals have been forwarded for consideration of NLSC.
Agenda Point 6.1.5 reviewed the dropped components in ID Projects.

Dropped components were reviewed for: A. Upgradation of Industrial Park at Singarayakonda, Prakasam District (Road Side Greenery & Social Forestry; Water supply including overhead tank & pump house; Administration and other service complex). B. Development of Industrial Park at Peddapuram, East Godavari, District (Road Side Greenery & Social Forestry; Effluent Treatment Plant). C. Development of Industrial Park at Grandrajupalli, Chittoor, District (Land filling/Levelling including boundary wall and fencing; Water supply including overhead tank & pump house; Road Side Greenery & Social Forestry; Other (Sewerage System)). D. Development of New Industrial Estate at Kopparthy, YSR Kadapa District (Land filling/Leveling including boundary wall and fencing; Effluent Treatment Facilities; Road Side Greenery & Social Forestry; Other (Sewerage System)).

The Director of Industries informed that the proposal for dropping the Effluent Treatment Facilities component in the ID Project at Kopparthy is being resubmitted with proper justifications for dropping.
The Director of Industries requested to place the proposal for dropping Effluent Treatment Facilities at Kopparthy in the upcoming NLSC and accord approval.
Agenda Point 6.2.0 requested the dropping of EPT in ID Projects - New Industrial Estate, Kopparthy, YSR Kadapa.
The Director of Industries requested for dropping of Effluent Treatment Plant in the ID Project, Kopparthy, YSR Kadapa, to be placed at NLSC.
Once accepted by NLSC, the remaining work will be completed for submission of UC and final project closure.
Agenda Point 6.3.0 discussed the progress on ongoing CFCs.
Agenda Point 6.3.1 reported on the CFC in Printing Cluster, Kakinada.

The contribution breakdown for the Printing Cluster, Kakinada, is: Grant in aid Gol (70%, Rs. 1033.2 Lakhs), State Gov. Contribution (20%, Rs. 295.2 Lakhs), SPV Contribution (10%, Rs. 147.6 Lakhs), Total Project Cost (100%, Rs. 1476 Lakhs).

For the Furniture Manufacturing Cluster: 1. Purchase committee formed, and the 1st meeting held for specifications and tenders. 2. State Govt. matching grant released on 31/03/2022. 3. The SPV is yet to raise its Share capital up to 10%. 4. IA to take further action.

Final approval for the Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster was accorded in 54th NLSC, and the sanction order was issued on 29.07.2021.

For the Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster: 1. Purchase committee meeting conducted on 29-03-2022. 2. State Govt. matching grant released on 31-03-2022. 3. The SPV is yet to raise its Share capital up to 10%. 4. IA to take further action.
The Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster project is under delay zone.

Agenda Point 6.3.6 addressed the Fire Accident in Gold Cluster, Vijayawada.
The Director Industries informed that the SPV raised its Share of 10% and will share the information.

Agenda Point 6.4.0 presented proposals submitted by APIIC for New/Upgradation of Industrial Parks under MSE-CDP in Andhra Pradesh.
The Convener, SLSC, informed that a Committee comprising SPV, CDO & GMDIC needs to be constituted for physical verification to update the latest position.
Agenda Point 6.4.1 discussed new proposals for New ID Projects, Upgradation & FFC.

The new proposals include: 1. Upgradation of Auto Nagar Gajuwaka (Block B & Block D), Visakhapatnam District. 2. Industrial Park at Gopavaram Village & Mandal, Y.S.R Kadapa District. 3. Industrial Park at IP Jagadurthy, Jagadurthy Village, Dhone Mandal, Nandyal District.
Total 20 Projects have been received by MSME-DFO, Visakhapatnam.
Out of the 20 projects, 15 proposals have been scrutinized and verified by the Committee to ascertain suitability as per new MSE-CDP guidelines.
All 15 proposals have been appraised by SIDBI and are in line with MSE-CDP guidelines.
The SLSC recommended all 15 ID Projects after due verification by MSME-DFO for placing before the next NLSC for consideration.
SLSC decided that physical inspection of 15 ID projects should be completed within 10 days.
The remaining 7 ID proposals will be placed before the next SLSC, proposed to be held shortly.
APIIC presented on the 15 proposals.
Total 25 DPRs submitted by APMSMEDC were received by MSME-DFO, Visakhapatnam.
Out of the 25 DPRs, 12 proposals have been scrutinized and verified by the Committee to ascertain suitability as per new MSE-CDP guidelines.
Only one DPR, Veeranjaneya Printing Cluster, Tirupati, was found in line and suitable to place before NLSC.
Agenda Point 6.4.2 listed ID Projects not scrutinized.
These 5 ID projects were received at a later stage and not scrutinized due to insufficient time.
The SLSC directed to scrutinize these proposals and place them before the next SLSC Meeting.

The 5 ID projects not scrutinized are: 1. IP Thatiguntapalli, Annamayya District. 2. IP Guttapadu, Kurnool District. 3. IP Kappalabanda, Sri Sathya Sai District. 4. IP Koduru, Anakapalli District. 5. FFC at Pydibhimavaram, Srikakulam District.
Agenda Point 6.5.0 discussed New CFC proposals.
Agenda Point 6.5.1 discussed proposals received and evaluated, with shortfalls communicated.

The Committee observed that the remaining 11 DPRs do not meet the basic criteria of MSE-CDP guidelines, such as SPV Registration, Land in the name of SPV, Geo tagging, land or lease details, Board Members, Cluster Member details, etc.
Hence, all 11 DPRs were rejected.

The rejected proposals include: 1. Printing Cluster, Tirupati (proposal found as per MSE-CDP guidelines, except land conversion issue; SPV applied for land conversion through single window with DIC). 2. Shri Shradda Agro Vizianagara Association, Garividi (Land allotment not done, geo tagging details not available; members have UAM registrations with validity ceasing from 01-07-2022; contribution of individual SPV members missing in amount; rejected with advice to resubmit with clear land titles in SPV name). 3. The Additional Development Commissioner assured to take up the issue of SIDBI appraisal delays at a higher level in SIDBI HQ and request for speedy and timely disposal of DPRs.

The Detailed Project Report (DPR) is for setting up a Common Facility Centre at Mangalagiri, AP, under the MSE-CDP Scheme for the Mangalagiri Gold Ornament Cluster, promoted by LN Goldsmiths Foundation.
The DPR is submitted to the DC MSME GoI through the MSME Development Corporation GoAP.

The DPR contains chapters on Executive Summary, Introduction, Brief Particulars of the Proposal, Details of Project Promoters/Sponsors, Eligibility as per MSE-CDP guidelines, Implementing Arrangements, Management and Shareholding details, Technical Aspects, Implementation Schedule, Project Components, Fund Requirement/Availability Analysis, Usage Charges, Commercial Viability, Financial and Economic Viability, Projected performance of the cluster, Status of Government approvals, Favorable and Risk Factors (SWOT Analysis), Risk Mitigation Framework, Economics of the project, Cluster Profile, Diagnostic Study Findings, and Conclusion.
The DPR also includes Financial Projections/Estimates/Assumptions in Annexures and Other Supporting Documents in Appendices.
Mangalagiri, in Guntur district, is known for its handloom weaving and has emerged as a hub for gold ornament production.
The Gold Ornament Manufacturing Industry in Mangalagiri employs around 12,000 goldsmiths.
About 2,000 units in Mangalagiri specialize in producing gold jewelry, supplying approximately 1500 kilograms annually.
The proposed project aims to establish a Common Facility Centre (CFC) for Gold Ornament Manufacturing in Mangalagiri.
The LN Goldsmiths Foundation, a Section 8 company, was incorporated on 05 November 2024 with CIN U88900AP2024NPL116554.
The project cost is â¹999.36 Lacs.
The SPV contributes â¹49.90 Lacs (5%), AP State Government contributes â¹149.90 Lacs (15%), and Rs. 799.49 Lacs (80%) is sought from the Government of India as Grant in Aid.
The CFC is designed to be self-sustaining through user charges.
The CFC is set to commence operations from March 2025.
The SPV is a not-for-profit entity under Section 8 of the Companies Act, 2013.
The project implementation schedule spans 18 months from the sanction of the grant.
The CFC will offer services including casting, chain making, ball making, finishing, miscellaneous processes, designing & prototyping, assaying, hallmarking, and training & skill development.
The CFC is proposed to be established in a leased building on Gowthama Buddha Road, Mangalagiri, with a total floor area of about 7000 sq.ft.
The lease agreement is for 15 years, registered vide Document Number 15945/2024 on 01/11/2024.
The CFC building is located 1 km from National Highway 16 and Mangalagiri Railway Station, and 40 km from Vijayawada International Airport.
The cost of machinery and equipment is â¹830.32 Lacs.
The CFC does not undertake manufacturing and selling activities; it provides services using raw materials provided by artisans.
The building has a dedicated transformer with a capacity of 65 KV and a connected load of 35 KV.
No specific effluent treatment is required as the processes do not generate harmful chemicals.
Firefighting equipment is installed as per standards, and a No Objection Certificate (NOC) was issued by the Disaster Response & Fire Services Department.
Manpower will be recruited from the vicinity and trained.
The project is scheduled for completion within 6 months of grant sanction, subject to timely formation of the purchase committee and receipt of funds.

The project cost breakdown includes Civil & Interior Works, Furniture, Fixtures (â¹106.61 Lacs), Machinery & Equipment (â¹830.32 Lacs), Preliminary & Preoperative Expenses (â¹8.70 Lacs), and Working Capital Margin (â¹53.73 Lacs).
The proposed means of financing are Promoters Contribution (5%), AP State Government's Contribution (15%), and Grant from GoI under MSE-CDP Scheme (80%).
Usage charges for CFC services will differ for members and non-members, with training being free for cluster members.
The CFC is commercially viable, bridging critical gaps in technology, quality, and market access.
The project's financial parameters (Breakeven Point, ROCE, NPV, IRR) are within acceptable norms.
The CFC is expected to increase beneficiary units, direct and indirect employment, and production.
The cluster's total domestic turnover is projected to increase, and export turnover is expected to commence.
The profit margin for cluster units is projected to increase.
The building plan for the leased CFC premises is approved by the Andhra Pradesh Capital Region Development Authority.
The SPV is registered in the NGO DARPAN Portal with Unique ID AP/2024/0477330.
The SPV is registered under GST with GSTIN 37AAGCL0238E1ZS.
An application for Consent to Establish (CTE) has been filed with the Andhra Pradesh Pollution Control Board.

SWOT analysis highlights strengths like centralized advanced facilities, cost-effective operations, enhanced quality standards, skilled workforce development, increased market access, strong marketing network, accessibility to markets, supportive government policy, and strong management.
Weaknesses include dependency on user fees, limited initial awareness, high initial capital requirement, and potential skills gap.

Opportunities include expansion into export markets, product diversification, job creation, public-private partnerships, increased consumer trust through quality certification, and strong government support.
Threats include market competition, economic fluctuations, technological obsolescence, resistance to change, and regulatory compliance/export barriers.

Risk mitigation strategies are proposed for technology adoption, financial sustainability, market competition, price volatility of gold, limited export knowledge, initial resistance to change, operational challenges, and technological obsolescence.
The project cost is â¹999.36 Lacs, with financing from Promoters (5%), AP State Government (15%), and GoI Grant (80%).
The LN Goldsmiths Foundation is incorporated as a Section 8 company.
The Memorandum of Association (MOA) and Articles of Association (AOA) of the SPV are detailed.
The SPV has opened a project-specific bank account with Bank of Baroda.
Quotations for interior fit-outs have been received.
The SPV has provided undertakings for utilizing at least 60% of installed capacity and for bringing in its contribution and meeting cost escalations.
The Andhra Pradesh Capital Region Development Authority has issued penalization orders for deviations in building plans for the property at D.No. 9-44A, Old Mangalagiri.

The State Disaster Response & Fire Services Department has issued a conditional No Objection Certificate (NOC) for occupancy to the existing building of Krishi Legal Educational Center (Law College) at Sy.No. 111-1A1, Near D.NO.9-44-A, Old Mangalagiri, Guntur District, subject to compliance with deficit fire safety systems.
A Common Application Form I Part A for establishment has been filed with the Nodal Agency.
The application for Consent to Establish (CTE) has been filed with the Andhra Pradesh Pollution Control Board, Guntur Regional Office, for LN Goldsmith Foundation.
The application falls under the Orange Category as per CPCB guidelines, and a balance CTE fee of Rs. 1,59,600/- needs to be paid.
The Aadhaar details of promoters are provided.
Income Tax Returns for AY 2022-23 and 2023-24 for Nagaraju Gunti and Mahesh Padavala are included.
The Trading, Profit & Loss Account and Balance Sheet as of 31.03.2022 for Nagaraju Gunti are provided.
The Income Tax Return Acknowledgement for Srinivasa Rao Gajula for AY 2023-24 and AY 2024-25 are provided.
The Income Tax Return Acknowledgement for Mahesh Padavala for AY 2023-24 and AY 2024-25 are provided.
The Income Tax Return Acknowledgement for Nagarjuna Kandula for AY 2022-23 is provided.

The minutes of the Board of Directors meeting held on 01.01.2025 approved the establishment of the Common Facility Centre and the application for Grant in Aid from the Government of India under the MSE CDP Scheme.
The Government has issued the Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Policy 2023-27.

The Director of Industries stated that the Government of Andhra Pradesh aims to build a robust industrial sector that contributes significantly to the state's economy and creates large-scale employment.
The Government is keen on realizing its vision and repositioning brand AP on the global platform.
The Government is prioritizing plans to review and revise the Industrial Development Policy to make it more competitive and appealing to investors.
This initiative is essential for revitalizing economic activity, promoting the state's economic growth and social development, and establishing a supportive environment for industrial advancement.
The Director of Industries stated that Andhra Pradesh has consistently been at the forefront of industrial development, implementing numerous policy initiatives to foster growth and innovation.

The state's industrial policy aims to address key areas such as Balanced, Resilient, and Sustainable Growth, Green Energy Transition, Integration into Global Value Chain, Gateway to the East, Riding the Emerging Tech Wave, Capitalizing on Demographic Dividend, Circular Economy, and Industry 4.0 and AI Adoption.

The Director of Industries submitted that considering the evolving needs of investors, climate change practitioners, and the necessity to create employment opportunities for the indigenous workforce, the state is course-correcting its Industrial development policy.
The forward-looking policy aims to establish a supportive ecosystem that fosters economic value while encouraging responsible actions towards climate goals and human safety.
The Director of Industries, Mangalagiri, has prepared and proposed a new Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Policy (4.0) 2024-29.

The Finance Department remarked that Capital subsidy on investments and additional subsidies like Top up Subsidy on PLI subsidy, Employment Subsidy, and Decarburization Subsidy are proposed for the first time and are a welcome move that will attract many investors to the State of AP.

The Finance Department advised the Industries & Commerce Department to tap maximum cash outgo under various categories of incentives/subsidies to 75% of FCI, in respect of the 'Early Bird' category to expedite of-take of the policy.
The Finance Department remarked that the Industries department has to work out a self-financing model to pay Industrial incentives proposed under various policies.
The Government, after careful examination of the proposal, hereby introduces the Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Policy (4.0) 2024-29.
The Policy Document, under Annexure, is appended to this order.
This policy shall be valid for a period of 5 years from the date of the policy notification, or till a new Policy is announced.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh may extend the period of this Policy as and when required.
The policy may be amended and modified during implementation.
The Policy shall be applicable to the entire State.

This policy shall be applicable to (a) New and existing enterprises investing and establishing enterprises) and investments) and (b) Existing enterprises investing in expansion of enterprises) and investments).
The Incentives mentioned in the policy will be extended to Industries as per the operational guidelines to be notified separately.
This order issues with the remarks of the Finance (FMU-I&I, Energy and I&C) Department.
The Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Policy (4.0) 2024-29 has been issued.

The policy includes sections on Preamble, Policy Period & Applicability, Policy Framework, Focus sectors, Reducing Cost of Production, Enabling Speed of Doing Business, Strengthening MSMEs & Entrepreneurs, Financial Incentives, Special Package for Early Bird project scheme, and Policy Implementation.
The policy document includes a list of abbreviations.
The preamble highlights Andhra Pradesh's strategic location, its long coastline, and its role as a key player connecting India to the world.

Post-bifurcation, Andhra Pradesh has invested significantly in industrial legacy and promoting its strengths, attracting FDI in the automobile sector, and initiating the development of 3 industrial corridors.
The state leveraged digitization to transform industrial approval and tracking processes, achieving the No. 1 position in 'Ease of Doing Business' rankings.
Andhra Pradesh's Gross State Domestic Product (GSDP) 2023-24 is estimated at INR 14.39 Lakh Crores, with a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 11% from 2011-12 to 2023-24.
The state's economy has diversified with significant contributions from agriculture, industry, and services.
In the last decade, the state started comprehensive infrastructure plans, combining ports, airports, industrial corridors, parks, and essential utilities.
The state saw rapid proliferation of major industries to all corners, including Visakhapatnam, Vijayawada, Chittoor, Tirupati, Anantapur, and Kurnool.

Andhra Pradesh stands at the forefront of India's industrial transformation, with a strong foundation in manufacturing, a thriving ecosystem of innovation, and a commitment to sustainable development.
The government aims to create an enabling framework for industrial development that harmonizes economic prosperity with environmental stewardship and social responsibility.
There are over 1,066 Large and Mega Enterprises operating in the state.
Since the formation of the state, in the last 10 years, INR 1.4 Lakh Crores worth of investments have been realized, and 2.54 lakh employments have been created.

The highest investment values in the state have been directed towards the Chemicals & Petrochemicals sector (36%), followed by Infrastructure (15%), Basic Metals & Alloys (8%), Food, Agro & Marine Products (6%), Renewable Energy (6%), Auto & Auto components (6%), and Electrical & Electronics (5%).
Andhra Pradesh's export portfolio includes a significant portion of raw materials, with 53% of exports going to RCEP (28%) and USMCA (25%) trade blocs for value addition.
11% of the state's export basket generates 78% of its export revenue.
Top export products from Andhra Pradesh include pharmaceuticals, marine products, shipbuilding & floating structures, organic chemicals, iron and steel, and wood pulp and fiber.
Andhra Pradesh accounts for 9 Lakh registered MSMEs as of February 2024, approximately 3.23% of India's formalized MSMEs.
The National Sample Survey 2015-16 estimates 34 Lakh MSMEs in the state, indicating many operate in the unorganized sector.
The MSME sector generates nearly 10 jobs for every 1 Crore investment and accounts for 23.5% of GDP and 28.3% of exports.
The majority of MSMEs are concentrated in the services sector (79%) and are classified as Micro enterprises (97%).
In the manufacturing sector, MSMEs are primarily engaged in food processing, textiles, non-metallic minerals, and pharmaceuticals.
There are 28 exclusive MSME parks in Andhra Pradesh, spread across 1,378 acres, with a 64% occupancy rate.
The state is implementing 9 Common Facility Centers (CFCs) and 32 Infrastructure Development projects for MSME clusters.

The state is developing 3 industrial corridors with linkages to major infrastructure: Visakhapatnam-Chennai Industrial Corridor, Chennai-Bengaluru Industrial Corridor, and Hyderabad-Bengaluru Industrial Corridor.
Andhra Pradesh has 1 Major and 5 non-major ports in operation.
The state has 7 airports facilitating domestic and international connectivity.
The state has an extensive network of national and state highways and comprehensive rail routes connecting major industrial hubs.
Dedicated Freight Corridors are enhancing cargo movement efficiency.
There are 211 industrial parks providing ready industrial land.
Andhra Pradesh is a power surplus state with an installed power generation capacity of 20 GW, with over 39% from renewable sources in FY 23.
The total energy consumption during the period was 72,400 MU.
The state is developing significant renewable energy capacity to reduce power costs and decarbonize the economy.
Andhra Pradesh is home to numerous higher education institutions, including central universities, autonomous institutions, state universities, deemed universities, and private universities.
Notable institutions include AIIMS (Mangalagiri), IIM (Visakhapatnam), IIT (Tirupati), IIPE (Visakhapatnam), and NID (Vijayawada).
Andhra Pradesh has a strong foundation in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education, with approximately 75% of students choosing Science streams after 10th grade.
The state has a literacy rate of around 67% and a labor force participation rate of 55%.
Andhra Pradesh has been graded in the 'achievers' category for coastal states in Logistics ease by the 'Logistics Ease Across Different States' (LEADS) report 2023.
Andhra Pradesh ranks 8th in the Export Preparedness Index released by NITI Aayog in 2022.
8 districts from Andhra Pradesh are among the 'Top 100 Export Districts' in India.
The state is in the top 10 in the NITI Aayog's SDG Performance Report 2023-24.
Andhra Pradesh has been recognized as one of the top 7 leading states in energy efficiency by the Bureau of Energy Efficiency in its 2023 State Energy Efficiency Index.
Companies have heavily invested in Asia due to low labor and production costs and substantial consumer markets, leading to overconcentration and supply chain risks.
Companies are now looking to diversify production and supply chain activities by establishing alternative manufacturing or sourcing locations like India.

India is considered a favored alternative due to its relationships with major economies, large consumer market, cost-competitive manufacturing, skilled labor force, strategic geopolitical location, economic reforms, and supportive ecosystem.

The state of Andhra Pradesh aims to continue its reform-based agenda and address key areas such as Balanced Resilient, and Sustainable Growth, Green Energy Transition and Decarbonization, Integration into Global Value Chain, Gateway to the East, Riding the Emerging Tech Wave, Capitalizing on Demographic Dividend, Circular Economy, Industry 4.0, and AI Adoption.
The renewed, forward-looking policy aims to establish a supportive ecosystem that fosters economic value while encouraging responsible actions towards climate goals and human safety.
This Policy shall be valid for a period of 5 years from the date of the policy notification, or till a new Policy is announced.
The policy may be amended and modified during implementation, but amendments and modifications shall be applied prospectively.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh may extend the period of this Policy as and when required.
The Policy shall be applicable to the entire State and shall give direction to boost economic development.
This policy shall be applicable to new and existing enterprises investing and establishing new units, and existing enterprises investing in expansion of units.
Enterprises need to obtain Consent for Operation (CFO) and commence commercial production during the operative period of the Policy to be eligible for incentives.
This policy shall substitute IDP 2023-27 from the date of notification.
Enterprises availing benefits under IDP 2023-27 shall continue to avail eligible benefits under that policy till the end of its operative period.

The vision is to transform Andhra Pradesh into an internationally competitive industrial hub, seamlessly integrated into global value chains and renowned for achieving product perfection across sectors.
The guiding principle motto is to reduce the cost of production and improve the speed of business for enterprises.
The policy aims to create a globally attractive manufacturing destination.
The policy aims to build a competitive ecosystem for sustainable manufacturing.
The policy aims to achieve product perfect value creation and build marquee Global Indian brands.
The policy aims for Green Energy Transition by integrating various verticals of RE generation to increase green energy footprint.
The policy aims to leverage inland waterways for transportation through interlinking of rivers.
The policy aims to attract FDI in Emerging Sectors.
The policy aims to dovetail with Gol Schemes, complementing national initiatives.
Andhra Pradesh will create a conducive environment for enterprises looking to diversify manufacturing bases and expand to new markets without compromising climate goals.
This policy will encourage enterprises to diversify production by offering competitive incentives and support in achieving emission reduction endeavors.
The policy aims to support enterprises in achieving the highest standards of quality, ensuring products meet emission reduction norms and standards.
The government will provide comprehensive support to enterprises seeking globally recognized quality certifications, including incentives, technical assistance, and access to training programs.
The state will encourage local enterprises to manufacture quality products.
The government aims to establish the state as a premier destination for Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) by creating a conducive business-friendly and climate-responsible environment.
The state will focus on enhancing infrastructure, ensuring ease and speed of doing business, and providing robust support systems to attract global investors.
The government will actively engage with global giants through targeted outreach programs and high-level delegations.
The state will highlight its competitive advantages, including advanced infrastructure, favorable business climate, and industry-friendly policy initiatives.
By fostering partnerships with Fortune 500 companies, the state aims to drive technological advancements, enhance skill development, and create high-value employment opportunities.
The government is committed to creating substantial employment opportunities through this policy, aiming to generate jobs for 5 lakh individuals over the next five years.
Andhra Pradesh has the advantage of qualified manpower due to premier educational institutions like IIT Tirupati, IIM Visakhapatnam, SPA Vijayawada, NIT, NLU, NIFT, etc.
The State Government is committed to Human Resource development and has actively promoted private sector participation in setting up training and skilling institutes.
The government recognizes the urgency in action towards climate change and is committed to promoting the use of renewable energy sources.
By harnessing the state's abundant renewable resources, the government aims to reduce dependence on fossil fuels, lower greenhouse gas emissions, and mitigate the impacts of climate change.
This approach ensures a cleaner environment and supports long-term economic growth by creating green jobs and fostering innovation in the renewable energy sector.
The state is looking to achieve 40 GW energy from renewable sources by 2030.
This policy will help the renewable energy sector by addressing issues related to financing, land consolidation, and promoting research & development and innovation.
The government aims to promote the principles of Recycle, Reuse, and Reduce (RRR).
It will support research and development in circular economy technologies and practices, fostering innovation and the creation of new solutions.
Encouraging collaborations between the public sector, private companies, and academic institutions to accelerate the development and implementation of circular economy initiatives.
Industry 4.0 plays a crucial role in the manufacturing sector, transforming production methods, enhancing productivity, and boosting global competitiveness.
Industry 4.0 relies on the Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI).
The convergence of AI and IoT enables manufacturers to leverage data from IoT devices for informed decision-making and operational optimization.
The state will create a conducive environment for research, workforce training, and bridging skill gaps.
It will address ethical issues in the responsible utilization of AI in manufacturing and simplify compliance with regulations and industry standards.
The government aims to harness the potential of inland waterways to enhance the state's transportation infrastructure.
Water transport is the cheapest way to transport goods among various modes of transportation.
Investing in the development of ports, terminals, and related infrastructure along inland waterways can create new economic opportunities and generate employment.
India's trade with the Global East is projected to grow faster than the global average.
Andhra Pradesh (AP) is poised to become a 'Logistics Hub for the East' due to its strategic locational advantages.
The state features three ports with drafts over 18 meters, contributing to 15% of India's total port handling capacity.
The Vizag-Chennai Industrial Corridor, along with the Chennai-Bangalore and Hyderabad-Bangalore corridors, further strengthens its logistical significance.
Enhancing value addition near ports for high-value goods will enable AP to leverage its logistical strengths and stimulate economic growth.
The Government of India has implemented several initiatives to establish India as a significant manufacturing hub.
In alignment with national initiatives, the state will take requisite measures to complement existing efforts.
These steps may include providing additional incentives, introducing new schemes, and framing new rules to create a conducive environment for manufacturing and economic development.
The State's exports stood at USD 19 Billion in FY 2024, with the majority being bulk cargo (raw material).
The State shall focus on adopting strategies that include responsible product diversification, strengthening the current ecosystem, and focusing on value addition based on current export potential.
The state will encourage GI tagging of local produce such as agri produce, marine products, toys, and garments.
The target is to increase Gross Value Addition from Manufacturing from INR 3.4 Lakh Crores in FY 24 (AE) to INR 7.3 Lakh Crores by the end of the policy period.
The target is to attract Investments worth INR 30 Lakh Crores, with approximately 15% of investment worth INR 5 Lakh Crores to be operationalized during the policy period.
The target is to attract a minimum of USD 10 Billion of FDI (INR 83,000 Crores) to the state during the policy period.
The target is to create first-time employment of 5 Lakhs during the policy period from the manufacturing sector.
The target is to develop more than 175 Industrial Parks during the policy period.

The target is to increase exports by 15% year-on-year and double the export value from the state from USD 20 Billion (INR 16,600 Crores) in FY 24 to USD 40 Billion (INR 33,200 Crores) by the end of the policy period.

The government will implement its vision and targets by focusing on defining sectors of focus, reducing cost of production, driving initiatives enabling Speed of Doing Business, strengthening MSMEs and Entrepreneurs, and providing Financial Incentives to fast-track investment attraction.
The government has identified two categories of focus sectors: sustenance sectors and propelling sectors.
Sustenance sectors are those with an established presence and potential to add to GSDP and employment.
Propelling sectors are gaining traction globally and have the potential to link Andhra Pradesh to the global supply chain.

The government intends to bring down the cost of production for the larger manufacturer community through interventions in land consolidation, infrastructure, logistics, rationalization of tariffs and duties, and labor productivity.
Andhra Pradesh has three National industrial corridors: VCIC, CBIC, and HBIC.
The industrial corridors will expand and enhance the competitiveness of the manufacturing sector and facilitate employment creation.
The program will expand multi-modal transport networks along corridors, enhance institutions for corridor management, and address skills gaps.
The state has 20 existing clusters with available industrial land spread across 14,093 acres.
The state has identified 30 additional clusters covering 1.3 Lakh acres, with 54,781 acres being port-based and 75,683 acres being hinterland-based.
Of the total identified land, 44,777 acres is in the state's possession.
These clusters will be integrated into the industrial corridor network, facilitating linkages, efficient logistics, and seamless movement of goods.
Provision of external infrastructure like road, water, and power connection to industrial parks is critical for investors.
The government will invite private sector participation to fast-track external infrastructure projects.
A dedicated Private Industrial Parks policy is introduced, elaborating on various models to incentivize the development of private industrial parks.

Three Industrial Parks development models are proposed for private player participation: Industrial Park Development with complete private land, Industrial Park Development with Partial Government / APIIC Land, and Industrial Park Development with Complete Government / APIIC Land.
To achieve port-based value addition, the government will attract investments from large shipping and logistic operators to establish and operate sector-specific giga-size fulfillment centers.
The fulfillment centers will perform raw material inventory management on-demand.
The state has the advantage of two perennial river systems, Krishna and Godavari.
The state has received approval for National Waterway 4 (NW-4).
The State Government will focus on developing NW-4 to leverage the benefits of inland water transport for logistic movement.
The state has received approval for two dedicated Freight corridors (DFC): North-South DFC and East Coast DFC.
The state will prioritize road infrastructure projects connecting DFCs to existing and upcoming seaports.
Government will take measures to rationalize power tariff, water tariff, building permission charges, layout charges, and other charges affecting cost competitiveness.
Efforts will be made by related departments to arrive at equilibrium tariff structures that assure price stability for manufacturers.
The government intends to roll out a Skill Census in collaboration with industry associations to systematically collect data on workforce skill sets.
The government intends to bring PPP model-based operations of Industrial Training Institutes (ITIs), open for adoption by nearby industry/industry association.
Land parcels will be earmarked for the development of dormitories with supporting amenities to facilitate better living conditions for employees in industrial parks/areas.
The state has launched the Single Desk Portal (SDP) in June 2015, which helps industries obtain over 93 regulatory clearances in 21 days.
The SDP supports end-to-end transaction processing with online payment and application status tracking.
Investors can obtain clearances from 19 departments covering pre-establishment approvals, pre-operation approvals, and renewals.
An investment facilitation cell has been created to reduce the hassle of coordinating with multiple agencies post-submission of requests on the Single Desk Portal.
Each investor will be assisted by a Liaison Officer who helps in following up with different line departments and keeps the investor updated on approval progress.
Andhra Pradesh has traditionally been a favored destination for overseas investors.
The Industrial Policy aims to strengthen this trend and promote accelerated growth in foreign investments.
A healthy business environment with a predictable and non-discriminatory regime reduces the risk of doing business and is a major contributor to driving foreign investments.
The Government is committed to providing world-class infrastructure, state-of-the-art R&D centers, and quality human capital to attract FDI inflows.
Select country-specific desks will provide bespoke investor facilitation, handholding services, and a comprehensive portal with business opportunity information.

To improve the speed of doing business, various services requiring approvals will be classified into three categories: self-certification based, in-principle approval based on self-certification with final approval post-inspection, and services deemed approved if post-inspection approval is not received within the defined SLA.
All interventions will be re-engineered cautiously to ensure industrial safety is not compromised.
India's digital landscape is thriving, with over 751 Million internet subscribers as of 2024.
Andhra Pradesh actively promotes digital growth, innovation, and adoption of new technology in development.
The department of Industries will create an integrated data management system to provide information on demand, market, infrastructure, value chain, marketing events, export potential, etc.
The system will track industrial output from each district, integrate with current systems like Gatishakti, and enable targeted policy measures.
A dedicated forum constituted by industry associations, subject matter experts, and government will be created to receive feedback from industry at regular intervals.
MSMEs are considered the backbone of economic growth and major employment generators.
As of February 2024, there are around 7.41 lakh registered MSME units, employing around 61.98 lakh people as of July 2024.
The State recognizes the need for support for the MSME sector to keep pace with global manufacturing trends and tap export markets.
A dedicated MSME and Entrepreneur Development Policy will be introduced to provide focused support for MSMEs and new entrepreneurs.
More than 175 MSME parks, with at least one park per constituency, will be developed.
A dedicated corpus of INR 500 Cr will be created during the policy period towards CGTMSE, Technology transfer, revival of sick units, R&D, etc.
A holistic 8-dimensional approach will be adopted to elevate MSME competitiveness and nurture new entrepreneurs.

The state classifies investment categories into four investment bands: Sub Large Projects (51-500 Cr), Large Projects (501-1,000 Cr), Mega Projects (1,001-5,000 Cr), and Ultra Mega Projects (5,001 Cr and above).
The overall incentive a company can claim shall not exceed 100% of FCI in the state of Andhra Pradesh.
Government is working towards an ESCROW account-based disbursement mechanism for timely disbursement of incentives.
For Sub Large Projects (FCI above INR 50 Crores up to INR 500 Crores), a capital subsidy of 12% of FCI is offered.
For Projects delayed beyond the committed completion date, the incentive will be reduced by 0.5% for each month of delay.
For Enterprises wholly owned by women/BC/SC/ST/specially-abled investors domicile from AP, an additional subsidy of 5% of FCI is applicable for Sub Large Projects.
Incentive for Sub Large Projects shall be disbursed in 5 equal annual installments from the DCP.
For Sub Large Projects, a Top-up on PLI approved applicants from Government of India offers 10% of the total incentive amount sanctioned under the Gol Scheme, capped at 5% of FCI.
For Sub Large Projects, Employment creation subsidy is offered based on the Direct employment to investment ratio, ranging from 8% to 10% of FCI.
For Sub Large Projects, Local Procurement Subsidy offers reimbursement of 1% of annual export turnover for exporting units in select sectors.
For Sub Large Projects, Power Cost reimbursement of INR 1 per unit is provided for 2 years from the date of commencement of commercial production.
For Sub Large Projects, 100% net SGST reimbursement is provided for 5 years from the date of commercial production.
For Large Projects (FCI above INR 501 Crores up to INR 1,000 Crores), a maximum capital subsidy of 12% of FCI is offered, subject to installation of committed total plant capacity.
For Large Projects, the incentive will be reduced by 0.5% for each month of delay beyond the committed completion date.
Incentive for Large Projects shall be disbursed in 7 equal annual installments from the DCP.
For Large Projects, Top-up on PLI from Government of India offers 10% of the total incentive amount sanctioned under the Gol Scheme, capped at 5% of FCI.
For Large Projects, Employment creation subsidy is offered based on the Direct employment to investment ratio, ranging from 8% to 10% of FCI, disbursed in 7 equal annual installments.
For Large Projects, 100% net SGST reimbursement is provided for 5 years from the date of commercial production.
Mega Projects (FCI Above INR 1,001 Crores up to INR 5,000 Crores) and Ultra Mega Projects (FCI Above INR 5,001 Crores) will receive tailor-made benefits.
For Mega & Ultra Mega Projects, a maximum capital subsidy of 15% of FCI is offered, subject to installation of committed total plant capacity.
Incentive for Mega & Ultra Mega Projects shall be disbursed in 10 equal annual installments from the DCP.
For Projects delayed beyond committed completion date, the incentive will be reduced by 0.5% for each month of delay.
For Mega & Ultra Mega Projects, Top-up on PLI from Government of India offers 10% of the total incentive amount sanctioned under the Gol Scheme, capped at 5% of FCI.

For Mega & Ultra Mega Projects, Employment creation subsidy is offered based on the employment to investment ratio, ranging from 8% to 10% of FCI, disbursed over 9 years for Mega and 10 years for Ultra Mega projects.
De-carbonization subsidy is applicable for all investment bands, incentivizing circular economy, clean production, waste reduction, resource efficiency, green energy, and safety measures.
The total incentive under De-carbonization subsidy will be limited to a maximum of 6% of FCI.
Stamp Duty reimbursement of 100% is provided for purchase of land, lease of land/shed/buildings, mortgages, and hypothecations.
100% fee charged for land conversion will be reimbursed.
Government will investigate sick enterprises and extend support for reviving sick units on a case-to-case basis.
Special incentives are offered under the 'Early Bird Project Scheme'.
Category I: First 200 projects meeting eligibility conditions and receiving CFE within 18 months will be offered an Investment subsidy of 30% of FCI.
Category II: Investments in sectors/sub-sectors identified for promotion by Gol under PLI schemes, meeting eligibility conditions, will be offered an investment subsidy of 40% of FCI.
For Category II projects, the time requirement to receive CFE will be relaxed to 24 months.
Companies availing benefits under Category II are not eligible to avail benefits under Category I.
The incentives for Category I and II will override the 'incentive subsidy' applicable in the respective investment band.
Units will have to achieve DCP within the standard investment period defined for the respective investment bands to claim incentives under this scheme.
For Mega & Ultra-Mega projects under the Early Bird Scheme, the state will negotiate a competitive tailored incentive package.
The State Investment Promotion Board (SIPB) has been constituted with the Chief Minister as Chairman and Chief Secretary as Member Convener to expedite decision-making on industrial projects.
The SIPB shall meet once a month for taking final decisions on investments/promotion activities and for approval of Megaprojects.

The State Investment Promotion Committee (SIPC) chaired by the Chief Secretary meets every month to monitor and review the performance of the single desk system, policy issues, implementation of large/mega ongoing projects, screening of mega project proposals, and scrutiny of issues/proposals for SIPB consideration.
The operating guidelines for this policy will be issued separately.

The Andhra Pradesh Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Corporation (AP MSME DC) invites Expressions of Interest (EOI) for the empanelment of qualified Consultants or Consultancy Organisations.
The EOI is for the development of Common Facility Centres (CFCs) under the MSE-CDP scheme.
The MSE-CDP is a flagship initiative of the Ministry of MSME, Government of India, aimed at enhancing productivity, competitiveness, and sustainability of MSEs through cluster-based interventions.
The scheme primarily supports the development of Common Facility Centres (CFCs) and Infrastructure Development (ID) projects within industrial clusters.
Under the CFC component, financial assistance of up to 80% of the project cost is provided by the Government of India for the creation of shared facilities.
AP MSME DC functions as the Implementation Agency (IA) for the CFC Component.
AP MSME DC is committed to empowering MSMEs by promoting cluster-based development models.
The Corporation works closely with District Industries Centres (DICs), Industrial Associations, and cluster-based SPVs.
AP MSME DC is responsible for convening State-Level Steering Committee (SLSC) meetings, coordinating with SIDBI and the Office of DC-MSME, and monitoring progress.

The purpose of this EOI is to empanel qualified Consultants or Consultancy Organisations with expertise in providing comprehensive technical and procedural support for the implementation of CFC projects under the MSE-CDP scheme.

Empanelled consultants will assist SPVs and the Implementing Agency in cluster identification, preparation of Detailed Project Reports (DPRs), need assessments, and suggesting technological interventions.
Consultants will be responsible for preparing e-tender documents, facilitating the procurement of machinery and services, and supporting the SPV during the entire procurement cycle.
Consultants are expected to undertake technical feasibility studies, develop layout plans, monitor on-site progress, and guide the SPV in achieving quality benchmarks.
Their role extends to assisting in joint inspections, supervising commissioning and trial runs, and preparing technical documentation for Utilization Certificates (UCs) and project closure reports.
The empanelment aims to create a pool of dependable technical experts to ensure CFCs are technically sound, financially viable, and implemented within prescribed timelines.
AP MSME DC invites EOIs from competent and eligible professional Consultants/Consultancy Organisations for empanelment as Technical Consultants for the development of CFCs under MSE-CDP.
Eligible bidders can submit their EOIs on or before December 15, 2025 (17:00 Hrs).
The last date and time for submission of EOIs is December 15th, 2025.
Shortlisted Applicants will be intimated by Email/Letter regarding the place, date, and time of making a technical presentation.
The officer in-charge for correspondence is Shri. A. Sudhakar, Executive Director, AP MSME Development Corporation.
Application Fee: A non-refundable application fee of Rs. 20,000/- must be paid through NEFT/RTGS.
EOIs without valid proof of fee payment will be considered non-responsive.
Empanelled Consultants or Consultancy Organisations will be expected to offer professional services across key stages of project implementation.

Consultants will provide specialized advisory and analytical services, contribute to the execution of planned interventions, offer domain-specific insights, and assist in data analysis and sectoral research.
Consultants may be engaged to conduct technical training programs, evaluations, diagnostic studies, and develop marketing strategies.
Empanelment will be carried out after assessing the professional standing, ethical credentials, technical capabilities, and demonstrated experience of individuals or firms.

AP MSME DC proposes to build a panel of technical consultants with experience in one or more of the following domains: Agro processing & Food Technology, Textiles, Handlooms, Garments and Making of Gold Ornaments, Renewable Energy & Energy Efficiency, Engineering, Electrical, Electronics, Rubber, Wood & Furniture, Coir, Bamboo, Cashew, Medical Devices & Precision Equipment, Civil Infrastructure & Industrial Layouts, Handicrafts, Khadi, Village Industries, Retail, Printing, Logistics, Commerce, and Cluster Development & Value Chain Integration.
Once empanelled, consultants may be invited to submit proposals for specific assignments.
The Applicant shall be a Consultancy Organisation registered in India for at least 5 years and having operational presence in Andhra Pradesh, OR a Government Agency based in Andhra Pradesh.
The applicant must have successfully completed at least 3 DPRs and got approval under MSME schemes such as MSE-CDP, SFURTI, or similar Central Government supported initiatives.
The Applicant should have successfully undertaken activities pertaining to the implementation of at least 2 Central/State Government Projects in India and preferably in Andhra Pradesh.
The Applicant should demonstrate sufficient personnel, organizational, and technical strength to carry out cluster-based assignments.
The Applicant shall have a registered office in India and must have an office/service network in Andhra Pradesh, preferably in Vijayawada.
The Applicant should not have been blacklisted by any Government or Government Entity in the last 3 years (2022-23, 2023-24, 2024-25).
The applicant must have achieved a minimum annual turnover of â¹20 lakhs in at least one of the last three financial years (2022-23, 2023-24, 2024-25).
Shortlisted applicants will be required to make a technical Presentation before the Evaluation Committee.
The empanelment of Consultants/Consultancy Organisations shall be valid for a period of three (3) years from the date of constitution of the panel.
The tenure may be extended at the discretion of the AP MSME Development Corporation (AP MSME DC) or the Department of Industries & Commerce, Government of Andhra Pradesh.
AP MSME DC reserves the right to add new Consultants/Consultancy Organisations to the empanelled panel at any point during the validity period.
The final decision on selection shall lie solely with the AP MSME DC/Department of Industries & Commerce and will be binding on all empanelled parties.
Non-performance or under-performance of any empanelled Consultant/Consultancy Organisation may lead to exclusion from future opportunities and removal from the panel.
The Terms of Reference (ToR), timelines, deliverables, payment terms, bid security (if any), and any other project-specific conditions shall be defined separately for each consultancy engagement.
Empanelment shall not be construed as a binding commitment for award of work.
The maximum service charge to be collected from SPVs shall not exceed 2% of the project cost.

Consultants engaged under this empanelment shall not be eligible to participate in any procurement or implementation assignment arising from projects for which they have provided consultancy services.
All data, reports, or information shared by AP MSME DC shall remain confidential.

The AP MSME DC will examine all submitted EOIs to determine whether the applicants meet the eligibility criteria, have submitted all required documents, and have complied with the format and procedural requirements.
Any EOI found to be non-responsive, incomplete, or lacking supporting evidence may be rejected.
The selection and empanelment process will involve shortlisting based on eligibility criteria, technical presentations, and assessment by a Selection Committee.
Only EOIs received in full and within the specified deadline will be opened for further processing.
The Selection Committeeâs recommendations shall be placed before the Competent Authority, whose decision on empanelment shall be final and binding.
All expenses related to the preparation and submission of the EOI shall be borne entirely by the applicant.
AP MSME DC reserves the right to modify, suspend, or terminate the empanelment process at any stage without assigning any reason.

EOIs shall be submitted, only in physical format, in a sealed envelope clearly superscribed 'EOI for Empanelment of Technical Consultants under MSE-CDP (CFCs)' and must reach the specified address on or before December 15, 2025.
EOIs received after the deadline shall be summarily rejected.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh aims to establish itself as a hub for Aerospace and Defence (A&D) production.
The state plans to achieve this by leveraging its strengths in shipbuilding, aerospace manufacturing, and precision electronics.
The Andhra Pradesh Aerospace and Defence Policy (4.0) 2025-2030 has been submitted.
The policy aims to make Andhra Pradesh a global R&D and manufacturing hub in the aerospace and defence sector.
The goal is to propel India as a world leader with strategic autonomy and self-reliance.
The policy addresses the evolving needs and challenges of the A&D sector.
It focuses on setting up state-of-the-art infrastructure.
It aims to create a conducive regulatory environment.
It will foster innovation in the A&D sector.
The policy will promote skill development.
It will generate employment opportunities to meet the rising demand of the sector.
The policy emphasizes collaboration between academic institutions, industries, and research organizations.
It aims to support MSMEs, startups, and large enterprises.
The goal is to create an integrated and robust supply chain ecosystem.
The Director of Industries has informed that the policy will identify Anchor units for A&D Clusters.
The policy aims to attract new investments worth INR 1 Lakh Cr.
It plans to develop sub-sector focused MSME parks in a hub & spoke Model.
The policy aims to create employment opportunities for 1 Lakh people in the coming 5 years.
The Government has introduced the Andhra Pradesh Aerospace and Defence Policy (2.0) 2025-2030.
The detailed policy document is appended at Annexure-I.
The Andhra Pradesh Aerospace and Defence Policy (4.0) 2025-2030 is valid for 5 years from the date of issue or until a new policy is announced.
The policy may be amended and modified during implementation.
Amendments and modifications will be applied prospectively and will not curtail any benefits or concessions already granted.
This order is issued with the concurrence of the Finance Department.
India ranks as the 4th largest defense spender globally.
India accounts for 3.4% of global military expenditure.
India's defense budget for FY 2025-26 is a record INR 6.81 lakh crore (USD 77.4 billion).
The domestic defense manufacturing ecosystem achieved a production milestone of INR 1.46 Trillion in FY 2024-25.
Private sector firms contributed 21% to the domestic defense manufacturing production.
Over 12,000 MSMEs are involved in the defense manufacturing supply chain.
Defense exports surged thirty-fourfold over the past decade.
Defense exports reached INR 23,622 crore (USD 2.84 billion) in FY 2024-25.
The target for defense exports is INR 50,000 crore (USD 6.02 billion) by FY 2028-29.
Policy support for defense manufacturing includes the establishment of Defence Industrial Corridors.
100% FDI is allowed in defense manufacturing.
509 items are included in the Positive Indigenization List.
Andhra Pradesh is strategically positioned to capitalize on A&D opportunities due to its geographic advantage.
Andhra Pradesh has world-class port infrastructure.
Andhra Pradesh has a thriving industrial ecosystem.
Andhra Pradesh is in proximity to A&D hubs like Karnataka and Telangana.
The new A&D policy is an upgraded version of the previous one.
The updated policy will focus on setting up state-of-the-art infrastructure.
It aims to foster innovation.
It will promote skill development and generate employment opportunities.
The policy emphasizes collaboration between academic institutions, industries, and research organizations.
It aims to support MSMEs, startups, and large enterprises.
It seeks to create an integrated and robust supply chain ecosystem.
The policy aims to attract both domestic and international investments.
The vision is to make Andhra Pradesh a global R&D and manufacturing hub in the aerospace and defence sector.
The policy aims to propel India as a world leader with strategic autonomy and self-reliance.
Targets for policy implementation include identifying Anchor units for A&D Clusters.
The target is to attract new investments worth INR 1 Lakh Cr.
The target is to develop sub-sector focused MSME parks in a hub & spoke Model.
The target is to create employment opportunities for 1 Lakh people in the coming 5 years.
The target is to establish Centers of Excellence (CoEs) and special initiatives to drive futuristic & Innovative technologies.
The policy aims to position Andhra Pradesh as a globally recognised hub for defence innovation and advanced manufacturing.
Andhra Pradesh will develop plug-and-play Aerospace & Defence (A&D) zones near industrial hubs.
These zones will ensure regulatory compliance and offer flexible land payment options.
The state will set up specialized defence manufacturing clusters with shared infrastructure like Common Facility Centers (CFCs).
MSME parks with sub-sector focus will be developed within these clusters in a hub and spoke model.
The policy supports R&D through Centres of Excellence, innovation platforms, and academia-industry partnerships.
The aim is to advance technology and prototype development, focusing on futuristic technologies for defence and national security.
Emphasis will be on indigenous defence production, localizing critical components, and promoting Make in India.
This will strengthen supply chains and reduce import dependency.
Infrastructure development, including transport corridors and A&D parks, will improve logistics and lower production costs.
This will enhance global competitiveness.
The state will nurture A&D start-ups via incubation, funding, testing support, and mentorship.
This will encourage innovation and integration into the defence value chain.
The development plan rests on seven core strategies to accelerate ecosystem creation and ensure long-term competitiveness.
High-potential investment proposals will be fast-tracked.
Anchor units will be incentivized to create downstream MSME participation.
CoEs, incubators, and public-private R&D centers will be promoted to build IP and facilitate early-stage defense startups.
Thematic parks with plug-and-play infrastructure will be developed to house aerospace, electronics, and precision manufacturing units.
Tier-2 and Tier-3 suppliers will be supported through targeted vendor development and capacity-building programs.
Shared facilities will be planned to reduce capex burden on small manufacturers and improve access to defense certification.
Partnerships with industry, academia, and skilling agencies will be fostered to create job-ready manpower for the A&D sector.
A dedicated A&D Industry Facilitation Division will assist investors with policy guidance, handholding, single-window clearances, and exports.
The A&D ecosystem will be anchored around interconnected thematic clusters integrating R&D, Startups, and Talent development with manufacturing and testing infrastructure.
Each cluster will specialize in a key sub-domain such as Aerospace & Electronics, Missile and Ammunitions, Unmanned Systems, and Naval Systems.
This policy shall be valid for a period of 05 years from the date of policy notification or until a new policy is announced.
The policy may be amended and modified during implementation if any need arises.
Amendments and modifications shall be applied prospectively and shall not curtail any benefit or concession already granted.
The incentives under this policy are applicable to all Defence Public Sector Undertaking (DPSUs) and Private Industries, including MSMEs.
These apply to investments in new or expansion projects for Aerospace and Defence Manufacturing and Maintenance Repair & Overhaul (MRO) activities.
Projects (both new or expansion) must have commenced production in the policy period to be eligible for incentives.
Aerospace and Defence related activities include those listed in annexure 9.1.
They include components identified as Positive Indigenization List (PIL) by the Department of Defence Production (DDP) and Department of Military Affairs (DMA).
They include items categorized under the MAKE initiative as outlined in the Defence Acquisition Procedure (DAP) of the Government of India.
They include Maintenance, Repair, and Overhaul (MRO) services for Aircraft, Defence & Naval equipment, and related systems.
They include Defence Technology & Test Centres (DTTCs) for advanced testing.
They include specialized testing ranges, simulation centers, and training academies for Indian Army, Navy, and Air Force.
They include Centres of Excellence for R&D and innovation in the Aerospace and Defence sector.
MSMEs and Startups working on any part of the value chain are also eligible for support.
Any activity not covered above will be evaluated and approved on a case-to-case basis.
The state of Andhra Pradesh is committed to establishing a robust Aerospace and Defence (A&D) sector through a comprehensive development plan.
This plan focuses on creating interconnected thematic nodes with common areas for testing and storage.
It aims to foster innovation and build a skilled workforce.
These nodes will act as strategic hubs, leveraging proximity to existing A&D facilities and infrastructure.
Thematic nodes will include: Naval Cluster, Missiles and Ammunition Cluster, Unmanned systems Cluster, Aerospace and Electronics Cluster, R&D Cluster, and Aircraft Component Cluster.
The Naval hub in Visakhapatnam â Srikakulam will focus on specialized shipbuilding, naval systems, and maritime R&D.
It will leverage the region's coastal strengths to support indigenous manufacturing, testing, and MRO services.
This cluster will boost the local economy and strengthen India's defense ecosystem.
The Missiles and Ammunition Cluster in Jaggaiahpet will focus on the development and production of strategic defense systems.
It will support end-to-end capability development, including design, testing, and assembly infrastructure.
The Unmanned systems Cluster in Kurnool â Orvakal is suited for unmanned systems, robotics, and component manufacturing.
The Aerospace and Electronics Cluster in Lepakshi â Madakasira will specialize in aerospace systems, aircraft assembly, and advanced aerospace systems and subsystems.
It will serve as a Centre of Excellence for electronic subsystems critical to modern defense platforms.
Andhra Pradesh proposes the establishment of a DRDO Industry Academia Center of Excellence (DIA-CoE) at IIT Tirupati.
Tirupati will be formally recognized as the fifth hub dedicated to R&D in advanced defense technologies and innovations.
The Aircraft Component Cluster in Donakonda will focus on the precision manufacturing and assembly of aircraft components.
These hubs will align with the national objective of enhancing indigenous defense production and fostering self-reliance.
They will attract investments from DPSUs, private industries, and emerging defense startups.
An area will be earmarked for common facilities for testing and R&D, as well as for shared resources and common storage of weapons and equipment.
This will result in reduced costs and enhanced efficiency.
Industry stakeholders will have access to specialized testing equipment and labs.
The facility will include designated common storage areas for efficient handling and assembly of components.
The state government will work with organizations like DRDO, ISRO, and DPSUs to develop common testing and R&D facilities in each hub.
The state government will also work with private industries to establish common storage facilities in each hub.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh proposes a model for setting up shared facilities to foster innovation and technological advancement.
For R&D centers, the State Government will collaborate with other Government R&D entities.
For testing facilities, the State Government will support private industries and collaborate with government entities and private industries.
For common storage facilities, the state government will support the private industry.
Land costs are a significant part of the overall investment in setting up a manufacturing facility.
The policy offers flexible land holding options to reduce the cost of production.
For private sector entities with consolidated revenues less than INR 500cr, the policy offers upfront payment, staggered payment, or lease and buy model for land.
PSUs and DPSUs along with private industries with consolidated revenues more than INR 500 Cr will need to pay upfront for land procurement.
Andhra Pradesh Industrial Infrastructure Corporation (APIIC) is the nodal agency for land allotment procedures and allotment of government lands for industrial use.
The state has identified a land bank of ~23,000 acres for A&D hubs.
APIIC, along with line departments, will facilitate the creation of truck infrastructure internal and external to the parks.
The state is incentivizing private developers for Industrial Park Development on private or government lands through the Private Parks policy.
Provisions for industrial housing with common amenities shall be encouraged at the time of layout approvals for the parks.
Land allotment will be facilitated for industrial housing.
Andhra Pradesh has a robust single desk portal for project proponents to attain approvals with defined SLAs.
Andhra Pradesh Economic Development Board (APEDB) is the state nodal agency for Investment Promotion.
A dedicated facilitation division for Aerospace & Defence (A&D) will be established under APEDB.
This division will provide policy guidance, investor support, sector-specific export promotion, and single-window clearance.
The state will establish a INR 100 crore corpus to support startup-driven innovation, develop Centers of Excellence, and accelerate research commercialization.
Beneficiary groups for incentives are categorized based on their Fixed Capital Investments (FCI).
Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) have an investment period of 2 years.
Large Enterprises have an investment period of 3 years.
Mega Enterprises have an investment period of 4 years.
Incentives and concessions are applicable for both Manufacturing and Services activities.

Special category enterprises (wholly owned or holding majority stake by women/ BC/ SC/ ST/ minority/ specially-abled/ transgender entrepreneurs with domicile in the state) are given higher incentives.
Anchor OEM has a minimum eFCI of INR 300 Cr and a minimum order size of INR 30 Cr or supplies min. 25% of production to specific entities.
Anchor Supplier has a minimum eFCI of INR 300Cr and at least 50% turnover from supply to the A&D industry in India.
Regular Supplier (Large & Mega) has a minimum eFCI of INR 125 Cr and supplies min. 25% of production to specific entities.
Regular Supplier (MSME) has investment as per GoI definition and min. 50% turnover from supply to specific A&D entities in AP.
Eligible Fixed Capital Investment (eFCI) for Large and Mega investments includes only investment in Plant, Machinery, and equipment.
For MSMEs, Eligible FCI includes investment in Plant, Machinery, and equipment, including cost incurred towards Land and Building expenses.
MSMEs can avail a combination of incentive categories, with the overall incentive claim not exceeding 75% of Fixed Capital Investment.
Investment Subsidy for Micro enterprises: 25% of FCI (Cap- INR 60 Lakh) for General, 45% for Special Category.
Investment Subsidy for Small enterprises: 25% of FCI (Cap- INR 6 Cr) for General, 45% for Special Category.
Investment Subsidy for Medium enterprises: 25% of FCI (Cap- INR 10 Cr) for General, 35% for Special Category.
Technology Transfer Subsidy for MSMEs: 50% of technology acquisition cost, up to INR 1 crore, distributed over four years.
Power Subsidy for Micro enterprises: INR 1 per unit for 5 yrs from DCP at INR 1 Lakh per annum (General), INR 1.5 per unit for 5 yrs from DCP at INR 1 Lakh per annum (Special).
Power Subsidy for Small enterprises: INR 1 per unit for 5 yrs from DCP at INR 5 Lakh per annum (General), INR 1.5 per unit for 5 yrs from DCP at INR 5 Lakh per annum (Special).
Power Subsidy for Medium enterprises: INR 1 per unit for 5 yrs from DCP at INR 15 Lakh per annum (General & Special).
Net SGST Reimbursement for MSMEs: 100% net SGST payable on sale of final products for 5 years from the date of commercial production, not exceeding 100% FCI.
Logistics Subsidy for Defence and aerospace units:
30% of transportation cost limited to INR 50 Lakh per annum for 4 years from DCP for finished products to Logistics Park/Transport Hub/Harbor/Port.
50% of transportation cost limited to INR 2 Cr per enterprise for importing Plant, Machinery, equipment from Logistics Park/Transport Hub/Harbor/Port to Production Site.
This subsidy is applicable for projects with a contract value of Rs. 50 crore or more, provided on commencement of production for the first year.
Branding & Marketing Assistance for MSMEs: 25% of cost incurred for travel, stall, and creatives, with a limit of INR 1 Cr per annum per enterprise for 3 yrs.
Quality Certification Cost Subsidy for MSMEs: 50% of total cost incurred for obtaining certification, limited to Rs. 1 crore per enterprise.
Skill Development Assistance for MSMEs: 50% training cost with a cap of INR 3 Lakh per enterprise.
Rebate on Land cost for SC/ST led Enterprises: 75% of land cost limited to Rs.25.00 Lakh, applicable only to SC/ST led Enterprises.
Stamp Duty and Transfer Duty Reimbursement: 100% stamp duty and transfer duty on purchase of land for industrial use, and for lease, mortgages, and hypothecations.
Land conversion charges: 100% fee charged for land conversion will be reimbursed.
De-carbonization subsidy: Capital subsidy as a percentage of eligible project cost for investment in plant and machinery for de-carbonization intervention.
Maximum incentive under de-carbonization is 6% of FCI.
For MSMEs, de-carbonization subsidy is 10% for Non-Red category and 15% for Red category of eligible project cost.
Investment Subsidy for Large Enterprises: 15% of eFCI with a maximum cap of INR 75 Cr for Anchor OEM or Supplier (3 years disbursement) and INR 60 Cr for other enterprises (5 years disbursement).
Technology Transfer Subsidy for Large Enterprises: 50% of technology acquisition cost, up to INR 1 crore, distributed over four years.
Employment Subsidy for Large Enterprises: Incentivized based on the Direct employment to investment (FCI) ratio, ranging from 8% to 10% of FCI, disbursed over 7 years.
Logistics Subsidy for Large Enterprises: Same as for MSMEs.
Rebate on Land cost for Large Enterprises: 25% rebate for the first five anchor OEMs or suppliers, and 10% rebate for other eligible large-category beneficiaries.
Top-up on PLI from Government of India for Large Enterprises: 10% of the total incentive amount sanctioned under GoI PLI scheme, capped at 5% of FCI made in AP.
Net SGST Reimbursement for Large Enterprises: 100% net SGST payable on sale of final products for 5 years from the date of commercial production.
De-carbonization subsidy for Large Enterprises: 20% for Non-Red category and 25% for Red category of eligible project cost, with a maximum incentive of 6% of FCI.
Stamp Duty reimbursement for Large Enterprises: 100% stamp duty and transfer duty on purchase of land for industrial use, and for lease, mortgages, and hypothecations.
Land conversion charges for Large Enterprises: 100% fee charged for land conversion will be reimbursed.
Local Procurement Subsidy for Large Enterprises: 1% reimbursement on annual turnover for exporting units, up to 3 years, with a cap of INR 10 Crores.
Startup Grants: Up to Rs.2 Lakhs upfront initial grant, and up to Rs.15 Lakhs in a phased manner based on performance.
Grants for Woman/BC/SC/ST/Minority/Differently Abled & Others led startup: Up to Rs.20 Lakhs in a phased manner.
Interest subsidy for Startups: 8% on term loan.
Seed funding with Equity for Startups: Up to Rs.50 Lakhs, based on equity sharing model.
Go to market support for Startups: Up to Rs.50 Lakhs, based on equity sharing model.
Support for attending events/Fairs for Startups: 75% of cost, up to Rs.3 Lakhs, per event per startup per year.
Accelerator program support for Startups: 50% of cost fee reimbursement, up to Rs.2 Lakhs per program, maximum 2 programs per startup.
Patent filing cost support for Startups: 50% of patent expenses incurred, up to Rs.2 Lakh for India patent, Rs.10 Lakh for foreign patent.
SGST reimbursement for Startups: 100% for 5 years.
Need Based Seed funding with equity for Deeptech & Advanced tech Startups: Up to INR 1 Cr, and 100% rental subsidy for workstations for one year.
All startups will be facilitated through the 'Andhra Pradesh Innovation & Startup Policy 4.0' and the Ratan Tata Innovation Hub network.
Incentives for MRO: MRO units are eligible for the same incentives and subsidies as any other manufacturing or services entity based on their eFCI.
