Incentives for R&D: Firms will get eligible incentives as per the Andhra Pradesh Research & Development Policy.
Incentive structure for Mega Enterprises: Tailor-made benefits on a case-to-case basis.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh has notified various policies to develop the ecosystem.
Firms and their suppliers can alternatively choose to apply under other GoAP policies, but can only apply under one policy.
The Commissionerate of Industries and Commerce shall be the nodal agency for effective execution of the policy.
State Investment Promotion Committee (SIPC) and State Investment Promotion Board (SIPB) will decide tailor-made incentives for Mega Investments.
Incentive approval and disbursement procedures will be in line with Government Order (GO) No. 68 dated 26th October 2024.
Companies have to apply on Andhra Pradesh Single Desk portal for incentives.
All applicants shall adhere to the land allotment guidelines issued by the Andhra Pradesh Industrial Infrastructure Corporation (APIIC).
Categories for Manufacturing activities include Platforms, Tier 1, Tier 1A, Tier 2, Tier 3, and Tier 4.
Platforms include Ships, Submarines, Tanks, Aircrafts, Artillery, Armoured Personnel Carriers (APCs), and Missiles.
Tier 1 activities include Electrical systems, Structural systems, Mechanical Systems, and Electronic & weapon systems.
Tier 1A activities include Small arms, Ammunition, Explosives & propellants, and Standalone items.

Tier 2 activities include Component manufacturers for Electrical equipment, Mechanical equipment, Metallic structural components, Electronic components, Wires and harnesses, and Composite structural components.
Tier 3 activities include Materials and sub-components like Metal and alloy forms, Composite materials, and Other chemical compounds.
Tier 4 activities include Raw material suppliers like Input metals and alloys, Composite materials, and Rubber & polymers.

List of Testing facilities identified for development includes Aircraft testing, Naval ballistics/ explosion testing, Naval biological testing, Defence dimension testing, Dynamic mechanical testing, Defence electrical/ electronics testing, EMI testing, Defence environmental testing, Naval firefighting systems, Hydrodynamic testing, InfraRed (IR) signature measurement and analysis lab, Defence material composition & analysis, Nuclear radiation testing, Radar Cross Section (RCS) measurement, and Vehicular emission testing.
India is poised to become the world's 3rd largest economy and transcend the USD 5 trillion GDP by 2025 and USD 10 trillion by 2030.
The MSME sector is set to play a pivotal role in reaching India's vision to be a developed nation by 2047.
Asia contributes over 40 percent of the world's consumption and 60 percent of global GDP growth.
MSMEs account for 50 percent of global GDP, representing 90 percent of businesses and ~70 percent of employment globally.
Nationally, the MSME sector contributes 30 percent to India's GDP and around 48 percent of total exports.
The MSME sector is a source of employment for around 110 million people.
With approximately 63.4 million units, MSMEs contribute about 33.4 percent of India's manufacturing output.
Andhra Pradesh aims for sustainable, equitable, and inclusive growth through policies across all relevant sectors.
The state envisages services and industrial sectors to be the largest drivers of growth under the Swarna Andhra Pradesh framework.
The industries sector's share of State GDP is envisaged to grow significantly by 2047.
The services sector's share of State GDP is also envisaged to grow significantly by 2047.
Andhra Pradesh offers an ideal ecosystem for MSMEs across their business lifecycle.
The 'Future-Ready' MSME Policy aims to address MSME challenges and provide support to enhance productivity, boost innovation, and facilitate diversification.
Andhra Pradesh is home to ~9.3 lakh registered MSMEs as of February 2024.
MSMEs in Andhra Pradesh contribute to 28.3 percent of the State's exports.
21 percent of registered MSMEs are in manufacturing, and 79 percent are in services.
Micro enterprises dominate the State MSME sector with a share of ~97%.
Approximately 70% of MSMEs are concentrated in the top 12 districts.
Andhra Pradesh has a high percentage of women-led enterprises (49%) compared to the national average (33%).
MSME sector is expected to take ~16% share (~87,000 crore) in the total credit under the Annual Credit Plan for FY 24-25.
Total number of manufacturing enterprises registered on Udyam portal in Andhra Pradesh is 1,89,724 units.
Food processing (~32%), Textiles (26%), Wooden products (6%), and Non-metallic minerals (5%) have the largest sector share within manufacturing.
The state has 29 operational MSME Parks across 17 districts.
Andhra Pradesh is among the top 10 Indian states in terms of MSME exports.
The state envisages increasing exports from USD 19.3 billion in 2024 to ~USD 450 billion by 2047.
Specialized entities like APIDC, APMSMEDC, APTPC, and AP MSME Facilitation Councils are dedicated to MSME development.
AP MSME Development Corporation promotes MSE clusters by providing handholding support under the MSE-CDP scheme.
The state encourages the development of cost-effective flatted factory complexes.
The AP MSME DC is conducting an on-ground survey to formalize and support MSMEs.
Under the Raising and Accelerating MSME Program (RAMP), a budget outlay of INR 121 Crores has been earmarked.
The MSME and Entrepreneur Development Policy 2024-29 aims to foster a dynamic MSME ecosystem and increase sector competitiveness.
The overarching aim of the policy is to position Andhra Pradesh as the 'Champion State' for MSMEs.
The policy would support infrastructure, access to finance and markets, capacity building, skilling, and sustainability.
The policy will focus on capitalizing opportunities under 'Make in India' and 'Make in Andhra Pradesh'.
It envisages significant growth in state MSME exports and integrating 500+ MSME Champions into the global value chain.
The policy emphasizes inclusion, equity, and diversity by supporting women, BC/SC/ST entrepreneurs, start-ups, and enterprises in backward regions.
This Policy shall be valid for a period of 5 years from the date of policy notification, or till a new Policy is announced.
The policy may be amended and modified during implementation; however, all such amendments and modifications shall be applied prospectively.
The Policy shall be applicable to the entire State.
This policy shall be applicable to new and existing enterprises investing in new units or expansion of units.
The vision is to transform Andhra Pradesh into a state with 'One Family One Entrepreneur' by 2030.

Guiding principles of the Policy include Formalization of sector, Lean & clean production, Integration in Global supply chain, Infrastructural Support, Product competitiveness, Capacity Building, Digitalization & Marketing, and Decentralization of Energy.
The policy aims to attract additional investment of INR 50,000 Crores in manufacturing from MSMEs.
The policy aims to formalize 22 lakh MSMEs (manufacturing & services) by 2029.
The policy aims to generate more than 5 Lakh direct and indirect employment by 2029.
The policy aims to double exports to USD 12 Bn (INR 99,600 Crores) from the MSME sector by 2029.
The policy aims to facilitate integration of 500+ MSME Champions in Global Value Chains.
The policy aims to set up 5 sector specific Centres of Excellence/ Technology centres/ extension centres.
The policy aims to set aside a corpus of INR 500 Crores during the policy period.
The policy envisages setting up of 'Ratan Tata Innovation Hub' with a Central Unit at Amaravati and five linked hubs in zonal locations.
These Hubs will foster innovation, entrepreneurship ecosystem, and mentor startups.
The Innovation Hubs will facilitate top-performing MSMEs to showcase 'Export Guides'.
The Ratan Tata Innovation Hubs will forge ties with national and international trade bodies, industrial associations, and testing & certification laboratories.
The Innovation Hubs will provide regular analysis of major export markets.
The Hubs will host a repository of Business Development Service (BDS) providers.

The policy structures support across eight pillars: MSME Facilitation, Incubation and Acceleration Infrastructure and Supporting Mentorship, Unit level competitiveness, Access to Finance, Sustainability & Circularity, Import Substitution / Export Promotion, Cluster-based approach for infrastructure development, and Building Inclusive and Equitable MSME Ecosystem.
A dedicated Chief Minister (CM) Udyami helpline shall be launched for MSMEs.
Entrepreneur Capability Centres (ECCs) will be set up in a hub and spoke model.
A dynamic state-of-the-art Industry 4.0 technology cum experience centre will be established at Amravati in PPP mode.
Government will establish 5 sector-specific extension centres linked to the Industry 4.0 technology centre.
Government has added 4 new facilitation councils for speedy redressal of MSME disputes.
An Online Dispute Redressal (ODR) mechanism is being designed by MoMSME and will be implemented in the State.
New Micro Enterprises including start-ups can take approvals for establishment and operation based on self-certification in notified industrial areas and parks.
Under the RAMP program, a capacity building program encompassing awareness workshops and programmes at district level will be implemented.
A virtual platform integrating all MSME incubators in the state will be created to provide incubation support.
The virtual incubation platform shall onboard mentors for providing handholding support to start-ups.
Incubation programs will be initiated at all major business incubators in the state.
Thematic acceleration programs will be initiated at existing incubation centers of IT Tirupathi and IIM Visakhapatnam.
A Rural-Technology Business Incubator (R-TBI) will be developed in each district of the state.
State shall offer a comprehensive package for new/ existing MSMEs to enhance their competitiveness.
Joint projects initiated by an industry association/ individual unit in collaboration with technical/ R&D and academic institutions shall be supported.
Government will launch the AP Future Skills Connect Platform in collaboration with industry associations and academic institutions.
GoAP shall leverage its MoU with ONDC and facilitate the onboarding of MSMEs on the platform.
Access to finance is a critical challenge for MSMEs.
Government shall direct all SPSUs and companies with a turnover of INR 250Crores and above to get onboarded onto the TReDS platform.
The State Government would be developing a framework in collaboration with TReDS platform providers.
Andhra Pradesh Credit Guarantee Scheme: Government of Andhra Pradesh would partner with CGTMSE by extending additional guarantee cover.
GoAP shall take focused measures to prevent incipient sickness in MSMEs and for the revival of distressed/ sick MSMEs.
Government will promote digital lending platforms for enhanced financial coverage to MSMEs.
Government intends to encourage MSMEs to create business models with backward and forward linkages to the circular economy.
The Government will initiate an extensive energy mapping exercise to identify clusters/ parks or pockets of MSME industries with above-average energy consumption.
To encourage water conservation, a one-time reimbursement of 75% of water audit cost will be provided to MSMEs.
To encourage energy conservation, a one-time reimbursement of 75% of energy audit cost will be provided to MSMEs.
25% of the cost incurred on approved equipment procured for implementing energy/ water audit recommendations will be reimbursed.
A cluster-based MSME rooftop solar program will be initiated.
The government will prioritize regenerative resources and renewables for common infrastructure investments in the MSME parks.
Integrating MSME's into the global value chain by enhancing export competitiveness and adopting a targeted import substitution strategy are key areas.
Government of AP will encourage MSMEs to leverage e-commerce exports opportunity.
GoAP shall undertake a comprehensive assessment to identify products across thrust sectors which have potential for manufacturing in AP.
Government will identify 500 MSME units from the thrust sectors and develop them as 'Export Champions'.
Government will organize global conferences with leading brands, suppliers, distributors, and complementary businesses.
Government will launch training programs and courses to equip MSMEs with relevant skills on contemporary design, sustainable packaging, global branding.
Government will support 100% reimbursement of the charges incurred by MSMEs for acquiring certifications and consultancy.
The state will organize reverse buyer seller meets (RBSMs) to provide MSMEs a platform for targeting international buyers.
Government recognizes the economic potential of industrial clusters and aims to propel and support infrastructure development through a cluster-based approach in a PPP mode.
Government will establish nano parks and MSME parks in PPP mode with plug and play infrastructure and shared facilities.
Government shall support the establishment of sector specific Common Facility Centers (CFCs).
Government will establish testing and certification labs in PPP mode.
Government will establish 2 dedicated anchor buyer led ancillary parks with common physical infrastructure.
The State MSME clusters would be mapped on the PM Gati Shakti Portal for effective infrastructure planning.
Government would develop a data-driven cluster competitiveness index.
The Government recognizes the need for an inclusive and equitable MSME ecosystem.
The GoAP has stipulated MSME Public Procurement policy in line with Gol policy, mandating 25% in public procurement from MSEs registered within the State.
The Government shall issue orders allowing state entities to float separate tenders for exclusive procurement from MSMEs.
The GoAP shall encourage the acceptance of insurance surety bonds in lieu of bank guarantees in public procurement.
The government shall mandate a minimum of 4% procurement from MSEs owned by disadvantaged groups (BC/SC/ST) and 3% from women owned MSEs within the total mandate.
The government shall establish a framework for state-led vendor development program.
10% additional capital subsidy for women/BC/SC/ST/specially-abled entrepreneurs having domicile in the state, who are undergoing expansion/ diversification/ new investment shall be offered.
20% of the land/ factories shall be reserved for women/BC/SC-ST/specially-abled/ MSEs in the MSME Industrial parks/ flatted factory complexes.
All Medium enterprises will be offered a Business Development Credits (BDCs) to the extent of 2% of their growth in turnover for a 5yr period.
25% assistance for listing & raising money in SME stock exchange with a cap of INR 5L shall be provided to the medium enterprises.
To avail policy incentives and concessions, the entity should meet the definition of Micro Small and Medium Enterprises Development Act, 2006 and be registered with Udyam portal.
Micro Enterprises: Investment <= INR 1 crore and turnover <= INR 5 crore.
Small Enterprises: Investment <= INR 10 crore and turnover <= INR 50 crore.
Medium Enterprises: Investment <= INR 50 crore and turnover <= INR 250 crore.

An entity will be considered as a Startup up to a period of ten years from incorporation/ registration, with turnover not exceeding one hundred crore rupees, and working towards innovation, development or improvement of products or processes or services, or a scalable business model.
The incentives would be applicable only for enterprises involved in Manufacturing activity during the policy period.
The overall incentive MSME can claim shall not exceed 75% of FCI.
Stamp Duty reimbursement: 100% stamp duty and transfer duty paid by the industry on purchase of land for industrial use, and for lease, mortgages, and hypothecations.
Land conversion charges: 100% fee charged for land conversion will be reimbursed.
Capital Subsidy for Micro Enterprises: 25% of FCI (Cap- INR 25 Lakh) for new enterprises.
Capital Subsidy for Small Enterprises: 25% of FCI (Cap - INR 1.5 Crores) for new enterprises.
Capital Subsidy for Medium Enterprises: 25% of FCI (Cap - INR 7Crores) for new enterprises.
10% additional capital subsidy for women/BC/SC/ST/specially-abled entrepreneurs having domicile in the state.
Technology Upgradation Cost for Micro Enterprises: 20% of FCI, Capped at INR 20 Lakhs.
Technology Upgradation Cost for Small Enterprises: 20% of FCI, Capped at INR 1 Crores.
Technology Upgradation Cost for Medium Enterprises: 20% of FCI, capped at INR 5 Crore.
10% additional capital subsidy for women/BC/SC/ST/specially-abled entrepreneurs having domicile in the state for technology upgradation.
Power Cost Reimbursement for Micro Enterprises: INR 1 per unit for 6 years from DCP, capped at INR 1 Lakh per annum.
Power Cost Reimbursement for Small Enterprises: INR 1 per unit for 6 years from DCP, capped at INR 5 Lakh per annum.
Power Cost Reimbursement for Medium Enterprises: INR 1 per unit for 6 years from DCP, capped at INR 15 Lakh per annum.
Net SGST Reimbursement for MSMEs: 100% for 6 years, with annual cap of 5% of annual turnover.
Skill Upgradation Cost for Micro Enterprises: INR 5,000 per person for a maximum of 10 persons.
Skill Upgradation Cost for Small Enterprises: INR 10,000 per person for a maximum of 20 persons.
Skill Upgradation Cost for Medium Enterprises: 100% of Employer contribution to EPF, capped at INR 1 Lakh per annum, for 3 years.
Energy & Water Audit Cost for Micro Enterprises: 75% of cost of Water audit (capped at INR 1 Lakh) and 75% of cost of energy audit (capped at INR 2 Lakhs).
Energy & Water Audit Cost for Small Enterprises: 75% of cost of Water audit (capped at INR 1 Lakh) and 75% of cost of energy audit (capped at INR 2 Lakhs).
Energy & Water Audit Cost for Medium Enterprises: 75% of cost of Water audit (capped at INR 1 Lakh) and 75% of cost of energy audit (capped at INR 2 Lakhs).
25% of cost of equipment as per auditing, Capped at INR 20 Lakhs for Micro, INR 40 Lakhs for Small, and INR 50 Lakhs for Medium enterprises.
Local Procurement Subsidy for MSMEs: 1% of annual export turnover for 3 years, with overall cap of INR 15 Lakhs for Micro, INR 1.5 Crore for Small, and INR 7 Crore for Medium enterprises.
Quality Certification Cost Top Up: Balance subsidy 100% cost to Gol.
The Commissioner of Industries serves as the overarching agency for implementing and monitoring this policy.
AP MSME Development Corporation (APMSMEDC) would be the agency in charge of implementing the schemes under the policy.
A State Level Empowered Committee under the Chairmanship of Secretary to Government, Industries and Commerce, GoAP will be constituted.
A State Level Review and Monitoring Committee would be set up under the Chairmanship of Secretary to Government, Industries and Commerce, GoAP.
The operating guidelines for this policy will be issued separately.
The 10th State Level Steering Committee (SLSC) Meeting of MSE-CDP was held on 13-02-2025 at 11:30 AM.
The meeting took place in the Secretary Chambers, 2nd Block, AP Secretariat, Velagapudi, Andhra Pradesh.
The meeting was conducted in a physical and video conferencing mode.
Dr. N. Yuvaraj, IAS, Secretary to Go AP, I&C Department, and Chairman, SLSC, was present.
Shri. S. Vijay Kumar, IEDS, JD I/c, MSME - DFO, Visakhapatnam, and Convener, was present.
Shri M. Abhishikth Kishore, IAS, Director of Industries, Go AP and VC & MD, APIIC, was present.
Shri. M. Vishwa, CEO, AP MSME DC, was present.
Respective GM DICs, SPV Members, and Technical consultants attended via VC.
Shri S Sudarshan Babu, Executive Director, AP MSME DC, was in attendance.
Shri V Gopi Krishna, Chief Engineer, APIIC, was in attendance via VC.
Shri A Sudhakar, Joint Director, MSME, was in attendance.
Shri M Srinivasulu Reddy, AD, AP MSME DC, was in attendance.
Shri DVSR Murthy, AD, MSME - DFO, Visakhapatnam, was in attendance.
SLBC Representative attended via VC.
The Convener, Sri S Vijay Kumar, welcomed the Chairman and other members.
The Chairman urged for fast-track clearance of existing projects as a top priority.
The Chairman emphasized focusing on new proposals and recommending them prior to the forthcoming NPAC.
The Convener initiated discussions as per the Agenda Points with the Chair's permission.
The Minutes of the 9th SLSC Meeting were confirmed.
The Action Taken Report on the Minutes of the 9th SLSC Meeting held on 18.09.2024 was reviewed.
MSE-CDP Clusters were reviewed.
Ongoing CFCs for which Final Sanction was Accorded were reviewed.
The CFC in Gold cluster, Nellore, was recommended by SLSC and received final approval from NLSC.
The final approval for the Nellore Gold cluster CFC was accorded vide No. 1(400) CDD/Nellore/2013 dated 11.07.2019 during the 48th Meeting of the Steering Committee.
The SLSC recommended an extension of time for the Nellore Gold cluster CFC, and EOT was granted up to 31.05.2024 during the 2nd NPAC Meeting held on 30.01.2024.

The contribution for the Nellore Gold cluster CFC was: 80% Grant from Govt. of India (Rs. 827.5 Lakhs), 10% Govt. of Andhra Pradesh (Rs. 103.86 Lakhs), and 10% SPV Contribution (Rs. 103.5 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 1034.86 Lakhs.
During the 9th SLSC meeting, the Secretary, I&C Department, GoAP, directed the cancellation of the final sanction accorded by Gol for the Nellore Gold cluster CFC.
GM-DIC, Nellore, informed that the issue was placed in the DIEPC meeting.
During the DIEPC meeting on 19-12-2024, the District Collector granted one month's time on the request of the SPV for the Nellore Gold cluster CFC.
A review meeting was held by AP MSME DC on 23.01.2025 for the Nellore Gold cluster CFC, but neither the SPV nor GMDIC attended, raising concerns.
Due to lack of initiative and continued delay for the Nellore Gold cluster CFC, the SLSC was to take a decision as per instructions from the 9th SLSC meeting.
The CFC in Printing Cluster, Kakinada, received final approval in the 54th NLSC and a sanction order vide No.1(1037)/CDD/CFC/Printing/East Godavari/2019 dated 29.07.2021.
The 8th SLSC recommended an EoT up to 31-07-2024 for the Kakinada Printing Cluster CFC.

The contribution for the Kakinada Printing Cluster CFC was: 70% Grant in aid Gol (Rs. 1033.2 Lakhs), 20% State Gov. Contribution (Rs. 295.2 Lakhs), and 10% SPV Contribution (Rs. 147.6 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 1476 Lakhs.
The 1st, 2nd & 3rd installments of Gol Grant were received for the Kakinada Printing Cluster CFC (Rs 929.88 lakhs out of Rs. 1033.2 Lakhs).
10% of the final work is under progress for the Kakinada Printing Cluster CFC.
The 4th installment of Gol Grant is yet to be released for the Kakinada Printing Cluster CFC.
A tender was floated for the remaining machinery for the Kakinada Printing Cluster CFC, and the bidder has been finalized.
It was suggested to propose an extension of time for the completion of the Kakinada Printing Cluster CFC until 31.03.2025.
The Chairman instructed to cancel the proposal for the Kakinada Printing Cluster CFC and directed the SPV to apply as per new MSE-CDP guidelines.
IA was directed to liaise with PFMS & O/o DC MSME regarding the procedure for claiming the Gol grant 10% (last installment on reimbursement).
The Chairman reiterated the need for SOP formulation by IA to complete projects on time.
The CFC in Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster, SPSR Nellore District, received final approval in the 54th NLSC and a sanction order on 29.07.2021.
The 8th SLSC recommended an EoT up to 30-09-2024 for the SPSR Nellore Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster CFC.

The contribution for the SPSR Nellore Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster CFC was: 70% Grant in aid Gol (Rs. 576.08 Lakhs), 20% State Govt. Contribution (Rs. 164.6 Lakhs), and 10% SPV Contribution (Rs. 82.3 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 822.98 Lakhs.
The 1st installment of Gol grant was released on 31-12-2024 for the SPSR Nellore Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster CFC.
IA was directed to utilize the funds and submit UC along with the request for the second installment of Gol grant for the SPSR Nellore Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster CFC.
An extension of time was requested for the completion of the SPSR Nellore Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster CFC until 30.06.2025 due to ongoing progress.
The CFC in Jaggayyapeta Gold Ornaments Cluster, NTR District, received final approval in the 54th NLSC and a sanction order vide No. 1(1034)/CDD/CFC/Jaggayyapeta/2019 dated 19-08-2021.
The 8th SLSC recommended an EoT up to 31-07-2024 for the Jaggayyapeta Gold Ornaments Cluster CFC.

The contribution for the Jaggayyapeta Gold Ornaments Cluster CFC was: 77.81% Grant in aid Gol (Rs. 614.52 Lakhs), 10.00% State Gov. Contribution (Rs. 80 Lakhs), and 13.19% SPV Contribution (Rs. 105.48 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 800 Lakhs.
The proposal for the 3rd installment of Gol grant was sent for release for the Jaggayyapeta Gold Ornaments Cluster CFC.
An extension of time was requested for the completion of the Jaggayyapeta Gold Ornaments Cluster CFC until 30.06.2025.
The CFC in Furniture Manufacturing Cluster, Rajahmundry, East Godavari District, received final approval in the 54th NLSC vide Lr. No. I(1039/CDD/CFC/Furniture/East Godavari/AP/2019 dated 27-08-2021.
The 8th SLSC recommended an EoT up to 31-08-2024 for the Rajahmundry Furniture Manufacturing Cluster CFC.

The Chairman directed the Dol & CEO AP MSME DC to spend the Gol 1st installment subject to fulfillment of terms and conditions and submit the UC with necessary documents for claiming the 2nd installment for the Rajahmundry Furniture Manufacturing Cluster CFC.
As the 3rd installment is to be released from the DC, MSME, the Chairman directed the Dol & CEO, AP MSME DC to pursue the matter for the Rajahmundry Furniture Manufacturing Cluster CFC.

The Chairman directed the CEO, AP MSME DC to submit a revised expenditure statement to DC, MSME for the release of the 1st installment of the Gol grant for the Rajahmundry Furniture Manufacturing Cluster CFC.

The contribution for the Rajahmundry Furniture Manufacturing Cluster CFC was: 70% Grant in aid from Gol (Rs. 1044.88 Lakhs), 20% State Gov. Contribution (Rs. 299.68 Lakhs), and 10% SPV Contribution (Rs. 149.85 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 1498.41 Lakhs.
Tenders for the supply of machinery for the Rajahmundry Furniture Manufacturing Cluster CFC have been finalized, and machinery worth Rs. 435 Lakhs has been supplied.
A request was sent to the DC-MSME on 14.06.2024 for the release of the 1st installment of the Gol grant for the Rajahmundry Furniture Manufacturing Cluster CFC.

Shortfall information was raised by AD, Clusters Division, Mo MSME on the CA Expenditure Statement for the release of the 1st installment of Gol grant for the Rajahmundry Furniture Manufacturing Cluster CFC.
An extension of time was requested for the completion of the Rajahmundry Furniture Manufacturing Cluster CFC until 30.06.2025.

The CFC in Pulses & Pulses Products Cluster, Machavaram, BR Ambedkar, Konaseema District, received final approval in the 54th NLSC and a sanction order vide No.1(1037)CDD/CFC/Pulses/AP/2019 dated 16.11.2021.
The 8th SLSC recommended an EoT up to 31-07-2024 for the Machavaram Pulses & Pulses Products Cluster CFC.

The contribution for the Machavaram Pulses & Pulses Products Cluster CFC was: 70% Grant in aid Gol (Rs. 1038.14 Lakhs), 20% State Gov. Contribution (Rs. 297.61 Lakhs), and 10% SPV Contribution (Rs. 148.31 Lakhs), totaling Rs. 1483.06 Lakhs.
The 3rd installment of Gol grant was released on 31-12-2024 for the Machavaram Pulses & Pulses Products Cluster CFC.
IA was directed to utilize the funds and submit UC along with the request for the 4th installment of Gol grant for the Machavaram Pulses & Pulses Products Cluster CFC.
An extension of time was requested for the completion of the Machavaram Pulses & Pulses Products Cluster CFC until 30.06.2025.
The CFC in Printing Cluster, Tirupati, received final approval vide Office of DC, Mo MSME vide Ir. No. 1(1533)/CDD/CFC/Printing/Tirupati/AP dated 07-06-2024.
The Chairman directed the CEO AP MSME DC for releasing the 3rd installment of Gol grant subject to fulfillment of terms and conditions and submission of UC for the Tirupati Printing Cluster CFC.
The Chairman instructed the GM, DIC, Tirupathi to convene the Purchase Committee for the finalization of the tender document for machinery for the Tirupati Printing Cluster CFC.

Final approval for the Tirupati Printing Cluster CFC was received from the DC, MoMSME New Delhi, on 07.06.2024.
Administrative sanction was received on 16.12.2024 towards GoAP contribution for the Tirupati Printing Cluster CFC.
Tender documents for the Tirupati Printing Cluster CFC have been received from SPV & Technical Consultant.

The 4th Meeting of the National Project Approval Committee (NPAC) of Micro & Small Enterprises Cluster Development Programme (MSE-CDP) was held on 13.09.2024.
The meeting was chaired by the Secretary (MSME).
The venue was Committee Room no. 169, Udyog Bhawan, New Delhi, conducted in physical and video conferencing mode.
The minutes of the 3rd meeting of NPAC were confirmed.
The action taken report on previous meeting decisions was noted.
Proposals for Final Approval were discussed.
Setting up of Common Facility Center (CFC) in Food Processing Cluster, Srikakulam, Andhra Pradesh, received final approval.

The means of finance for the Srikakulam Food Processing Cluster CFC were: Gol Grant under MSE-CDP (69.97%, Rs. 2095.00 Lakhs), State Government's contribution (15.00%, Rs. 449.00 Lakhs), and SPV's contribution (15.03%, Rs. 450.00 Lakhs), totaling 100.00% and Rs. 2994.00 Lakhs.
Final approval for the Srikakulam Food Processing Cluster CFC is subject to an undertaking from the State Govt. that CFC facilities will be equally open for Non-SPV members.
The facilities of the Srikakulam Food Processing Cluster CFC may also be accessible to enterprises of the Prime Minister Formalization of Micro Food Processing Entrepreneurs (PMFME) Scheme.
Documents for final approval of the Srikakulam Food Processing Cluster CFC must be sent to O/o DC(MSME) within a month, with a possible one-month extension.
Setting up of Common Facility Center (CFC) in Healthcare Cluster, Srikakulam, Andhra Pradesh, was deferred.
The NPAC deferred the Srikakulam Healthcare Cluster CFC proposal due to the nature of services not being broad-based and the need for target group and benchmarking by the State Govt.
Setting up of Common Facility Center (CFC) in Lab Grown Diamond Cluster, Navapur, Nandurbar (Aspirational District), Maharashtra, received final approval.

The means of finance for the Navapur Lab Grown Diamond Cluster CFC were: Gol Grant under MSE- CDP (70%, Rs. 2087.13 Lakhs), State Government's Contribution (Rs. 447.24 Lakhs), and SPV's contribution (15%, Rs. 447.24 Lakhs), totaling 100% and Rs. 2981.61 Lakhs.
Setting up of Common Facility Center (CFC) in Dairy Cluster, Bundi, Rajasthan, received final approval.

The means of finance for the Bundi Dairy Cluster CFC were: Gol Grant under MSE- CDP (70%, Rs. 696.3 Lakhs), State Government's Contribution (14.82%, Rs. 147.38 Lakhs), and SPV's contribution (15.18%, Rs. 151.04 Lakhs), totaling 100% and Rs. 994.72 Lakhs.
The Ministry of Food Processing Industries requested that CFCs proposed under the project be accessible to micro-enterprises supported by the PMFME Scheme.
Setting up of Common Facility Center(CFC) in Metal Craft Cluster, Jodhpur District, Rajasthan, received final approval.

The means of finance for the Jodhpur Metal Craft Cluster CFC were: Gol Grant under MSE- CDP (69.92%, Rs. 1925.52 Lakhs), State Government's contribution (15%, Rs. 413.08 Lakhs), and SPV's contribution (15.08%, Rs. 415.29 Lakhs), totaling 100% and Rs. 2753.89 Lakhs.
Setting up of Flatted Factory Complex at K. Pudur Industrial Estate, Madurai District, Tamilnadu, received final approval.

The means of finance for the Madurai Flatted Factory Complex were: Gol Grant under MSE- CDP (50%, Rs. 877.055 Lakhs), and State Government's contribution (50%, Rs. 877.055 Lakhs), totaling 100% and Rs. 1754.11 Lakhs.

Final approval for the Madurai Flatted Factory Complex is subject to an undertaking from the Govt. of Tamil Nadu /IA that project component costs are based on State PWD / CPWD scheduled rates and a copy of the Layout Plan signed by a competent authority.
Setting up of Flatted Factory Complex at Hosur (uzuvadi), Krishnagiri District, Tamilnadu, received final approval.

The means of finance for the Hosur Flatted Factory Complex were: Gol Grant under MSE- CD (38.92%, Rs. 900 Lakhs), and State Government's contribution (61.08%, Rs. 1412.37 Lakhs), totaling 100% and Rs. 2312.37 Lakhs.

Final approval for the Hosur Flatted Factory Complex is subject to an undertaking from the Govt. of Tamil Nadu /IA that project component costs are based on State PWD / CPWD scheduled rates and a copy of the Layout Plan signed by a competent authority.

The prevalence of the Covid-19 pandemic and the Code of conduct for Assembly elections in Telangana State were cited as reasons for delays.
The committee agreed to grant extensions based on the request of the State Government.

The document is a step-by-step guide for MSME startups to make exporting easy.
It is published by the Andhra Pradesh MSME Development Corporation.
The document version is 1.0, dated 2025.
The document contains a table of contents with sections like Abbreviations Used, Definitions, Introduction, and a four-level framework for the export process.
The four levels are: Pre-Export, Export, Realisation of Payment, and Post Export Process.

Abbreviations used include AD Bank, EPCG, AIR, APMSME, BL, BRC, CB, CBIC, CFS, CHA, CIF, CIP, COO, CPT, DA, DAP, DDP, DGFT, DoPPQS, DPU, DSC, ECGC, EGM, EIA, EPC, EU, EXW, FAS, FCA, FCL, FEMA, FFA, FIEO, FOB, FTA, FTP, GoAP, GoI, GSP, GST, GSTIN, HSN, IATA, ICC, ICEGATE, IEC, IES, IGST, INCOTERMS, ITC, LCL, LEO, LLP, LUT, MAI, MCA, MFN, MSME, NSDL, PAN, PTA, RBI, RCMC, REX, RODTEP, RoSCTL, TEE, USD, UTITSL, VA.

Definitions are provided for terms like Air Cargo Complex, Authorised Dealer (AD) Bank, Buyer, Container Freight Station (CFS), Customs Broker (CB), Exporter, Freight forwarders, Goods, Loading Port, and Port of discharge.
The introduction highlights the importance of MSMEs in India's economy and Andhra Pradesh's potential as an export hub.
It acknowledges the complexity of exporting for MSME startups and aims to simplify the process.
The document is written in simple language to help MSMEs understand international trade.
The 'Pre-Export' level covers mandatory statutory requirements and other preparatory steps.

Basic requirements for pre-export include: Registration of Organisation, Digital Signature Certificate (DSC), Current Account with Bank, Permanent Account Number (PAN), GST registration, Udyam Registration, Import Export Code (IEC), Registration cum Membership Certificate (RCMC), Certificate of Origin (COO), Registered Exporter System (REX) Registration, and Registration on the Indian Customs Electronic Gateway (ICEGATE) Portal.

For organisation registration, businesses must register under the Andhra Pradesh Shops and Establishments Act within 30 days of commencement. Public Limited Companies/Private Limited Companies/LLPs need to register with the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA).
A Class 3 DSC is needed for various portals and can be obtained online from MCA-authorized agencies.
An exporter needs a current account with a Scheduled Commercial Bank (AD Bank) that deals with foreign exchange.
A PAN is required for the organisation, or personal PAN for sole proprietorships.
GST registration is mandatory for businesses involved in the supply of goods and services.
Udyam Registration is required on the Ministry of MSME website, needing PAN, GST, and Aadhaar numbers.
An Import Export Code (IEC) from the DGFT is mandatory for exporting from India.
An RCMC from an Export Promotion Council (EPC) or FIEO is required to avail benefits under the Foreign Trade Policy.
A Certificate of Origin (COO) certifies the country of origin of goods and is required for import clearance.
REX registration is a self-certification scheme for exporters to the EU for consignments above EUR 6,000.
Registration on the ICEGATE portal is required for customs clearance.

Things to know before exporting include: Finalisation of product category (Free, Restricted, Prohibited based on HSN code), understanding costs and risks, and defining obligations of the exporter and buyer using INCOTERMS.
INCOTERMS for export through different modes of transport (sea, air, road, rail) are explained, detailing freight and risk transfer points.

Interfacing with external organizations before export is encouraged, including Government bodies, Banks, Free Trade Agreements (FTAs)/Preferential Trade Agreements (PTAs)/Most Favoured Nation (MFN), Customs House Agents (CHA)/Customs Brokers (CB)/Clearing Agents, Freight Forwarders, Export Credit Guarantee Corporation of India (ECGC), and obtaining necessary Certifications.
Sharing samples with buyers requires careful consideration of quality, secrecy, and proper documentation.
The 'Export' level covers the execution of the order and delivery of supplies.

Export of Goods through sea involves booking a shipping line, finalizing the invoice and packing list, finalizing the shipping bill, obtaining a Certificate of Origin, confirming container allocation, loading the container/moving goods, obtaining inspection/sanitary certificates, interfacing with Customs for verification and sealing (obtaining Let Export Order - LEO), and loading goods onto the ship (receiving Bill of Lading).
The Export General Manifest (EGM) filing by the ship's master is tracked for its impact on benefits.

Export of Goods through air cargo involves booking airline cargo, finalizing the invoice and packing list (following IATA guidelines), finalizing the shipping bill, obtaining a Certificate of Origin, and loading goods into the airplane (receiving Airway Bill).
The 'Realisation of Payment' level focuses on securing funding and handling payment issues.
Handling payments requires adherence to FEMA regulations, with documents typically sent through the exporter's bank to the buyer's bank.

Different methods of payment include Consignment sale (not recommended), Open account (less risky but not recommended), Documents Collection (DAP/DA), Letter of Credit (highly recommended and secure), and Advance Payment.
The 'Post Export Process' level covers claiming incentives, compliances, and documentation after export.
Customs Documentation & Finalisation includes Shipping Bill Finalisation and Export General Manifest (EGM) Filing.
Realisation of Export Proceeds must occur within 9 months from the export date, through banking channels.
GST Refund for Exporters can be claimed through Export under LUT (without IGST payment) or Export with payment of IGST.
Closing Export Obligations under schemes like Advance Authorisation and EPCG requires proof of export.
Record Keeping of all export-related documents for at least five years is mandatory.

Incentives for Indian Exporters include Remission of Duties and Taxes on Export Products (RoDTEP), Duty Drawback Scheme, Export Promotion Capital Goods (EPCG) Scheme, Advance Authorisation Scheme, Towns of Export Excellence (TEE), and Market Access Initiative (MAI) Scheme.
A Timeline Summary for post-export steps is provided.
Practical Tips for Exporters include double-checking HS codes, ensuring timely payment, maintaining digital records, tracking refunds, and consulting FIEO/EPC for complex schemes.
The Annexure includes information on Export of services, Additional Schemes/Incentives, and International opportunity listings.
Export of services is defined by specific conditions related to supplier and recipient location, place of supply, and payment in convertible foreign exchange.
Eligible services for incentives under the Foreign Trade Policy are listed.

Additional Schemes/Incentives include International Trade Fair Assistance, Rebate of State and Central Taxes and Levies (RoSCTL) for garments and made-ups, Status Holder Scheme, Gold Card Scheme for exporters, Interest Equalisation Scheme (IES), Towns of Export Excellence (TEE), and Market Access Initiative (MAI) Scheme.

International opportunity listings provide details of Global B2B Aggregators, Targeted/Country specific B2B Aggregators, and Integrated Service Providers for MSMEs, along with their services, costs, and relevant links.
The document also mentions the Andhra Pradesh MSME Development Corporation's address.

A separate government order (G.O.Rt.No.09) from the Government of Andhra Pradesh sanctions Rs. 10.7 Crore as state contribution for the Raising and Accelerating MSMEs Performance (RAMP) Programme, co-sponsored by the Ministry of MSME and supported by the World Bank.
The RAMP Programme aims to improve market access, access to credit, strengthen institutions, and address issues like delayed payments and greening of MSMEs.
The state's share is 10% of the project cost, with Rs. 10.7 Crores allocated for implementation.
The amount sanctioned is debited to the Head of Account 285100-800-11-09-310/312 (Development of Clusters in Tiny Sector).
The Commissioner of Industries is tasked with drawing and disbursing the sanctioned amount to the CEO, AP MSME Development Corporation.
The utilization of the sanctioned amount must be as per scheme guidelines.
The order is issued with the concurrence of the Finance Department.
The Government of India has introduced reforms to attract Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in the retail industry.
The Government has approved 51% FDI in multibrand retail under the automatic route.
The Government has approved 100% FDI in single-brand retail under the automatic route.
These reforms are expected to boost the Ease of Doing Business scheme.
These reforms are expected to boost the Make in India scheme.
There are plans to allow 100% FDI in E-commerce.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh (GoAP) has decided to bring out a policy on Mega Retail Parks.
Andhra Pradesh was ranked as No.1 under Ease of Doing Business by DPIIT in 2019-20.
The policy aims to develop the retail sector in a holistic manner.
The policy aims to create large-scale employment.
The \AP Retail Park Policy 2021-26\ has been drafted after stakeholder discussions.
The Andhra Pradesh Retail Parks Policy 2021-2026 has been introduced by the Government.
Andhra Pradesh has huge potential to become a leading destination for retail trade.
Andhra Pradesh is a leader in agriculture production.
Andhra Pradesh is a leader in horticulture production.
Andhra Pradesh is a leader in dairy production.
Andhra Pradesh is a leader in poultry production.
Andhra Pradesh is a leader in other raw material production.
Andhra Pradesh ranks amongst the top states in India across many sectors.
Andhra Pradesh is providing significant thrust to the Food Processing sector.
Andhra Pradesh is providing significant thrust to the Electronics sector.
Andhra Pradesh is providing significant thrust to the Textiles sector.
Andhra Pradesh is providing significant thrust to the Pharmaceuticals sector.
Andhra Pradesh is poised to emerge as a key sourcing hub for many segments of the Retail trade industry.
The Retail Parks Policy 2021-2026 aims to catalyze growth in the Retail sector in Andhra Pradesh.
The Retail Parks Policy 2021-2026 aims to provide thrust to the development of the Retail sector in Andhra Pradesh.
The Vision of the policy is to encourage retail trade.
The Vision of the policy is to generate employment opportunities in the Retail sector.
The Vision of the policy is to facilitate investments in Retail Parks.
Objective 1: To boost Organized Retail Trade within the State of Andhra Pradesh.
Objective 1: To increase the GSDP.
Objective 2: Encourage skill development in the retail trade.
Objective 2: Create more employment opportunities for all sections of society involved in retail trade.
Objective 3: To strengthen the existing unorganized retail sector.
Target 1: Attract new investments worth Rs.5,000 crore in the sector by 2026.
Target 2: Create 50,000 additional direct employment opportunities in the retail Industry by 2026.
This policy will be valid for 5 years from the date of notification.
The Department of Industries, Commerce & Export Promotion will act as the Implementing agency for the Policy.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh shall appoint a Nodal Officer at each District Industries Center.
The Nodal Officer shall provide hand holding services to retail park developers and retail enterprises.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh shall create a customized facility on the Single Desk Portal.
Retail park developers and retail enterprises can obtain all clearances online in a time-bound manner through the Single Desk Portal.
All labor regulation-related approvals are issued online on the spot.

Other clearances applicable to retail, such as Packers license (Legal Metrology), Tree felling permission, Pesticide/Insecticide license, AP Shops Establishments registration & Trade License in urban areas, are to be given online in a time-bound manner.
Essential renewals for retail pertaining to Labour regulations, Drug Retail (Pharmacy) & ULB Trade License will have the option for online auto-renewals.
A single online return under all Labour Laws can be filed using the Single Desk Portal.
All inspections under Labour, Factories, Boilers, Pollution Control Board and Legal Metrology are managed and monitored through the Central Inspection System in a transparent manner.
Establishments are categorized as per risk.
Periodicity, compliance, and other inspection requirements are simplified for low-risk establishments.
GoAP will work with retail associations to encourage local sourcing from Andhra Pradesh.
Buyer-seller meets will be organized to encourage local sourcing.
Distribution centres/warehouses will be considered as Service Industry.
Government will allow organized retailers to set up their warehouses/distribution centers within designated areas in the Park.
The Logistic Policy proposed by the Government would cover initiatives for encouraging the setting up of world-class Warehouses on a PPP basis.
Retail enterprises shall be allowed to stay open every day of the year.
Employees must be given compulsory weekly offs on a preferential basis.
General permission shall be available for 3-shift operations with women working at night.
Retail parks and retail enterprises must take prescribed precautions for the safety and security of employees when women work at night.
Retail enterprises shall be exempted from maintaining physical records for attendance and salary.
Retail enterprises will be provided the provision to maintain employee-related records in electronic form.
Retail enterprises will be allowed to accept returns in electronic form.
Special emphasis has been given to the development of human resources and skill development for the Retail industry.
State-run agencies and renowned private institutions will institute training-based certification and placement programs.
These institutions would collaborate with the Retailers Association of India and other associations.
These institutions would collaborate with the local retail industry to understand their resource requirements.
A merit-based, defined certification and placement procedure shall be instituted.
Projects involving fixed capital investment of at least INR 100 crore will be accorded Mega retail park status.
Projects involving more than 5,000 direct employment for establishing a Consolidated Single Product/sector Retail Park will be accorded Mega retail park status.
Mega Retail Park developers will be eligible for reimbursement of 50% of the cost of external infrastructure for the park.
The cap on infrastructure support is based on direct employment.
For 5,000 to 10,000 direct employment, the cap on infrastructure support is INR 3 Crores.
For 10,001 to 15,000 direct employment, the cap on infrastructure support is INR 4 Crores.
For 15,001 to 20,000 direct employment, the cap on infrastructure support is INR 5 Crores.
External infrastructure includes laying of approach roads to the Industrial Park from the nearest highway/two-lane road/major road.
External infrastructure includes upgrading of existing roads/widening of roads to the Retail Parks.
External infrastructure includes providing power, water, sewerage, and telecommunication facilities up to the boundary of the Retail Park.
Reimbursement of 100% of stamp duty for lease/sale of retail units within Mega Retail Parks on the first transaction only.
All incentives as per this policy will be disbursed only after meeting the mandated investment or employment targets.
All applications and incentive disbursement procedures for approvals will be as per the operational guidelines of the Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Policy of 2020-2023.
The A.P. Retail Parks Policy will come into operation from the date of issue of this order.
The A.P. Retail Parks Policy shall remain in force for five years.
The order was issued with the concurrence of the Finance (FMU-I&I, Energy and I&C) Department.
Retailing is defined as a set of activities or steps used to sell a product or service to consumers for their personal or family use.
Retailing is responsible for matching individual demands of the consumer with supplies of all manufacturers.
The retail field consists of supermarkets, department stores, chain stores, specialty stores, variety stores, franchise stores, mail-order houses, online merchants, and door-to-door sellers.
Retail stores buy their goods from wholesalers, stock the goods, and resell them to individual consumers in small quantities.
A retail enterprise is any entity that sells goods or provides service to the eventual consumer.
A retail enterprise deals with end consumers, maintains data of dealings with such consumers, and is responsible for service provided to end consumers.
Sale of goods by a retail enterprise can happen over various channels including brick-and-mortar, online, and other channels.
A Retail Park is a group of retail enterprises and other commercial establishments planned, developed, and managed as a single property.
A Retail Park is owned by a single or more than one owner.
A Retail Park comprises retail units such as shops offering goods and services.
A Retail Park includes family entertainment centers, hotels, offices/commercial complexes, restaurants, pubs, gyms, auditoriums for plays, multiplexes, and similar retail units.
A Retail Park must be on an area not less than five (5) Acres of land.
The park developer is mandated to set up a common Effluent Treatment Plant (ETP) and Common Sewage Treatment Plant (STP).
A Distribution Center is a facility at a single location that stocks a vast number of products sourced from different suppliers and distributes goods to retail stores or direct-to-consumer.

A Warehouse means any premises (including any protected place) conforming to all requirements including manpower specified by relevant and competent authority by regulations wherein a warehouseman takes custody of goods deposited by a depositor.
A Warehouse includes a place of storage of goods under controlled conditions of temperature and humidity or otherwise.
Mega Retail Park status is accorded to projects with an investment of at least 100 crore or direct employment generation of 5,000 for establishing a Consolidated Single Product/Sector Retail Park.
Mega Retail Parks must include setting up at least one of the following components: workshop, pre-processing units, large distribution centers, warehouses, and retail enterprises.
India is the fifth largest and preferred retail destination globally.
India is among the highest in the world in terms of per capita retail store availability.
India's retail market is estimated to reach USD 1.1-1.3 trillion by 2025, from USD 0.7 trillion in 2019.
India's retail market is growing at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 9-11%.
India's retail sector is experiencing exponential growth.
Retail development is taking place not just in major cities and metros, but also in tier II and III cities.
Healthy economic growth is a factor driving growth in the organised retail market in India.
Changing demographic profile is a factor driving growth in the organised retail market in India.
Increasing disposable income is a factor driving growth in the organised retail market in India.
Urbanisation is a factor driving growth in the organised retail market in India.
Changing consumer tastes and preferences are factors driving growth in the organised retail market in India.
The Government of India has introduced reforms to attract Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in the retail industry.
Cumulative FDI inflow in retail stood at USD 2.17 billion between April 2000 to June 2020.
India's retail sector attracted US$ 970 million from various private equity (PE) funds in 2019.
India is expected to become the world's third-largest consumer economy, reaching INR 27.95 lakh crore (USD 400 billion) in consumption by 2025.
Increasing participation from foreign and private players has given a boost to the Indian retail industry.
India's price competitiveness attracts large retail players to use it as a sourcing base.
Global retailers such as Walmart, GAP, Tesco and JC Penney are increasing their sourcing from India.
Global retailers are moving from third-party buying offices to establishing their own wholly owned/wholly managed sourcing and buying offices in India.

The Government is striving towards creating a congenial industrial environment in the state.

Changes within the industry itself are drivers of changes in retailing in Andhra Pradesh.

A variety of initiatives need to be introduced to provide a conducive environment for the growth of retail enterprises.
Relaxations in the current regulatory framework are being made through this policy to allow the retail industry to achieve its true potential.

Target 2: Create 50,000 additional direct employment opportunities in the retail Industry by 2026.
This policy will be valid for 5 years from the date of notification.
The Department of Industries, Commerce & Export Promotion will act as the Implementing agency for the Policy.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh shall appoint a Nodal Officer at each District Industries Center.
The Nodal Officer shall provide hand holding services to retail park developers and retail enterprises.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh shall create a customized facility on the Single Desk Portal.
Retail park developers and retail enterprises can obtain all clearances online in a time-bound manner through the Single Desk Portal.
All labor regulation-related approvals are issued online on the spot.

Other clearances applicable to retail, such as Packers license (Legal Metrology), Tree felling permission, Pesticide/Insecticide license, AP Shops Establishments registration & Trade License in urban areas, are to be given online in a time-bound manner.
Essential renewals for retail pertaining to Labour regulations, Drug Retail (Pharmacy) & ULB Trade License will have the option for online auto-renewals.
A single online return under all Labour Laws can be filed using the Single Desk Portal.
All inspections under Labour, Factories, Boilers, Pollution Control Board and Legal Metrology are managed and monitored through the Central Inspection System in a transparent manner.
Establishments are categorized as per risk.
Periodicity, compliance, and other inspection requirements are simplified for low-risk establishments.
GoAP will work with retail associations to encourage local sourcing from Andhra Pradesh.
Buyer-seller meets will be organized to encourage local sourcing.
Distribution centres/warehouses will be considered as Service Industry.
Government will allow organized retailers to set up their warehouses/distribution centers within designated areas in the Park.
The Logistic Policy proposed by the Government would cover initiatives for encouraging the setting up of world-class Warehouses on a PPP basis.
Retail enterprises shall be allowed to stay open every day of the year.
Employees must be given compulsory weekly offs on a preferential basis.
General permission shall be available for 3-shift operations with women working at night.
Retail parks and retail enterprises must take prescribed precautions for the safety and security of employees when women work at night.
Retail enterprises shall be exempted from maintaining physical records for attendance and salary.
Retail enterprises will be provided the provision to maintain employee-related records in electronic form.
Retail enterprises will be allowed to accept returns in electronic form.
Special emphasis has been given to the development of human resources and skill development for the Retail industry.
State-run agencies and renowned private institutions will institute training-based certification and placement programs.
These institutions would collaborate with the Retailers Association of India and other associations.
These institutions would collaborate with the local retail industry to understand their resource requirements.
A merit-based, defined certification and placement procedure shall be instituted.
Projects involving fixed capital investment of at least INR 100 crore will be accorded Mega retail park status.
Projects involving more than 5,000 direct employment for establishing a Consolidated Single Product/sector Retail Park will be accorded Mega retail park status.
Mega Retail Park developers will be eligible for reimbursement of 50% of the cost of external infrastructure for the park.
The cap on infrastructure support is based on direct employment.
For 5,000 to 10,000 direct employment, the cap on infrastructure support is INR 3 Crores.
For 10,001 to 15,000 direct employment, the cap on infrastructure support is INR 4 Crores.
For 15,001 to 20,000 direct employment, the cap on infrastructure support is INR 5 Crores.
External infrastructure includes laying of approach roads to the Industrial Park from the nearest highway/two-lane road/major road.
External infrastructure includes upgrading of existing roads/widening of roads to the Retail Parks.
External infrastructure includes providing power, water, sewerage, and telecommunication facilities up to the boundary of the Retail Park.
Reimbursement of 100% of stamp duty for lease/sale of retail units within Mega Retail Parks on the first transaction only.
All incentives as per this policy will be disbursed only after meeting the mandated investment or employment targets.
All applications and incentive disbursement procedures for approvals will be as per the operational guidelines of the Andhra Pradesh Industrial Development Policy of 2020-2023.
The A.P. Retail Parks Policy will come into operation from the date of issue of this order.
The A.P. Retail Parks Policy shall remain in force for five years.
The order was issued with the concurrence of the Finance (FMU-I&I, Energy and I&C) Department.

Invasion of major retail chains is adversely affecting the local jewellery making industry.

These firms are heavily dependent on casting units in jewellery making.

The artisans lack expertise in the use of technology in manufacturing Jewellery.
The artisans are heavily dependent on CAM centres in Mumbai.

The cluster also lacks modern machines like laser engraving machines.

Stakeholder concerns regarding existing gaps and the proposed CFC are tabulated.
Concerns include the quality of the product.
Concerns include the lack of finance for purchasing Die Moulding Centre Dies.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized Testing Lab in the Cluster.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized hallmarking facility for quality control.
Concerns include the lack of a Prototyping centre.
Concerns include poor jewelry design.
Concerns include the lack of knowledge and procedures involved in SPV formation.
Concerns include how to meet recurring expenditure on the proposed CFC and make it self-sustainable.

Mitigation for quality of product: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of finance for Dies: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized Testing Lab: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized hallmarking facility: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of Prototyping centre and poor jewelry design: Establishment of CAD / CAM Centre as CFC.
Mitigation for lack of knowledge on SPV formation: DSLR Consultancy will help the association in SPV formation and registration.
Mitigation for recurring expenditure: Levying service charges on members and non-members of SPV upon usage of facilities in CFC.
Mitigation for lack of land and building: Taking land on lease basis and constructing the building with financial support from the state government.
Mitigation for apprehension about DPR: DSLR Consultancy will prepare and facilitate the SPV to submit the DPR to SIDBI and steering committee.

A hallmark is an official mark or series of marks struck on items made of precious metals.
Hallmarks are a guarantee of certain purity or fineness of the metal.
Hallmarks are determined by formal metal (assay) testing.
Hallmark comprises five elements: BIS Mark, Fineness number, Assaying and Hallmarking Centreâs mark, Jewellerâs mark, and Year of marking.
Laser marking is a new method of marking using lasers.
Laser marking is valuable for delicate items.
Laser marking is valuable for hollowware.
Laser marking avoids damage or distortion caused by the punching process.
Laser marking means finished articles do not need to be re-finished.
Laser marking works by using high power lasers to evaporate material from the metal surface.
Two methods of laser marking exist: 2D and 3D laser marking.
2D laser marking burns the outline of the hallmarks into the object.
3D laser marking simulates the marks made by punching.
As BIS has made hallmarking mandatory, majority of cluster firms find it tough to know the purity of ornaments.
Majority of cluster firms are selling articles without Hallmark.
This results in higher rejection rates.
This results in a dent in profit margins.
Few firms send articles to Hyderabad for hallmarking.
Hallmarking costs in Hyderabad are higher.
Transportation costs to Hyderabad are additional.
Articles sent to Hyderabad are vulnerable to theft.
There is a definite need to establish a common testing cum 3D laser Hall Mark Facility.
The Testing Cum Hall mark facilities are estimated to be utilized by 500 micro firms from within the cluster.
Artisans from adjoining districts are also expected to utilize the facility.
The Hall Mark Cum Testing Unit would cater to testing of raw material (Gold, Cadmium, Copper) for purity.
The Hall Mark Cum Testing Unit would cater to testing of alloy (gold, cadmium and/or copper) used for making jewellery.
The Hall Mark Cum Testing Unit would cater to testing of finished goods with reference to Caratage.
The Hall Mark Cum Testing Unit would cater to Hall Marking of purchased and sold gold ornaments.

CAD (computer aided design) drawing and drafting systems are widely used in general industry.
CAD systems are used for designing models for mass production.
CAD systems offer speed in organizing accurate components.
CAD systems allow rapid translation into working 'blueprint' diagrams.
CAD systems allow work to be done once for a repetitive component.
CAD systems increase efficiency by reusing previously prepared standardized parts.
For exact translation of design into three dimensions, investment in a CAD/CAM system for 3-D prototyping may make sense.
Large manufacturers in the jewelry industry have used CAD and CAD/CAM for some time.
Computers are starting to be used in similar ways in the jewelry industry in smaller scale establishments.
The designer need not necessarily have technical knowledge concerning how the object is actually made.
The CAD/CAM system can take care of many technical concerns.
As 3-D prototyping systems become more commonplace, it will be less of a worry to the designer.
The actual 'creation' of a physical object is now possible for a designer who may not know 'how' to make it by hand.
Most current 3D prototyping systems make the object in some kind of plastic or carve it in wax.
This plastic or wax can be molded from directly or burned out and cast like an ordinary wax model.
Jaggayyapeta Gold Cluster uses CAD / CAM frequently.
Jaggayyapeta Gold Cluster does not have its own CAD / CAM infrastructure.
Jaggayyapeta Gold Cluster is totally dependent on facilities in Mumbai for CAD / CAM.
The cost and time involved for utilizing CAD / CAM in Mumbai are high.
This is a hurdle for the cluster's growth.
The CAD/CAM Unit would cater to designing of Jewellery using computers.
The CAD/CAM Unit would cater to creating prototypes using CAM.

Mitigation for lack of knowledge on SPV formation: DSLR Consultancy will help the association in SPV formation and registration.
Mitigation for recurring expenditure: Levying service charges on members and non-members of SPV upon usage of facilities in CFC.
Mitigation for lack of land and building: Taking land on lease basis and constructing the building with financial support from the state government.

A hallmark is an official mark or series of marks struck on items made of precious metals.
Hallmarks are a guarantee of certain purity or fineness of the metal.
Hallmarks are determined by formal metal (assay) testing.
Hallmark comprises five elements: BIS Mark, Fineness number, Assaying and Hallmarking Centreâs mark, Jewellerâs mark, and Year of marking.
Laser marking is a new method of marking using lasers.
Laser marking is valuable for delicate items.
Laser marking is valuable for hollowware.
Laser marking avoids damage or distortion caused by the punching process.
Laser marking means finished articles do not need to be re-finished.
Laser marking works by using high power lasers to evaporate material from the metal surface.
Two methods of laser marking exist: 2D and 3D laser marking.
2D laser marking burns the outline of the hallmarks into the object.
3D laser marking simulates the marks made by punching.
As BIS has made hallmarking mandatory, majority of cluster firms find it tough to know the purity of ornaments.
Majority of cluster firms are selling articles without Hallmark.
This results in higher rejection rates.
This results in a dent in profit margins.
Few firms send articles to Hyderabad for hallmarking.
Hallmarking costs in Hyderabad are higher.
Transportation costs to Hyderabad are additional.
Articles sent to Hyderabad are vulnerable to theft.
There is a definite need to establish a common testing cum 3D laser Hall Mark Facility.
The Testing Cum Hall mark facilities are estimated to be utilized by 500 micro firms from within the cluster.
Artisans from adjoining districts are also expected to utilize the facility.
The Hall Mark Cum Testing Unit would cater to testing of raw material (Gold, Cadmium, Copper) for purity.
The Hall Mark Cum Testing Unit would cater to testing of alloy (gold, cadmium and/or copper) used for making jewellery.
The Hall Mark Cum Testing Unit would cater to testing of finished goods with reference to Caratage.
The Hall Mark Cum Testing Unit would cater to Hall Marking of purchased and sold gold ornaments.

Concerns include the quality of the product.
Concerns include the lack of finance for purchasing Die Moulding Centre Dies.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized Testing Lab in the Cluster.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized hallmarking facility for quality control.
Concerns include the lack of a Prototyping centre.
Concerns include poor jewelry design.
Concerns include the lack of knowledge and procedures involved in SPV formation.
Concerns include how to meet recurring expenditure on the proposed CFC and make it self-sustainable.
Concerns include the lack of land and building for the proposed CFC.
Concerns include high land prices to purchase.
Concerns include apprehension about DPR preparation and submission to DC-MSME.
Mitigation for quality of product: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of finance for Dies: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized Testing Lab: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized hallmarking facility: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of Prototyping centre and poor jewelry design: Establishment of CAD / CAM Centre as CFC.
Mitigation for lack of knowledge on SPV formation: DSLR Consultancy will help the association in SPV formation and registration.
Mitigation for recurring expenditure: Levying service charges on members and non-members of SPV upon usage of facilities in CFC.
Mitigation for lack of land and building: Taking land on lease basis and constructing the building with financial support from the state government.
Mitigation for apprehension about DPR: DSLR Consultancy will prepare and facilitate the SPV to submit the DPR to SIDBI and steering committee.
The proposed CFC facilities will be commissioned in the Building facility.
The Building facility will be constructed on land taken on lease by the SPV.
The lease of the land is for a period of 33 years.
The rent for the land is â¹ 5,000 per month.
The rent for the land increases by 5% every year.
The lease agreement is enclosed as Appendix 4.
The layout of the buildings is enclosed as Appendix 8.
The proposed layout shows the configuration of various elements of the CFC.
A built-up area of about 3475 sq.ft is considered for the proposed common processing centre.
There will be 11 rooms of various sizes in three floors to accommodate the machineries.
The facility will also accommodate an office.
The facility will also accommodate a reception.
The facility will also accommodate a waiting hall.
All 11 rooms will be separated by wall partitions.
The raw material required like Gold will be brought in by the users of the CFC.
The user will bring the required raw material into the Die Moulding Centre.
Based on the user's requirement, operators will complete the job work.
The finished/semi-finished product will be given back to the user.
Some users may come for partial job works like sheet drawing.
Some users may come for partial job works like wire drawing.
Some users may come to use the Dies.
The user will be levied charges based on the quantum of work involved.

Reasons for selection: Presence of all requisite machinery as per specifications.
Reasons for selection: Good track record of the bidder.
Reasons for selection: One year warranty and free after sales service.
Reasons for selection: Presence of in-house experienced staff.
Reasons for selection: Reasonable cost of machinery.
The purity of gold is measured in Carats.
Caratage indicates how pure the metal is.
The gold Carat (ct) tells how many parts of gold and how many parts of other metal are in the gold alloy.
Jewellery standards specify benchmarks for gold to ascertain its fineness.
24 Carat gold is pure gold.
The basic problem for cluster firms is the lack of testing facilities.
Lack of testing facilities hinders the cluster from venturing into the export market.
Establishing a common testing facility with an XRF machine will allow easy calculation of alloy purity.
This will enable beneficiary firms to venture into exports.

Capacity utilization for Sheet & wire drawing is increased by 5% every year, with a maximum of 75%.
Capacity utilization for Die Moulding Centre considers a 1% increase in jobs every year.
Capacity utilization for testing cum hall marking centre will be 60% in the first year, increasing by 5% annually to a maximum of 75%.
Capacity utilization for CAD/CAM will be 60% in the first year, increasing by 5% annually to a maximum of 75%.
All charges are marginally below current market rates.
Charges are increased by 2% every year.
Chemical consumption for testing is considered as â¹ 1.00 Lakh per month.
Other Operating expenses are â¹ 20,000/- per month.
Power tariff is considered as â¹ 7 per unit for 10 HP.
Water charges are considered as â¹ 70 KL.
Salaries are considered for 24 people with an annual increment of 5%.
Repair & Maintenance expenses are considered as 2% of sales.
Administrative expenses are considered as 2% of sales.
Sales and Marketing expenses are considered as 1% of sales.
Lease rental for Land is â¹ 5,000 per month with a 5% increment every year.
Depreciation is calculated as per SLM and WDV methods.
Income tax is calculated as per current rates.
The project makes a profit from the first year of operation.
The revenue during the first year of operation is â¹ 242.79 Lakh.
The revenue increases to â¹ 289.24 Lakh by the end of the 4th year.
The increase in revenue is primarily due to increased capacity utilization.
The profit during the first year of operation is â¹ 80.15 Lakh.
The profit increases to â¹ 99.41 Lakh by the 4th year.

The preliminary and preoperative expenses are â¹ 10.85 Lakh.
The preliminary and preoperative expenses are 1.37% of the project cost.
Increasing total assets (Fixed & Current assets) in the balance sheet shows the strength of the project.
The closing balance during the first year of operation is â¹ 135.95 Lakh.
The closing balance increases to â¹ 1517.98 Lakh by the end of the 10th year.
As the SPV is registered as a Not for Profit company, profits will not be shared.
Profits are proposed to be utilized for the development of artisans in the cluster and further creation of fixed assets.
The first-year breakeven is reached at 43.15% of the operating capacity.
The breakeven at operating capacity improves to 37.43% by the end of the 5th year.

The project's IRR works out to 15.64%.
The project's RoCE is calculated as 33.98%.

Capacity utilization for Sheet & wire drawing is increased by 5% every year, with a maximum of 75%.
Capacity utilization for Die Moulding Centre considers a 1% increase in jobs every year.

A team of professionals from DSLR Consultancy formed a focus group.
The focus group conducted meetings and held discussions with key players of the cluster.
Discussions covered CFC requirements, site location, and stakeholder contributions.
Discussions covered grant in aid to be sought from DC-MSME.
The focus group also held discussions with Public Service Providers like DIC, CoI, MSME-DI, and other State Government agencies.
Discussions covered major gaps in the cluster as perceived by them.
Discussions covered their contribution in the proposed intervention.
Discussions covered the monitoring mechanism after commissioning of the proposed intervention.
The DSLR Consultancy team met key players of the cluster.
The DSLR Consultancy team met all supporting units like raw material suppliers.
The DSLR Consultancy team met machinery suppliers in the backward integration.
The DSLR Consultancy team met retail marketing outlets in the forward integration.
Stakeholder concerns regarding existing gaps and the proposed CFC are tabulated.
Concerns include the quality of the product.
Concerns include the lack of finance for purchasing Die Moulding Centre Dies.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized Testing Lab in the Cluster.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized hallmarking facility for quality control.
Concerns include the lack of a Prototyping centre.
Concerns include poor jewelry design.
Concerns include the lack of knowledge and procedures involved in SPV formation.
Concerns include how to meet recurring expenditure on the proposed CFC and make it self-sustainable.
Concerns include the lack of land and building for the proposed CFC.
Concerns include high land prices to purchase.
Concerns include apprehension about DPR preparation and submission to DC-MSME.
Mitigation for quality of product: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of finance for Dies: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized Testing Lab: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized hallmarking facility: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of Prototyping centre and poor jewelry design: Establishment of CAD / CAM Centre as CFC.
Mitigation for lack of knowledge on SPV formation: DSLR Consultancy will help the association in SPV formation and registration.
Mitigation for recurring expenditure: Levying service charges on members and non-members of SPV upon usage of facilities in CFC.
Mitigation for lack of land and building: Taking land on lease basis and constructing the building with financial support from the state government.
Mitigation for apprehension about DPR: DSLR Consultancy will prepare and facilitate the SPV to submit the DPR to SIDBI and steering committee.
The proposed CFC facilities will be commissioned in the Building facility.
The Building facility will be constructed on land taken on lease by the SPV.
The lease of the land is for a period of 33 years.
The rent for the land is â¹ 5,000 per month.
The rent for the land increases by 5% every year.
The lease agreement is enclosed as Appendix 4.
The layout of the buildings is enclosed as Appendix 8.
The proposed layout shows the configuration of various elements of the CFC.
A built-up area of about 3475 sq.ft is considered for the proposed common processing centre.
There will be 11 rooms of various sizes in three floors to accommodate the machineries.
The facility will also accommodate an office.
The facility will also accommodate a reception.
The facility will also accommodate a waiting hall.
All 11 rooms will be separated by wall partitions.
The raw material required like Gold will be brought in by the users of the CFC.
The user will bring the required raw material into the Die Moulding Centre.
Based on the user's requirement, operators will complete the job work.
The finished/semi-finished product will be given back to the user.
Some users may come for partial job works like sheet drawing.
Some users may come for partial job works like wire drawing.
Some users may come to use the Dies.
The user will be levied charges based on the quantum of work involved.
