Concerns include the quality of the product.
Concerns include the lack of finance for purchasing Die Moulding Centre Dies.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized Testing Lab in the Cluster.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized hallmarking facility for quality control.
Concerns include the lack of a Prototyping centre.
Concerns include poor jewelry design.
Concerns include the lack of knowledge and procedures involved in SPV formation.
Concerns include how to meet recurring expenditure on the proposed CFC and make it self-sustainable.
Concerns include the lack of land and building for the proposed CFC.
Concerns include high land prices to purchase.
Concerns include apprehension about DPR preparation and submission to DC-MSME.
Mitigation for quality of product: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of finance for Dies: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized Testing Lab: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized hallmarking facility: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of Prototyping centre and poor jewelry design: Establishment of CAD / CAM Centre as CFC.
Mitigation for lack of knowledge on SPV formation: DSLR Consultancy will help the association in SPV formation and registration.
Mitigation for recurring expenditure: Levying service charges on members and non-members of SPV upon usage of facilities in CFC.
Mitigation for lack of land and building: Taking land on lease basis and constructing the building with financial support from the state government.
Mitigation for apprehension about DPR: DSLR Consultancy will prepare and facilitate the SPV to submit the DPR to SIDBI and steering committee.
The proposed CFC facilities will be commissioned in the Building facility.
The Building facility will be constructed on land taken on lease by the SPV.
The lease of the land is for a period of 33 years.
The rent for the land is â¹ 5,000 per month.
The rent for the land increases by 5% every year.
The lease agreement is enclosed as Appendix 4.
The layout of the buildings is enclosed as Appendix 8.
The proposed layout shows the configuration of various elements of the CFC.
A built-up area of about 3475 sq.ft is considered for the proposed common processing centre.
There will be 11 rooms of various sizes in three floors to accommodate the machineries.
The facility will also accommodate an office.
The facility will also accommodate a reception.
The facility will also accommodate a waiting hall.
All 11 rooms will be separated by wall partitions.
The raw material required like Gold will be brought in by the users of the CFC.
The user will bring the required raw material into the Die Moulding Centre.
Based on the user's requirement, operators will complete the job work.
The finished/semi-finished product will be given back to the user.
Some users may come for partial job works like sheet drawing.
Some users may come for partial job works like wire drawing.
Some users may come to use the Dies.
The user will be levied charges based on the quantum of work involved.

Capacity utilization for Sheet & wire drawing is increased by 5% every year, with a maximum of 75%.
Capacity utilization for Die Moulding Centre considers a 1% increase in jobs every year.
Capacity utilization for testing cum hall marking centre will be 60% in the first year, increasing by 5% annually to a maximum of 75%.
Capacity utilization for CAD/CAM will be 60% in the first year, increasing by 5% annually to a maximum of 75%.
All charges are marginally below current market rates.
Charges are increased by 2% every year.

Other Operating expenses are â¹ 20,000/- per month.
Power tariff is considered as â¹ 7 per unit for 10 HP.
Water charges are considered as â¹ 70 KL.
Salaries are considered for 24 people with an annual increment of 5%.

Administrative expenses are considered as 2% of sales.
Sales and Marketing expenses are considered as 1% of sales.
Lease rental for Land is â¹ 5,000 per month with a 5% increment every year.
Depreciation is calculated as per SLM and WDV methods.
Income tax is calculated as per current rates.
The project makes a profit from the first year of operation.
The revenue during the first year of operation is â¹ 242.79 Lakh.
The revenue increases to â¹ 289.24 Lakh by the end of the 4th year.

The profit during the first year of operation is â¹ 80.15 Lakh.
The profit increases to â¹ 99.41 Lakh by the 4th year.

The preliminary and preoperative expenses are â¹ 10.85 Lakh.
The preliminary and preoperative expenses are 1.37% of the project cost.
Increasing total assets (Fixed & Current assets) in the balance sheet shows the strength of the project.
The closing balance during the first year of operation is â¹ 135.95 Lakh.
The closing balance increases to â¹ 1517.98 Lakh by the end of the 10th year.
As the SPV is registered as a Not for Profit company, profits will not be shared.
Profits are proposed to be utilized for the development of artisans in the cluster and further creation of fixed assets.
The first-year breakeven is reached at 43.15% of the operating capacity.
The breakeven at operating capacity improves to 37.43% by the end of the 5th year.
The average breakeven is evaluated as 37.97% over a period of 10 years.
The project's IRR works out to 15.64%.
The project's RoCE is calculated as 33.98%.

A team of professionals from DSLR Consultancy formed a focus group.
The focus group conducted meetings and held discussions with key players of the cluster.
Discussions covered CFC requirements, site location, and stakeholder contributions.
Discussions covered grant in aid to be sought from DC-MSME.
The focus group also held discussions with Public Service Providers like DIC, CoI, MSME-DI, and other State Government agencies.
Discussions covered major gaps in the cluster as perceived by them.
Discussions covered their contribution in the proposed intervention.
Discussions covered the monitoring mechanism after commissioning of the proposed intervention.

Concerns include the quality of the product.
Concerns include the lack of finance for purchasing Die Moulding Centre Dies.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized Testing Lab in the Cluster.
Concerns include the lack of a recognized hallmarking facility for quality control.
Concerns include the lack of a Prototyping centre.
Concerns include poor jewelry design.
Concerns include the lack of knowledge and procedures involved in SPV formation.
Concerns include how to meet recurring expenditure on the proposed CFC and make it self-sustainable.
Concerns include the lack of land and building for the proposed CFC.
Concerns include high land prices to purchase.
Concerns include apprehension about DPR preparation and submission to DC-MSME.
Mitigation for quality of product: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of finance for Dies: Establishment of a Common Facility Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized Testing Lab: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of recognized hallmarking facility: Establishment of a Common Testing cum Hall Mark Centre.
Mitigation for lack of Prototyping centre and poor jewelry design: Establishment of CAD / CAM Centre as CFC.
Mitigation for lack of knowledge on SPV formation: DSLR Consultancy will help the association in SPV formation and registration.
Mitigation for recurring expenditure: Levying service charges on members and non-members of SPV upon usage of facilities in CFC.
Mitigation for lack of land and building: Taking land on lease basis and constructing the building with financial support from the state government.
Mitigation for apprehension about DPR: DSLR Consultancy will prepare and facilitate the SPV to submit the DPR to SIDBI and steering committee.

The 7th State Level Steering Committee (SLSC) Meeting of MSE-CDP was held on 03-08-2023 at 3:30 pm in Hybrid Mode (Physical & Virtual).
The meeting was held in the Chamber of Secretary to Government, Industries & Commerce GoAP, AP Secretariat, Velagapudi.
The meeting was chaired by Shri N. Yuvraj IAS, Secretary to Govt of AP, Industries & Commerce Department, and Chairman of SLSC.
Shri D. Chandrasekhar IEDS, Additional Development Commissioner, MSME-DFO, Hyderabad & Visakhapatnam, and Member Secretary/Convener welcomed the participants.
ADC highlighted the performance of MSE-CDP in Andhra Pradesh compared to the national level in terms of CFCs and ID Projects.
Andhra Pradesh is ranked among the top 10 high-performing states in the implementation of the cluster scheme.
14 new CFC proposals and 7 new ID Projects were received, scrutinized, and placed before the SLSC for consideration.
12 CFC proposals received earlier were scrutinized, and shortfalls were communicated to the implementing agency and SPV members.
15 ID projects were already recommended after the approval of the 6th SLSC and will be placed in the ensuing NPAC Meeting for final approval.
Approximately 253 persons participated in the meeting, including GM DICs, SPV members, and other stakeholders.
The Convener initiated the discussion as per the Agenda Points.
The SLSC reviewed the action taken report on the minutes of the 6th SLSC Meeting held on 14-03-2023.
The SLSC confirmed the minutes of the 6th SLSC Meeting.
The proposal for the Auto Engineering Cluster, Kakinada, was recommended by SISC and accorded in-principle approval by NLSC on 27-09-2019.
The SPV identified land in SEZ, Kakinada, and the land was de-notified.
The SPV is unable to pay the exorbitant price fixed by APIIC for the land.
ADC requested the allotment of land on a nominal lease or rent.
The VC&MD, APIIC, informed that land cannot be given on lease without full payment as per APIIC norms.
The Chairman advised the SPV to reduce the land requirement or amend APIIC norms.
The Chairman instructed APIIC and APMSME DC to resolve the land issue within 3 weeks.
The proposal for the Gold Cluster, Nellore, was recommended by SLSC and accorded final approval by NLSC on 11-07-2019.
GM DIC, Nellore, advised guiding the SPV to identify alternative land/Govt Building within 1 month.
GM DIC Nellore is to identify private land or provide land through APIIC to the SPV.
The Printing Cluster, Tirupathi, old proposal was dropped, and a new proposal under new CDP Guidelines was placed before the NPAC.
The 5th SLSC recommended placing the Printing Cluster, Tirupathi proposal in the ensuing NPAC Meeting for final approval.
The status of completed ID Projects under MSE-CDP in Andhra Pradesh was reviewed.
Project closure certificates for all completed ID Projects need to be obtained.
The status of ongoing ID Projects under MSE-CDP in Andhra Pradesh was reviewed.

The ongoing ID Projects are: Upgradation of Industrial Park (Jewellery Park) at Machilipatnam, Krishna District; Upgradation of Growth Centre at Hindupur, Anantapuramu District; Upgradation of Industrial Estate, Autonagar, Phase-IV, Guntur District.
The committee advised APIIC/IA to complete all works within timelines as per the final approval accorded by DC-MSME.
The Chairman, SLSC, directed APIIC/IA to be ready for the inauguration of all 3 ID Projects on 2nd October 2023.
The status of ID Projects which were accorded Final Approvals was reviewed.

These projects are: Development of FFC at Atcutapuram in Non-SEZ, Area, Visakhapatnam District; Upgradation of Industrial Park at Nellimarla, Vizianagaram District; Upgradation of Industrial Park at IP Tanuku, West Godavari District.

The Additional Development Commissioner, MSME, advised APIIC/IA to open SNA Accounts and Holding Accounts, link them to the New Scheme CODE -4170, deposit APIIC's share, and submit to DC-MSME office for releasing the 1st Instalment of GOI Grant Amounts.
APIIC was also requested to speed up the tendering process and start the implementation of the projects.
The review of proposed dropped components was discussed.

The dropped components are: Upgradation of Growth Centre at Hindupur, Anantapuramu District (Admin Building Component); Development of Industrial Park at Peddapuram, East Godavari, District (Effluent Treatment Plant).
The SLS Committee agreed for dropping of components and recommended placing them in the NPAC meeting for necessary approvals.
Requests for Extension of Time (EOT) for ID Projects were discussed.

The projects requesting EOT are: New Industrial Estate at Kopparthy, YSR Kadapa District; New Industrial Estate at Gandrajupalli, Chittoor District; Upgradation of Industrial Park at Singarayakonda, Prakasam, District; Development of Industrial Park at Peddapuram, East Godavari, District; Upgradation of Existing Autonagar at Vedayapallem, SPSR Nellore District.
The SLSC recommended EOT up to 31.10.2023 for placing before the ensuing NPAC Meeting for according EOT.
The review of progress of ongoing CFCs was discussed.

The CFC in Printing Cluster, Kakinada, has a total project cost of Rs. 1476.00 Lakhs, with GOI Grant of Rs. 1033.20 Lakhs (70%), State Govt. Contribution of Rs. 295.20 Lakhs (20%), and SPV Contribution of Rs. 147.60 Lakhs (10%).
Final Approval for the CFC in Printing Cluster, Kakinada, was accorded on 29-07-2021, and the project was to be completed by 28-07-2023.

The CFC in Hosiery & Readymade Garments Cluster, SPSR Nellore District, has a total project cost of Rs. 823.00 Lakhs (approx.), with GOI Grant of Rs. 576.08 Lakhs (70%), StateGov. Contribution of Rs. 164.60 Lakhs (20%), and SPV Contribution of Rs. 82.30 Lakhs (10%).

The APMSMEONE Portal is a single-window digital platform for MSME programs and initiatives in Andhra Pradesh.
The portal enables Implementing Agency, ANOs, SPIU, and DNOs to manage training and capacity-building programs.
Users can create and manage training batches, enroll participants, record attendance, submit completion reports, and facilitate multi-level review and approval.
The portal aims for efficiency, transparency, and accountability.
The APMSMEONE Portal has a role-based access system.
Implementing Agency & ANOs create batches, enroll participants, mark attendance, and submit reports.
District Nodal Officers (DNOs) review and approve reports at the district level.
State Project Implementation Unit (SPIU) provides state-level oversight and approves reports.
The system provides a dashboard-driven experience in the RAMP Monitoring Tab.
The manual covers system access, navigation, batch management, participant enrollment, attendance recording, report submission, and the approval process.
To log in, open the APMSMEONE Portal, click Login, enter Username and Password, complete Captcha, and click Sign In.

To create an event, go to RAMP Event on the dashboard, fill in mandatory details (Select RAMP Event, District, Assembly Constituency, Location, Event Venue, Event Start Date, Event End Date, Event Time), and click Create New Event.
A confirmation message 'RAMP Event Created Successfully' will appear.
Batch ID format is RAMP event -District Code -Id Number (e.g., BDS-KRI-00001).
To modify an event, locate the 'Actions' column in the event list, click 'Click Here', complete mandatory fields, and update.
A confirmation message 'RAMP Event Updated Successfully' will appear.
Participants can be enrolled from the Event List by clicking 'Enroll participants' and providing details, or from the Web Portal via RAMP Calendar -> Enrollment Calendar.

Mandatory fields for enrollment include First Name, Last Name, Age, Gender, Email Address, Phone Number, Aadhar No., Udyam Registration number, Social Category, Minorities, Persons with disability (PWD), Designation, Organization, Sector, Address.
A confirmation message 'Enrollment Successfully' will appear.

To update participant details, click RAMP Registration Details, use filters (RAMP Component, Batch ID), click Apply Filters, scroll to the action column, click the list icon, update details, and click Submit.
A confirmation message 'Participant Details updated Successfully' will appear.
To delete a participant, click RAMP Registration Details, use filters, click Apply Filters, scroll to the action column, enter remarks, and click Delete.
A confirmation message 'Participant Deleted Successfully' will appear.
Attendance recording can be done via Mobile App or Web Portal.
For Mobile App attendance, first perform Venue Tagging by logging in, selecting Batch ID, filling coordinator details, capturing venue photos, allowing location services, and clicking Submit.
A confirmation message 'Venue tagging is successful' will appear.
Attendance cannot be marked unless Venue Tagging is completed.
For Workshop Attendance via Mobile App, select Attendance Module, choose the event/batch, mark participants as Present or Absent, upload a Group Photo, and click Submit.
A success message will confirm attendance recording.
The Attendance Report feature allows generating Detailed Daily Wise Attendance Reports and Abstract Reports.
To access reports, log in to APMSMEONE website, go to RAMP Attendance Module -> Attendance Report, fill fields, select report type, and Apply Filters.

Completion Report Submission involves logging in, navigating to the RAMP Monitoring Dashboard, selecting filters, locating the batch, clicking 'View Report', filling in mandatory fields (Workshop End Date, Workshop Batch No., Workshop Start Date, Workshop Duration), selecting amenities provided, uploading E&S Form and Press Release(s), filling submitter details, and clicking Submit.
The report is then forwarded to the District Nodal Officer (DNO) for review and approval.
The RAMP Monitoring Dashboard for Implementing Agency allows viewing submitted reports and logs.
The RAMP Monitoring Dashboard for District Nodal Officer (DNO) allows reviewing reports, updating status (Verify & Sign or Return), and viewing logs.
To Verify & Sign, the DNO answers a questionnaire, enters remarks, and clicks Save/Submit.
The batch status changes to 'Signed' and moves to SPIU approval.
To Return a report, the DNO selects 'Return', enters remarks, and clicks Save.
The report is sent back to the Implementing Agency for correction.
The View Log option allows DNOs to see the history of actions.
The RAMP Monitoring Dashboard for State Project Implementation Unit (SPIU) allows reviewing reports, updating status (Approve or Return), and viewing logs.
To Approve, SPIU selects 'Approve', enters remarks, and clicks Submit.
The batch status updates to 'SPIU Approval: Approved'.
To Return, SPIU selects 'Return', enters remarks, and clicks Submit.
The batch status updates to 'SPIU Approval: Returned'.
Handling Returned Reports involves reviewing remarks in 'View Log', making corrections, and re-submitting the report.
File upload formats accepted are PDF, JPEG, PNG.
Press Releases should be consolidated into a single PDF file.
The APMSMEONE Portal streamlines RAMP event management.
The Support Desk is available for assistance.
The Strategic Investment Plan (SIP) submitted by Andhra Pradesh was due on August 15, 2023.
The Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) facilitated several meetings for SIP evaluation.
The RAMP Programme Committee (RPC), chaired by the Secretary (MoMSME), approved the SIPEC recommendations, including funding quantum, on November 10th.
The RPC, in its 4th meeting on August 2, 2023, recommended incentivizing states.
A list of selected project proposals from Andhra Pradesh and their recommended funding quantum is annexed.
The RPC recommended that 50% of the total approved amount be for part-financing.
Subsequent tranches of Grant-in-Aid will be released only after 75% of the first tranche is utilized and at least 50% of project targets are achieved.
Fund flow arrangements will follow the guidelines issued by the Department of Expenditure on March 9, 2023, and subsequent orders.
The Ministry of MSME will release Grant-in-Aid to the Central Nodal Agency (CNA) in Ludhiana.
The CNA will set drawing limits for states as per the Sanction Order.
States will draw funds on a real-time basis from the RAMP scheme's CNA as payments are made to vendors and beneficiaries.
The available drawing limit will decrease with utilization.
As per the Department of Expenditure OM dated March 27, 2023, CNA limits will be frozen on March 31, 2023, at 12:00 midnight.
Limits remaining with states will be made zero on March 31, 2023, at 12:00 midnight.
The Ministry will allocate fresh limits for the next financial year.
The RAMP Programme Implementation Manual (PIM) was circulated to states during the Letter of Undertaking (LoU) signing.
States are required to prepare an Implementation Plan for selected project proposals part-funded under RAMP.
The Implementation Plan must contain specific details (not fully specified in the provided text).
An M&E framework for each selected proposal must be drawn up, including baseline figures for each indicator and data sources.
Every state should have a State Programme Implementation Unit (SPIU) in place within the State Industries/MSME Department, with procurement done as per GFR 2017.
Rs. 5 Crore already provided for SIP preparation should be utilized for the SPIU.
Additional funds for SPIU will be considered only after the utilization of the Rs. 5 Crore already sanctioned.
The SPIU will be responsible for implementation, monitoring, and evaluation of selected projects.
The SPIU shall coordinate with the National Project Management Unit (NPMU) in the Ministry for assistance.
States should draw and submit an Outreach plan for identification and mobilization of MSMEs.
The total Grant-in-Aid to the state includes an amount equivalent to 5% of the overall approved support from the RAMP budget for branding, awareness, and communication.
States are required to obtain Ministry approval before launching any branding campaign.
Any unspent balance in the Zero Balance Sub Agency account as of March 31st of every year will revert to the Central Nodal Agency (CTR Ludhiana) account, along with accrued interest.
States shall provide DLI-wise M&E data to the Ministry on a monthly basis, disaggregated by SC/ST/Women/PwD.
States shall provide implementation status of part-funded projects on a monthly basis.
States shall provide semi-annual and annual reports.
States shall submit Utilization Certificates of funds utilized every six months.
States shall submit Financial reports and Contract management reports at the end of every six months (July 31st and January 31st).
Failure to submit these reports by the due date will result in non-release of further funds (para 8.3.5(e) of PIM).
State Governments must conduct internal audits for financial management and procurement transactions as laid out in the PIM (para 8.5 to 8.6).
State Governments/SPIU/Implementing Agencies shall submit a compliance report to the Ministry on audit observations from the internal audit.
The financial audit of SPIU and participating public and private sector Implementing Agencies will be conducted by their statutory auditors.
The audit report should be submitted to the Ministry within 9 months of the end of each financial year, i.e., by January 31st of the subsequent year (Para 8.6(g) of PIM).
If the SPIU and implementing agencies have a 'disclaimer or adverse' audit opinion or fail to submit audit reports on time, further grants will not be released (para 8.6(h) of PIM).
SPIU and participating public/private Implementing Agencies shall submit a compliance report to the Ministry on financial audit observations within 3 months from the date of the audit report.

All funds released to states will be subject to the World Bank's 'Guidelines on Preventing and Combating Fraud and Corruption in Programmes for Results Financing' dated February 1, 2012, and revised on July 10, 2015 (Annexure 8 in PIM).
If any condition is left out in this communication, the provisions of the Programme Implementation Manual will be applicable.
States may take immediate action to complete preliminary steps and start project implementation at the earliest.
Implementation Plans and M&E frameworks should be communicated to the Ministry in time.
The National NPMU can be contacted for further assistance/information.
