The Government of Andhra Pradesh is implementing various social and sectoral programs for the state's development.
One of the promises under the 'Super Six' category is the creation of 20 lakh employment opportunities.
The Government is committed to creating substantial employment opportunities by focusing on key sectors and leveraging the state's strengths.
Various policy and schematic interventions are being introduced to generate jobs for approximately 20 lakh individuals over the next five years.
The Government has constituted a Group of Ministers (GoM) to suggest measures and mid-term corrections for achieving the goal of creating 20 lakh employment by 2029.
The GoM will also institutionalize a suitable monitoring mechanism.
Sri Nara Lokesh, Hon'ble Minister for Human Resources Development, IT Electronics & Communication; RTG; Skill Development, is the Chairman of the GoM.
Sri T G Bharath, Hon'ble Minister for Industries & Commerce, Food Processing, is a Member of the GoM.
Sri Gottipati Ravi Kumar, Hon'ble Minister for Energy, is a Member of the GoM.
Sri Kandula Durgesh, Hon'ble Minister for Tourism Culture & Cinematography, is a Member of the GoM.
Sri Ponguru Narayana, Hon'ble Minister for MA&UD, is a Member of the GoM.
Sri Kondapalli Srinivas, Hon'ble Minister for MS&ME, SERP and NRI Empowerment and Relations, is a Member of the GoM.
The GoM's terms of reference include suggesting measures to achieve the employment objective through best policies and interventions across line departments.
The GoM will periodically review and suggest necessary corrective measures/remedies.
The GoM will suggest a suitable institutional mechanism to monitor and regularly update employment provided in public and private sectors.
All line departments must nominate a senior official (not below HoD, JD, or JS level) to participate in GoM meetings and provide regular updates.
The Skill Development and Training Department and the Director of Industries will provide secretarial assistance and other support to the GoM.
The Skill Development and Training Department and the Director of Industries shall take necessary further action.
The Industries & Commerce Department has issued orders for the New Andhra Pradesh Food Processing Policy (4.0) for the period 2024-29.
The previous Food Processing Policy was formulated for 2020-2025.
Operational Guidelines for the AP Food Processing Policy were issued on 26.10.2022.
The Indian food industry is estimated to be USD 543 billion in 2023, compared to the global food industry of USD 8.1 trillion.
The global food industry is forecast to grow at a CAGR of 6.47% in the next 5 years.
India's food industry is expected to grow faster by 11% in the same period.
India exports over USD 40 billion worth of food, contributing approximately 2.5% of global exports.
Andhra Pradesh ranks 4th in the agriculture production of food grains, horticulture produce, milk, and meat products.
In 2023, the State's food industry was valued at USD 49 billion, representing 9% of the Indian market.
Andhra Pradesh's food industry contributes significantly to global exports from India, comprising 15% of the overall food exports from India.
Andhra Pradesh houses over 5,500 food processing units, including ~180 large enterprises and over 150 medium processing units.
Chittoor, Ananthapur, Kurnool, Guntur, Krishna, Vizianagaram, West, and East Godavari are the top contributing districts for food processing units.
Andhra Pradesh accounts for about 15% of total food processing industries in the country.
Andhra Pradesh is India's largest producer of mango, papaya, tomatoes, lemon, chili, turmeric, rice, groundnut, cotton, fish, and shrimp.
The state is ranked 1st in the country in shrimp production.
A renewed, forward-looking policy is needed to establish a supportive ecosystem for the food processing industry, considering investor needs, climate change, and employment opportunities.
The Andhra Pradesh Food Processing Policy 4.0 (2024-29) aims to foster economic value, encourage responsible actions towards climate goals, and ensure human safety.
The Finance Department's remarks have been obtained and incorporated into the policy.
Incentives under Technology Upgradation and Capital Subsidy are mutually exclusive.
The AP Food Processing Society (APFPS) shall act as the Nodal agency for processing and disbursement of incentives and will be allocated a budget for this purpose.
APFPS is tasked with developing unique revenue generation models to ensure sustainable payout of incentives.
The Government approves the Andhra Pradesh Food Processing Policy 4.0 (2024-29).
The policy is applicable to the entire state and aims to boost economic development in the food processing segment.
Incentives mentioned in the policy will be extended to eligible industries as per separate operational guidelines.
The Director of Industries, Vijayawada, and CEO, AP Food Processing Society, Vijayawada, shall take necessary action for implementing operating guidelines.
The policy document is appended to the order as an Annexure.
The policy period is 5 years from the date of notification or until a new policy is announced.
The policy may be amended prospectively, without curtailing granted benefits.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh may extend the policy period.
The policy is applicable to the entire state.
The vision for Andhra Pradesh's food processing industry by 2029 is to be a leading hub, leveraging technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship.
The vision includes minimizing post-harvest losses, boosting value addition, focusing on cluster-based development, enhancing product quality, and integrating with global markets.
The vision also aims to foster a dynamic ecosystem driven by market-focused research, varietal improvements, and targeted skill development.

The guiding principles include targeting potential and growing markets, improving industry ecology, promoting quality standards, fostering research and innovation, ensuring food safety and quality, and re-skilling and up-skilling the workforce.
Andhra Pradesh faces significant post-harvest losses (estimated at 15-20%) in perishable goods like fruits, vegetables, and seafood.
The policy focuses on reducing these losses by developing cluster infrastructure, including processing facilities near farm gates, Export Hubs, and Food Parks.
Improved cold chain logistics will ensure faster market access, reduce wastage, increase farmer incomes, and strengthen the supply chain.
The policy emphasizes improving product quality, fostering cluster-based development, and promoting efficient storage and value addition.
Additional incentives are offered to industries engaged in secondary and tertiary processing.
Cluster development will be prioritized, integrating storage, processing, and distribution infrastructure.
The policy supports local enterprises with subsidies and technical assistance, while promoting sustainability and innovation.
The policy supports industries in upgrading technology to enhance efficiency and product quality.
Technology transfer will be facilitated through partnerships with research institutions and technology providers.
Market Assistance initiatives will help enterprises access domestic and global markets.
The policy promotes organic food processing to tap into the growing demand for sustainable and healthy food products.
Financial incentives, technical assistance, and infrastructure support will be provided for organic processing units.
The policy promotes sustainable practices through waste processing and the development of industrial ecology.
Industries are encouraged to adopt waste-to-value approaches, such as converting food waste into biofuels, animal feed, or compost.
The policy emphasizes ensuring food safety and maintaining high standards of quality throughout the processing chain.
Support will be provided for implementing robust quality control measures, certification processes, and food safety management systems.
The policy encourages the adoption of advanced testing facilities and traceability systems.
The policy fosters collaboration between industry, academic institutions, and research organizations to drive research and innovation.
A state corpus of INR 250 crores is established to promote research and innovation, quality certifications, traceability, and organic production processing.
The policy underscores the importance of quality certification and traceability to enhance product integrity and build consumer trust.
Support will be provided for obtaining national and international certifications (FSSAI, HACCP, ISO, GAP).
Skill development is critical for building a capable workforce for the food processing sector.
The Andhra Pradesh State Skill Development Corporation (APSSDC) will support vocational training initiatives.
Demand-driven courses in food packaging, testing, quality control, and food processing will be offered through collaborations with renowned institutions.
The policy aims to create localized employment and entrepreneurship opportunities for rural youth.
The policy aims to position Andhra Pradesh as a preferred destination for Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in the food processing sector.
The policy offers competitive incentives and a conducive business environment to attract global investors.
The policy emphasizes expanding exports by encouraging value-added production and ensuring products meet international quality and safety standards.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh aims to transform the state into a food processing hub.
The policy aims to foster an entrepreneurial ecosystem by promoting the 'One Entrepreneur per One Family' initiative.
The target is to attract new investments worth INR 30,000 Crores in the sector by 2029.
The target is to attract FDI investment worth USD 1 Bn in the sector by 2029.
The target is to create 3,00,000 additional employment opportunities in the sector by 2029.
The target is to develop 10 commodity-based food clusters, including meat processing.
The target is to establish Commodity Boards for key crops/produce on a PPP mode.
The target is to establish one Premier Food Processing Institute in PPP mode.
The target is to develop Food Parks through prospective private players with basic enabling infrastructure and common facilities.
Tribal regions in Alluri Sitharama Raju and Parvathipuram Manyam are to be notified as Organic zones.
The Andhra Pradesh Food Processing Society (APFPS) will serve as the nodal agency for implementing the policy.
APFPS will provide guidance to entrepreneurs on accessing incentives and benefits.
The policy focuses on value addition as the key driver for growth across Agriculture, Horticulture, Aqua, and Animal Husbandry sectors.
The policy aims to create a balanced ecosystem that encourages innovation and processing at every level of the value chain.
The primary objective is to transform raw produce into higher-value products, boosting market competitiveness, enhancing export potential, and increasing profitability.
The policy places a strong emphasis on promoting secondary and tertiary processing units by offering tailored incentives.
Andhra Pradesh has 8.42 million hectares of cultivable land and benefits from an extensive irrigation network.
Major crops grown in the State include paddy, maize, groundnut, cotton, pulses, and millets.
Andhra Pradesh is recognized for its diversified crop portfolio.
Andhra Pradesh leads India's horticulture sector, contributing over 16% to the state's Gross Value Added (GVA).
Andhra Pradesh is the largest producer of horticultural crops including mango, banana, sweet orange, pomegranate, papaya, chilli, turmeric, cocoa, coconut, oil palm, and tomato.
The livestock sector accounts for over 31% of Andhra Pradesh's agricultural output.
Andhra Pradesh ranks first in egg production, contributing 20.13% of India's total egg output.
Andhra Pradesh is a leading producer of milk and meat.
In 2022-23, the state produced 15.45 million MT of milk and 1.09 million MT of meat.
The fisheries sector accounts for 28% of Andhra Pradesh's agricultural output.
Andhra Pradesh leads India in fish and shrimp production, producing 0.84 million MT of shrimp and over 5.16 million MT of total fisheries output in 2023-24.
AP contributes 37% of national shrimp exports.
Government is setting aside INR 250 Crores corpus to support programs/projects for R&D, quality certifications, organic certification, and promotion of Millet production.
Commodity Boards will be established for key commodities to drive innovation, promote value addition, and improve infrastructure and market linkages.
The objective of Food Parks is to provide modern infrastructure facilities for food processing units in a plug & play model.
GoAP plans to develop at least 77 MSME Parks and 26 Large Parks.
Nano food parks (Less than 10 acres) will be developed to promote micro food enterprises.
GoAP plans to develop at least 175 Nano Food Parks in 175 constituencies.
The Government plans to establish an Animal Feed Park on PPP mode.
Andhra Pradesh is planning to establish four state-of-the-art export hubs, each covering over 500 acres.
These export hubs will offer end-to-end services such as aggregation, packing, cold storage, quality testing, phytosanitary certification, and export compliance.
The policy encourages investment in cold storage facilities, refrigerated transportation, and pack houses.
The development of irradiation units is a key focus to enhance food safety, extend shelf life, and meet international export standards.
The policy encourages the establishment of irradiation units in key production zones.
The policy prioritizes the establishment and enhancement of food testing laboratories across Andhra Pradesh.
These laboratories will be equipped with advanced testing technologies.
The policy emphasizes the development of modern abattoirs to enhance the efficiency, hygiene, and safety of meat processing.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh is promoting the food processing industry by enabling the convergence of various schemes from central and state departments.
The policy emphasizes the integration of sustainability and circularity within the food processing industry.
The policy encourages the adoption of eco-friendly practices, such as waste-to-energy conversion, utilization of by-products, and water conservation technologies.
The AP government launched the Single Desk Portal (SDP) in June 2015 to help industries obtain regulatory clearances.
The SDP supports end-to-end transaction processing with online payment and application status tracking.
An investment facilitation cell has been created to assist investors with coordinating approvals on the Single Desk Portal.
MSMEs are considered the backbone of economic growth and major employment generators.
As of February 2024, there are around 7.41 Lakh registered MSME units in the state.
The state will notify a dedicated MSME and Entrepreneur development Policy.
The state classifies investment categories for the food processing sector into investment bands.
The overall incentive a company can claim shall not exceed 75% of FCI.
Fiscal incentives are applicable for investments made in agri, food processing, and allied segments in Andhra Pradesh.
The Government of AP adopted the definition of MSME laid out in the MSMED Act, 2006.
Projects are classified based on Fixed Capital Investment (FCI) for MSME, Large, and Mega projects.
FPOs/SHGs/Federations/Cooperatives/Societies are classified as per GoI definition.

Fiscal incentives such as Power tariff reimbursement, SGST reimbursement, Skill upgradation cost, Energy and water audit cost, local procurement subsidy, and Quality certification are applicable as per MSME policy.
Projects with FCI of more than INR 50 Cr up to INR 100 Cr fall under the large category.
Projects with FCI of more than INR 100 Cr are treated as Mega category.
The Government will extend tailor-made benefits to projects with FCI of more than INR 100 Cr on a case-to-case basis.
Capital Subsidy is available for new enterprises.
Capital Subsidy is available for Technology Upgradation/Modernization.
Capital Subsidy is available for Waste Processing.
Capital Subsidy is available for setting up of Modern Abattoirs/Meat processing/Animal Feed units.
Food Testing Laboratories are eligible for financial assistance.
Power tariff reimbursement is provided to the food processing industry.
Net SGST reimbursement is provided for a specified period and capped at 5% of annual turnover.
Energy and Water audits are subsidized.
Skill upgradation is subsidized.
Local Procurement Subsidy is extended to exporting units in select sectors.
Quality Certification costs are reimbursed.
A top-up of 10-15% additional incentive is provided for sanctioned projects under PMKSY scheme of MoFPI, GoI.
Additional Interest Subvention is provided for projects under AHIDF and AIF.
Standard Incentives are applicable for all investment bands (MSME, Large, Mega).
100% stamp duty and transfer duty paid on land purchase for industrial use will be reimbursed.
100% stamp duty for lease of land/shed/buildings, mortgages, and hypothecations will be reimbursed.
100% fee charged for land conversion will be reimbursed.
The operating guidelines for this policy will be issued separately.
The Department of Agri. & Horticulture will coordinate with APFPS in data consolidation and propose Commodity Development Boards.
The Department of Fisheries will coordinate with APFPS to propose shrimp/fish development Boards.
The Department of Animal Husbandry and Dairying will coordinate with APFPS to establish Animal Feed Park, abattoirs, and meat processing units.
APIIC will coordinate with APFPS in developing Food parks, export hubs, and Sector specific industrial parks.
AP MSME DC will coordinate with APFPS in conducting Capacity building programs, EDP, Formalisation, and Thematic interventions.
SERP & MEPMA will work to promote and strengthen SHGs to avail benefits of Food Processing schemes.
The Tribal Welfare Department will coordinate with APFPS to promote and strengthen Tribals to avail benefits of Food Processing schemes.
The Andhra Pradesh State Skill Development Corporation will coordinate with APFPS in facilitating skill development courses.
The Renewable Energy department will facilitate Open Access for Solar power generation plants.
Rythu Sadhikara Samstha will encourage farmers towards natural farming.
The document is a compendium of technologies available for transfer and commercialization from the National Research Development Corporation (NRDC).
NRDC is India's premier technology transfer organization, established in 1953.
NRDC functions under the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research (DSIR), Ministry of Science & Technology, Government of India.
NRDC has a wide network with R&D organizations like CSIR, NIOT, DRDO, ICMR, ICAR, and universities.

NRDC supports new ideas and inventions, ensures intellectual property protection, facilitates technology transfer from labs to industry, provides access to technologies, exports Indian technological expertise, and offers IP and technology consultancy services.

NRDC is recognized as a large depository of technologies in agriculture, agro-processing, food processing (including millets), chemical, herbal, electrical, electronics, biotechnology, mechanical, and marine sectors.
NRDC has signed about 5000 technology license agreements and filed 2000 patents.
NRDC has exported technologies and services to over 20 developing and developed countries, including African nations.

This compendium summarizes 262 technologies with TRL 6 and above in agriculture, electrical, electronics, chemical, electrochemical, mechanical engineering, oceanographic, corrosion, food, and millet technologies.
The compendium serves as a reference for policymakers, industries, entrepreneurs, startups, MSMEs, research scholars, scientists, and other stakeholders.
The document includes technologies in the Renewable Energy Sector.
Solar tree technology can harvest 100 times more solar power using 1% of land compared to conventional SPV layouts.
Two solar artifacts are available: Sourya Aapatram (1KW) and Sourya Banaspati (5KW).
Sourya Aapatram has a maximum power generation capacity of 1 kW and a load capacity of 0.5 kW for 3 hours.
Sourya Banaspati has a maximum power generation capacity of 5 kW and a load capacity of 1 kW for 10 hours.
Salient features of solar trees include less land requirement, simple rotating mechanism, strong metal frame, and low maintenance.
The Wind Solar Hybrid (WiSH) System combines wind and solar power for a steady power supply.
The WiSH system includes a wind turbine, solar photovoltaic unit, charge controller, outdoor control panel, and a battery bank.
A 500W wind-solar hybrid system is capable of providing power in standalone situations like borewells and pumps.
Applications of WiSH system include catering to domestic and agricultural energy requirements in off-grid villages and meeting the requirements of large domestic buildings in urban areas.
Salient features of WiSH system include superior performance in low-speed Indian wind regimes, auto-furling over-speed protection, and a charge controller for steady power supply.
The Biomass Gasifier Based Power Generation System allows dual-fuel operation of existing diesel gensets, reducing diesel consumption by over 70%.
The biomass gasifier system optimally utilizes biomass for power generation.
A gasifier is a reactor that converts biomass into producer gas, a clean gaseous fuel.
Applications of the biomass gasifier system include making up for the absence of grid electricity in remote areas.

Salient features of the biomass gasifier system include smooth fuel movement, continuous grate-shaking mechanism for ash removal, preheated air entry for good gas quality, and a cooling tower to minimize water requirement.
Natural Gas Based Pot and Muffle Furnaces for the Glass Industry are energy-efficient and economically viable.
The natural-gas-based pot furnace minimizes energy wastage by using pre-heated air for combustion and utilizing heat from outgoing flue gases.
The natural-gas-fired muffle furnace is designed to increase production by 10% and can use better-quality muffles made of silicon carbide for enhanced life.
Advantages of natural gas-based furnaces include energy savings up to 50% for pot furnaces and 30% for muffle furnaces.
These gas-fired furnaces are environmentally sound and less harmful to the workforce.
Biogas from Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) utilizes waste biomass to generate energy, reducing waste management problems, pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, and the use of fossil fuels.
MSW contains significant fractions of paper, food waste, wood, yard trimmings, cotton, and leather, making it a source of biomass.
Technological interventions have been incorporated to make the biogas production process more mechanized and efficient.
Features include a Biomass Grinder cum Stirrer, automatic gas evacuation system, and recycling of slurry water to improve gas production yield and reduce fresh water consumption.
Applications of biogas from MSW include a renewable and clean source of energy from biodegradable waste, with the digestate serving as enriched organic fertilizer.
Salient features of biogas from MSW include non-polluting gas generation, reduced greenhouse gas emissions, and digestate as enriched organic fertilizer.
Co-digestion of Tannery Solid Waste for Biogas Generation addresses the problem of managing process solid waste (fleshing) and effluent treatment plant sludge from tanneries.
The technology co-digests fleshing and waste activated sludge (WAS) for biogas generation.
A pilot-scale demonstration plant of capacity 750 kg/day has been implemented at Calcutta Leather Complex (CLC), Kolkata.
Salient features of co-digestion of tannery solid waste include protection of the environment, minimization of disposal problems, odor and groundwater pollution, and reduction of carbon footprint.
The digestate can be used as manure.
The High Solid Treating Compact Digester cum Biogas Plant can treat any organic waste without water addition and produces more biogas.
This dry digestion principle allows for higher organic loading rates and better volatile solid removal efficiency (~90%).
The scalable process unit can treat from 5kg to 500 Kg/day of organic waste.
Applications include recovering biogas and manure from organic wastes from houses to commercial units.

Salient features include compact size, no water addition required, ability to treat any food waste, higher biogas yield with high methane content, no mosquito breeding problem, and less slurry output usable as manure.
Biohydrogen Production from Biogenic Waste (Solid/Liquid) technology produces biohydrogen and fatty acids from waste/wastewater through acidogenic fermentation, apart from remediation.
Biohydrogen can be used as an energy carrier for the automobile sector, raw material in various industries, or as an additive in CNG.

Salient features include generation of 50,000 liters of bio-hydrogen with 60% COD removal efficiency, applicability to any waste/wastewater with higher organic load, and scalability from 10 m3/day to 100 m3/day.
Major raw materials include industrial wastewater and solid waste like food/vegetable waste.
Major plant equipment includes acidogenic bioreactor, biogas holding tanks, and gas flow meters.
The Solar Biodiesel Hybrid Minigrid of 50KW Peak Capacity addresses the increasing demand for electricity and reliance on fossil fuels.
This system harnesses renewable energy from Solar Photovoltaics (PV) and Biodiesel.
Biodiesel can be produced from various feedstocks like Used Cooking Oil and Waste Vegetable oil.
The system is a unique solution for uninterrupted power in remote areas and finds applications in Smart City projects.
Salient features include a peak capacity of 50 kWp, solar PV capacity of 48.35 kWp, diesel genset capacity of 50 kW, and battery bank of 48V, 2350 AH.
Solar Hydrogen Generation Technology has potential to resolve energy shortage and environmental concerns by storing renewable energy and using it as fuel.
Photocatalytic water splitting using semiconductor materials is studied for hydrogen production.

Salient features include a hetero-structured photocatalyst system with high photocurrent density and H2 generation rate (TRL LEVEL-4/5), and an inexpensive carbon-based photocatalyst system (TRL LEVEL-4).
Renewable Biohydrogen (H2) and Platform Chemical from Biogenic (Solid/Liquid) Waste technology produces hydrogen and fatty acids from waste/wastewater, apart from remediation.
The technology can be a standalone process or a unit operation in ETPs.
Hydrogen can be used in the automobile sector, chemical industry, and oil refining.
Sustainable Integration of Iron Redox Flow Battery with a Renewable Energy Source is critical for meeting the demand for renewable energy.
Redox flow batteries (RFBs) are considered future electrical energy storage technologies due to their low operating costs, scalability, and versatility.
The proposed project assesses the energy efficiencies and techno-economic feasibility of integrating a 500 W all-iron RFB system with a renewable energy source.
Applications include Iron-based redox flow batteries which use eco-friendly, non-toxic, cost-effective iron salts as electrolytes.
Technologies in Environment Management & Waste Management include Gas Sensors for Environmental Monitoring.
Industries manufacturing fertilizers, pesticides, chemicals, and petrochemicals are major sources of dangerous gaseous elements.
MEMS-based gas sensors are miniaturized with low power consumption, robust, and stable electrical properties.
These gas sensors have three main components: Sensor chip, Electronic circuit, and power supply.
Applications include pollution monitoring, explosive detection, alcohol breath tests, food quality checks, and disease detection from breath.

Salient features include detection of a wide range of gases like Ammonia, CO, H2S, NOx, Alcohol, Benzene, etc., miniaturized sensor chip size, fast response time, and integration with portable electronics.
Plastic Waste Sorting System for Five Types of Plastics uses Near Infrared (NIR) spectroscopy and chemometric techniques to sort singulated plastics moving on a conveyor.
Applications include segregating waste plastics into different value-added polymer fractions for efficient recycling.
It sorts Poly-Ethylene Terephthalate (PET), Poly-Propylene (PP), Poly-Vinyl Chloride (PVC), Poly-Styrene (PS), and Poly-Ethylene (PE).

Salient features include real-time, non-destructive, and fast sorting of waste plastics, accurate classification of plastics (near 100% for PET), and automated, low-cost system using open-source hardware and software.
Composite Board from Agro-Waste technology produces medium density boards or composite boards from agricultural wastes like paddy husk, paddy straw, and certain reed materials.
These boards are used in false partitions, ceilings, table tops, furniture fixtures, and mirror backings.
Comparative advantages include an environmentally friendly process that utilizes agricultural waste, low-density timber scrapings, and a binder.
Process Technology for Separation of Glass and Phosphor from Waste CFLs enables complete recycling of fluorescent lamps.
Metallic components, glass, and phosphor powder can be easily separated.
Process specifications include a processing time of 15 minutes, use of simple organic solvents, and an energy-efficient process.
Applications can be applied to waste CFLs, night glowing toys, tube lights, and spent LEDs.
Advantages include complete recycling of waste CFLs and tube lights and recovery of glass and phosphor material.
Gasification of Powdery Biomass/Coal/Industrial Wastes uses a gasifier reactor to improvise mixed flow and plug flow reactor characteristics for high intensity reaction and gasification.
The gasifier-reactor attains a temperature in the range of 900-1200Â°C to produce low tar and char formation.
Major application areas include Rice Mills, Coir industries, Saw Mills, and other agro-processing industries.

Comparative advantages include capability to handle feedstocks with a wide range of particle sizes, renewable energy generation, reduction in carbon emission, and value addition to agro-wastes/industrial wastes.
Utilisation of Municipal Solid Wastes (MSW) from Landfill for Road Embankment Construction uses segregated MSW as an embankment material, solving cost efficiency and environmental hazard problems.
The process involves segregation of MSW into different size fractions before use.
Salient features include methodology for utilization of MSW from landfills, segregation of up to 65-75% of MSW, and typical design cross-sections for 3m and 5m height MSW embankments.
Comparative advantages include reduced pollution, protection of environment and health, sustainable road construction, and preservation of urban land.
Process for the Preparation of Waste PVC (Poly Vinyl Chloride) Modified Bitumen is useful for paving applications.
This process reuses toxic PVC waste, which is difficult to recycle and has no safe disposal method, in bituminous roads.
Salient features include extending pavement life, enhanced strength of bituminous mix, and safer disposal of hazardous PVC plastic waste.
Comparative advantages include utilization of waste product PVC (waste to wealth approach) and no adverse effect on the environment.
Geopolymer Cement is a sustainable technology utilizing waste by-products like fly ash and blast furnace slag, with significant carbon emission reduction potential (over 70% compared to OPC).

Salient features include properties similar to Portland Pozzolana Cement, fire resistance up to 900 degrees Celsius, and major raw materials including fly ash, ground granulated blast furnace slag, chemical admixtures, and alkali hydroxides or silicates.
Comparative advantages include LEED Green Building Technology compliance, higher durability than OPC, and 70% less CO2 generation.
Rapid Composting of Municipal Solid Waste aims at enhancing the rate of organic matter degradation while keeping the nutrient content of the compost high.
The approach is to keep all vital parameters (temperature, pH, aeration, moisture, etc.) at optimum levels to speed up the composting process.
A four-ton compost pilot plant employs an aerobic composting process for the organic fraction of municipal solid waste.

Advantages include shortening the composting period with considerable reduction in C/N ratio and reducing the composting period from 6 weeks to 2 weeks by employing cellulolytic fungi, Trichoderma reesei.
Plasma Disposal of Plastic Waste and Generation of Syngas for Power Generation addresses the increasing plastic waste generation through plasma pyrolysis, resulting in by-product syngas.
Salient features include uniform gasification, single-step treatment, complete destruction of plastic waste, reduced need for landfill, and safer disposal of plastic waste.

Advantages include energy recovery, volume reduction of waste streams, destruction of stable bacteria, supply of excess electricity for sale, prevention of formation of complex molecules like dioxins, and reduced need for landfill.

Recycling of Plastic Wastes into Tiles for Structure Designing for Societal Usage utilizes waste plastic bags and bottles to design materials for tiles in building toilets and rooms for public benefit.
The novelty of the concept includes mechanical strength, flame retardancy, water permeability, UV protection, and aesthetic response.
Waste Plastics to Fuel and Petrochemicals technology converts waste plastics (polyethylene and polypropylene) exclusively into gasoline, diesel, or aromatics.
The gasoline and diesel meet most of the BS IV/VI specifications, while the petrochemicals are rich in toluene and xylenes.

Advantages include conversion of waste plastics to automotive-grade fuel or petrochemicals, a clean and economical automotive-grade fuel from an alternative source, impetus to waste plastics collection, economic benefits to rag pickers, and a green solution to waste plastics disposal.
Technologies in Ocean Resources include Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) Operational up to 150m.
The modular streamline structure helps integrate additional payloads with less effort and reduced drag.
It is stable against roll motion, making it suitable for seabed mapping and scientific data collection.
The design allows for slight positive buoyancy for better diving control and safety.
It has dual communication including both RF and Acoustic communication.
Advantages include deployment for seabed mapping, coastal surveillance, mine countermeasure, and oceanographic measurements.
Deep Water Electric Work Class Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV) ROSUB6000 is developed to map coral reefs and assess damage or rejuvenation.
The images of corals recorded by the ROV are useful for studying the biodiversity of coral reefs and their evolution.
Advantages include use for research, scientific exploration, and engineering applications like underwater inspection of pipelines.
Autonomous Underwater Profiling Drifter (AUPD) is a common underwater platform that carries CTD sensors and profiles seawater measurements at predetermined depths.
These floats drift freely, periodically ascend to the surface, report to the satellite, and descend again.
Advantages include a high-pressure rated hull, buoyancy engine, and controller, with the hull made of lightweight and corrosion-resistant Aluminum Alloy (Al 6061).
Wireless Expendable Conductivity, Temperature and Depth Profiler System (WXCTD) is a temperature probe dropped into the ocean from a ship.
It measures temperature profiles as the probe descends in the upper layer (500m) of the ocean.

Advantages include studying upper ocean thermal structures, accurate conductivity and temperature data collection, accurate depth measurement using pressure sensors, and data transfer through wireless communication.
Shallow Water Chirp Sub Bottom Profiler System can profile the seabed with penetration up to 1m in fine sand/clay, operable up to 30m depth.
It is a tow body-based sonar system that can be towed behind a vessel even in very shallow waters.
Advantages include indigenous subsystems, user-friendly GUI, and configurable operational parameters.
Drifting Buoy System measures near-surface ocean currents and temperature with geostationary satellite communication for near real-time data.
The measurement scheme is capable of measuring variability in sea surface temperature and small mesoscale surface eddies.
Advantages include a durable float, components with proven micropower parametric measurement, data forwarding electronics, and customizable transmission parameters.
Drishti is an IoT device for fish farmers that provides real-time fish weight estimate, supports fish feed control, and timely harvest.
It provides insights directly from the field through SMS and assists in farm management.

Salient features and applications include being a battery-powered standalone unit to detect and predict Fish Biomass, identification of marine pathogens and their symptoms in fishes, and being an underwater miniature low-power edge device that uses AI for field-based data insights.
MARESOL is an indigenous C-Profiler designed for collecting real-time in-situ profiles using a tow fish operated from a moving ship/boat.
The equipment can be used as standard deck equipment for research and mapping expeditions at a lower cost per data.

Salient features and applications include continuous collection of CTD data without stopping the ship, quick sensor head changes on deck, precise, low-cost, and rapid method to observe ocean currents and eddies, and remote system control.
ROSHNI (Renewable Ocean System for Harnessing Novel Illumination) is a portable, lightweight seawater lantern developed for off-grid power and emergency power systems.

Salient features and applications include continuous operation for up to 12 hours per seawater replacement, use of tap water with salt if seawater is unavailable, a higher version with mobile charging provision, and utility among communities with limited power access or during emergencies.
Recombinant Ectoine from Deep Sea Bacteria is a major compatible solute from halophilic bacteria, Bacillus clausii, known to stabilize cell functions under stress conditions.
Products developed represent a new supplement in the derma pharmacy industry.
The process involves constructing and optimizing ectoine biosynthesis genes in Bacillus clausii and expressing them in Escherichia coli M15.
A maximum ectoine production of 6.7 mg/L was achieved.

Process for the Production of Lutein involves isolating a fast-growing, high biomass, and lutein-producing microalgal strain, Chlorella sorokiniana, and optimizing culture media, methodology, harvesting, and purification.

The process includes cultivating microalgae, harvesting using electrocoagulation, rinsing, spray drying, cell disruption, alkaline treatment, solvent extraction, solvent removal, HPLC quantification, purification, and re-dissolving in olive oil.
Biosurfactant from Marine Bacteria is used for environmental clean-up and waste management.
Biosurfactants are amphiphilic compounds that decrease surface and interfacial tension.

The process involves using a biosurfactant-producing bacteria (Brevibacterium sp. COD27), optimizing culture conditions, using an enriched medium, and ensuring stability in a wide range of physicochemical conditions.
The biosurfactant is stable and works efficiently at a low concentration of 0.1%, degrading 87% of crude oil in 30 days.
Salient features include biodegradability, non-toxicity, high selectivity, and activity at variable pH, temperature, and salinity.
C-Phycocyanin from Marine Spirulina Technology involves standardizing marine Spirulina culture in raceway ponds for biomass and C-PC production.
The technology includes a 50-tonne capacity paddle wheel operated raceway pond for pilot scale testing and an electrocoagulation system for large-scale harvesting.
Salient features and applications include standardized marine Spirulina culture, proven biomass and C-PC production, and testing of large-scale culture in 25-ton capacity raceway ponds.

Pharmacoactive Nutrient from Marine Algae involves the production of 'Pharmacoactive Growth Promoter' (PGP) from live biomass of marine microalgae Chlorella vulgaris by a modified hot water extraction method.
Beneficial properties of PGP include anti-inflammatory activity, wound healing property, detoxification, constipation relief, and growth stimulation.
Salient features and applications include a nutritionally and pharmaceutically valuable hot water extract from C. vulgaris, containing protein, carbohydrate, crude fat, and minerals.
Recombinant Glutaminase Free L-Asparaginase from Marine Actinobacteria Nocardiopsis Alba is a promising therapeutic agent for leukemia chemotherapy.
The invention relates to the construction and optimization of biosynthetic genes from the Nocardiopsis alba L-asparaginase gene and its expression in Escherichia coli.
The developed enzyme can be used in pharmaceutical compositions for treating cancer, tumors, and diseases involving cell proliferation.
Salient features include isolation of N. alba NIOT-VKKMA08 from marine sediments and aerobic growth in starch casein agar.
Technologies in Agro & Agriculture Sector include Mobile Distillation Unit for Essential Oils from various aromatic crops.
The mobile distillation unit can be attached to any tractor and transported directly to the farmer's field for distillation.

Advantages include easy transportability, capacity for distilling all types of essential oil-bearing aromatic crops, utilization of spent distilled biomass waste as fuel, and enhanced distillation efficiency and oil recovery.
Cotton Production and Processing Technologies cover various aspects from farming practices to by-product utilization.

Cotton farming practices include general breeding methods, hybrid seeds, soil management, water management, integrated nutrient management, integrated pest management, disease control, and farm machinery.
Seed processing, ginning, pressing, mechanical processing (spinning), and chemical processing of cotton fabrics are also covered.

Cotton by-product utilization includes cotton seed meal, particle boards, binder-less hard boards, pulp & paper, corrugated boards, bio pulping, micro crystalline cellulose, edible cultivation, biogas, and bio-manure from textile mill waste.
Palm Oil Extraction Technology involves processing fresh fruit bunches within 24 hours of harvest to produce palm oil.
The technology includes designing expandable processing plants (2.5 ton to 10.0 ton FFB/hr) and commercializing the technology through project engineering companies.
Impact of the technology includes promoting high-yielding oil crops to bridge the gap between demand and supply of edible oil.
Biogas and Bio-manure from Poultry Litter technology treats poultry litter for the generation of renewable energy (biogas) and bio-manure.
The 'Anaerobic Gas Litter Reactor (AGR)' is specially designed for treating poultry litter generated from Indian poultry farms.

Comparative advantages include biogas and bio-manure generation, economic viability, replacement of conventional electricity, a salable by-product (bio-manure), improved hygiene, better bird health, and reduced mortality.
Low Cost Jute Based Disposable Sanitary Napkin for Rural Women utilizes jute fiber and jute sticks as the absorbent core material without synthetic super-absorbent polymer.
The manufacturing process is simple, chemical-free, and can be adopted by non-skilled/semi-skilled persons.
Advantages include a stable, low-cost sanitary napkin, biodegradable core with good water retention, an eco-friendly manufacturing process, and cost-effectiveness.

Jute Fibre Reinforced Linear Low Density Polyethylene (LLDPE) Composite Product manufacturing uses a cost-effective mixing process of jute fiber with polyolefin using a kneader-extruder system in a batch process.
Salient features include using chopped jute fibers or loom waste material, optional pre-drying of fiber, and incorporation of up to 20% jute fiber by weight in LLDPE.
Advantages include market improvement in impact strength, 20% increase in Charpy impact strength, and improved functional property like exposure to UV rays.
Rot Resistant Natural Durable Jute Geo-textiles are ecologically safe, biodegradable, and leave no residue in the environment.
Jute geo-textiles have properties like hydraulic, tensile strength, trapezoidal tear strength, porosity, and permeability comparable to synthetic textiles.
Salient features include treatment with textile-friendly, anti-microbial agents that impart durable rot-resistant properties.
Advantages include being eco-friendly, retaining permeability and flexibility, being lightweight and cost-effective, and not possessing hormonal properties.
Clean Extraction of Banana Fibre from Pseudo Stem and Empty Bunches uses an anaerobic process mediated through microbial action, completed in 6 days of water soaking.
The in-situ production of enzymes facilitates the separation of fibers.

Advantages include a simple method to produce banana fibers, obtaining good quality fibers, being inexpensive, pollution-free, having zero damage or loss of fibers, biogas generation, higher earnings for farmers, and creating new employment.

COIRRET - Innoculant for Retting Coconut reduces the retting period of coconut husks and upgrades the quality of un-retted green husk coir fiber through treatment with a combination of bacterial cultures.
By applying the bacterial consortium 'COIRRET', the retting period is reduced from 11 months to 3 months and green husk fiber quality is improved within 72 hours.
Advantages include reduced cost of production, maximum utilization of husk potential, being an environmentally friendly process, and treatment in RCC tanks.
Mobile Fibre Extraction Machine addresses the problem of collecting husks from remote villages where on-site de-fibering is not possible.
The machine separates coir fiber and pith directly from the coconut husk, eliminating multiple steps and machines required in traditional methods.
Advantages include low machine cost, portability, hygienic working environment, and suitability for other coir processing countries.
PITHPLUS is a technology for the bio-conversion of coir dust into a useful organic manure with applications in agriculture and horticulture.
The product obtained after bio-conversion has excellent properties as a growing medium, especially in soilless containers for high-value horticulture crops.
Salient features and advantages include converting coir waste into organic manure, being a perfect organic growing medium for fruits and vegetables, and being a popular soil conditioner worldwide.
COCOLAWNTM: A Readymade Lawn is a ready-to-use lawn constructed using coir pith and other materials, serving as a natural, eco-friendly substitute for synthetic lawns.
It has vast potential in tourist resorts, hotels, playgrounds, and rooftop plantations.
A ready-made lawn consists of a netting material made of coir, non-woven layers, and a layer of fertilizer of treated coir pith and natural grass.
Biopesticidal Nema Gel utilizes highly mobile nematodes entrapped in a hydrogel matrix to overcome constraints of high temperature and stability for controlling insect pests.
The Nema Gel contains an indigenous insect-killer nematode that is heat tolerant and kills a broad range of soil and foliar insect pests.

Salient features include safe application for plants, farm animals, non-target pests, human health, and the environment, increased water holding capacity of the soil, and visible efficacy within 24-48 hours.
ANKUSH - A New Silkworm Bed Disinfectant is an eco-friendly silkworm body and rearing seat disinfectant that avoids environmental deterioration and user hazards.
The product is biodegradable, economical, and as effective as popular but hazardous bed disinfectants.
Manufacture of Potassium Humate from Lignite provides an efficient method for extracting humic acid in the form of potassium humate from lignite.

Salient features include favorable effects on plant tissue nutrient balance, fertilizer uptake, growth, yield, and quality; increased soil N-utilization efficiency; enhanced uptake of K, Ca, Mg, P, and trace elements; increased water holding capacity; stimulated seed germination and viability; and improved drainage and aeration.
POSHAN: A Multi-Nutrient Formulation for Correcting the Nutrient Deficiencies in Mulberry is a balanced nutrient formulation with growth promoters for mulberry.
Foliar application is relevant for timely application of specific nutrients to the leaf.

Salient features include favorable effects on plant tissue nutrient balance, fertilizer uptake, growth, yield, and quality; low cost; farmer-friendly application; and correction of physiological disorders caused by macro and micronutrient deficiencies.
Technologies in Food and Beverages Sector include Osmo Air Dried Amla (Emblica officinalis) (Sweet & Salt).
Osmo air-dried amla is a ready-to-eat product where salt/sugar is incorporated, making the drying process less energy-intensive and providing good taste and texture.
Salient features include being a concentrated fruit product with good nutritive value, ready-to-eat form, good shelf-life, and promising export potential.
Advantages include shelf-life up to 8-10 months at ambient temperature and varied application as a substitute for fresh fruits.
Modified Atmosphere Packaging of Minimally Processed Vegetables (Cauliflower, Carrot, Green Peas) addresses the demand for safe, fresh, and hygienically packed vegetables for retailing.
Salient features include using hurdle technology for shelf-life extension and technology ready for cutting vegetables.

Advantages include employment generation, maintaining freshness and quality, rendering vegetables in convenient and 'Ready-to-cook' form, bulk reduction for better storage, extended shelf-life by 3-5 folds, boosting export of vegetables, and rendering 60% value addition.
Tomato Processing involves processing surplus tomato production into products like juice, paste, puree, ketchup, sauce, chutney, and pickles.

Salient features include a product mix of tomato puree/paste, ketchup, sauces, and soups, primarily utilized in the domestic market, with potential markets in flight catering, hospital catering, and armed rations.
Advantages include reduction in post-harvest losses, increased shelf life, highly palatable and acceptable products, and increased variety.
Value Added Products from Turmeric include turmeric powder, turmeric oil, turmeric oleoresin, and colorants (curcuminoids).
The developed process reduces processing steps, especially heat treatment of rhizomes, and enhances the extractability of high color and flavor constituents.
Advantages include premium products, improvement in color, and flavor enhancement.
Fresh Ginger Products include preserve, candy, ginger amla syrup and beverage, ginger honey syrup and beverage, chips, pickle, paste, powder, and in brine.
These products can be successfully marketed in urban areas where convenience products are becoming popular.
Advantages include use as mouth fresheners, in confectionery products, replacement for fresh ginger, and as appetizers.
Bottling of Sugarcane Juice provides a method for preserving sugarcane juice for months, creating a shelf-stable natural sugarcane beverage with a shelf life of 4 months.
Advantages include catering to the demand for natural soft beverages and the possibility of carbonation.
Coconut Beverage from Tender Coconut is a pure and nutritious beverage derived from the liquid endosperm of a tender coconut.
It is a natural source of electrolytes, minerals, vitamins, complex carbohydrates, amino acids, and other nutrients.

Advantages include packaging, distribution, and commercial sale with high keeping quality due to natural electrolytes and refreshing taste, and market catering to consumers preferring minimal chemical additives.
Production of RTS Fruit Juice & Beverages includes manufacturing of soft drinks like sweetened carbonated drinks and still beverages containing fruit juice/pulp.
The fruit juice-based beverages are nutritious and include pomegranate, mangosteen, guava, mango, jamun, and papaya.
Salient features include being a pasteurized product with no chemical preservative and a reasonable long shelf life.
Advantages include being refreshing, palatable, and thirst-quenching.
Processing of Pearl Millet for Value Addition overcomes constraints like coarse skin, undesirable color, presence of anti-nutrients, and poor keeping quality.
Various processing methods have been developed and standardized to improve the nutritive value and utilization of millets.
Salient features include increasing the shelf life of processed pearl millet flour to 2-3 months from 5-8 days and improved acceptability of color and appearance.

Advantages include development of various value-added products like chapati mix, dhokla mix, idli mix, pasta, supplementary foods, and baked products, with cost being almost 50% of traditional products and superior nutrients.
Malted Weaning Food formulation based on millets has market appeal for infants and geriatrics.
Ragi, a minor millet, is unique for malting and is a good source of protein, carbohydrates, and other nutrients.

Advantages include the product being based on malted ragi, which is a good source of amylase enzymes that reduce viscosity, low viscosity reducing dietary bulk, and natural calcium content with high biological value.
Online Fortification of Whole Wheat Flour/Refined Wheat Flour improves the overall nutrition of staple food and is suitable for Atta and Maida.
Advantages include employment generation and suitability for existing roller flour mills.
Spirulina Algae is a blue-green vegetable micro-algae with extraordinary nutritional qualities.

Salient features include being a single, natural source providing the highest amount of protein (71%), containing all natural vitamins including B complex, and being the only vegetable source of vitamin B12.
Applications include food supplement, health and medicine, pisiculture (specialty feed), and cosmetics.
Technologies in Water Treatment Sector include Manufacturing Thin Film Composite Reverse Osmosis Membrane for Desalination and Water Purification.
The technology covers the process for manufacturing low fouling thin film composite (TFC) reverse osmosis (RO) membrane in two steps using semi-automated machinery.
Comparative advantages include fabrication of TFC membranes with indigenously designed machinery, cost improvement of fouling resistance property, and improvement of chlorine stability.
Instant Water Filter is a water purification system suitable for potable water supply, particularly in emergency situations.
It meets drinking and cooking water requirements on an emergency basis and serves as a disaster management tool.

Comparative advantages include producing potable water within hours without electric power, low operating cost, removal of turbidity, organic matter, and bacterial contamination, and no change in dissolved salts.
Hollow Fibre Microfiltration and Ultrafiltration Membrane technology is developed for manufacturing hollow fiber (HF) microfiltration (MF) and ultrafiltration (UF) membranes.
These membranes are suitable for the removal of bacteria, virus, turbidity, and colloidal materials from contaminated water.

Comparative advantages include solute cut-off values in the range of 12000 to 91000 Da, 4-6 log bacterial rejections, fouling resistance properties, and applicability in point-of-use domestic water purification units and large-scale purification plants.
Hand Pump Attachable Iron Removal Plant for Community Water Supply removes excessive iron from drinking water.
The plant is suitable for 250 persons with 40 lpcd and 10 hours of operation.

Comparative advantages include continuous operation, high removal efficiency, easy operation, no need for chemical addition, skilled operator, electric power, or mechanical parts, and minimum maintenance with negligible operational cost.

A Process for Removal of Arsenic, Chromium, Cyanide and Pesticides for Improving Water Quality uses nanoparticles of zinc peroxide (ZnO2) capped with glycerol/triethylamine (TEA)/polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP).
The synthesized ZnO2 nanoparticles remove arsenic and chromium from contaminated water to levels below detection limits.
Comparative advantages include low cost, high effectiveness, and being environmentally friendly.
Arsenic Removal from Groundwater uses a naturally occurring ferruginous manganese ore (FMO) as an adsorbent for iron and arsenic in contaminated groundwater.
A domestic three-compartment filtration unit employing this technique has been developed.
Comparative advantages include applicability at domestic and community levels, use of non-toxic FMO as adsorbent, cost-effectiveness, and a sludge management protocol.
Coal Mine Water Reclamation technology purifies coal-impacted water to be fit for drinking.
The process separates suspended particulate matters, removes dissolved contaminants including heavy metal ions, and kills harmful micro-organisms through ozonisation.
Advantages include reclamation of coal mine water free of harmful microorganisms, low purified water cost, and an environmentally friendly process.

Domestic Filter for De-fluoridation of Water is a domestic type adsorption-based multi-stage water filtration unit using activated alumina (AA), ferrite impregnated (FIA) active alumina, and silver impregnated activated carbon (SIAC).
The developed filtration unit is promising for commercialization in areas where fluoride concentration is higher in water.

Comparative advantages include effective reduction of fluoride concentration, simultaneous bacterial remediation, no electricity requirement, low adsorbent replacement cost, and low cost of filtered water.
Electrolytic De-fluoridation Process is a water purification system suitable for fluoride-affected areas with water containing excess fluoride.
The defluoridation process is based on electrolysis using aluminum plate electrodes.

Advantages/Salient Features include simplicity of fabrication, ease of operation with minimum maintenance, production of potable water with palatable taste, less sludge production, simultaneous reduction in hardness and bacterial contamination, low treatment cost, operation using solar energy, and configuration to any design capacity.
H2S Strip Microbial Water Testing Kit detects H2S producing organisms in drinking water, which are present along with Coliforms.
The kit encompasses screw cap bottles with test media and a suitable indicator.
Advantages include low cost, simplicity for non-skilled people, ease of use in the field, and incubation at room temperature.
The Government of Andhra Pradesh has a strategy to ensure the welfare of all sections of society by enabling economic participation and opportunity for every citizen.
The State vision plan is 'Viksit Andhra Pradesh@2047', aiming for effective and sustainable socio-economic growth and development.
The Government's mission is to 'transform vision into reality' through an actionable, measurable, time-bound, and cluster-based development approach with defined result-based indicators.

To bridge capacity/competency gaps within the Government, particularly in sectoral diagnostic reviews, strategic and operational planning, technical assistance, technology enablement & transfer, capacity development, and monitoring and evaluation, the Government needs expert assistance from consulting agencies and individual consultants.
The Government issued comprehensive guidelines for procuring consulting services and individual consultants in 2015.

These 2015 guidelines have been reviewed and revised after almost a decade to be current with present challenges, growth/development/welfare missions, and the goal of achieving Viksit Andhra Pradesh 2047.
Revised guidelines for procuring services from consulting agencies and individual consultants are hereby issued, superseding the 2015 guidelines.
Annexure-I contains the revised procurement guidelines.
Annexure-II contains mandatory clauses for contracts between Government Departments/HoDs/State Autonomous Organizations and Consulting Agencies/Individual Consultants.
All existing contracts with consulting agencies/individual consultants shall be closed within three months from the date of these orders or upon expiry, whichever is earlier.

If closing existing contracts entails serious disruption in citizen service delivery, financial implications, or other serious complications, these cases must be brought to the notice of the Finance Department within thirty days with a request for continuation and proper justification.

Special Chief Secretaries, Principal Secretaries, Secretaries of Administrative Departments, and Heads of Departments, Public Sector entities, and autonomous bodies are requested to ensure scrupulous implementation of these orders.
APCFSS shall design, develop, and deploy an online application for effective implementation of these orders and provide technical, implementation, and maintenance support.
A copy of this order is available at https://goir.ap.gov.in.

The abstract states that the Finance Department has issued orders for Revised Guidelines for Procurement of Services from Consulting Agencies/Individual Consultants for effective implementation of Development Missions under Viksit Andhra Pradesh@2047.
The Finance (HR. I-Plg & Policy) Department issued these orders on 30-08-2024.
The previous order referenced is GO MS No. 89, Finance (HR.I) Department, dated 16.07.2015.
Annexure-I provides Guidelines for Procurement of Agencies and Individual Consultants for Consulting Services.

The scope of these guidelines covers the procurement of Agencies for consulting services with specific scope of work and deliverables, or full-time consultants with specific job roles and responsibilities.
The scope also covers the procurement of individual consultants directly by Procuring Entities for specific job roles, responsibilities, activities, or tasks.

These guidelines are applicable to all Government Departments, Heads of Departments, and all State Autonomous Organizations (Companies, Corporations, Societies, Boards, Authorities, Institutions, Projects, etc.), referred to as Procuring Entities, regardless of funding source.
Procuring Entities shall engage consulting agencies through one of the specified procurement options.
The first option is to procure NISCI-Empanelled Agencies at rates not exceeding their empanelment rates.
This NISCI-empanelment option must be mandatorily explored first.

If requirements cannot be met by NISCI-empanelled agencies (with proper justification), Procuring Entities may opt for procurement through a Tender Process, using one of the specified Agency Selection Methods.
For engaging Individual Consultants, Procuring Entities shall use the Individual Consultant Selection (ICS) method.
In the case of the Tender Process option, one of the following Agency Selection Methods shall be employed:
Quality-cum-Cost Based Selection (QCBS) involves evaluating proposals based on a combination of quality and cost criteria.

QCBS is appropriate when the scope of work can be precisely defined, ToRs are clear, the scope is domain-specific requiring customization, and emphasis is on technical capability over financial quote.
QCBS is also suitable when the scope requires high technical treatment and should be handled by a technically competent agency.
In QCBS, the weightage ratio between Technical and Financial Evaluation is decided and specified in the RfP, with the Technical Score weightage being higher.
The tender process includes a Technical Evaluation against pre-specified parameters.
Agencies scoring above a cut-off Technical Score participate in the Financial Tender.
In Financial Evaluation, the lowest quoted price receives the highest Financial Score, with others on a pro-rata basis.
A Combined Technical & Financial Score (CTFS) is calculated for each agency.
The agency with the highest CTFS is selected.
Least Cost Selection (LCS) involves evaluating proposals separately on quality and cost criteria, ensuring minimum quality standards are met before considering the least cost.

LCS is appropriate for small, standard, or routine assignments where the intellectual component is minor, well-established practices exist, and well-defined outcomes can be achieved at different costs.
In LCS, a Technical Evaluation determines if agencies are qualified.
Technically qualified agencies participate in the Financial Tender.
Agencies are rank-ordered by price in descending order.
The agency with the least price is selected.
Single Source Selection (SSS) allows selecting a particular consulting firm under special circumstances with adequate justification in the overall interest of the Procuring Entity.
SSS is appropriate when the assignment is a natural continuation of a previous competitively awarded contract with good consultant performance.
SSS is also appropriate when the agency's availability is essential (e.g., emergency operations).
SSS is used when only one consulting organization has the required qualifications, experience, or proprietary knowledge.
In SSS, the ToR is shared with the prospective agency, which submits a Technical-cum-Financial Proposal.
The Tender Evaluation Committee reviews and clears the proposal if appropriate.
Negotiations are carried out on financial aspects, and the consulting fee is finalized as per guidelines.
The agency is onboarded after necessary approvals.
For individual consultants, the Procuring Entity shall use the Individual Consultant Selection (ICS) method.
The Procuring Entity posts the requirement details in state/national dailies, consulting job sites, and their website.
The posting includes the role title, scope of work, responsibilities, minimum education/experience, and competencies.
Individual consultants respond with their Curriculum Vitae (CVs) detailing eligibility.
A Consultant Selection Committee interviews and selects the most eligible consultants based on pre-defined criteria.
Selected consultants receive Consultant Engagement Letters detailing their role, responsibilities, remuneration, activities, and deliverables.
A contract is entered into with the selected Individual Consultants.
Remunerations for Individual Consultants are specified in the guidelines.
Procuring Entities shall follow a step-wise process utilizing the designated online application.
Step 1: Preparation of a detailed Terms of Reference (ToR) is crucial for understanding and correct execution of the assignment, reducing risks for the Procuring Entity.

ToRs for Agencies should include: Procuring Entity introduction and context, detailed scope and description of service/work, references to relevant materials, engagement period, deliverables & timelines, review/approval mechanisms, proposed consultants (roles, responsibilities, profile requirements, engagement period), reporting requirements and Nodal Officer arrangements, capacity building/knowledge transfer needs, schedule of payments and reimbursement of out-of-pocket expenses, and provision of office space/equipment/assistance.

ToRs for Individual Consultants should include: Procuring Entity introduction and context, deliverables & timelines, review/approval mechanisms, proposed consultants (roles, responsibilities, profile requirements, engagement period), reporting requirements, capacity building/knowledge transfer needs, schedule of payments and reimbursement of out-of-pocket expenses, and provision of office space/equipment/assistance.
Step 2: Preparation of the Procurement Proposal after firming up the ToR, to be submitted for Finance Department concurrence.

Procurement Proposals for Agencies should include: Type of service sought, chosen procurement option and justification (especially for tender process), estimated cost, Agency Selection Method opted for and justification for SSS, constitution/composition of Selection/Evaluation Committee, ToR as attachment, and any other relevant details.

Procurement Proposals for Individual Consultants should include: Type of service (Procurement of Individual Consultants), Selection Method (ICS), estimated total cost, constitution/composition of Selection Committee, ToR as attachment, and any other relevant details.
Step 3: Submission of the Procurement Proposal & Concurrence by Finance Dept.
The proposal is forwarded through proper channel to the Finance Department for concurrence.

A Proposal Screening Committee is constituted in the Finance Department: Principal Finance Secretary (Chairperson), Secretary GAD (Services) (Member), Secretary of the Procuring Entity (Member), Secretary (HR), Finance Dept. (Convenor).

If GAD-Services or Finance Department is the Procuring Entity, the committee is reconstituted with a Secretary nominated by the Chief Secretary (Chairperson), Principal Finance Secretary (Member), Secretary (GAD-Services) (Member), and Secretary (HR), Finance Dept. (Convenor).
The Committee peruses the proposal and may accord concurrence with or without modifications, or deny concurrence with remarks.
If additional information is sought, the Procuring Entity shall provide it.
The Committee may provide specific observations/recommendations that the Procuring Entity shall incorporate.
Step 4: Onboarding the Agency/Individual Consultants after Finance Concurrence.
For NICSI-empanelled Agencies: ToR is sent to at least three empanelled agencies, and technical-cum-financial proposals are obtained from a minimum of three for evaluation.

The Agency Selection Committee evaluates proposals based on approach & methodology, work plan & deliverables, profiles of proposed resources, agency experience (similar scope, government/public sector), existence in the consulting field, financial capability/net worth, and quoted consultant rates (not exceeding NICSI rates).
Upon selection, the agency is approved by the Competent Authority.
A Letter of Engagement is issued, and a contract is entered into, incorporating mandatory terms from Annexure-II.
For Tender Process for Agencies (QCBS or LCS): A Request for Proposal (RfP) is prepared incorporating ToR elements.
The RfP is published on the AP eProcurement Portal.
Proposals are received and evaluated as per the respective method, and the Successful Agency is determined.
For Single Source Selection (SSS): The selection process specified in Para IV.i.iii is followed.
Upon selection, the agency is approved by the Competent Authority.
A Letter of Engagement is issued, and a contract is entered into.
For Individual Consultants: The procurement process follows the Individual Consultant Selection (ICS) method described in Section-IV(2).
Step 5: Extension/Renewal of the Contract for Further Periods.

Contracts may be extended subject to: satisfactory performance assessment, the extended scope being a logical continuation of the previous scope, and consultant rates remaining as per the existing contract, NICSI rates, or guideline rates (whichever is lower).
Renewal proposals require Finance Department concurrence.
The first renewal (up to one year) does not require perusal by the Proposal Screening Committee.
Subsequent renewals of the same agency are subject to perusal by the Proposal Screening Committee.
VI. Financial Terms for Consulting Resources / Individual Consultants.
These terms apply when the Procurement Option is Tender Process.

Remuneration of Consultants: Person-month rates are applicable for procurement of Agencies for consulting services or full-time individual consultants, and for direct procurement of individual consultants.
For periods less than a person-month, remuneration is calculated pro-rata, assuming a person-month consists of 25 working days.
A table details consultant levels, minimum experience, minimum education, and maximum rate per person month (â¹):
Young Professional: Up to 3 years experience, Graduate/Postgraduate, â¹40,000 â 75,000.
Junior Level Consultant: 3 to 6 years experience, Graduate/Postgraduate, â¹75,000 â 1,00,000.

Middle Level Consultant - 2: 10 to 15 years experience, Graduate/Postgraduate, â¹1,50,000 â 2,00,000.
