Expert Consultant: More than 20 years experience, Postgraduate/Doctorate, â¹3,00,000 â 5,00,000.
Institutional Overheads: Agencies can quote up to 10% of total manpower cost as Institutional Overheads, in addition to manpower cost.
Institutional Overheads are not applicable when Procuring Entities directly engage Individual Consultants.
Reimbursement of Out-of-Pocket Expenses: For outstation travel (travel, conveyance, accommodation, per diems), expenses are reimbursed upon submission of reports and original bills/vouchers.
Reimbursement can be up to 15% of total manpower cost, subject to contract terms, for procurement as per para I(1)(i).
For consultants as per para I(1)(ii) and I(2), out-of-pocket expenses are paid as per Procuring Entity's rules/regulations/policies.
Application of Goods and Services Tax (GST): Applicable GST shall be paid as specified by the Government of India.
No other costs besides those mentioned are payable to Agencies.
Annexure-II lists Mandatory Contract Terms and Conditions.
Important Instructions for Contracts: Key details of ToR, RfP, financial implications, and payment schedule must be incorporated.
Additional mandatory terms and conditions should be included.
Minor changes to terms may be incorporated if they don't undermine the spirit of the conditions.
The Administrative Department/HoD/State Autonomous Organization is referred to as 'Procuring Entity'.
The Consulting Agency or Individual Consultant is referred to as 'Service Provider'.
Mandatory Contract Terms and Conditions:

1. Payment Terms: Payments start from the date of actual commencement of service (Agencies), actual deployment of resources (Agency providing resources), or actual onboarding (Individual Consultants), not from the contract date.
Invoice submission does not guarantee payment; all reports/documents/milestones must be delivered satisfactorily.
2. Contract Extension: Contracts automatically expire if not extended, subject to due discharge of obligations.
Contracts can be extended on mutually agreeable terms if a requirement exists and performance is satisfactory.
No assurance of continuation beyond the contract term is implied.
Contracts shall not be automatically renewed; any claim of auto-renewal is null and void.
3. Duplication of Billing: Service Provider shall not bill for committed consulting resources to another Procuring Entity or to the same Procuring Entity under a different contract.
4. Cessation of the Contract: The contract ceases to be valid on the end date of the engagement period.

5. Termination for Breach/Non-Performance: Procuring Entity may terminate for: inability to accomplish assigned works or unsatisfactory quality, failure to achieve milestones timely, lack of honesty/integrity or false undertakings, unrectified default/breach after notice, actual conflict of interest, non-compliance with applicable laws, threat to corporate survival (bankruptcy, insolvency), or failure to comply with arbitration decisions.

Consequences of termination for breach include: cancellation of services, mandatory knowledge transfer, Procuring Entity's right to impose conditions for efficient transition, payment for authorized and satisfactorily performed services up to termination date, and Procuring Entity's right to retain amounts to offset losses.
6. Termination for Convenience: Procuring Entity can terminate with at least 60 days' written notice; Service Provider cannot claim damages/compensation.
Service Provider may terminate with at least 60 days' written notice, subject to Procuring Entity approval.
7. Consulting Resources Deployed (by Service Provider): Procuring Entity is not responsible for indiscipline, medical claims, or compensation of resources deployed by the Service Provider.
These resources remain under the Service Provider's control and supervision; the Service Provider is liable for wages and statutory dues.
If a deployed resource is unsatisfactory or engages in unlawful activity, the Service Provider must withdraw them upon Procuring Entity order.
Service Provider indemnifies the Procuring Entity against all claims regarding deployed resources.
If a deployed resource enters a dispute, it's the Service Provider's sole responsibility to contest it.
Procuring Entity is not liable for accidents involving Service Provider's resources; the Service Provider is solely responsible.
If a resource leaves or is withdrawn/surrendered, the Service Provider must provide a replacement with comparable qualifications within 30 days.
Service Provider shall not seek or accept instructions from external authorities regarding contract performance.
Service Provider must comply with all applicable laws and indemnify the Procuring Entity for any violations.
For Individual Consultants onboarded by the Procuring Entity: The Individual Consultant shall not take actions adversely affecting the Procuring Entity's interests.
The Individual Consultant shall not offer direct or indirect benefits to Procuring Entity representatives.
The Individual Consultant shall comply with all laws, ordinances, rules, and regulations.
The Individual Consultant shall comply with standards of conduct; failure may lead to termination.
The Individual Consultant shall not contravene any laws, Acts, Rules, or Regulations and shall indemnify the Procuring Entity for any violations.
8. Unauthorized Usage of Data: No data should be stored in deployed resources' systems other than permitted.
Access to data requires prior Procuring Entity approval.
Non-compliance may result in penalties.
Service Provider shall provide a list of resources accessing critical data.
Service Provider shall enter into an NDA with all consulting resources and submit copies to the Procuring Entity.
Service Provider must ensure Procuring Entity data is not accessed by unauthorized users or for unauthorized purposes.
Non-compliance can lead to contract termination without notice and legal remedies, covered under the Indemnification Clause.
9. Omissions in the Contract: Service Provider must notify the Procuring Entity of any omissions or information believed to be incorporated.
Procuring Entity is not liable for financial implications due to omissions, whether reported or not.
10. Non-Disclosure of Material Facts: Service Provider shall not conceal or misrepresent facts about their organization, financial position, or deployed resources.
Wilful non-disclosure may attract penal action, including termination and blacklisting.
Submission of forged/fabricated documents during any stage will be viewed seriously and may lead to legal remedies.

11. Indemnification: Service Provider shall indemnify the Procuring Entity for costs, damages, losses, penalties, or liabilities incurred due to breach, non-observance, failure, or omissions by the Service Provider.
Monetary damages may be inadequate compensation for irreparable harm; Procuring Entity has the right to equitable relief for breaches.
Procuring Entity may take legal action (civil and criminal) against the Service Provider for breaches under relevant Acts.
Procuring Entity reserves the right to take appropriate legal action against the Service Provider.
12. Liquidated Damages: Procuring entity collects Liquidated Damages based on business impact, up to 100% of the contract value for non-compliance or breach.
The procedure for determining Liquidated Damages will be communicated; the Procuring Entity's decision is final.
Service Provider must pay within 30 days of communication.
Failure to pay within the timeline may lead to contract termination, but the liability to pay remains.
13. Failure to Submit Documents/Undertakings: Service Provider must submit all directed documents and undertakings.
Non-submission may lead to appropriate action, including contract termination.
Upon termination/cancellation/expiration, Service Provider shall promptly return confidential information.
If return is not possible, Service Provider shall destroy copies and furnish a Certificate of Destruction.
14. Quality of Services: Service Provider shall ensure deployed resources render services satisfactorily and conform to the scope of work.
Non-conformity observed by the Procuring Entity may lead to appropriate action, including contract termination.
15. Measures Taken for Fraud and Corruption: Definitions provided for 'Corrupt practice', 'Fraudulent practice', 'Collusive practices', and 'Coercive practices'.

Procuring Entity may terminate the contract if Service Provider representatives engaged in corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices, and the Service Provider fails to remedy the situation.
Procuring Entity may sanction the Service Provider, including declaring them ineligible, if they engaged in such practices.
Non-disclosure of relevant facts is a breach of contract and liable for action, including termination.
Service Provider shall report to the Head of the Procuring Entity if any official demands/accepts bribes or favors.
Service Provider shall not participate in meetings with Procuring Entity officials without official intimation.
16. Entire Contract: Terms in ToR, RfP, and LoA form an integral part of the contract and supersede prior agreements.
No agent or representative has authority to make statements not set forth in the contract.
17. Insurance: Service Provider shall arrange comprehensive insurance for contractual liabilities and claims.
Service Provider shall arrange insurance to cover all risks assumed under the contract and for deployed resources.
Procuring Entity has no liability for insurance costs.
Service Provider is liable for loss or damage to third-party equipment at the work execution site.
Individual Consultants are solely responsible for arranging adequate insurance for their obligations and personal needs.
18. Understanding of the Scope of Work and this Contract: Service Provider accepts full responsibility to understand the Scope of Work and contract terms.
Procuring Entity has sole discretion to terminate if the Service Provider's understanding materially varies from the contract's objectives.
19. Conflict of Interest: Service Provider shall disclose all actual and potential conflicts of interest in writing.
Individual Consultants must follow Procuring Entity rules, display honesty, secrecy, and sincerity.
Services of Individual Consultants may be discontinued if found unsatisfactory or in conflict with Procuring Entity interests.
20. Inoperative Period due to Delay in Addressing Dependencies: Service Provider must promptly alert the Procuring Entity about dependencies affecting contract execution.
Failure to alert timely is solely attributable to the Service Provider; Procuring Entity is not responsible for delays.
If delay is caused by a dependency to be addressed by the Service Provider, the time delay is considered Inoperative Period, and payments for that period are withheld.
21. Medical Clearance: Procuring Entity may require a Statement of Good Health from consultants/individual consultants.
Dependents/legal heirs of consultants/individual consultants are not entitled to compensation in case of death, injury, or illness during the contract term.
22. Force Majeure: Defines Force Majeure as an event beyond reasonable control, unforeseeable, unavoidable, and not caused by the Service Provider, making performance impossible or impractical.
Force Majeure does not include negligence, intentional action by the Service Provider, or events a diligent Service Provider could have foreseen and avoided.
Failure to fulfill obligations due to Force Majeure is not a breach, provided the Service Provider took reasonable precautions and alternative measures.
Service Provider affected by Force Majeure shall continue performance as far as practical and minimize consequences.
Service Provider must notify the Procuring Entity of a Force Majeure event within 14 days, providing evidence, and notify of restoration of normal conditions.
Performance periods shall be extended by the duration of the Force Majeure event.
During Force Majeure, the Service Provider may demobilize or continue services to the extent possible, with proportionate payment.
Disagreements on Force Majeure existence or extent shall be settled through Arbitration.
23. Audits and Investigations: Invoices are subject to post-payment audit during the contract term and for two years after expiration/termination.
Procuring Entity is entitled to a refund for amounts paid not in accordance with the contract.
Procuring Entity may conduct investigations related to the contract, award, obligations, and Service Provider's operations.
The right to investigate and the obligation to cooperate do not lapse upon contract expiration/termination.
Service Provider shall cooperate fully with inspections, audits, and investigations, providing relevant documentation and access to premises.
Audit and investigation procedures will follow the acts and rules in force for the procuring entity.
24. Arbitration: Disputes shall be referred to the Secretary of the Administrative Department or Principal Finance Secretary for appointment of an arbitrator.
Disagreements persisting beyond amicable attempts shall be dealt with under the Arbitration and Conciliation Act.
Venue of arbitration is Amaravati, Vijayawada; governing law is Indian law.
The Arbitrator's award is final and binding.
For Individual Consultants, parties shall use best efforts to amicably settle disputes.
25. Jurisdiction: All disputes arising out of this contract are subject to the jurisdiction of the Courts in Amaravati, Andhra Pradesh, India.
26. Intellectual Property Rights: Title to equipment/supplies furnished by the Procuring Entity rests with the Procuring Entity and must be returned in good condition.
Service Provider is liable for damage or degradation beyond normal wear and tear.
Procuring Entity is entitled to all intellectual property and proprietary rights for products, processes, inventions, etc., developed by the Service Provider under the contract.
Maps, drawings, reports, and other data compiled by the Service Provider are the property of the Procuring Entity, treated as confidential, and delivered only to authorized officials.
Service Provider is subject to the Indian Official Secrets Act, 1923, and cannot publish or broadcast information related to assigned subject matter without prior sanction.
Procuring Entity retains exclusive title and all intellectual property rights on deliverables; Procuring Entity has the right to equitable relief for infringement.
27. Return of Equipment: Upon termination/cancellation/expiration, Service Provider shall promptly return Procuring Entity-provided equipment.
28. Prohibition of Sexual Exploitation & Abuse: Service Provider shall comply with the 'Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013'.
Breach of these provisions constitutes a breach of contract and grounds for termination.
The Procuring Entity may refer alleged breaches to relevant authorities for legal action.
29. Terms of the Performance Bank Guarantee (PBG): Service Provider shall comply with PBG terms.
Procuring Entity shall invoke the PBG in case of inability to service the contract or breach of terms.
Service Provider must replenish/restore the PBG to its original value upon invocation.
PBG proceeds are payable to the Procuring Entity as compensation for losses resulting from Service Provider's failure to complete obligations.
Procuring Entity has the right to invoke and appropriate PBG proceeds upon breach, after due notice to the Service Provider to rectify the breach.
